I own several Anker products including two portable battery chargers (1st and 2nd generation). I bought this car charger expecting a similar quality device. Unfortunately, my charger arrived DOA. I contacted Anker customer support, and after a short e-mail exchange, they agreed to send me a replacement immediately without requiring me to send them back the defective unit. The new charger arrived via USPS 4 days later and works perfectly. I'd give Anker 5 stars for customer support--getting a replacement was no hassle at all. Every company deals with defective units; that's simply the reality of selling electronics. However, NOT every company has quick, friendly customer service. That alone makes me more likely to buy products from Anker in the future.The charger itself works flawlessly now that I have a working unit. It charges my Android phone twice as fast as my old car charger which barely kept up with the battery drain of running Google Maps. This charger will allow me to use the GPS and Google Maps AND charges my phone while doing so.The design is simple, elegant, and solid. No creaking plastic, no rough edges, no "cheap" feel to any aspect of the charger. I'm very happy with my working unit. Since I got a defective one the first time, I'll post updates to this review in the future so that I can comment on the longevity of the charger.Anker customer service = 5 starsCharger = 5 StarsTotal = 10 Stars?Either way, this is a bargain and well worth the purchase price.

When this worked, callers reported some of the best clarity they'd heard from me. The rest of the time (50%) they could only hear half of what I was saying.Here's the deal:When I called Plantronics about this the first question I got was, "Are you using an iPhone 5?" The tech claimed there was a known issue with the iPhone 5 and they were working on a fix, but in the mean time I could down load a firmware patch for the headset.The patch which is supposed to make it work on an Apple phone is only  installable from a computer running WINDOWS.Okay. Fair enough. Borrowed a laptop. Installed the patch. Tested it with a friend and the problem had not been fixed.Plantronics offered to exchange the unit for another one. But if I'd done that and it too had been affected by this issue, which the tech admitted plagued this unit (one assumes every example of this unit) then I would not have been able to get a refund because, he said, "Plantronics does not issue refunds."So it's in a box going back to Amazon.So: Plantronics: One Star. Amazon: Five stars.FWIW: I've just gotten an LG HBS 730, which in addition to being a stereo headset and separating functions into more hardware buttons (always a plus), makes consistently intelligible connections.Good luck.

The Steepower Micro USB Car Power Adapter is one of those perfect on-the-go car chargers for most people.  Any device that uses a micro USB cord such as a Smartphone, MP 3 player, Kindle, or a digital camera can readily be charged.  I especially like the built-in cable.  No need to carry one along with you ... simply take the charger out of the glove box and you're good to go.Another interesting thing is the fact that the micro USB spring cable, a full six feet in length, can uncoil and be used in the backseat of your vehicle.  It's one of those plug and play type devices that make life so much easier.  It's also very convenient in that you can charge two devices at once.  One built in USB cable, the other you'll have to bring along.The basic specs are on the side of the unit.  The spring clips nicely secured the Steepower Micro USB Car Power Adapter into my lighter socket.  Once inserted into the socket there was about 1 1/2" sticking out.  The adapter works well, is very handy, especially when you're on-the-go and your phone or other small device needs a charge.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:►  USB Car Charger with a coiled Micro USB Cable►  Quick start guideSPECS:♣  Input:  10 - 16V DC♣  Micro connector output:  5VDC, 1A♣  USB port output:  5VDC, 1AFEATURES:►  Charges Many Micro USB Devices►  Simultaneously charges a second device using the additional USB Port►  Works in any vehicle that has a lighter socket or accessory outlet►  Compact one piece design with coiled cable►  Micro USB coiled cable can expand up to 6 feet►  Illuminating blue LED light to indicate that the charger has power (on the interface around the additional USB port)Sample provided for review.
summary: The Steepower is the perfect car charger for the on-the-go crowd ...

reviewText: It's hard to know quite what to say about a clear piece of plastic that is supposed to protect my phone's screen, since I haven't actually broken my phone's screen while I've had this on. Maybe it's working. If Corning had created their initial version of Gorilla Glass as well as advertised, I wouldn't think a protector was needed at all, but the new version of Gorilla Glass suggests maybe protectors make some sense after all.The shipping was fast on this. It cost very little. Installation was easy, the highly negative reviews notwithstanding. I had no trouble with fit, glue balls, etc. I honestly don't know what these other people are talking about. Maybe the manufacturer made some adjustments.If you aren't hard on your phone, you may not really need this. The problem is finding out that you really do. I was willing to spend $2 for a little insurance.
summary: Protection that might be needed, and then again maybe not

reviewText: I recently upgraded some of my docks from 30-pin to lightning - using the FlyBridge. That device really wants your phone to be naked but can accomodate a case up to about .35mm - and this case works PERFECTLY (it also works with my car dock).It's beautiful - just enough transluscence to let the Apple logo show through, but for all intents and purposes the phone looks like it was intended - nearly naked. This case protects the full top - no other thin case (even eLago) does that. That was important to me because I have a minor but annoying scratch on the top that this covers.Now you do need to understand that you are giving up some protection for thinness. This is not an Otterbox or even a bumper - no front protection and really I only expected it to protect from scratches.I dropped my phone (about 3 feet) and the case took the brunt of the impact - it cracked - but my phone was perfectly fine, so it performed even better than my expectations (and I'm replacing it!).
It's just nice to have a stylus in each room and one in my purse. These fit my needs perfectly!

When I bought my new iPhone, I resisted purchasing a case at AT&T.;  They made me feel guilty about it, but since I bought the replacement insurance, I thought that if I purchased a case, I would just be helping them out.  Silly thinking!In time, I figured I needed a case after all, so I got this one.  Perfect.  It is slim and easy to place on the phone - it fits like your foot fits in a loafer.  The buttons on the sides work fine, and the headphone jack hole fits all my headphones -- something past covers on other phones didn't do!The surprise fun feature was the jelly button included.  Included are three little stick on buttons that go on that often used bottom button.  Instead of it being a concave button, it is now a convex button, and surprisingly I like the feel better.  It is  optional to use.  The buttons come in three colors, all included:  black, white and orange.  This also helps me identify my phone -- look for the orange dot -- in a sea of iphones with black cases.I did already purchase a screen protector, which was not included with the case.Strong recommend.

reviewText: good quality at a reasonable price. I use this at the office and this works great, great sound awesome mic quality

Ok I'm comparing this to the other case I have, the i-Blason Armadillo (ASIN B00F0R83VG), which I bought on Amazon for $12.99 + free shipping.First off, on both cases, all the holes for speakers & buttons line up perfectly. Don't worry about that.The OtterBox is definitely a great case, but this "mid-grade" Otterbox (Commuter series) seems extremely similar to the iBlason which is 1/4th the price.OtterBox comes with a screen protector which is nice (probably a $3 value), and the hole to access to stylus is a little better on the OtterBox.The iBlason has much more protection on the corners (bump guards), which makes me feel it has better drop protection, but it also makes it a bit more difficult to slide in & out of your pocket.The OtterBox also has a slightly sturdier backing to it. Also, I think the OtterBox tries to leave a small cushion of air between the case and the phone, for extra protection, kindof like bubble wrap.I think the OtterBox is slightly better quality overall than the iBlason, though the iBlason has the corner bump guards which are definitely more protection. I give them both 4.5 or 5 stars, but I'm marking the Otterbox down just due to price. The higher models are probably worth $40-$50, but the Commuter should really be closer to $20-$25.If you feel you need moderate protection for your phone (an occasional mishap or drop), I would probably recommend the ~much~ cheaper iBlason. Personally, I'm keeping the iBlason and giving the OtterBox to my wife.However, if you drop your phone daily, have an extreme work environment, or are really really rough on your phone, get the Defender series for about the same price. Or if you need waterproof, check out the Armor series.
summary: Definitely great. There are ~much~ cheaper options if you're undecided

I purchased the headset specifically to be over the ears because regular ear buds do not stay in my ears. The headset is very comfortable; it stays put even when performing the most vigorous exercises. Call quality is okay. The person on the oher hand sounds a little dull, but since I do not talk much on the phone, it does not bother me. I just need to be able to hear when someone is calling. The sound quality is good. I like to listen to the music loud, and the headset produces clear and loud sound. The only downside of the sound is the bass is a little low. I wouldn't say it is absent, but it is on the lower side. Overall, I was really satisfied with the product considering that the price is very reasonable. However, after about 3 months of use, the mic and remote stopped working. The headset could still be used to listen to the music, but not to talk or control the music anymore. Another thing, I was using the headset on my iPhone, and for whatever reason Siri would constantly get activated even though I would not push the button on the control to activate it which became pretty annoying up to the point when I had to disable Siri.
summary: Great comfort and sound quality for the price but short live span

reviewText: These screen protectors came as part of a combo purchase recommended by Amazon.  I ordered a charge/sync cord and wall charger for my iPhone and the best price available included these screen protectors.  I needed to replace the one on my phone as it had a scratch, nothing minor so I had been putting it off. When these arrived I pulled off my old protector, cleaned the screen on my phone very carefully and started to put on the first one. It apparently came with dust already attached to the sticky side so I ended up with a small bubble under the protector.  I also noticed that it had a very noticeable kind of swirly rainbow look to it under the lights in my office. I decided that since I got five of these I would try again.  I managed to get it on a bit crooked on my first try and discovered the rainbow effect again.  Since I had three left I decided to give it one last try.  I got it on straight this time but once again ended up with a piece of dust on the underside of the protector and the rainbow effect was still there.Don't waste your money on these.  I threw the last two away.

reviewText: Compare this case to OtterBox, and see what you get. Oh that's right! They don't make a case for the HTC Thunderbolt fitted with an extended battery, and for under $40? With the belt clip? Nope! Not happening.This case seems like it would protect my Thunderbolt from just about anything aside from being ran over lol! I thought this would be just what I needed to protect a phone that I have to spend a year+ with, and I can imagine nothing worse than breaking it half way through my contract and having to keep paying the bill or buy one at full price. I work in a corrosive environment, so I figured this would offer the best protection while at work, and on my off days I can peel the rubber off, and use the inner case for regular day to day protection from the dings and scratches that may occur when I slip it in my pocket. The package included a screen protector which I have to admit I have not used yet, since I already had one on my phone. Only thing "negative" about this case it that it does make the phone feel much bigger, but it's understandable considering how thick the rubber around the phone is. Over all I'm happy with this purchase, and if your looking for something that may save your phone from a drop, this may do it... but as a disclaimer I have not been daring enough to try it lol

My S5 will only charge if it is one particular location on the pad. The beeping.  Beeping to tell you it's started charging is fine, but about 2:30 this AM, my was beeping non stop.  Didn't take the time to see if it was just turning on and off but it sure was annoying. At least all I had to do was spin the phone around and it stopped, I guess problem one is a solution for problem two.

reviewText: I have to admit to being skeptical -- but this case is definitely worth a closer look. There are many cases that look the same: a rubbery interior and then a hard shell on the outside. But the Speck case stands out for a couple of reasons:1) It's really thin. I compared this to other cases, and it's much slimmer. The whole deal with the iPhone 5/5S is how thin it is, and this case accentuates that. It's as thin as it can be and still provide protection. Major kudos for that.2) With the phone in it, the case feels very natural in your hand. The sleek polished back and sides give this a great feel. All the buttons and cut-outs are in exactly the right places. It's very snug and a perfect fit.So I was pleasantly surprised -- the phone feels great in this case. I gave it 4 stars because at the bottom, there is no way to use this case with the Apple "lightning adapter". My car has the older iPhone/iPod connector, and so I have to use the Lightning adapter for the iPhone 5/5S. This case won't fit the adapter -- it only works with the Lightning cable. So yes, I got out a Xacto knife and went to work on this case to cut out a slot in the base so the adapter would fit. Really, it would take a minor re-design to make it work with this connector, and many other case designs do this. So 1 star off for that.

Bought this for my Galaxy S (Vibrant) with hopes of using the phone in my car more for streaming music and GPS.This worked great in my wife's car, but not in mine, as I don't really have a flat surface on my dash.  The curves of the dash made the friction mount wobble a bit and not be as sturdy as I'd like.  Plus, the friction pad was a bit bigger than I was expecting (not that it's a bad thing, I guess I didn't expect it to be that substantial).The windshield mount, however, worked great on the windshield (it also stayed securely on the friction pad).  It has a bunch of different settings that allow you to easily change the angle/direction of your phone.  It fits the phone very snug and I never worried about its security.Overall I think this would work great for many people, but just didn't work out for me.  I've stopped using it in my car and now use the windshield mount as a phone dock in my office (attached to a window).
summary: Works OK...but didn't work out for me

I have a Samsung Galaxy SII phone.  I use it with a Logitech bluetooth adapter at work to stream music over a pair of desktop speakers, so I was used to using Bluetooth for audio.  I figured that this Belkin product would be worth checking out for an older car that can play CDs but not mp3 files from disc.The device installs easily and the wires aren't too obtrusive.  The audio quality is good enough for road use and is sufficient for both music and calls.  Others have noted that the device doesn't autoconnect.  I end up having to go through a screen or two on the phone to hook it up and get audio playing.  And, if I'm not careful about it, the music just starts blaring out of the phone.  That's a small hassle, but a notable one.The device seems reasonably durable.All in all, this is a reasonable solution for people with cars that don't have the latest Sync systems.  It might not be the most convenient system in the world, but it gets the job done fairly well and will save you from hauling around massive libraries of CDs.
summary: Works well enough, but not needed in many new cars

This is just like the original charger I got with my Nexus phone several years ago, but if I had to do all over again I would go directly to an aftermarket charger that offers more than 0.7A(mps).The speed that a wall or car charger juices up your device depends on the Output listed on the charging unit's label. The 5V or "Voltage" listed there is a USB standard, but it's the second number you want to pay particular attention to: the Amperage, signified as A or mA (milliAmp). With all other things being equal, the higher the Amperage - the faster the charge.The rub is the charger doesn't decide how much electricity to send, but rather the device itself that PULLS electricity from the AC plug or USB port. All Android-based devices will limit the energy draw to a maximum of about 500mA (or  of a full Amp) when connected to a USB port. Most aftermarket chargers follow the USB data standard that includes 4 "pins" within a connector - 2 for power-charging and 2 for data-transfer (meaning your device recognizes it as a USB port); whereas most OEM chargers usually have the data pins "shorted" so the device sees only charging pins, thus indicating a power-charger and allowing itself to draw the maximum current. It's fairly complicated and counter-intuitive at first, and it took me a long time to find out why my devices were charging so slowly on a supposedly fast after-market charger. This is demonstrable by the very chargers Amazon itself sells... theAmazon Kindle 9W PowerFast Adaptercosts more - but you'll only get up to 1.8A output no matter which cable used since they have effectively killed the data pins on the charger; whereas they also sell the better valueAmazonBasics Wall Charger with USB Outlet (2.1 Amp Output)with its higher output, but it has all 4 USB pins intact - so unless you have a specialized charging-only cable the most you will ever draw at any time from it is around 500mA. You absolutely need a good charging-only cable to take advantage of the faster speed provided by the higher output of most aftermarket chargers.With this particular Samsung OEM charger you don't have to worry about getting any specialized cables, you will always get 700mA (0.7A)... that's just not terribly fast compared to other chargers on the market. I prefer a charger to give at least 2.1A, and my favorite does 3.0A - but most of them have to be used with a specific, Charging-Only cables (See Below).If you have purchased a different aftermarket charger and wondered why it didn't seem to juice your device very fast, or just doesn't seem to be living up to its full potential - thePortaPow Specialised 5ft 24AWG Charge Only Micro USB Cable for Blackberry, Xperia, HTC One, Google Nexus, Other Fast Charging Devicesis likely all you need to increase the power flow. If you don't already have a verified charging-only cable now or don't own a charger that has output of more than 700mA, I can tell you that your best bet is to purchase theAmazonBasics Wall Charger (2.1 Amp Output)in combination with thePortaPow Charge-Only Micro-USB Cable. This will give you a full charging speed of 2.1A, and you will simply be amazed how fast your device charges. There is no harm to the device because the phone or tablet will only draw as much as it can handle.
summary: OEM Charger that just doesn't go fast enough

I used the PowerPak to charge numerous devices including my 3rd generation iPad, iPad mini, iPhone 4 and iPhone 5S. In all cases but the 3rd generation iPad, complete charge from about 60% was complete in less than an hour. The iPad, which has a much higher mAH battery thn the others) took 2-3 hours to reach 100%. I was able to charge all four devices on one charge of the PowerPak with some charge remaining (1 light). It took around 5-6 hours to bring the PowerPak back to a full charge (4 lights), which seems very reasonable. Although I did not have the opportunity during the evaluation period to use the PowerPak under outdoor conditions, the design is very robust and when the access door is closed, it appears to be water tight. I would not hesitate to use it outdoors under inclimate conditions, providing I could keep the USB ports themselves from direct contact with rain or water submersion.I found it very useful to have one of the USB ports designed to charge mobile phones and the other rated at a higher capacity for tablets, especially iPads. They are clearly labeled on the access panel as 5V1A and 5V2.1A so there is no confusion on which one to use. The smaller port to recharge the PowerPak is also in the same area, protected by the access door. The PowerPak Xtreme is ideal for use in any situation which requires spending significant time outdoor away from easily accessible power sources. This would include any type of work in the field such as construction sites, oil fields and similar environments, as well as camping, fishing and hunting trips. This would also be useful on long car, bus or plane trips where access to USB power sources may be limited, although the less rugged New Trent iCarrier IMP120D battery is a bit lighter and ideal in those environments.I rate the New Trent PowerPak Xtreme a 5 out of 5 stars based on my use so far.
summary: New Trent PowerPak Provides Extended Life for Portable Electronics in the Field

I am coming from using those 20 dollar Invisible Shields from Zagg. After the 1st one got ruined (within 3 months) I refused to spend another 20 bucks for another. This deal is amazing. It even looks clearer and is smoother than the Zagg shields. The price is is where this product shines.Just be sure of 2 things during application. NO DUST on surface (I used the sticky part of the 1st shield I miss used as a sticky dust magnet to prep the surface for 2nd try.. worked perfect. The other tip is make sure you lay it down perfect (not laying on edge of the chrome frame of the phone. If you do it will leave bubbles on the edge.. this is why I retried a 2nd time I was "slightly" off perfect and it left a lil bubble top right edge.Tip for application: Peel off layer marked "2" completely. Than peel only a tiny bit of layer "1" and get it lined up on the surface (down near home button on phone) make sure there is no bubbles. Then use a credit card to push up the phone... at the same time peel layer 1 off (same motion) If you had no dust on the surface and you are lined up perfect... you will see no bubbles and it will look flawless. Good luck!!!I use an Incase Slider case. The 1st time I didn't have the shield perfectly laid down the case made it worse and threw lots of bubbles along the edge. The 2nd time I got the shield perfect the case didn't even seem to touch it... ZERO bubbles. Its like nothing is on the phone at all.I came back here mostly to buy 2 more packs for the future. 20 times cheaper than zagg invisible shield (I feel like i saved tons of cash doing this)
summary: Took 2 Applications but I nailed it 2nd try

Here my LePow's Modre Bluetooth Speaker review:Before reviewing the speaker, I would like to write a note about LePow's costumer service: they are really amazing, the best experience I have. Since one of my speakers came damaged they promptly send me a refund and my new order was sent in less than 2 days - Great!Now about the speaker:This little speaker has good quality and the sound is loud and enjoyable. They are ease to pair, the battery is long lasting, and they are really small so you can bring it with you everywhere you go.Having different brands of Bluetooth speaker under $100 I can classify them in following order:1) Braven 570  - The best sound in the list, open and clear with tight bass and soft treble, the mids are clear and very smooth. You have volume controls, hands free and a USB port to charge your phone in an emergency. Since the controls are in the right side of the speaker you have to get the speaker in your hands to use them. The Bluetooth range is great (30 feet). Price: around $100.2) LePow's Modre -  Good sound, lack a bit of treble and bass, is very portable and has good construction. The only control available is the on/off at the speaker's bottom, you have to use your phone for volume and start hands free. The Bluetooth range is great (30 feet).  Price: around $ 30.3) GoGroove BlueSYNC SRC - The sound is ok, but a little harsh in the treble and lacks some bass.  Easy to pair, the controls works flawless and they are positioned on the speaker top, so they are very easy to access and to use. Price: around $304) Pyle PWPBT60 - The sound is ok, a lot of bass, but the mids and trebles are muffled. Lacks certain openness to the sound. They are sturdy, heavy, but have the worst Bluetooth connection. The connection drops all the time when someone or something is placed between the speaker and the phone, very annoying. The Bluetooth range is very limited. Price: around $70If you want a good sounding speaker that you can carry with you everywhere and don't want spend a lot of money, LePow's is the way to go. They come in a nice pack (a nice cup) with nice cables, they have a great design, very good construction. Enjoy !

I do have  a charger in the car but I mainly bought this for my vacation trips since I always end up with a dead phone before the night has started.Pros:- Works with iOS 7 beta 6 -- I've tested it, you DO get the message, "This cable or accessory is not certified and may not work reliably with this iPhone." In case you don't know, here's how this works.  GSM phones (like AT&T;, T-Mobile, and most overseas carriers) use a "SIM" card.  For a while, SIM cards came in one size, and that fit any phone.  However, as phones started to get more and more sophisticated and manufacturers scrambled to fit more inside the device, the SIM card was targeted for size reduction.  First came the Micro-SIM, which is still popular and in use today in many devices (such as the Samsung Galaxy S4).  Then came the Nano-SIM, which is even smaller, and is used in the GSM version of the Apple iPhone 5, 5C, and 5S.But here's the trick... aside from the size of the SIM, all three SIM cards are exactly the same.  In other words, you can take a big SIM and cut it down into a micro or nano SIM size.  The chip in the middle of the card doesn't get damaged and doesn't know or care how much plastic is around it.I purchased this because I wanted to cut my AT&T; Micro-SIM card down to Nano-SIM size for an iPhone 5, but still have the option to use the Nano-SIM in the Galaxy S4 by using an adapter.First, I didn't bother using the cut-down stickers that came with this product.  I just wasn't confident enough that I could make the precise cuts without damaging the data chip part of the SIM card.  Additionally, using stickers gives you only one chance to cut a SIM down.  Once you destroy the sticker, it can't be used again.The size-up adapters are functional but not perfect.  There are three adapters... nano-to-micro, nano-to-full-size, and micro-to-full-size.  Each size-up adapter has a cutout where you can put the smaller SIM so that you can use it in a larger slot.  The cutout has a clear plastic film in one side to keep it in place.  Unfortunately, I found that the extra thickness from the extra film made it hard to insert the adapter into a phone.  Also, it is very hard to keep the smaller SIM in the cutout, because the film has to be on the back side of the SIM.  Many phones require you to insert the SIM card face-down.  If you use these adapters, the smaller SIM falls out of the cutout when you flip the adapter over.  Additionally, I found that the smaller SIM would often fall out of the adapter as I tried to slide it in.  I can't recommend these SIM adapters, as they are very difficult to use.  I recommend using the "snap-in" type SIM adapters.  They don't add thickness to the SIM and they secure the smaller SIM in the adapter while it is in use.Overall, I don't think this is a good quality product.  In a pinch, it will work.  But there are better-working alternatives available on Amazon.

reviewText: I got this case along with 2 other slim cases, not sure which I'd want to use long-term. After trying all three, I quickly decided that the protection of this (slightly) bulkier case made it my choice. The design is good, and I like the polycarbonate shell inset. I also liked how it added a level of grip that the other cases did not (and the phone itself doesn't really, either).I used this case on my Nexus for around 2 weeks, and then started noticing that the polycarbonate shell was not fitting in the inset as well as it had at the start. For someone who is finicky about the fit and finish of things, this didn't sit well with me. It was as if the rubber part of the case fit exactly right, but the shell was slightly too large - it bowed out just a little from the rest of the case. When I ran my finger along the back of the phone, it would catch on the shell. It's only a couple of millimeters, probably, but it was enough that it bothered me.I tried removing the shell and bending it JUST slightly in the opposite direction, I even thought about gluing it, but I don't believe glue would hold it.  So ultimately, I switched to one of the other cases. As much as I like the design and extra protection of the Spigen Slim Armor case, the end result is I'm not using it on my phone.  If they can figure out a way to resolve that problem, I'd switch back to it in a heartbeat. So, if you aren't bothered by slight issues like that, I'd highly recommend this case.  If, though, you are slightly (or extremely, even) OCD, then this case might not be for you.
summary: I want to love it, but the OCD side of me won't let me

Item was provided by manufacturer for review. The review represents my unbiased opinion.The size of this battery pack was just slightly bigger than my iphone 4s. I can get about 4 charges for my iphone, give or take, on par with what I would expect for the battery. The benefit of this device is that it is a solar charger, giving you an opportunity to use it away from a power source.Charging time and ports: charging time took only a few hours for a complete charge from a wall source. The LED indicator lights showed the charge status on a 4 light system. There are 2 ports on this device, a 1 amp and a 2 amp, perfect for smartphones and ipad. To charge the device, any standard micro usb charger would work.Solar Panel Feature: The solar panel is on one side of the battery pack. When the solar panel is charging, the lights will turn on and indicate so. In my test, I had the solar charger charging for a day, in my car, where it would theoretically get plenty of sunlight. However, the 2nd day became quite cloudy. However, the solar panel still indicated it was charging. Basically, whenever there is sufficient light, the battery will charge itself through the solar panel. The lights will flash, followed by the “status” of the charging of the battery pack.After 1 cloudy day of charging, it charged my iphone 3%. As other reviewers have noted, it’s going to be difficult to charge the battery pack fully from the solar panel alone. However, this would be a great opportunity to gain free energy. Leave it in a window or what not for a week or so, and you should be able to charge your phone. The solar panel is a great idea. It would be useful for teaching kids about harvesting energy from the sun, or just harvesting free energy whenever you can. It’s a nice secondary feature to the battery pack. While I didn’t try it, I can see this solar battery pack working well as a night light. Charging up during the day (while you’re out camping or what not and hiking) and using it to provide power to an led usb light for some light at night, at camping or what not.Design: The best thing about this battery pack would be the solar option. It would be that it is possible to get some charge when there is no other option available. All the power buttons and ports are on one of the short edges. This gives the ability to put the battery pack in a small area (like a pocket) and have all the cables and control and indicators on one side for easy review. The basic outline is charging port, power button, LED indicator lights, charging port from wall, and charging port. The color of the device is black with a white border around the edge. You can polish and keep the solar panel clean with the wipe cloth that’s included in the package.Weight: The weight of the device is no heavier than any other similar 8000 mah battery pack device. The solar panel really doesn’t add much weight, but adds a nice, unique feature to the battery pack.Extras: The battery comes with a small carrying case, tips for the USB connector. It has 4 tips with 1 wire. The tips interchange (30 pin, the new iphone 5 connector lightning, micro usb and mini usb). Definitely convenient to carry 1 wire for so many heads to charge. It also comes with a carrying case.Highlights for this battery pack include the two available charging ports, solar panel, and the included cable for maximum devices you can charge.

I've been waiting for this phone for a long time.  I got tired of Apple's "50 shades of grey" upgrade in IOS7, and so had my Verizon rep for my corporate account send me the Lumia 928 back in September of 2013.  I loved it, and would've ordered one right there until I saw a leaked photo and some tentative specs of the Lumia 929 that was to be released in a couple months.  I decided to wait, since the improvements over the 928 were many.I almost lost patience in November, December, and January when all the rumored release dates passed, but I'm glad I waited.  My rep was able to overnight one to me so I had it on release day.  I gave my old iPhone 5 to one of my employees and never looked back.This is a VERY nice phone in all respects.  In every way I compare it to my iPhone 5, it wins.  The only downside is the thin choice of apps still in the Microsoft store, but that's improving.  The iPhone and Samsung phones started out the same way.  The only things I really miss from the iPhone are a few apps, not the phone itself, since I have a lot of home automation, and there is, as yet, no Windows phone options for my Logitech security cameras, my Ecobee thermostat, and a few of my power switch modules.But apps aside, from a hardware perspective, this is a clear win.  The full 1920x1080 screen is gorgeous to view.  Even in sunlight I can see what I need to see.  I was a little worried about the size for two reasons - first, I didn't want something that was awkward to hold.  I've seen people with the "phablet" devices and I just can't picture lugging something like that around as a PHONE - may as well use my retina iPad mini...  But I also just bought a new 2014 Jeep Cherokee Limited, and the technology package in it has a special upper section of the arm rest that includes a Qi charging plate and a little sliding holder to keep the phone there.  I really hoped this would fit in there ,and it did, even with a case on.  Snug, but it works great.  And the increase in resolution over the 928 means that there's more tiles I can fit on the main screen.And for me, that's where the iPhone loses compared to Windows.  I never cared much for the lock screen's lack of information, which was why I invariable jailbroke my iPhones.  And the limited options for the screens when the phone was unlocked made it annoying to have to dig into folders to find what I was looking for, or swipe the screen.  I was very happy when they made folders an option, so you didn't have 20 or 30 pages of icons, but it still was annoying sometimes.  I like that with Windows I can resize the icons and fit  lot of things that I use daily on a single screen.  I also love the live tile implementation of things, so I can see at a glance what's been happening without having to rely on a notification center type of screen.It's easy to hold, since in reality it isn't THAT much larger than the iPhone 5 was.  The buttons are easy to get at and responsive.  I like that they changed the USB port to the bottom, since the 928 had it on the top and that just drove me bonkers during my week of testing.  The sound is quite good for such a small device.The processor is snappy, which makes sense since it's the quad core snapdragon processor.  There's little to no waiting for pretty much anything I open on here.  Graphics are incredible and smooth for the few games I've put on here so far.  Zooming photos or the camera is also very smooth.And the camera - it's amazing.  I have several higher end digital cameras, and an awesome $1600 Sony camcorder, but the photos this turns out are more than acceptable to me.  It used to be I'd "settle" for photos with my iPhone due to convenience, when I didn't want to lug my large camera case around with the cameras and lenses for some event.  And yes, if I really want to capture something to the best of my ability, I'll use my real photo equipment.  However, for the other 95% of the time, I'll be more than happy to use my phone now and not have to carry anything else out.  The options are easy to get at, white balance, ISO, flash, so many more options that with the iPhone...  And the single finger zoom, rather than the pinch, or the slider at the one spot on the iPhone, makes bracketing my pictures so much easier.  I find I can get just the shot I want so much easier with this than I could with the iPhone, and the quality, needless to say, just doesn't compare.  The 20 mp camera here and the optics used make you think that there was no way this photo could've been taken by a phone.We have a client in a medical building that's on the lower floor, and in their server room, we NEVER have gotten a signal with any phone from any carrier.  And yesterday I was able to receive a phone call in there, and hear and be heard.  That was a first for our company in that site.  Another pleasure for the phone is being able to hit "END" and have it end the call.  I've spent most of my time after the IOS 7 update on my iPhone being unable to end a call myself, it would not respond to me pressing "END" no matter how many times I tried.  Phone calls would only end when the other side hung up and my phone realized it.I love the built in Qi charger.  I had a Duracell case for my iPhone and another extended battery that charged on a proprietary pad, and had gotten used to that method of charging.  So I bought two charging pads, one for the office, one for home.  I've gone through three cases so far trying to find a good one, and the charging on the pads and even in my Jeep works through the cases just fine.  It's a convenience that you don't realize you'd use until you get accustomed to it.  No plugs, no cables, just set the phone down and the charging begins, with no special case required like the iPhone.  The back gets a little warm, but I've never felt it get hot no matter how long I had it placed on the charger.This has quite a large battery in it, and initially I thought it'd last longer than the iPhone, but the downside to the live tiles is battery consumption.  With little talking and little game playing, it runs down quicker than you'd think.  I went from 100% at 7 AM at a client site to about 40% left after 8 hours. There's a lot of forum posts out there about things you can do to lessen the impact, but for me I'd rather deal with the battery consumption and have all my data, since this is first and foremost a business tool for me.  Each mail account has its own live tile so I can see at a glance what the status is of new messages for my own Exchange server, or Gmail, or my Windows Live account.  I'm not much of a facebook user but it's there as well, keeping me updated on info for my family.  All of this visible without opening any programs up.  For me, that convenience makes up for the battery being used quicker.Another bonus for me is with my Jeep.  I have the large Uconnect system, that can let you do voice texting over the stereo system.  This never worked with my iPhone, but it works fine with the Icon.  It reads me a text, and I can voice back what my reply is, and the car will repeat what I said and give me the opportunity to accept what it heard, or change it.  Very handy since I don't pull up the phone to send or receive texts and such while driving.  Another thing I don't use much, but it's nice to have when I need to.For me, the lack of an expansion slot for an SD card or something isn't an issue.  I have a Lenovo Helix tablet / laptop that I use for all my data.  I pull photos to it from my Onedrive (used to be Microsoft's Skydrive) so I really don't have a need for extra storage on the phone.  But for some people who use a phone as their center of their digital existence, it will be a major issue.  So if you absolutely must have additional storage on the device, this may not be for you.  But with the the seamless cloud storage integration, I don't think it's that critical for a lot of people.And I like that I have such a viable option for Microsoft Office documents here, that I can open a Word document from my Onedrive and it looks like I expect it to, and that I can edit it and then have the results later on my computer when I'm back at the office.All in all, I'm 100% happy with the hardware, just a little impatient with developers of the programs I need for home automation to make a Windows Phone variant of their software.  There's nothing I feel I lost in my transition from the iPhone, I've only gained.  For me, this is a much more usable phone in all respects than my iPhones ever were.  And it's a big step from the old Windows Mobile phones back in 2007 and 2008.This is one phone that shows that the Windows Phone platform isn't just a fluke, and it has all the opportunities to flourish.  Of course, that success isn't in Microsoft's hands, but in the hands of the people who write apps.  It doesn't matter how awesome a phone is, if people can't get the things they want or need to run on it, most of them will stick with the platform that they can.  So I really hope the Microsoft store starts fleshing itself out.
summary: A great upgrade from my iPhone 5

reviewText: I've always been an apple user but had the opportunity to try this phone by Nokia recently. The Lumia 928 is a smart looking Windows Phone. I do prefer the iphone, BUT everyone has their personal preferences. The phone seems great and worked great - but I still prefer my apple products.That said, I'm basing the review on the product itself and not my personal likes/dislikes.The Lumia 928 works on the Windows Phone 8 operating system. It worked smooth and fast and very responsive as well. You can customize just about everything with this phone, the look, size and color of things and the tiles as well. And all change with easy. I like how the live tiles update and all your info is right there on the screen to your preference. The display is the AMOLED display and makes the screan sharp and clear and works nice even in the sunlight. The screen is 4.5 inches which is a decent size.The camera works well in daylight or even low light. It also has a flash which is pretty decent as well. It can record in HD 1080p with noise canceling as well. Call quality is also good, calling and receiving and the speaker on the phone works clear and your able to hear the person as well. It can run on the 4G network and comes with 32 GB of internal storage- I wish it had more but for most users this is plenty of space. Or at least added in external storage or such.Battery life is decent and it has a pretty neat feature where it can charge wireless! The battery is not removable but lasts about 13 hours of talk time.Like many smartphones there are a ton of Apps available.. many say there are more on OS, and Android, but non the less there are many apps. There is no swype keyboard for those that prefer this.
summary: Smart Looking Windows 8 Phone, Works Well, Many Features

The Motorokr does everything you need a car Bluetooth adapter to do, but a fraction of the cost of most other units.  The FM transmitter is strong enough for clear reception by my rear antenna, which was not true for my previous FM transmitter.  With my Motorola Droid, free Pandora radio, and the Motorokr, its like having free satellite radio in the car.  Some of the Motorkr features are especially useful, like searching for the bext FM frequency and announcing it, as well as simple phone controls on the front of the unit.  For me I just need to plug it in to the car adapter for about 1 hour and it will run on batteries all week.  The only issue I have is that it occasionally shuts off FM transmission and/or Bluetooth by design - I would like the option for Bluetooth and FM to remain ON when I am not streaming music or using the phone, so I can receive a call and listen on FM at any time (note I can still listen via the adequate Motorokr built-in speaker).

During a very pricey trip to the Apple store to replace my water-damaged iPhone 4s (a water bottle leaked in my handbag), I decided I needed to not risk that happening again.  The sales people there were very helpful, and we looked through all the cases they had in stock.  For some reason, they carried Griffin Survivor for the iPod, but they didn't have this version.  But the guy who was helping me suggested that this was my best bet (God bless people who don't work on commission!).  I mean, they had some serious waterproof cases (like, for underwater use) - but those were not functional for everyday use.So we looked up the Griffin Survivor case right there in the Apple store, and I added it to my cart.It meant a lot to me that the guy who lives and breathes iPhones all day long thinks that THIS is the best case to get for decent water/damage protection while still being functional.  That's about the best endorsement you can get.I received my case and it was an effort just to get it out of the carboard box it came in.  As I took it apart, I had to keep track of how it came apart so I could put it back together.  There are 4 pieces, of which 3 are necessary for protection.  There are two pieces that snap around the iPhone to form the first layer of hard casing, then there's the big rubber piece that this hard case fits into.  To get water/shock protection, you do need the big rubber piece, for sure.  Because the speakers/ports etc are all otherwise exposed.  The fourth piece is the belt clip, which is not necessaryThe rubber case covers all the water susceptible parts of the phone.  You can still access them all because there are flaps that move away of you want to charge the phone or use the video camera or headphone jack.  However, know that this is NOT water proof.  You cannot submerse it.  I doubt it would survive a drop into the toilet (maybe if you fished it out VERY quickly it would be ok).  But a fall into a wet sink or use in the rain or being in the same handbag as a leaky water bottle - I'm pretty sure this would stand up really well.  And I definitely feel like I could drop this without damage.Size-wise, this will make your iphone about the size of a non-stuffed men's wallet.  You can stick it in a pants pocket, but it would look weird in a shirt pocket, which you probably can do just fine if it weren't in a case.  Look, the case definitely adds bulk.  But I think it's manageable.Anyway, in sum, I am very happy with this purchase.  I am glad that the guy at the Apple store made this recommendation.  That was really ALL I needed to be sure, and now that I have it I know it was the right choice too.
The only bad thing about this case it that the white discolored after a really short period of time.  It now looks more gray and dirty.
The case is pretty, not exactly as the photo appears but pretty just the same. I can't comment on its use because it turned out I bought the wrong model, but that's my fault.

I was provided some free samples of styluses for review. They were (in case you are interested in other options for a stylus):*Sty-HD 9 pcs Rainbow of Colors Capacitive Stylus/Styli Touch Screen Cellphone Tablet Pen for iPhone 4 4s 3 3Gs iPod Touch iPad 2 Motorola Xoom, Samsung Galaxy, BlackBerry Playbook AMM0101US, Barnes and Noble Nook Color, Droid Bionic*Business Stylus Executive Pen - Capacitive Stylus Touch Screen Cellphone Tablet Pen for iPhone 5 4 4s 3 3Gs iPod Touch iPad 2 3 4 Motorola Xoom, Samsung Galaxy S4 S3, Barnes and Noble Nook Color, Droid Bionic*Sty-HD 2 Pack of Premium Precision Micro-Knit Hybrid Fiber Tip Capacitive Stylus Pens for iPhone 5 4 4s, iPod touch, All iPad: 1st Gen, 2, the NEW iPad, iPad 4th gen with Retina display, iPad Mini, Samsung Galaxy Tablet and Phone Black and Silver Color*Sty-HD 17 pcs Colorful 3 Styles Capacitive Stylus/Styli Touch Screen Cellphone Tablet Pen for iPhone 4 4s 3 3Gs iPod Touch iPad 2 Motorola Xoom, Samsung Galaxy, BlackBerry Playbook AMM0101US, Barnes and Noble Nook Color, Droid BionicAt first I was disappointed in all the styli I received due to responsiveness, but I later figured out that I needed to apply more pressure. If you do not apply enough pressure, it will be unresponsive on some devices, with some devices requiring more pressure than others. While you don't have to apply a whole lot of pressure, just a light touch of the stylus may not work, so keep this in mind. Also, keeping the stylus perpendicular to the plane of the device works better in many cases (though not usually necessary). If these are issues for you, then you may not like using a stylus.My review for this 9 piece pack is as follows.This set is indeed very nice and colorful. However, the colorful finish can be scratched easily with sharp objects.Using a stylus helps keep fingerprints off your device, which is a nice benefit.These styli do have a plastic clip, however. It would be nicer if they were metal but I can't complain much given the price.Overall 4 stars because they are not as responsive as a real finger, but it does work well enough with a moderate amount of pressure applied.
summary: Nice set of colorful styli, but some quirks

reviewText: Okay so you can read all the reviews and they all say the same thing...great case, great protection (second to none), fits is dead on, can't get a better case...etc..I wanted to point out some basic things and then let you the reader who is currently in the buying mood for your new expensive smartphone...here goes.1) All the happy loyal customers say one thing more than anything else, it's a great case for protection.  Don't read this, buy the case and then write a crappy review that says, "love the case but it makes my phone too BIG!" or "love the protection but my smartphone no longer fits into my skinny jeans..."  you get the point.  This case is about PROTECTION.  You simply can't get a better fitting case for PROTECTION.2) You just invested in a $700 or more smartphone/tablet/device that can do anything and more than most desktops found in many homes across the planet.  Why would you not invest a few bucks into PROTECTING your investment?  It takes one simple drop to chip the sides or paint not to mention that the front case could crack.  Yes, there are plans now that allow you to replace your phone, but why go through the hassle of starting new again.3) Yes, the plastic screen protection that comes with it is not that great, but if you have owned an Otterbox before you know the deal.  Peel that one off, invest in a real screen protection film or better yet, get a Tempered Glass Protection screen.4) And as everyone who has owned an Otterbox before knows, the hard clip case is either useless and you never really carry it or you are someone who carries their phone on your hip all the time.  I myself, do not.5) The rubber grip is just enough to be able to shove the phone in your back pocket without too much trouble and yet it has enough grip that it doesn't jump out of your hand while using it one handed.All in all, an excellent case.  You just bought yourself a pretty expensive piece of technology, protect it and forget about the fact that it doesn't have cute little bunnies on it or it isn't olive or baby blue.

Then I saw this product that used a magnet to hold the phone, it looked so sleek compared to the cradle model from competitor M.  The price was right at 20 bucks so I threw caution to the wind and purchased this InfiniApps Slyde CD mount.Received it quickly (love Amazon Prime), and found it easy to install (pictures and video's can be found easily so I won't go into the details), it's just simple!  While driving with it I noticed that it had a little "jiggle" to it.  Not terrible, but definitely noticeable and this is not typical of what I had experience with similar CD slot mount from competitor M.Here's where it gets good....  Even before I had a chance to let them know of the problem InfiniApps reached out to me first.  They sent a message through Amazon letting me know they had a new version of Slyde CD mount that would mitigate the problem customers might experience when their phone is mounted.  They also let me know they were going to ship the newer model to me FREE OF CHARGE.  That totally blew me away that they would be proactive to let me know they were aware of the problem, that they had a new model that fixed the problem and that they shipped it to me promptly at no cost.I've received the new mount and see that the replacement has a very slight change to the neck of the mount.  It's a bit beefier, just a bit, but it appears to make a huge difference.  Took a ride and the "jiggle" is gone.I have to say I really like the InfiniApps Slyde CD mount, it's very easy to install and even easier to use.  I just jump into my vehicle and in a matter of a second my phone is securely mounted (and now without any "jiggle").  I have a Razr Maxx HD with a Incipio Feather case.  I put the metal plate between my phone and case (didn't bother to use the sticky tape) and the phone holds securely.  It stays as I attach it, in portrait or landscape mode.  It doesn't slide and has never come loose.It's the real deal and for the price it's a steal.  I'm buying a second for my wife's car and now have stocking stuffer for Christmas for my kids and friends!  You need to GET ONE NOW!
summary: Updated Model Now Excellent! Get One Now!

reviewText: I was provided a Bolse High Output 3-Port USB Car Charger for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found.What You Should Know Before You Buy:♦ This thing is very small for a 3 Port Charger. It only sticks out of your car's charging outlet about 1 inch.♦ Has three ports for a total of 5.4A output (a 2.4A Tablet port, a 1.5A Apple port and a 1.5A Android port).♦ Fast charging speeds for charging two devices concurrently, including an iPad.♦ Very compact for travel if you need to take a car charger with you on trips (renting a car at your destination for example).Detailed Review:♦ Look - The product came in tiny cardboard box with only a small sticker on it, no wasted packaging here.  Inside the box was the charger and a small instruction manual.  You see right away that this charger is surprisingly small for such a powerful 3-Port charger. It is the smallest one I've seen with these kind of specs.  It has three USB ports on the front, a 2.4A Tablet port, a 1.5A Apple port and a 1.5A Android port for a total of 5.4A output. It appears to have a very nice build quality.♦ Installation - As with any car charger, you basically just plug the unit into you car's charging outlet. Once plugged in, I noticed that the spring pushed back a little, but not enough to make it fall it.  Once in, the fit was pretty snug and secure.  No problems.  This charger makes most other 3-Port chargers look giant. My Pathfinder's charging outlets are on the side of the passenger area where a knee can easily bump the charger. This much smaller charger gives the passenger a little more leg room in my vehicle.♦ Use and Performance - Once installed, I did some basic tests to see how the Bolse car charger handles various charging situations. During my work commute, I took my iPhone 5 that had 48% charge remaining and I did a stand alone test using all ports for 5 minutes each.  The results are as follows:In the 2.4A Tablet port for 5 minutes increased the charge to 53%, or +5%.In the 1.5A Apple port for 5 minutes increased the charge to 58%, or +5%.In the 1.5A Android port for 5 minutes increased the charge to 63%, or +5%.Back in the 1.5A Apple port for 5 minutes increased the charge to 68%, or +5%.All ports worked great with my iPhone 5 and increased the charge on my phone by 1% per minute, which is right on par with most other chargers that I have tested.  I then plugged in my iPad 2 in the 2.4A Tablet port and it charged up just fine with my iPhone still in the 1.5A Apple port.  Individual and simultaneous charging tests were great.  I also plugged in my Bluetooth Music Receiver into the third port just for good measure with no problems.  For my situation, this was great with having several devices in my car on a regular basis.Conclusion:Overall, this is an amazing 3-Port Car Charger with really high power and great charging results.  It is really tiny and works great for multiple device vehicles.  At the time of this review, the price was $12.99 which really can't be beat with these kind of specs.  Highly Recommended!
summary: What You Should Know Before You Buy!

reviewText: Yes this adds weight and bulk to the phone but that's as expected. Its charging up for the first time just now and its taking awhile which i assume it would. The plastics aren't quite Otterbox quality but it works great with this case given the rubberized TPU shell is sturdy, so once assembled i don't notice a difference, just a solid case with a killer battery. This is my first Zero Lemon product and i must say the quality of the items received along with the cost is amazing. Ive come just to expect an Otterbox case alone at the cost of 59.99, and now for the same cost i get a 10,000 mah battery with it, outstanding value.I cannot comment on the battery life as it is charging for the first time and will probably not be back to update the review unless their is a problem but here's my initial thoughts. I also own the 6400 mah Hyperion battery and was getting 2 days of usage from that battery, so dump another 3600 mah on top of that and i would expect at least another day or day and a half. Thrilled with the possibilities, so just time to wait and see after a few factory suggested break in / charge cycles.The only gripe i have is shipping. I wish Bastex Wireless would dump DHL Global Mail and consider other options. They must do a ton of bulk shipping especially since this is the first batch of 500, so that's 500 packages right there alone. Not sure if this is even realistic but the wait time with DHL on the lowest shipping option was pretty long at 7 days to move from Texas to St. Louis. It sat in STL ready for transport to USPS for 3 business days before it just this morning appeared at my local USPS facility for delivery. Iv'e seen other reviewers also knock this company you do business with, and i would hate for them to reflect poorly on your business, which produces an outstanding product. Next time i will choose expedited for 9.99 i believe, which may make shipping a little less of a headache for someone impatient like myself.Im 110% happy so far with my purchase, and Bastex Wireless does a great job with communication on Zero Lemons Facebook page given how many gripes and irritated customers there appear to be, which i saw basically over shipping transit times, or someone misreading that they were allowed to preorder and just because Amazon says shipped doesnt mean it shipped since Bastex had to wait for the product.All that said for $60, and i have the reassurance of a 6 month guarantee against failures...Would for sure do repeat business and urge anyone on the fence to give them a shot.

The New Trent Ultra-Thin case is a great sturdy, protective case. The case comes in 3 parts: a soft outer case that supports the back of the phone, a plastic front with a clear plastic screen protector, and a silver or black outer shell. The 3 step instructions, provided outside of the box, are pretty straight forward. I did struggle a bit to get the phone to fit into the soft outer case, since it is quite tight, but once the phone was in, it was a pretty snug fit. The case is not heavy or bulky at all and fits in the palm of your hand like a regular phone case, except that it feels much more sturdier.The buttons on the side of the phone (volume, headphones, charge outlet) are easily accessible and are either completely protected by the case or are covered by flaps on the outer shell of the case. The phone itself is also easy to access and there are no issues or delayed responses while tapping on the phone through the screen protector. One thing that bothered me, the transparent film covering the home button looks and feels a bit flimsy. I noticed some fingerprint/nail dents on the film already and wonder if the film will eventually puncture through with continued use. I have an iPhone 5, not a 5s so I cannot comment on the fingerprint recognition.Overall I would recommend this case.

I'll just list out the aspects of the phone.  More convenient that way.-Touchscreen: Not as responsive nor as user-friendly and intuitive as the iPhone, but definitely usable, stylus (which is provided), and finger-wise. Sharp, bright colors, with an auto-adjust function that works amazingly well, even in bright sunlight. Slightly recessed, so it does collect dust and other debris (which I found surprisingly annoying, since even lint easily picks up from my pocket), but overall, very attractive and usable.-Windows Mobile 6.1: Though there are still some bugs, a marked improvement over the last version.  The one really annoying aspect of the system is still the slow loading time, and the main nagging thing I noted is that there's a HUGE lag after text messaging, after the message informing you that the text was sent.  The system freezes for a good 5-10 seconds, and won't let you do anything during that time frame.  Mostly just annoying, though certainly not a detractor, especially if you don't text a whole lot.-The keyboard: Spacious, despite the compactness, and slightly curved, with an assisted spring mechanism that feel very, very solid.  The one qualm I have is that they keys are nearly flush with the tray, and the top row can be difficult to press, since it's nearly flush beneath the screen.  Other than that, with some use, it's easy to get used to, and doesn't add bulk or awkward feeling to the phone, like some full QWERTY keyboards. The keys are also backlit, which is a nice touch, especially in shadowed or darkened areas.-The keys: There's plenty of softkeys and shortcuts available, and they're very well-suited for the phone.  There's an optical joystick (passing your finger over the surface allows you to scroll without physically pressing the top/bottom keys, or the screen), which also serves as an "OK" key.  I really liked that addition to the phone, since I'm not a big trackball fan, and the sensitivity is customizable, since a too sensitive setting can sometimes lead to wrong commands. There's a dedicated panel key, which is somewhat like a home-screen key, since it takes you to the main panel selection every time. There are also dedicated phone keys, a toggle on the side for volume, and a power/sleep button on the top.  They don't detract from the phone, and the only sticking point is that they're sometimes a bit stiff to press.  Other than that, it's a nice, somewhat comforting feeling to have dedicated keys available, unlike the iPhone.-The panels: These have been touted as, and are, really, the main attraction of the phone. They're are an interesting, very positive feature, since they're customizable (you can even move them around, though this has to be done through choosing a panel and editing it, instead of just dragging it across the screen, which would have been much more intuitive), and varied, and give the Windows system a more personal feel. They can be a bit laggy, but they're fun and functional (the fish panel is just amusing, with the ability of the fish to change color, follow the touch, or swim away if pressed), though I've yet to find a use for the Google page, since it always defaults to Internet Explorer, which I don't utilize.-Internet browsing: Pretty snappy and speedy, even on the Edge network.  The area in which I live doesn't support the 3G bands on this particular phone (I have the overseas Xi, while the U.S. will ship the Xia), though bigger cities with the 1900mHz towers do.  I don't use Internet Explorer, since it's still one of the most useless and dated mobile browsers out there.  The phone is shipped with Opera Mobile 9.5 installed, which works similarly to Safari on the iPhone, though thankfully the cut and paste options are available, unlike the iPhone.  (Trust me, after you've given up that option, and then come back to it, you'll really notice the difference.  Why Apple hasn't picked up on that yet, I'll never know...) There is also the option of downloading Skyfire, which works very well, sometimes faster than Opera.  Both platforms support Flash, and display the full-page layout, like you'd see on your PC.  Either way, pretty enjoyable experience there.-Text/Multimedia Messaging: Windows finally incorporated the threaded conversation for text messaging, much like the iPhone did, creating a more "IM" feel to conversations, and making it much easier to keep track of specific conversations.  It lags a bit, as mentioned prior, but a great improvement, without a doubt. It also does Multimedia messaging, and for that alone, in some ways, it is worth more than the iPhone, since Apple still refuses to include that basic function.-Camera/Video/Music: The camera is 3.2 MP, a very decent camera, especially considering the phone size.  It includes a flash, and can be adjusted for various speeds, colors, effects, etc.  There is also a video-camera, which records up to 30fps, though only 24fps, I believe, for the American version.  Why the difference, I couldn't say.  The music player is easy to access (it has it's own panel), and there is also a Sony FM radio included, which is a nice touch, and easy to use, though only with the headphones included, since they act as an antennae, apparently.  Still, very decent media package.-Construction: I have the silver finish, which is really just stunning.  It's very has a very durable, solid feel to it, though can be somewhat slippery, and feels very comfortable in the hand.  The size in my opinion is perfect, compact and sleek, and though this means smaller screen size and somewhat cramped keys, it's really my favorite aspect of the phone.  Has the old, comfortable handset feel of a Nokia candybar phone, actually. Sony really put a lot of thought and effort into it, and it shows.-Other features:  The 3.5mm headphone jack is WONDERFUL.  I had a Sony a few years back, and the one sticking point that kept me from using it as a full-time MP3 player was the fact that I was supposed to use Sony's headphones.  The fact that Sony has branched out, and incorporated the headphone jack, along with the capabilities for a Micro SD card slot (located on the side, when you remove the back cover), really shows that they're creating a platform which is more friendly to users who branch between companies. (Sony usually has their own M2 storage card, which is more pricey than the Micro SD.) Whether it lasts or not depends on their continued association with HTC, I suppose, who designed and helped create the physical phone. I suspect that if they next phone doesn't run Windows Mobile (which has been rumored), those features might disappear. Oh well.  The fact that they're included on the Xperia is really a very nice, convenient touch. The phone also connected with the network very easily, loaded all the information, and formatted the phone, without any heavy programming from me, which was awesome.Overall?  Fantastic phone, with very reliable software, convenient system, sleek and sturdy construction, speedy network connections (even overseas), and plenty of opportunities for personal tweaks and modifications, given the open platform from Windows.  I'd love to give it five stars, instead of the four, but the price was ridiculous, especially considering that it's really just another Windows Mobile smartphone, albeit better-looking and more personal than some others.  Still, it's without a doubt my favorite phone to date, when combining the ease of use and construction appeal.  Well worth buying, if you can burn the money.
summary: Fully-loaded, functional and sleek, yet over-hyped, and certainly over-priced

I use this product in my 2012 Hyundai Sonata sedan as a holder for my cell phone to allow me to use it as a GPS device while driving. The cell phone I currently use in this mount is a Google LG Nexus 5, which is encased in a Spigen TPU case. The Mountek mount is very easy to install and remove from the CD player slot in my car. I just push it into the slot, turn the knob a few times, and voila, in seconds the mount is ready to go and stable. The "arms" that encase the phone are spring loaded and open with the touch of the top button with surprising force. Then you just sit your phone in and push the arms shut until it is snugly fit around your phone. The mount is adjustable enough that I could see almost any phone fitting fine in this, even something huge like a Galaxy Note phone. They even thought to put a hole on the bottom plate of the mount, which I can run the charging cable through for my phone and charge it while it is on the mount. I've been using it for months now, and never once had the phone or mount dislodge while in use, so I am happy with it in that regard.The one and only caveat, which is mentioned in many of the other reviews, is that this mount will very quickly cause some permanent warping in the fabric "dust cover" that protects your slot loading disc player in your car. Even after just an hour or two of use, you'll notice some permanent misshaping of the dust cover. It doesn't have any effect whatsoever on the performance or functionality of my cd player, it's merely a cosmetic issue, but it happens fairly quick and I can't think of any easy way to fix it. It's barely noticeable, but worth pointing out to any potential future buyers. For this reason, I deducted one star, but overall still highly recommend this mount to almost anyone.
summary: Love this product, with one very small caveat

reviewText: The unit I received rattled. There didn't seem to be a way to contact VORITY; and there didn't seem to be a way to open the charger to diagnose the issue further. I assumed that something inside was loose and returned it. However, the power light still turned on, indicating that the charger was in full working condition. It seemed to charge my phone, but I didn't want problems down the road.When I unplugged a USB device from the charger, it lifted the charger enough to turn off the power light. I think this may be an issue with the choice of the side connectors used.I think the aluminum strip that says VORITY is painted on. It feels cold to the touch, which means it is some kind of metal, but it can chip away (and become worn with time I assume).This product disappointed me. For the amount of money I was spending, I expected something heavier, with a real aluminum strip. It feels like a generic USB charger. I don't think the rattling helped either.I notice that VORITY actually posts specs (and features), which might contain differentiating factors. However, other manufacturers do not post specs, so I cannot compare VORITY's specs with others.

I have an extended battery on my S3 as I prefer long usage vs bulk/weight. Mine lasts 2+ days usually with moderate usage. After dropping my S3 a few too many times and breaking my screen ($140 later with samsung repair) I'm investing in a case to prevent this from happening again.I got the iSmooth screen protector (hope the edge doesn't peel like my last few)I also got this case for double layer, heavy duty protection. I can't find a otterbox equivalent that is relatively slim so this is my choice. It does add bulk but just enough for protection.- My extended battery case from Anker fits well within.- I have to put on 1 layer at a time to get it on. can take it out quickly without separating layers. this is important as i exchange batteries instead of charging so my phone is always ready to use- buttons are very easy to press- feels solid and easy to grip, slight rubbery feel for inner layer, plasticky feel for outer layer- camera and flash is unobstructed- adds a lip to the front edge so front falls won't hit screen first as muchWith 2-year upgrade plans from verizon, I need to keep my phone in decent shape for 2 years. I've found since I use it so much and hold it so often, I drop it enough to warrant good protection. we'll see how good this protects it over time. in my opinion if it works well this is way better than a hardware warranty and cheaper. those warranty's are a pain in the butt and the deductible cost isn't negligible.

I loved mine so mine so much that I bought two more for my daughters. It charges quickly with a USB cord, holds a charge forever, and charges my Galaxy Nexus to 100% in about 45 minutes while still retaining 75% of it's own power. I love the hidden micro-USB that tucks into the side and hugs my phone.  Anker products are top-notch (I also have a replacement cable for my HP laptop) and they have great customer service and follow up - they actually emailed me a few times asking if I was happy with my purchases and would I write a positive review.  I only write electronics reviews after having something for awhile because some stuff is so cheaply made that burn-out occurs in just a few months...have not had that problem with any Anker item.

This armband case works well for when I'm walking the dog and listening to music on our daily 4.5 miles. This is a very lightweight armband and the case itself is basically foam so it doesn't rub unpleasantly against your arm. My iPod (4th gen) slides in perfectly. My only issue is that the clear plastic used over the touchscreen is a bit thick and when added to the scratch resistant cover that I already have adhered to my iPod to protect it, it can sometimes be bit difficult to switch songs without it becoming a pain.
summary: Have to get a little Pushy...

reviewText: Its a really nice case doesnt stain and was cheap. My sister saw it and wants one for herself so I'm getting her one.

Overall the Incipio Ultralight cases are pretty good. However there is a pretty glaring flaw with these cases. I like them because they protect the phone while being minimally intrusive. However because they're a slim fit case the area around the upper left corner of the phone near the volume control is very weak. Every one of these cases I've had broke in the same spot. This aside the cases are very sleek, slim and work great with the phone. The chrome one is very shiny which is hard to tell from the product pictures. Although the pictures look more like a dull or brushed chrome it's certainly a mirror finish. These cases are great because of the slim fit but you sacrifice some durability especially near the volume controls.*** UPDATE ****This case has since broken in the aforementioned place. My wife pulled it out of her purse, it got snagged on something and then SNAP. So keep in mind this design weakness when purchasing. They're great looking cases but ours lasted less than 2 months.
You have to have it juuuust right in the cigarette lighter to make it connect, but for the price, it's exactly what I expected. I am happy with the purchase.
By far this absolutely the best of the best. It is by far durable. It's excellent quality out last it's good pricing.

reviewText: After I ordered this, I started reading things all over the internet about fake LifeProof cases that are poorly made yet sold for the same price under the "LifeProof" brand. I studied all of the signs that prove they are real/fake, and this one is the real thing!! I love it, however it is pretty hard to hear through the speakers and talk on the phone. I ended up having to pause my interview over the phone so i could take the case off, which was a little annoying. He could barely hear me. if you lose the headphone piece then the whole thing is essentially useless, and that piece is very easy to lose. I lost mine in a hotel in the middle of wyoming. It is pretty hard to text, because the screen doesn't lay flat and you really need to press hard to type, but that was to be expected. Its very nice knowing that my phone is protected when we go to the beach or even around any potential fatality that awaits iphones. (like toilets and, if you work at a restaurant, full sinks and large puddles.) I don't think i would buy it again, just because i really don't think its worth the price. it does need some minor tweaks to be the perfect case. it is very protective though!
You get what you pay for. The bow fell off in under 24 hrs. Good for someone who doesnt use their phone too often.

I bought this to replace an otterbox case that was supposedly unbreakable.  I guess I dropped it one too many times b/c the plastic at the top around where you insert the earpiece broke.  Could have been much worse and been the screen to my phone so for that I'm thankful.  I think this is just as good as Otterbox but way cheaper.

This is a double layer case so it's expected it will be bigger and heavier than most... but the worst issue w/ it is that the texture is very soft rubber and you can't grab it out of you're pocket easily if you are sitting & it starts ringing.  The size isn't great ... why buy the new super slim phone and put a mattress around it... I want a slimmer case overall.
summary: Sticks in pocket & is too big overall
