reviewText: I have a lot of headphones and headsets. I have Bluetooth models, a couple high-end wired ones, some studio headphones for when I'm making music, and other little cheap-o earbuds and things for convenience. That said, I rarely use most of them. Some are just uncomfortable, some are inconvenient, and some don't please me with their audio quality. For the record, I absolutely HATE beats by Dre (and Monster, masters of overpriced accessories and hyperbole) and I'm none-too-fond of 50-Cent's bass-heavy headphones, either. My favorite `phones have been my trusty Koss PortaPlay (purchased 20 years ago, and still outperforming most in the price range and lasting longer) and my BlueAnt headset. My least favorites (aside from the aforementioned fashion accessories by Dre and 50-Cent) are most earbuds packed in with anything, and my first pair of lower-priced, over-ear Sony Studio Headphones, which had excellent sound quality but had a tendency to crush my ears and head, making extended use impossible.When I got the TRITTON Kunai headset I was expecting something in the middle-of-the-line range, and for the most part that's what I got. However, the build quality and sound are much better than I expected from accessory company Mad Catz, who have made some of my least-favorite controllers and game accessories over the years. Clearly, they brought their A-game to this headset. I was impressed.► Build: The TRITTON Kunai feels nice and solid. The whole unit has a nice rubberized feel. It's like these headphones were made with shark skin. They're sturdy, and the magnetic, replaceable, colored side panels allow some customization without a lot of effort.The cable is hard-wired into the headphones-- something I consider a negative-- and the in-line controls are, in my opinion, WAY too close to the main unit (and your head) making it impossible for you to look at the controls when you use them. I would have preferred the controls to be lower by about 6", because I'm not always certain I'm hitting the right button despite the raised symbols on them. My fingers just aren't that sensitive, and I'd like to look at the controls when I use them sometimes.The ear cups are very soft and feel great. Oddly, they're rectangular-shaped instead of circular or oval. They do a great job of sealing and providing maximum comfort while blocking out the outside world and keeping your music or phone conversation to yourself.The cord itself could be longer at 3.9 feet. It's not a major complaint, but with it being hardwired into the main unit, it means you have to consider an extension if you need more slack.► Sound Quality: These have a range of 20 Hz - 20 kHz. What that means is that don't get super-bassy, though they handle bass well, and they don't get up in the highs that I, as an adult, can no longer even hear. That's OK for me. For a teenager these might seem a little more limited in range because they can hear more high notes than I can.The mids are fine, not muddy or "thick", and everything is clear. As headphones go, these are a couple notches above average in terms of audio quality, but they're not any threat to Sennheiser, Klipsch or even some of BlueAnt's best stuff. I think they're better than the bass-heavy, muddy garbage by Dre or 50-Cent, but then I'm not a huge hip hop fan (at least, not hip hop after 1990) and like to hear details in my music, which the TRITTON Kunai handles admirably well. Again, not top-of-the-line by any means, but certainly not junk like many headphones on the market these days.As noted previously, these aren't super-bassy. If you're a bass fan, you may want to stick with the other guys. If you want clear bass that mixes with the rest of the music, then these might do the trick.For voice, they're good. They do add a richness to voice calls that isn't present in my Bluetooth headsets and earpieces, and they do a great job of filtering out noise.► Function: The TRITTON Kunai headset is pretty specific in the title about being for Apple iPod, iPhone, and iPad. This isn't a lie. I tried these on my Android phone and they worked fine as a headset, but the controls were completely useless. None of the in-line controls worked. I couldn't control volume, playback, pausing, or answering the phone with them. This could be because my phone didn't play nice, or it could be that they were serious about the whole "for Apple" thing.However, in the quick-start guide, they also list the PS Vita, Nintendo 3DS, the Wii U gamepad, and "Tablets/Phones" as being compatible. What "compatible" means is questionable. I guess your mileage may vary. The packaging says the in-line controls are only compatible with Apple devices, so I'm thinking the compatibility with those other devices may not include the in-line controls and is only referring to their function as a headset. You can get the microphone and headphones to work but you can't control the device with the headphones.On my iPad mini, the TRITTON Kunai performed well. Double-clicking the middle button skipped tracks. Single-clicking paused and played. the volume buttons worked as they should. I was pleased, and found myself wishing these controls worked on my Android phone.► Packaging/Info: The packaging is, frankly, a mess. I won't consider this in my review score, but it should be known that Mad Catz really made a messy package here. The outside sleeve has ALL information presented in five different languages, which makes it cluttered and hard to find what you're looking for.Inside, they provide a two-page quick-start guide and direct you to go online for a full manual. Considering the price of this headset, I'd think a physical manual wouldn't be too much to ask of them.They also provide some stickers with the TRITTON logo on them. I have no idea what I'd use these for, but perhaps they'll appeal to teenagers who like stuff on their locker or Trapper-Keeper. To me, they're silly fluff and I'd rather have seen them spend the printing efforts and material on a real manual.►► The Bottom Line:  The TRITTON Kunai Stereo Headset by Mad Catz is a great wired companion to your iOS device. Good sound, excellent comfort and build quality, and some nice customizing touches make this headset a good choice. I have to dock a point for the short cord and in-line controls too close to the main unit, making it a little more awkward to use them. This lost point is also considering the odd choice to include stickers instead of documentation. Still, this is a well-built headset that will satisfy most buyers who want it for an Apple device.If you're looking at this headset for Android, Windows Phone, or any other device, you may want to knock another star off my review, because the headset won't do much of what you're looking for, and it's not designed for those devices. It will support them to some degree, but it's not going to do the job if you want in-line controls.Recommendation:  If you're an Apple device owner, get it. If you're not an Apple device owner, shop around first.
summary: Far better than I expected from Mad Catz

reviewText: The iTorch by New Trent (New Trent iTorch IMP52D 5200mAh External Battery Charger) is an amazingly portable external battery which can charge most (if not ALL?) of your mobile on-the-go USB chargeable devices. As a road warrior who's always going, sometimes by foot, sometimes by plane, sometimes by public transit, and sometimes by car, it's always useful to have extra power with you on the go. When you're on the road and don't have access to a wall or car charger, or when you just need to be on the move, the iTorch is perfect. I've been a long-time user of the New Trent Power Pack (Model IMP500), but believe you can never have too much power, especially when others are always asking for a boost. I love both New Trent products, and my old device has saved my butt on more than one occasion. What I really like about the iTorch in particular is the added bonus of the laser pointer and flashlight. It may sound silly, but it's already come in handy several times. I try to minimize the clutter in my bag and therefore never have a flashlight on hand. There are times, however, when a little light can go a long way. As a professional, a laser pointer for presentations is great too, and not one that takes little expensive watch batteries. BUT, to focus on it's main purpose, the iTorch is compact, portable, and easy to handle. I utilized it last weekend and managed to go from Friday morning to Sunday night without ever needing to plug my iPhone 5 into a wall; I made it most of Friday on my initial charge, and added two days of typical use using the backup external portable battery. I could have gone longer. The iTorch is not the most powerful external battery, but it's also not the heaviest! This thing is light weight! While there are other products that might go further, this little guy can give you the boost you need (for your iPhone, iPod, iPad, Camera, Bluetooth, etc.). Note the iTorch does NOT come with a wall-wart to plug it in to recharge, BUT, it charges off a standard micro USB. I was please to find out the iTorch can charge off the plug and cable I use to charge my second generation Amazon Kindle and several other devices that use micro USB (one less charger to add to my collect). Sleek to handle and easy to use, it's a great investment to have on hand and will pay for itself the first time you can fully charge your phone while rushing in a cab to the airport, or even during a flight to an important business meeting. Now that I rely on my mobile tech for everything, I never go anywhere without a battery backup!
Doesn't fit correctly, I paid to have it professionally installed and it still ended up with crap getting under it afterward, waited 24 hours to use it and everything. Would never buy again.

This battery is always in my bag, and has saved my bacon more than a few times.It is one of the few that can go to work on a nearly dead phone and give it the current needed to charge it while using it, all the way to top-off.  Most smaller batteries would peter out or pump low current, but this Anker puts 1500mA into the phone.The CABLE is critically important to get all the available current, and it would be great if Anker would include a high-current charge cable with these batteries.  Most of the microUSB cables I have are not up to the task, but this battery is.
summary: Runs and runs, charges at full power

reviewText: My MyTouchQ gets a lot of wear and tear.  So, I like that this is a two-pack.  But it doesn't cover edge to edge. reviewText: I picked these up to protect the screen on my iPhone 5C. They look good on, but are (like all screen protectors) a bit tricky to put on.They do everything they can to make it easy: there's a protective cover on the front and back, it comes with a microfiber cloth to clean your screen before hand, it comes with a "squeegee" to press out bubbles, and a little adhesive piece to try and remove dust.The only problem is that whenever I tried put one on there's always a couple pieces of dust. You can try and open it up to remove one piece, but there's always the chance of some additional dust getting in there. Where there is dust, there will be bubbles, and those kind can't be squeegeed out.I ended up, on my third try, getting it so there was only one speck in the corner, which wasn't very noticeable. I was happy with that, until I heard about glass protective screen covers, and ended up getting one of those. With those, even if there is a speck of dust, it isn't noticeable because the glass doesn't warp and bubble very easy.Still, these are pretty good and not all that difficult to install. Having three is essential, because you're bound to mess up at least on your first try.
summary: Set of 3 screen protectors, works just fine with my iPhone 5c

reviewText: I love the screen protectors, there only 3 in the package, other than that, they work well.  I am impressed with the weblink for instruction on how to apply the screen to your phone.

The business I work at is very problematic for cell phone reception. Lots of electronic devices, metal in walls, etc, that mess up what is already fairly weak reception in this area.Bought this to hopefully resolve my issues. At first, it did not want to work on our business network.  Our IT dept was mostly clueless.  Took it home to make sure it worked Ok...it did.Back to work, 3 to 4 calls to Verizon, finally figured out what was needed. Our IT was able to open the required ports/etc, and now it works great.(Verizon does have this configuration information on their website, but it is hard to find, and not complete for every situation )My phone (like many others), only shows 2 bars when connected to this, but the signal is solid throughout most of the facility, which is fairly large.Oh, others have mentioned that many of these are used units that may still be registered to another account.  That was true for this unit, too. But, I called Verizon, explained I had purchased it through Amazon, and they were able to reset the unit for me, no problem.  (especially after I had told Verizon that I had tried to purchase a refurb Extender from Verizon, but they were out of stock).Although in my case it took several calls to Verizon and some configuration on my end, the final result is completely worth it.  I now have a solid and clear connection for all my calls.
summary: Once I got it working, it works great!

reviewText: Maybe you saw the original version of this review. If you did, forget everything you read, because in the few months between then and now, this phone has taken a disastrous nosedive.Here's the deal: Lots of electronics these days, they're made to break. I was hoping that this one was an exception, but after a few months of gentle use and great care, I have been entirely disappointed.I won't make a grocery list of glitches and crashes, it'd take far too long. Just know that if you go into this thinking "But I just want it for X feature", you'll probably be disappointed. My cell signal is weak compared to other phones with the same company. The battery life is painfully weak. Buttons to call your contacts just don't respond. Occasionally, text fields will ignore all input, making it impossible to type anything, anywhere, until you reboot - which takes a weirdly long time. The wallpaper doesn't even stay up. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. Don't even get me started on apps - native, purchased, downloaded, they crash all the same.This phone's strongest selling point is the Google Play Store, which is expansive, reasonably-priced, and very secure. However, that comes with any Droid, and if you are looking into the Droid OS, don't let this discourage you - I hear wonderful things about other Droid phones. But this isn't the one for you. And mind, this isn't just one buggy phone. Many reviewers agree with me, including my own sister, who got the phone at the same time I did and is struggling just as much.Bottom line: I'm surprised this thing ever reached shelves. A stain on Motorola and Android, both of which are generally far superior to this piece of work.
summary: This thing raises my blood pressure.

reviewText: these screen protectors are great!  Fit the phone nice and protect it well.  Just what I expected from a screen protector!

Ive used this thing countless of times since I have a lot of gadgets that require charging a lot. I have used it to charge my nexus 7 tablet, my phone and any portable device that can charge via usb.Often I will have 2 devices connected at the same time to charge on the go. It is a great companion for thos days when you know you will be using your device a lot and not be near an outlet for a prolonged period of time (outdoor trips, conventions, visits to family/friends and dont want to sit near an outlet or carry your chargers...just a usb cable etc). I have even managed to get two full charges for my phone and tablet from this before I needed to recharge this. It would probably stilll chagre more but I want to make sure this is charged when I need it.It charges via a microusb cable which is great for me since all my devices use micro usb. It will also turn off by itself if no device is drawing current from it so there is no need to remember to turn it off.Has markings for various amp levels so devices that require higher amps should be connected there and the rest at the lower ones.For example my phone needs a around 2A when charging so I connect it to that port while the tablet is at the 1.3A port. If nothing else is connected you can just use the 2A port as it will only supply what is needed. But do no connect something that may draw high amps to lower amp ports. I am sure it has protection from such things but you can never know if everyone has designed things the right way and its better not to find out.I believe it supports up to 3 devices connected at the same time up to a maximum amp level. I do not remember but can check if anyone needs this info. It also charges things pretty fast, so if you only have 20 to 30 minutes drive till you reach a location you will get a decent amount of charge to last you where you are going.
summary: Bulky but great for being able to charge on the go.

reviewText: I purchased this for myself. The bow actually makes holding on to the phone so much easier. It's almost like a stand.

At first, it worked ok for like 3 months, charging 4 devices.  Then it could only charge 3 devices.  If one puts on the 4th one, it periodically shuts down and turns back on, every few seconds.  Then it can only do 2 devices, then only one device.  Finally, it turns itself on and off by itself, even if we are charging no devices.  It just died.

I bought this charger for my Galaxy Note 2 (from seller MobileCityOnline) and have been using it almost daily for about 2 months to commute to and from work (approximately 1.5 hours each way). By the end of the work day, my phone's battery is usually down to about 45-50%. I plug in the charger on the drive home while streaming Pandora internet radio via 4GLTE, while simultaneously connected to my car's Bluetooth Audio, and I usually reach a full 100% charge after about 50-60 minutes of continuous charging.The "tangle free" cord is coiled, in case you can't tell by the product photo, and extends to about 3 feet comfortably without being overly stretched. Any longer than that, and you may be risking a potential eye injury. The cool blue LED light is a nice bonus as it illuminates my interior at night with just enough light to see my console.I also haven't noticed any unusual or significant decrease in my phone's average daily battery life. In other words, my phone's battery doesn't drain any faster now than it used to. (Note: I never power off my phone except to reboot for system updates.) I do, however, plug into a wall charger overnight.Overall I think this is a great product at a very reasonable price. I feel bad for those reviewers who had negative experiences with this product -- perhaps they received defects. I for one have had a very positive experience with this charger and will certainly post an update to this review after 6 months.
summary: Works great in a pinch at a price that doesn't hurt

reviewText: I bought the wireless charging cover for my Samsung Galaxy S4, but wasn't too happy that none of my cases fit anymore.  I found this case where the seller confirmed it worked with the wireless charging cover.  I received my case and sure enough, it fit perfectly!  Also, there is no interference with the wireless charging process - the charger picks up the phone immediately when I set it on the charger.I read some previous buyers complained that this cover was slippery.  Although the matte finish is very smooth, I do not consider it "slippery."  Someone else described it as kind of a flour-powdered feeling, which I think would be a little more accurate, although the finish is very clean.  I consider it superior because it does not pick up smudges or fingerprints.  For example, my Lenovo Thinkpad Twist has the same sort of soft, rubbery finish and it's just a fingerprint and smudge magnet, which is very irritating.  I feel like I have to handle it with fingernails or gloves.  Not so with this case.  The smooth, matte finish stays clean - after using it a couple of days bouncing around from my hands, my pants pockets, my desk, my car and my kid playing with it, there's not a single smudge or mark on it.Highly recommended - especially if you are using the OEM wireless charging cover.  I just wish it was offered in more colors for the Galaxy S4.
summary: Fits Over Galaxy S4 Wireless Charging Cover Perfectly

I know, I'm a little blunt.  So there.  I bought my first Otterbox for my iPod Touch and it worked fabulous.  When I bought my HTC Droid Incredible I wanted something just as fabulous, but a little less bulky.  The iPod case had the thick plastic screen and the two piece snap plastic case - it was a vault!So I bought this case and it is love, love, love.  The silicone liner keeps funky junk out of the headphone jack and charger port.  The screen guard does what it is supposed to do, keeps the screen from getting jacked.  The hard plastic case is textured enough to get a grip, but not so much as to be annoying. It is also thick enough to protect the lens on your camera if you put the phone down. Unlike other folks, I don't think the case is too bulky at all.I keep my phone in my purse or pocket, and the silicone is not a fuzz magnent, thank goodness.  I had a $5 case off of eBay that I used until this one came in and it was awful. It stayed grimy and attracted pocket lint like the dickens!This case is not waterproof.  Don't take a shower with your phone.  It is not shockproof - don't drop your phone on concrete or tile.  Come on people.  If you are that big of a klutz perhaps you should consider the Casio Boulder phone.  This case keeps my phone safe from every day wear and tear.  It will not protect it from high drops onto hard surfaces, zombie attacks, your toddler, being ran over by cars, or being eaten by my neighbor's dog.  I give it 5 stars and if the iPhone 5 ever comes out, I'll be getting an Otterbox for that, too.
summary: If you have a phone and dont have an Otterbox - you are an idiot

reviewText: I wound up buying a new car stereo (it was time anyway) because of the interference from this device.  The hiss and static was horrible.  I want to stress that it functioned well, but the radio interference was enough for me to get rid of it.  I'm hoping that there's something else I can find.The other issue is that I was using this to charge a portable 12v battery.  If I neglected to disconnect that battery, this device would allow power back through itself instead of cutting it off even when I had the switch disengaged.As this is for a vehicle, the manufacturer really needs to address the line noise issue.

reviewText: I have been an Apple user for many years, but grew increasingly unhappy with the screen size of the Iphone. Some Samsung products look interesting, but all require a 2-year contract or the non-contract pricing is absurd. This Blu phone seems like a solid alternative so far. I like the dual SIM card feature. Am using StraightTalk from Walmart. The listed screen resolution was a momentary cause for concern before buying, but as others have stated, how much resolution is truly needed for a 5.5" screen? Now that I have the phone, the screen looks fine. Bought a 32gb memory card on sale and it's wonderful to have so much space (coming from an 8gb Iphone)!! At this price point, I feel less stress about this phone - if it's lost, stolen, or dropped, it's not such a heartache than if I had paid many hundreds for a no-contract Samsung.

reviewText: Since finally getting an iPhone 4S in October 2011, I have used my regular point and shoot camera less and less.  I did notice that taking photos with the iPhone is not as easy as I would like, so I was excited to check this item out.It is nice that this grip is adjustable to work around any case or protective cover that you have on your phone.  This camera grip works with the free Belkin LiveAction app only.  It does not use the camera app included on the iPhone.  That would be fine, but I think the shutter speed is even slower than the iPhone camera app.  Plus, it is still difficult to not jerk the phone when pushing the button to take a picture.  So if you actually need a really good quality photo out of your camera, just use the remote on your iPhone earbuds that came with your phone.  I lost mine, but I know that it worked great.  I wish I didn't loose mine.Also this grip has a way to easily switch between taking video and taking photos.  One thing that I found useful is the tripod mount.  That is something that does not come with the iPhone.  OK not all the time does one carry around a tripod, but if you wanted to be in the picture without looking like you were holding your phone with your arm in the picture, there is a 5 second timer and a 10 second timer.The instructions that come with this grip are not so great, in fact, there aren't really instructions, just warranty information.  On the Belkin website, there isn't much information either.  It's just something you would have to play with and figure out on your own.  This is another item to bring with you when going on an outing, it might be easier to just take the point and shoot.
summary: Not as helpful as I was hoping it would be

UPDATE 6/5/14After attempting two sets, one DOA and the second set looked like it had been broken during shipping, the third set works great. The sound isn't as good as my higher end earbuds, but it is pretty good. Range is pretty limited, about 15 feet. The fact that these are essentially wireless, except for the wire that leads to both ears, is the cool part. Great for working out or doing something where you don't need wires in your way. They have a very specific charger, so don't lose it. They are inexpensive so I figured that into my review.Note -- this works very well as a Bluetooth phone headset.PREVIOUS ONE STAR REVIEW:**UPDATE** Because the first set arrived and didn't work at all, another set was sent as a replacement for trial. It arrived with one corner of the earbud broken and they would not work at all either. I had four separate people test and try to get these to work to no avail. I absolutely cannot recommend this product.Well, they're comfortable. And they're stylish. But they don't work. We've followed the directions and have never been able to charge these. There is supposed to be a light that indicates they're charging according to the directions. But no light has ever been seen. The directions also indicated that if they don't start charging, unplug and try again. We have unplugged and tried several dozen times. Then I thought maybe there just wasn't a light or we couldn't see it, so we left it plugged in to try to charge for two hours. They didn't charge. Nada.I received a sample for honest evaluation.

reviewText: This product is worth every dollar you pay. It is small enough to fit into my pants or jacket pocket. It charges my smartphone (Nexus 5) at least twice (from 20% of battery). I was impressed!It has an automatic shut off so it only draws power when it's actually in use, in contrast to some other cheaper chargers on the market.Overall, this does exactly what it says it will, is easy to use, and is great to take along on trips for charging anything that charges via USB.

This case was recommended by reviewers to be used with the Seidio Innocase holster for the iPhone 4. Sure enough, it's a great pairing. The NGP material is a little harder than I'm used to, but that's okay and it's kind of growing on me. The fit is perfect, and all controls are easy to use. The cutout at the bottom is big enough for even the bulkiest of dock connectors. My only slight dislike is the bevel around the screen edge. It's nice and high to protect the screen, but it's a bit "sharp". Combine that "sharpness" with the rigidity of the material, and it makes the phone fairly uncomfortable to press to your ear, especially for long conversations. It would be better if it were more rounded or flat or something, but it's not too bad as it is.Anyways, if you're looking for a good iPhone 4 case/holster combo, this is the way to go!

reviewText: The first thing I noticed is the packaging.  This appears to be a Chinese to English translation and it is very difficult to understand what the instructions are telling you to do.  For example I don't really understand how you are able to clean the pen and restore it to the initial sensitivity.  So I would recommend you have someone with their primary language as English type up better instructions on the back of the package if these are to be sold to US customers.The next thing I noticed is the pens center of gravity (see attached screenshots). With the pen fully extended the center of gravity is too far back on the pen so it flips out of your hand; it needs to be a bit heavier toward the tip of the pen.  Also when its fully extended its still too small for the large size of my hand so its almost better to not extended it at all.  (See attached picture of another full length pen to show how I like it to rest on my hand like a normal pen or pencil does)Next I have a drop holster for my Droid X which I wear on my belt so with the pen in the headphone jack while it works its probably not something I would keep attached.  I would probably just keep the pen in my backpack and pull it out whenever I needed it.I really liked the micro fiber tip on this pen, it was so much better then the cheaper rubber tip pens.  It was able to glide across the screens of my devices much easier and felt more natural.  My only question would be would the micro fiber tip ever get snagged and tear after long term use?  I know the rubber tipped ones only last so long and then they go bad so I hear.
summary: I really like the micro fiber tip

reviewText: I really did.  I really REALLY did!  I have been through a couple in-car speakerphones.  The first, the BlueAnt, was stolen.  I liked that one a lot but it wasn't terribly loud with incoming voices/callers but others could hear me fine.  The second, a Motorola, was crystal clear both outgoing and incoming but it had some technical glitches and I returned it because it kept unpairing and did not want to reconnect... oh but that sound quality was second to none (sniff, sniff).  Then there was this product.  It paired immediately and without issue. I never had any issues with it unpairing or "acting up." I was hoping for the answer to my hands-free problems (it is the law in CA).  Alas, the Motorola T225 fell short.  While it was loud and crystal clear on incoming voices, people complained they couldn't hear me and I sounded "really far away."  At first I thought it may have been a service issue or the fault of the other party but then more and more people confessed that they just "pretended" to listen as I sounded far away (thanks guys!).  I actually have to SHOUT in order for people to hear me on this thing.  I have a loud voice to begin with so shouting to be heard isn't natural for me but I did it for a couple weeks to make due.  Unfortunately, when it is a serious call (not just a "please remember to pick up my kid") shouting doesn't feel right.The quest for a (near) perfect Bluetooth speakerphone goes on...
summary: I really wanted to like this.

reviewText: I'm not a phone-case person. I like to dock my phones, which is almost always mutually exclusive to having a case on my phone, plus I just don't like the extra bulk. But after the tragic end to my last phone (took a spill in St Louis and it was all downhill from there), I decided it was time to at least try to protect my new Nexus 5.It's definitely a slim case, and maintains the overall aesthetic/feel of the phone itself. The side buttons are fine-- as I'm not a case person I can't really tell you how they compare to other cases, but they seem perfectly reasonable to me. The cutouts all seem to line up correctly, though I haven't used the aux port at all. It feels like it will/would offer a reasonable amount of protection in the event of a fall. Thankfully I haven't had to test that.My concern is that I primarily charge my phone wirelessly. I have generic Qi chargers in my life, and have an AirDock on it's way to me (about which I am mega excited). The AirDock people have implied that this case will probably work with the dock (I plan to update this review when it arrives), so I'm not terribly worried about it *working*, but I am concerned about how hot the phone gets while charging all encased. I suppose that's another reasonable excuse for me to not like cases in general. My average battery temperature has gone up an average of at least a couple of degrees while I've had the case on, charging or not. Whether that's bad for the phone or not is tough to say, as I don't have another identical phone on which I can test the alternative.I like this one enough that, assuming the AirDock works with this case on, I will likely accept it into my life full time, as I do want to protect my phone and like the aesthetics of it just fine. If it doesn't work with the AirDock, I'll likely move on.
summary: A solid choice for the price

reviewText: This product for the price provides all the usefullness of a bluetooth device and a headphone to listen to music from the phone.

Typical for other New Trent products I received in the past, Ultra arrived in a premium package with a flip cover and a lot of info to walk you through all the features even before opening the box. Available in two finishes, orange and gray, for my review I chose an orange finish since it will stand out better in any outdoor situation and will be easier to locate if you drop it or misplace it. Yes, I did say "drop it" which for it's IP67 rated enclosure shouldn't be a problem. Of course, such protection comes at expense of an additional weight and size bulk, but it's manageable. With a dimensions of about 5.5" x 3" x 1" it's about 1.5 times thicker than a typical ext battery of such capacity. Also, at 366g it's a little heavier than other similar capacity batteries. But upon closer examination you will realize that additional protection layer fully justifies this extra bulk. The front and the back of the battery are made from a durable scratch resistant PC material, while the edges enclosed in a dense rubber material with a ribbed case design that gives you an excellent grip. You have full corner and side protection and both front and back have 8 standoffs to keep Ultra from sliding off any slippery surface.On a front of the battery, you have a power switch, fully sealed and rubberized, next to 4 blue led indicators for 25% capacity/charge incrementing indicators. The design of the switch prevents any accidental turn on where you have to press and hold it for 2 seconds before you start charging. This is a very important detail since you can have this battery in a backpack with other stuff, and don't have to worry about accidental turn on/discharge. The charging micro-usb input is on a side/corner with a secure port cover. As a matter of fact, it's secure enough that you will need to apply some force to open it. The same with 2 output full usb ports. It designed like that intentionally in order to meet full water and dirt protection. As a matter of fact, the included detailed manual mentions that a battery has been tested to endure being 3 feet underwater for up to an hour.Of course, this is still a battery, so let examine it's functionality. As I mentioned above, it has one charging Input and two Output ports, rated 1A and 2.1A. According to the spec, the input is rated at 5V/2A which suggests a super fast charging of the battery itself. My battery came 50% charged, and while I was timing it going up to a full 100% charge using included high quality usb cable, I noticed that charging speed was more inline with 1A-1.5A which is typical for external batteries and their 5V regulated converters. Basically it means that a full charge from empty will need about 12 hr on average, but you have to realize you are dealing with a huge 14,000 mAh capacity and this charging time is very reasonable. Regarding a total capacity, as you can imagine it's a max rated capacity of the internal 3.7V battery, and while converting it to 5V going to your usb cable, the efficiency of the conversion will lower the actual available capacity, so you should expect realistically about 11,000 mAh. This is typical for every external battery as well, to lose total capacity due to conversion efficiency. Regarding 2 output ports, although they are rated as 1A and 2.1A, I was able to charge my Note 2 out of each port with max 1.8A speed. You just have to keep in mind that you are sharing 3.1A between two ports, so for example charging Note 2 and Nexus 7 will be done simultaneously at full speed, but charging two Note 2 phones will lower the charging speed of both.Overall, I was VERY impressed with a built quality of this Ultra battery. Without a doubt, high capacity is a huge plus and it will be fantastic for outdoor use. I have reviewed a ton of external batteries in the past, and can tell you with certainty that I'm not sure if any of those would survive a serious outdoor drop, and can tell you for sure they won't survive drop in a water or a mud. If you are doing a lot of outdoor activities or working outside and need to keep a rugged external battery by your side, there is no other choice I can think of now beside this new Ultra. Extra rugged design/enclose will also come at extra premium you have to pay in comparison to other batteries with a same capacity, but in my opinion it's well worth it.
summary: Top choice rugged battery with super capacity!!!

reviewText: This charger is prefect for the car and does exactly what is says! I was able to plug in my ipod in one port and have my phone charge in a separate port via a usb plug.  Both charged flawlessly at the same time.  The only reason I give it 4 stars and not 5 stars is I think the product would be better it it was slightly bent. This might not be a problem in some cars, but for me, it's a little tight to squeeze in there and would be better if it was bent.  Otherwise, perfect charger!

These cases are great! I've purchased at least 4 of these.They're extremely convenient (they hold two cards). They also do a dynamite job of protecting my phone. I drop my phone while unlocking the door (30 inches). I drop my phone on asphalt when I get out of my car (30 inches). My phone falls off my desk. My phone flies out of bed when the alarm goes off. If you use a screen protector and this case, then your phone will be fine.These cases REALLY do hold two cards securely and snugly. Cards don't fall out. CArds are also easy to access.I am pretty hard on my phone and cases. I think otterboxes make me look like a clumsy klutz. I prefer the slimmer, sleeker look Speck offers. Each case keeps cosmetic appearance for AT LEAST 3 months. I usually grab a new case after 4 months (once the side wall cracks). If you're tough on your phone/case and you want a practical solution, then this is the case for you. The card slot is a must have for me. I don't carry a wallet, and this case prevents me from losing my license and credit card.3 to 4 months may not seem like a long time. Those who have used the speck candyshell without the card case know what I mean: cases get scratched/snapped. Repeatedly removing my phone from the case also causes the plastic to snap (cleaning or accessing the headphone jack).One note of caution: the case's 3mm headphone port works perfectly for Apple's headphones, but larger 3mm plugs may not make it. In order to insert these plugs, you'll need to pop your phone out. This is the case's only downside (in my opinion at least).
summary: Best case on the Market for iPhone 4/4s!

reviewText: Tiny & MIghty!I used this for a weekend conference, that I kinda crashed on a friend's good graces.  I slept in a hotel chair (which wasn't too bad), and did not have a lot of amenities.  One thing a really had to have working, though, was my iPad.  I was using UPad & Evernote & iMovie to record a lot of this conference for future use.  The screen was on nearly constantly, and the battery started to go south after about 6 hours.  I hooked it right up to this at the beginning of a 2-hour session with the iApple iUSB iCable, and the iPad didn't complain about not buying from Cupertino.2 hours later I was nearly 100%, and good for the rest of the day.  I charged this overnight, and the next day repeated this procedure.I have used the Energizer 18000XL for about a year, and it has all these different attachments, and plugs, and this & that that take up a lot of room, and never get used.  The ONLY think I'd ever used it for was my tablet & phone, and the USB connection was kinda loose, and frustrated me at times because I would think my tablet or phone was charging , and it wasn't.  Also, the slightest disconnection, and the Energizer turns off, requiring a button push to get it charging again.This one is smaller, feels a lot more solid, and will be the one I use first from now on.
summary: LIke it better than my Energizer 18000mAh

I, like a lot of Benz owners, found that bluetooth didn't mean streaming music, but only phone connectivity. I was so disappointed, I wanted to trade my new (used) Benz in! Well, I did a lot of research and found the Mercedes-Benz Media Interface Plus. It's a device that costs $250-300! I kept it in my shopping cart for weeks, wavering on whether or not to buy it!Well, one day, I stumbled on the Kinivo device, and decided to purchase it, based on others' positive reviews! When I got it, I was shocked as to how great it sounded! Definitely good enough for me to forget the deficiency in my vehicle's capabilities!I read how other users had to buy a grounding device. I also saved that in my shopping cart, but I was lucky because I didn't need it at all. No buzzing sound for me... just perfect music!I didn't give it 5 stars for one trivial reason... the cable from the charging device wasn't quite long enough. I choose to keep my Kinivo in my glove box, so I ran the wire from the charger to the glove box. It didn't quite make it, so I had to improvise. You can almost NOT see the wire as it sneaks in the back of my glove box. But it's not in the way of my passenger, so it's all good! Maybe I'll go back out and see if I can hide the device outside of my glove box; but I'm really happy with the way it's installed now.

It's really hard to complain for this price because it's really an incredible value. I recently ordered (and returned) an iPhone 4 case with a 1700mAh battery built into it. The case was 9 times the cost of this battery and only charged my phone 10% more. That said, it does have it's drawbacks. Due to the curvature of the newer devices (iPod touch 4g and iPad 2) the battery will not fit into the 30 pin slot far enough to make a connection. The battery will light up and "think" it's plugged in, but it's not. It would not charge my son's iPod touch 4G no matter what I did. Much the same issue with the iPad 2. Just simply could not make full contact for a charge to happen.That said, it works perfectly with my iPhone 4 and original iPad due to the flat base. I let my phone die completely and plugged in the battery and it was charged to 60% in about 2 hours. I'm a little annoyed about this because it says it will charge my phone to full in 2 hours, but I think they're playing with words here because it may very well fully charge an iPhone 3G to full simply because of lower capacity. However, as I mentioned above, I paid MUCH more for a battery case that didn't charge my phone much more than this one did, which brings me to another minor complaint. The shape of the battery is rather awkward. It's almost half the size of the phone and it's not exactly comfortable to hold while the battery is plugged in. You get what you pay for though. If you want a quick boost to your battery while your phone is sitting in your bag, this will do the trick nicely. If you want to continue using your phone while it's charging, you're going to have to pay more for a battery case.The LED indicators are a nice bonus as well. I like to see how much charge time is left by noting how many of the LEDs are lit. After charging the battery, the FULL light was on, but I noticed the next day when I actually plugged it into my phone it was down to 3 bars (from 4). I definitely don't like what this indicates. If the battery drains 25% in under 24 hours with no use, I'm not sure how much I'm actually going to benefit from it. Only time will tell on that one.The size is small enough that I can drop it in my purse and forget about it until I need it. I also own the 11000mAh New Trent iCruiser which definitely has more bulk, so I have this little guy as an emergency backup. Overall, if all you need is a quick boost to your battery when you're away from a power source, this really can't be beat for the price. Just know what to expect and what not to expect and you'll be pleased with the value received.
summary: Does NOT work with iPod 4G or iPad 2

Thus lapdock is an accessory specifically designed for Motorola's ATRIX 4g phone, turning it into a semi-laptop for increased productivity and entertainment (larger screen). The lapdock itself does not have a processor on-board, but instead "borrows" that of the high-end Atrix to unlock a new secondary user interface. It does, however, have a built-in battery which can last over 8 hours(!) and some LED's that notify the user of the amount of battery life left. The build quality of the lapdock is comparable with that of an Apple Macbook. It's sleek, it's super slim, and it oozes the word "premium" when held in the hand. That's to be expected through, considering the somewhat expensive price tag.The dock connects the phone via microUSB and a microHDMI port, which means the phone can also be charged when plugged in. The lapdock feature- what makes the Atric high-powered smartphone stand out from the crowd- will please moderate users. When the phone is docked (microUSB and microHDMI ports used), the lapdock accessory becomes a Linex-esk netbook with an 11" screen, stereo speakers, USB ports, a giant touchpad, a full chicklet qwerty keyboard, and a desktop Firefox browser. Astonishingly, the desktop browser is really responsive, and watching streaming videos (Hulu, SolarMovie, NetFlix) were often faster/more optimized than Chrome on a regular Windows computer. However, watching YouTube videos did have some lag, as did flash-heavy websites like The New York Times. The touchpad lacks multitouch, but is responsive like the keyboard. The phone's headphone jack can also still be accessed when docked.2 USB ports on both sides of the computer allows for basic files to be read and transferred to the phone's memory. However, unlike other lapdocks, this model lacks an SD card reader to create the thinner design. When docked, users can also access the regular Android screen of their phone (like using the lapdock as a larger monitor for the phone). In this mode, any Android apps will run, although it's not as smooth as the optimized Linux/Lapdock secondary UI.The lapdock is a great mobile companion which offers incredible battery life (8 hours & charges the phone), and sleek looks (metal, thin design). It won't replace a computer if you need constant access to things like Powerpoint Documents or such Desktop software- but for advanced web browsing and video watching, it does the job in style. Overall, a great concept from Motorola that needs some refining, but can be appreciated and applauded.
summary: It Does the Job in Style.

reviewText: I bought this phone case because it maintains the sleek look of the iPhone 5. Other cases may offer better protection but their bulkiness ruin the appearance of the phone & mine isn't subjected to rough treatment. The holster clips securely onto the belt. The spring loaded clip has a "U" shaped lip on the end that prevents it from slipping off the belt. It can be rotated + or - 90 degrees.The shell snaps onto the phone and completely covers the back & the sides. The top & bottom edges of the screen are not covered but are somewhat protected by the raised side pieces, good enough for my needs.  If you want more protection, get the OtterBox. The back of the shell also contains a very handy kickstand that can be used in the portrait or landscape position. It's a bit stiff when new but becomes easier to open & retract with use.The phone is easy to remove from the holster but fits securely in it. It's survived 2 trips to 6 Flags & all the coasters without any sign of it trying to escape. The earphone & sync jacks are accessible when the phone is holstered.Good design, sturdy & a reasonable price: that is 5 stars in my book.

reviewText: Until recently, I NEVER used a stylus - after all, that is why God gave us fingers! At least I never used one until I took a look at my husband's iPad screen, and compared it to my own. His was clean and pristine. Mine was ... covered with fingerprints. The difference? He was using a stylus.After receiving a complimentary sample of these from the Friendly Swede, I tested them out with great success.I originally encountered a resistance problem with my iPad screen because I had a cover on it (polarized). I didn't like the cover - it didn't really help with privacy - so I peeled it off. Instant success.Unlike the little plastic tips, these are a fiber kind of material, they feel much sturdier than the others, and after testing and using these for a few weeks, I was impressed. The cloth that comes with these, along with the elastic tethers make these a fun addition. I love being able to tuck the pen inside the foldover on my case and carry it with me easily.Very nice selection.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this unit, but was really disappointing.  The sound quality is just OK.  If the phone reception is at all garbled this unit will make it worse.  At times I have to ask the caller to hold while I turn the blue tooth off in order to understand them.  The volume control is adjusted by moving your finger up or down on the surface of the unit.  This is somewhat problematic because trying to adjust the fit of the unit can change the volume.  The batter life is severely lacking, only two hours of talk time.  The charging unit is cute, but it's hard to get the ear piece in and out and is really not very handy.  To get reasonable talk time, you have to carry the charger with you (you don't have to plug it in the wall) and plug the ear piece into it in between long calls.  Just one more thing to carry in your pocket and loose. The real kicker for me is that it provides a very loose fit on my ear and tends to move out of my ear when I tip my head.  For a long time I've used a Plantronics unit that cost about 1/3 as much as this one and it has better sound, a battery that lasts for days and more straight forward controls.  I'm going back to my Plantronics unit.  Don't waste your money on this one.
summary: Works but not as well as lower priced units

The one I was sold my Mobileshop 2000 was most likely a fake. I have a very hard time believing this piece of junk passed any sort of quality control from Samsung. The device was coming apart right out of the box, and one of the earhooks came broken. The power switch did not have the orange indicator like all official Samsung photo show. The voice and audio streaming worked fine, but the device did not have the Voice Prompt or Multisync features that it is supposed to have. For these reasons I am convinced I received a badly constructed fake. I have already requested a refund and can't wait to get a different bluetooth that actually has some quality in it's build.

I take the iPhone 4S out of my pocket a couple of dozen times a day so perhaps it isn't surprising the seal around the front screen started peeling away over time. What I found surprising was contacting customer service shortly after Otterbox acquired LifeProof earlier this year and getting little response the first time and no response the second. The form for service requires the serial numbers off the front AND back pieces of the case. The front was still legible but the back was not. I provided the front serial number because I could read it and it is the part with the problem and added a comment I could not read the serial number on the back part - NOT GOOD ENOUGH. I received a perky form letter from customer service asking me to remove my phone from the case, take a picture of the illegible serial number and send it back to LifeProof. I asked what good it was going to do for them to have a picture of the serial number when I couldn't read it with a magnifying glass and received no reply. I let the seal peel back for a couple more weeks and submitted a new form with a link to the requested picture of the illegible serial number. Again, NO RESPONSE.Amortized over the service life this LifeProof case cost 30 cents a day! For a product in this price range the customer support attitude and effectiveness is poor and it seems worse under Otterbox corporate ownership. The case itself is expensive. It is lighter than the Otterbox original but it is still not light. It doubles the thickness of the iPhone. I agree with another water sports enthusiast reviewer, buy a screen protector and a much less expensive case and put the phone in a waterproof pouch when you are on the water.
summary: Overpriced and poor service since Otterbox bought them

After having purchased over 20 different power banks, I received this unit free for review.  It compares well with others in it's capacity class.  The slim, brushed aluminum case looks very nice.  It weighs 9 ounces,  measures 2 & 7/8 by 5 & 1/2 inches and 9/16 inches thick.  It has a small test button to determine the charge.  During re-charge the lights stay on; during discharge they light only briefly to conserve power.  It is capable of being re-charged at up to 2A. When charging other devices, it has dual USB outputs of 1A and 2.1A with single and dual lightning symbols.  The charging cord supplied is heavy duty and carries the high currents better than most.  Trying some other cords limited the current severely due to thin gauge wires.  Unlike most power banks, which show 3-4 lights for a long time then die fast, this unit still has 47% of its available charge when it goes to a single light and about two-thirds available when it goes to 2 lights on.Upon receipt, it showed two lights on. It charged to 100% in about 2.5 hours starting at 1.4A with a current meter in the circuit, which can limit the current.The 4 charge indicators are not linear.  Instead of each one representing 25% charge,when re-charging:all 4 on indicates  90-100%, so leave it on the charger a while longer after it lights that fourth light,4th blinking is 60-90%,3rd blinking is 30-60%,2nd blinking is 10-30%,and one blinking is 0-10%.  My rough checks indicate the re-charge lights work as specified.When discharging:all 4 on is 90-100%,3 on is 70-90%,2 on is 40-70%,1 on is 10-40%,and none on, but still providing power, is less than 10%.  My initial tests indicate that the fourth and third lights go out quicker.  Then the final lights last much longer.I started my tests with both outputs supplying .86A while maintaining 4.90V for a combined power of 1.72A.  After 2 hours, my Kindle keyboard was fully charged, having started at about half charge.  During that time the power bank got noticeably warm.  As expected the 4th light went out quickly and the third not quite as fast.  I continued charging the second device for another 2.6 hours at .85A.  Total power delivered was 1.72A x 2 hr + .85A x 2.6 hrs = 5.65 amp hours.  It then had one light lit.  I assumed it was probably near empty, so re-charged it in about 7 hours.For the second test, I took it all the way from 100% to empty as follows:Charged my Clip Zip from 66% to 100% at .15A in 40 minutes while the MP3 player continued to play.  Not a heavy test, but rather shows that the stated 80ma cutoff current is low enough to fully charge small music players - something many power banks cannot do.  About .1Amp-hr (Ah) supplied so far.Charged my simple Alcatel cell phone from zero to 100% with a starting current of .61A.  It finished in 1.75 hrs, tapering off at the end for another .8Ah.  Total so far of .9Ah or 9% of capacity - bank showed 3 lights - on the edge of the predicted state.Then I charged my ASUS HD 7 tablet from 56% to 100% in 2.25 hr, starting at 1.2A from the high power outlet.  44% x 3.8 = 1.67 Ah, 2.57 Ah so far or 26% of capacity - 2 lights still lit.  Amp-hr supplied was calculated from the charge state of the tablet, which may be on the low side, since the tablet was in sleep mode and drawing a small current. Predicted state would have been still 3 lights.At this point I had charged all my devices except some of the other power banks.  I picked a depleted ECTech 12K bank as the final test load, charging at a steady rate of .95A again through the current meter.  After 1 hour, the Poweradd bank was down to 1 light.  Total power supplied was 2.57 + .95 = 3.52 Ah or 35% supplied thus far.  Predicted state would have been 2 lights.  Not looking good at this point.  But I continued.  After another 1.85 hr the last light went off for another .95 x 1.87 = 1.78 + 3.52 = 5.3 Ah so far.  I figured it was near the end.  But it kept supplying .95A for another 1.4 hr, maintaining a steady 4.90V, with the current actually rising to just over 1.0 A in the final minutes.  So another 1.4 x .95 = 1.33 + 5.30 = 6.63 Ah delivered.  Total delivery of 6630 mAh x 4.90 V or 32.5Watt-hr.  Figuring the average Li-polymer cell voltage was 3.7V, the bank holds 3.7 x 10 = 37 Watt-hr for a decent converter loss of 12%.  After the last light went off, it continued to supply about 20% of the total delivered power, not 10%.  When it went to a single light on, it still had 47% of the total delivered power left, not 40%.Li-polymer cells sometimes take a few charge cycles to reach maximum capacity, so I will report again after a few more cycles.In summary, don't give up hope when those lights start going out, those last lights indicate more power left than you think.  It should keep delivering full current and voltage right up to shut down - much better than most power banks.  It is packaged in a slim, elegant case with good versatility.  Use the better than average provided USB cord, if possible, when transferring high currents.  Light duty cords will not deliver full power.  While you can use both outputs at once, do so with caution - that heat build up indicates extra power loss.  If you trip the (unstated) maximum current draw or hit the high temperature limit it will go into safety shut down.  That requires disconnecting it, cooling down, and putting it back under re-charge for a while to reset the limit circuits.Update 4/14/2014:Ran one more test today.  Discharged the bank from 100% to off at .83A to .89A, current meter in circuit always.  Obtained a total of 6950 mAh or 34.2 Wh at 4.92V output.  A little higher than the previous test showing only 8% loss in the converter.  During this test the lights changed by:4 lit - 97-100%3 lit - 68-97%2 lit - 47-68%1 lit - 4-47%none lit 0-4%This time the bank was near empty when the last light went off.  It still went to one light at about 47% remaining.

reviewText: This is my second pair of the BTH240 (I lost my first). And I've owned 2 pairs of BTH220. I've also given 3 pairs of the 220s as gifts. I love these headphones. They are comfy, the batteries last a long time, and the sound quality is fine. The stereo is more defined on the 240s vs the 220s, and I still am not sure which version I like more. The 240 looks nicer, but the 220 has easier to feel buttons. These are some of the sturdiest headphones I've owned. With non-bluetooth headphones, the cable is the first thing to go.

The disadvantages to this is that it is not the kind of clip-on that opens like a clamp but rather slips on to your lapel of collar. Other reviews have described the unit well, let me share my experiences.I use this device with a Samsung Captivate and an Apple iMac running OSX 10.6 Snow Leopard.It paired with both instantly.On the Captivate, it works as advertised- streams music in surprisingly high fidelity, takes calls (pauses the music), and seems to have built-in background noise suppression (for the mic).  Audio quality listening to music, and on calls is very good.I did an A/B to determine the Bluetooth's effect on sound quality by playing a song on the Captivate through the MW600 for a few seconds, then paused it, swapped the included earbud's jack from the MW600 directly into the Captivate's jack and re-started play.  There was very little sound difference (plugging in directly sounded very slightly better, but not enough to matter).One drawback so far is that the song titles are supposed to display on the MW600's screen, but do not with the Captivate.  This might be an issue with the built-in audio player software in the phone, I'll try some other music software.  As far as I know the Captivate supports all the latest cool-guy Bluetooth standards.One nice plus is that the included charger uses a micro-USB connector, the same as the Captivate (and other phones, I'm sure), so I now have an extra wall charger that will work with both phone and MW600, plus I can use the Captivate's USB to Micro USB charging cable to charge both (off my computer's USB) when I travel and in the car.I paired it with the built-in Bluetooth on my iMac, set it as the audio in/out device in System Preferences> Sound, and played music with iTunes.  The sound quality was very very good, the transport buttons on the MW600 (play/ pause/ FF/ RW) controlled iTunes instantly (no lag), and the song titles DID show up on the MW600, streamed from iTunes, also instantly. Again, the response time from pausing, playing, or skipping forward or back was instantaneous, no lag.  I'm very impressed with the usage of iTunes streamed from the iMac to the MW600, it works perfectly in every way.With Skype, I set the MW600 as the audio in/out in Skype> Preferences, and was a bit buggy at first.  Skype locked up twice when I tried to place a call.  I finally figured out- OSX can see the MW600 as either "Bluetooth Headset" (mono) or "Bluetooth Headphones" (stereo).  If you set it (in System Preferences> Sound) as "Bluetooth Headset" (mono), it works perfectly with Skype.  Skype must not play well with stereo audio over Bluetooth.I placed a Skype test call, recorded my voice and it sounded fine.  Not landline fidelity fine, but o.k. for VoIP.The built in FM radio works well, my only niggle is that you can't program station presets, you either scan through available stations (press and hold to scan to the next strong station) or skip ahead 100KHz at a time (99.1, 99.2, 99.3, etc).  If you're say, at 89 and you want to tune a station at 106, you can't just hold the forward button down and scroll all the way there, you have to go one station at a time, or .1 at a time.  That's a drag.The MW600 automatically displays the station name, ("Jack FM", "KCRW", etc) when you tune it in, then scrolls the artist and song title as it plays (if the station supports it).One final thing, I compared the MW600 ear buds against the ones that came with the Captivate- the Captivate ear buds sound better- more bass, generally higher fidelity, so that supports other comments here that the included ear buds are not the best.  I have a good set of headphones tucked away somewhere, I'm confident that it'll sound great, used for air or train travel, quietly listening in bed at night while reading, etc.Others here have complained about the volume slider.  It is not really an issue for me.  Certainly, it's not as easy to use as a knob, but once you figure it out and use the MW600 a few times, you can get the hang of it.You put your fingertip on the raised slider area, press and slide toward the top of the MW600 (to turn it up).  There's a "+" sign bump at the top, just hold your fingertip there and the volume steadily raises, lift your finger when it's at the volume you want- the display shows a graphic of the volume level.  Do the opposite to lower the volume.  No big deal.So, to summarize, it works perfectly and flawlessly for Bluetooth functions on the iMac- Skype/ VOIP and iTunes streaming.It works nearly perfectly on the Captivate phone, the only minus is that the song titles do not appear in the window.The radio sounds great, has cool display features, but tuning stations is a bit cumbersome.It has a pretty incredible amount of features and quality, stuffed into a very small, very lightweight package.

I love the velvety smooth feel of TYLT's flat ribbon car charger. It is just the right length at 2 feet to put on the seat, console, cup holder, or phone holder, but short enough to prevent the user from being able to talk on the phone while driving - and it should be. It fits in the iPhone just snug enough to not fall out, but can easily be removed if needed to make or receive a call. The other end fits in the power outlet/lighter socket with the right amount of strength. I haven't plugged another USB device in the extra charging socket, but that's only because I really don't have anything else to charge. The TYLT ribbon cable charges the iPhone pretty quickly too - more like a quick charger than a trickle charger. Some other reviewers indicate the cable should have an LED to show the phone is charging, and that would be nice, but looking on the phone's display isn't that difficult. The flat ribbon design avoids tangling, especially during storage, I just kind of bunch it up and put it away. Overall it is a nice charger, has nice style, is bright and colorful, but may a little bit over priced.
summary: This Ribbon Charges Your iPhone 4s or below Plus another USB device.

reviewText: It's a very good deal to get three of these so cheap.  They hold up very well and I haven't had one that has come off on its own to do losing its stickiness.

The OXA Perfume 2600mAh external battery is a great companion to your smaller phones like the iPhone. I was able to charge from about 15% to a full 100% on my phone about as quickly as I would with my regular wall charger, and the battery still had a bit more power left for another small charge later in the day.The battery came with a USB cable that takes a variety of interchangeable tips, including the Apple 30-pin dock connector and micro USB. Since I have an iPhone 5, I just used my regular Lightning cable, which works fine with the OXA.The 1A output on the OXA is good for the iPhone and other smaller USB devices, but it won't work well for iPads or large Android/WIndows phones that use 2.1A chargers.Overall, I'm very happy with the OXA Perfume, and it's a fantastic value for the price.
summary: Great external battery for my iPhone 5

reviewText: Love this! Why do I need to say more? It works. It arrived on time. It has a cool light that lets you know it's charged. Boom. Awesome.

This case is great for people who don't need to much protection.  I am a very careful person and never drop my phone, so I am not worried about too much drop protection.  If you are the type of person who is worried about dropping your phone from 6 feet high on concrete, go check out one of those ugly, bulky cases.  I picked this case because it is slim, adds no bulk and actually makes the Galaxy S4 look better.  It has a lay on the table design and the tpu back is thick enough that the camera and flash lens are also safe from touching flat surfaces.  I also like the fact that it adds more grip to the phone.  The Galaxy S4 without a case is very slick and slippery. I personally think that this is the best case if you're trying to protect your phone from scratches, minor drops and want better grip.  Also the silver looks sexy with the black Galaxy because it picks up on the silver accents of the home button, camera ring, speakers and samsung symbol.  The only reason I am giving it 4 stars is because I feel like they should have made the speaker cutout a little bit bigger.  It is such a perfect cutout that it will occasionally muffle the sound if laid on its back.

BEFORE YOU READ, check out my unboxing/review of this product on YouTube: [...]I am a Power User for Anker so I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promise that my review is fair and honest.This is a lovely external battery that features a 6000mAh capacity, a built in micro USB charging cord, a second USB charging port (for devices that don't use the micro standard), 4 LED indicators to see how much life you still have in your device, a USB to micro USB cord (but in my opinion it is way to short and you can see it in the video I posted) and enough power for about three extra charges.I tried using this battery on all my devices that use a wall charger. I tested it using an iPhone 4, Samsung Galaxy s3, and a Nikon Coolpix s9200. Unfortunately when i was trying to charge my camera, it did not have enough power to charge it. I knew this was true because when i had plugged it into the wall at home, it charged up fine. It gladly charged up my other two phones.Tests:I was able to charge the iPhone 4 from 10% to 100% in about 4 hours. When it was done it had the last two LED's lit.Then, I charged my s3 from 27% to 100% which took about two and a half hours. It had only one lit LED when it was finished charging.My last test was the s3 again, and it charged from 47% to 85%, which took an hour, but died before it could get to 100%.Pros:Very slick, thin, designBuilt in charging cordLED indicators showing how much "juice" you have leftDual USB chargingCons:The included USB cord, in my opinion, is extremely shortCouldn't charge my s9200 Coolpix cameraThis battery is great for those who need an extra charge throughout their day. It fits nicely in a pants pocket or you can just through it in your briefcase or backpack to school or work. I just think that a 6000mAh battery should be able to hold a little bit more charge than about less than 4 phone charges, but its great for an emergency charge.If you are in need of a reasonably priced external battery, then this is the one for you.Thank you Anker for sending this product out to me.
summary: Excellent Battery, But doesn't charge my camera

reviewText: If you're looking for a bluetooth boombox that you can put on a bookshelf and fill up a room with very good quality sound, the A73 will do the trick.  The speakers are large and you can pump up the volume with little in the way of distortion.  It would be perfect for an apartment, although it's certainly not high powered enough to propel a noisy party.The device is fairly intuitive.  It's easy to figure out on your own without the manual how to access the radio, bluetooth and auxiliary sound input.There are limitations to the A73.  It's supposed to be designed to lug around (and the handle and internal battery of course allow you to do that), but the base is kind of skinny, making the unit prone to falling over.  The main speakers are exposed (there is no grill), which means that they might be easily pierced and ruined.  I'd never take this thing out on the beach or to a picnic.  It's not robust enough.  It's designed to be carried from room to room indoors.  I would bring the A73 out to the backyard or to the driveway when I'm working on my bike or car, but I'd be careful where I placed it.A unit like this should have a USB connection for a flash drive in addition to the bluetooth and auxiliary inputs.  I don't understand why TDK didn't spend a few extra bucks to put something like that in.  Also, an AM radio band would have been an inexpensive, but valuable addition.Overall, it's the sound this unit provides that carries the day.  But a more versatile boom box would be preferable.
summary: Very nice sound, somewhat limited versatility

Built in LED flashlight provides added convenience when needed.*  High Capacity 10000mAh with Dual USB output, 2.1A output charges most tablets efficiently while 1A output is used for smaller devices like smartphones and GPS.*  High compatibility - Charges most devices that can be charged via USB, these includes most tablets, most smartphones, GoPro, GPS, and some digital cameras.*  High quality grade-A internal cells with real 10000mAh capacity. Smart internal circuitry prevents short circuit, over-charging and over-heating.Package includes: 1 X Protective Travel Case, 1 X Ox-10 10000mAh High Capacity External Battery, 1 x USB Wall Charger, 1 X USB to Micro USB cable, 1 X Micro USB to Apple 30 pin connector, 1 X Micro USB to Mini USB adapterI have used this travel kit many times when I haven't had access to a plug and have found it a lifesaver. reviewText: So, you want to protect your new iPhone 5, but you don't want the device to lose it's sleek and sexy design. The Linear case is exactly what you're looking for. This case is a breeze to put on, and unlike many other snap cases, this one actually stays put. The clear back is fairly resistant to scratches and lets the nice metal back of the iPhone 5 show through. The side protection includes easy access to the mute switch and ports, all the while brilliantly mimicking the original exterior design of the iPhone. It's the case that doesn't look like theres a case on your phone. The addition of an included front screen protector is a nice touch for the price too.  All around, one of the best looking and best functioning cases I've ever used for my iPhone. Highly recommended.

reviewText: The Good:*  Easy to setup*  A hidden stand that slides out and hidden when not in use*  Solid protection for the back side of the phone*  Very durable design with that "heavy-duty" lookThe Bad:*  iPhone4 buttons may be hard to press for some individuals who have weaker or pain in hands*  May obstruct the opening for some "L-Shaped" headphones*  Slightly bigger and heavier than many casesThe Bottom Line:This is not the first Speck products that I have used.  This was very very intriguing to the fact that it has a slide-out stand, which is probably it's biggest selling point.  Putting the case on was easy for the most part and requires a little forced at the end to cover iPhone controls.  Keep in mind that the case will cover iPhone's power and volume controls with case's own grey buttons, which I admit could cause trouble for certain individuals as it makes it slightly tougher to press now.  It makes a headphone connector slightly more recessed(about 1CM,) which isn't much, but could limit certain "L-Shaped" headphones from fitting.  The stand is very nifty and easy to use, and may seem that it only supports vertical view, but that's not true as you can turn the phone horizontally and watch YouTube videos on a flat surface with ease.BEWARE!  This case is almost impossible to take off!  Because it has a "glove" design and not a snap-on from both sides design, it is a pain in the neck(hands and even teeth if you are going that route) to take off.  I was not able to take the case off with my bare hands yet.  In fact, if you can give me a tip or two on how to do so, please comment!Another thing to consider is that the case weighs 1.8 ounces.  My last Speck case weighed just 0.7 ounces.  It also slightly wider than most cases.  As I said before, HEAVY DUTY construction.
summary: Great case, especially if you take a lot of self-pictures, but may cause minor troubles for some.

I tried a few BT headsets and it came down to the Nokia BH-800 and the Jabra JX10.  Both units have good audio quality.  I also liked that both units are small.  Thus, you don't look like you are on your way to a Star Trek convention while you are wearing them.While I liked the JX10's design over the BH-800, it had trouble understanding my voice commands.  I use Microsoft Voice Command with my XV6700 PocketPC phone.  I had to speak to the JX10 very slow and clearly to achieve only a 50% success rate in it understanding my commands the first try and subsequent tries.  The BH-800 understands my commands closer to 90% on the first try and 99% on the second try.The JX10 was comfortable in my ear without the earloop.  It never came close to falling out- it passed the head tilt test and the bend over test.  With the earloop, however, I could barely hear the unit.  The earloop prevents the unit from coming close enough to the ear.Pros:1. Good audio quality.  People can clearly hear me and I can clearly hear them.2. It's small.  It's less "geeky" than some headsets.3. Nice look and button layout.4. Charge cradle and USB charging is a nice bonus.Cons:1. I had to remove the ear loop so that I could get the unit close enough to my ear to hear it.2. I felt like I might break the unit when connecting and disconnecting it from the cradle.3. Did not work well with Microsoft Voice Command.  This was the show stopper and why I picked the Nokia BH-800 instead.
summary: Nice Headset.  Did not work well with Microsoft Voice Command. :-(
