reviewText: I really like this case.  It adds considerable bulk to the phone, but I feel like it is well protected from any mishap.  All of the buttons and ports are easily accessible.  Screen protector is fantastic - you do not even notice it is there.Now my issue - the holster.Main problem - the belt clip.  While the locking belt clip is a good idea when you want to prop it up, I am finding that it inadvertently activates when I am sitting in a chair or getting in and out of the car.  Once it activates, the phone comes right off your belt.  I contacted Otterbox about this and their suggestion was "You may have better results if you adjust the positioning of where the holster is on your side."  Come on - that is not really an answer.  I plan to "break" the tab that holds it open to make sure this does not happen.Second Problem - and maybe not a problem, but the phone is only held in by a single 1" tab.  I am used to a flip top pouch to hold my phone and this thing makes me very nervous.  I am concerned that if brush up against something it will pop out without me knowing.  I do quite a bit of outdoor activities in noisy areas and it would be easy for it to pop out without knowing.

Update: After about three months my unit has completely died. It worked great while it lasted and I am debating getting a second one or a new brand.This little device is just that little, and one if the reasons I chose to try it. It is nice and small and no cables hanging from the audio jack. It easily paired with my iPhone 5 and the sound is much better than I expected. I read other reviews that the sound was too soft and low but it was plenty loud in my car without having to crank up the volume. In fact I had to turn it down.My biggest complaint is the instructions, which are awful. The instructions say the red charging light turns off when charging is complete. After over twenty hours mine was still on, but the blue light came on too. I had to read the Amazon reviews to find out that both lights on means charging is done. The instructions also have no way of turning the device off. I had to figure that out on my on by pressing the button longer than 8 seconds for pairing and both lights go out.Overall, it is well worth the price. Repairs easily by holding the power button. Very happy so far.
summary: Sounds great, nice and small, instructions are awful - only lasted three months

reviewText: The unit looks very promising when you unpack it, but this is where the positive notes end.Let's still try to find positives:-Unit does look and feel good to the touch and adds nice weight to the Nexus 5.-Not bulky at all.-Decent capacity at 2,500 mAh as per documentation that comes with it.-USB cable that came with unit has a little smiley face that lights-up when you touch it, which is cute, but has absolutely no charging indicator purpose whatsoever....and the Cons:-Trying to slide it in was a challenge as the micro USB did not seem to match the phone properly, but after wiggling it, it finally came in.-Charging is also slow.-While charging, unit makes a high pitch sound which is extremely annoying.-Back button is only a "charge/no charge button" and does not have any smart features that might tell you level of charge remaining while keeping charging (like holding button for 3 seconds to maintain functionality either on or off AND telling you charge status of battery pack).I guess, it is back to square one and try to find a juice pack for the Nexus 5.This is the second order I place with I-Blason products and the end results in both occasions were disappointing.
summary: Micro USB did not align right and makes high pitch sound.

reviewText: The AR.Drone is a great idea, at least the Drone part of the name, not so much the AR (augmented reality). However, the implementation leaves a lot to be desired.This is a fun toy to fly when it behaves, but it doesn't behave too often. I've had numerous very erratic behaviors from my drone. When flying full speed in a direction, the drone often flips itself over. Despite having the altitude limited setting toggled on (should keep it under 10 ft high) I've had the drone ignore the altitude and fly up into a tree, breaking a plastic part upon falling. The drone will often erratically lose altitude and bounce off the ground with the propellors still running. Or, the drone will randomly fly up into the sky, without you telling it to do so. What is so frustrating about all of these erratic behaviors, is that they eventually end up in broken parts and you have to shell out more money buying new props, gear shafts, gears, or having to send the AR Drone in for a repair. I've bought theParrot AR.Drone Mounting Toolswhich I think should be included with this product andParrot AR.Drone Replacement Gear with Shaft Setwhich is helpful since the aluminum shafts are so easily bent and the gears take a beating on some falls. I do have to give Parrot credit for creating a product so repairable and having every part available. I am impressed with how will the drone holds up to some substantial falls, but due to the erratic behavior, there are just too many bullets for it to dodge. Eventually something breaks. I've had the styrofoam indoor hull break only once, but instead of ordering Parrots repair tape, I was able to repair it with normal double sided tape.Customer service has failed to impress me. After first noticing the erratic behavior, I sent an email with my issues. Parrot never responded to my email. I had to call them and talk to someone to get a return authorization. I paid for shipping to get the drone repaired, which was about $10-15, but they paid for shipping back to me. After getting it back, it still behaved erratically. So I sent it back to them after a crash had broken a part, again paying for shipping. I received it back with the part repaired, but it appears they never tried to address the erratic behavior this time. So I called Parrot again to have them address the issues, and they were very nice over the phone, acknowledged that the erratic behavior hadn't been looked at the last time, and said they would send me a return authorization and upon asking, they said they would cover the shipping this time. However, that was around 2 months ago, and I still have not received the return authorization. I've been too busy to contact them again, but I will soon.The camera quality is very poor on both the front facing and ground facing camera. This would be understandable, if Parrot didn't photoshop in very good looking pictures onto the iPhone controllers in all their advertisements. The framerate is poor, and so the augmented reality aspect of the drone seems like it would be worthless, although I have never tried. The battery life has been surprisingly long for me, somewhere around the quoted 15 minutes, which seems like a while when you are flying.Beyond those complaints, it is a very fun toy when it works. I've enjoyed flying it when it behaves, and it is great to show to your friends or tease your dog with. Unfortunately, judging from other people's stories about their drones, I'm not convinced that my drone has anything wrong with it, but am leaning towards the conclusion that most other drones are operating like mine. It seems like Parrot bit off a bit more than they could chew and that the first generation of the AR.Drone was more of an expensive beta than a polished product.I hope this review helped. The second generation drone looks to be pretty promising. Let me know if I can answer any questions by leaving a comment.

New Trent Trentium iPhone 5/5S Case (NT630Cr-B) was tested on an iPhone 5S.This case comes in three pieces: screen cover with hard shell, rubberized backing that extends over the sides and top of the hard shell, and a hard backing that fits over the middle of the rubberized backing. This last piece appears to give support to the back, but it also provides a stylish two tone. However, I wish it snapped into place better. It appears to be a little loose.The case completely covers all parts of the iPhone. Clear plastic is found over the screen, cameras, flash, and home button. The plastic is very durable and has a hint of a checkered pattern. When used over the screen, it produces a rainbow of colors noticeable when the screen is off. The screen cover is a little harder to keep clean than the iPhone screen and appears to attract more dust. The screen cover does not reduce touch performance.I was very surprised to find that the plastic over the home button does not interfere with the iPhone 5S fingerprint identification. However, it does make the home button significantly harder to push; over time, the plastic may stretch or break with repetitive pressing.Fabric is placed over the phone speaker. Holes are used for the bottom speaker and microphone. The headphone jack, charging port, and volume on/off switch are covered with access ports. Ports are easily accessible, but does cause problems when non-Apple cords are used. The volume, on/off buttons, and cameras work very well through the case.The case is advertised as being slim, and it is, but as with all complete body covers it does add bulk. The phone becomes several additional millimeters in all dimensions.The case is very durable and protects the iPhone well. My concerns for potential damage from dropping or scratches have been greatly reduced. I expect the case to keep my phone looking brand new for months to years. I work an office/lab job and keep my phone in a relatively clean environment, but I can see how this case could provide sufficient protection for more physically demanding jobs.Pros:Protects phone wellRelatively slimDoes not hinder performance.Stylish designCons:Screen cover produces colors when screen is turned off and is harder to keep clean.Larger non-Apple cords do not fit through the case.Home button harder to use.Adds more bulk to the iPhone than expected when advertised as slim.Rating: 4.5 out of 5

This vehicle dock is meant to work with the Atrix 4g phone, also from Motorola.  As a dedicated accessory to a specific product, it pairs very well with the Atrix phone.The car dock comes with a small insert that allows you to use your phone with it regardless of whether or not you have a case.  Some bulky cases might prevent you from docking successfully, but small form factor ones should work without a problem.  If you have no case or cover, the insert lets your phone slip snugly into the dock.  The insert sits in the dock itself, it doesn't have to be attached to your phone.  You wouldn't even know it was there after your 1st use.The suction cup is very well designed and attached firmly to my windshield.  I've had problems in the past with docks not sticking to my window, especially in very hot or very cold conditions, but this dock holds tight and doesn't so much as wobble.  Also included is a small 'cup' for attaching this to your dashboard.  I prefer the window mount, but you can attach to your dashboard if you like.The cord included plugs into a car power adapter (also included) and into the AUX port in your vehicle.  The power adapter has 2 USB ports on it, meaning you can charge another device while this one is plugged in, a great feature.  If you do not have an aux or input in your vehicle (or stereo) you might want to review your options for getting sound from the atrix to your car, but the phone will still charge, and you can always just turn the speaker way up.  I found I had no problem hearing navigation commands or calls over the phone speaker on high volume.When the phone is plugged in it automatically launches the dedicated cardock app.  This gives you several large icons, easy to hit with one hand.  There are several default ones, and multiple pages of customizable slots where you can add any program you want.  For example, I added Pandora radio app to my front page, as well as the 'camcorder' program.The default 'my location' icon is nice in that it acts as a compass, telling you your current direction.  If you click on 'my location,' though, the interface it launches is not ideal.  I found I had better luck using the google maps 'navigation' app included with the atrix.  When that program launches it offers voice search by default, whereas the 'my location' required you to hit a tiny button in order to do voice navigation.My only complaint with this product is that there was a production run of non-functional car docks.  That is, some docks do nothing when you plug your phone into them, they're not working.  A quick internet search shows that a certain number docks shipped with some kind of defect.  I ended up with one of those units.I was able to get a replacement dock through Motorola, but the process was not as smooth as I would have liked.  At first they wanted me to factory reset my phone, losing all my data.  Next, they wanted me to pay for return shipping (and, indeed, required a credit card number before they would honor my warranty).  In the end they replaced my unit, though it took a while and many many phonecalls.I give this product 4 stars overall.  This is a great great cardock, but it's a bit expensive and Motorola customer service was more of a hassle than they should have been.
summary: Expensive, some bad units, but a good product

reviewText: I was expecting that company with the name in mobile business will treat its flagship product with proper attention. Especially when the sales are poor and company loses money every month.I was wrong.Not only the OS is half-baked, no useful programs, no maps of my region, no even descent music player. In addition, the phone reboots itself for no reason, 2-3 times a day, no matter what I do.That is super-annoying.Having said that, I admit that I like the overall idea of WP8, but honestly, implementation is horrible.To whom I would recommend this? I dont know, maybe to my family's enemy or to some crazy microsoft lover/Nokia geek, so he/she could spend days and nights setting up and rebooting this useless piece of hardware...I dont know. Seriously, with all this hype around Windows Phone platform, and how it is so much better then other competitors - why is the flagship hardware, backed by 2 super corporations, is so buggy, unreliable, useless? How come?
summary: Only a half-baked blank, not a real finished product

My first impression of the Hercules WAE-BTP02 Portable Bluetooth Speaker was very favorable as I unpacked it.  Upon opening the Amazon shipping box, you see a really cool circular box containing the speaker. The packing inside is great; you know the item will not get damaged in shipping.Set up was a breeze. I connected to my laptop easily by pairing the devices. Connection to an iPad and iPod required downloading an app from the App store and then a few second later...they were connected.Then my disappointment began.I am no audiophile, but I was immediately disappointed at how unbalanced this speaker sounds.  It is definitely lacking in the bass range.  The treble / high end sounds are noticeably dominant.  If this were the only issue, I would rate this product 4 stars.The second star deduction comes from interference. I have tested the speaker in 2 areas of the house (1 downstairs and 1 up) and both times have experienced connection issues. This prompted me to explore how bluetooth works. At first I thought perhaps it was like infrared and was more line of sight.  Why? Because when I put my body inbetween the laptop and the speaker, the speaker cut in and out or it would have static sounds. I had the same experience with the iPod touch and the speaker. From what I read, this shouldn't happen. Bluetooth functions in the same frequency range as many other devices (around 2.4 GHz)and is not line of sight dependent. Not sure what the issue is.  There was no microwave running when these issues happened. We do have a lot of devices, so maybe that is part of the problem. If so, I would imagine most other people have their fair share of wireless devices and may have the same issue.Right now there are 4 other reviews of this speaker up and I seem to be the only one with this concern though.  Maybe you will have better luck.
summary: If only the speaker was as impressive as the packaging

I have a Samsung Droid Charge, and the battery drains to a critically low level after about 10 hours with minimal use (e.g., no phone calls and reading 3 or 4 emails during the day). I can usually make it through a day at work and then charge it in the car and at home. But it can be useful to carry an emergency charger such as this Energizer when you will be out and about longer than your phone's battery will last.My charger came with 2 of the 4 power bars lit. It took about 3 hours for the charger to reach full charge attached to my desktop PC. I used it to charge my cell phone, which was at 78%, and the phone reached 100% after an hour; the charger still had 3 power bars lit.I can recommend this charger if you can carry it in your purse or briefcase, but it's too bulky to carry in your pocket. It would also be more useful if it came with a cable to recharge it via an electrical outlet; if you are on vacation, you may not have access to a powered USB connection.Given the $50+ price tag, it's probably cheaper to buy a spare battery for your phone (if you have one with a removable battery) and keep it charged; you can easily carry the spare battery in your shirt pocket.

I had high hopes for this when I saw how well my rather large smart phone stuck to the green adhesive portion of this holder.  There are 4 points on this device if one of the 4 is sub par you have a worthless piece of junk. That is exactly what we have here. 3 out of the 4 parts are good. 1 is very bad.  Here they are:  1. The suction mount..Very good, it seems solid it was difficult to pull it off the windshield. Good long lasting material. 2. The tightener for the adjustable arm..also very good. When tightened down its not going to move.. 3. The green sticky adhesive ..this is what I thought the weak point would be if there was one. Not the case. The adhesive is very strong , it holds a droid razr maxx with no problem..Took some effort to pull it off.  4. This is what makes it useless. the arm attaches to the phone holder using one of those ball in socket joints..like garmin gps mounts. It just kind of flops around in its socket like the ball is too small for the socket. there is no way to tighten this up at all. So there is no way to position your phone or gps . It will stay where you want it for a second but if you were using this in a vehicle for example it would just droop straight down from basic driving vibrations. One option would be to super glue it so its stationary but not really what I wanted from an adjustable holder.
summary: Very poor product. Can't believe there are a few good reviews

The Elago S4 Slim Fit 2 Case for iPhone 4/ 4S has a great feel if you don't need full protection.Pros:All the ports and buttons are accessible with this design. The side buttons, top, and bottom are all open to allow you to appreciate the stainless steel of the iPhone 4/ 4S. The plastic is sturdy, snaps into place easily, can be relatively easily removed, and doesn't creek when in place on the phone.Cons:The case isn't full protection. There is no lip on the screen side of the phone. Placing the phone down on a table will have it resting on the glass rather than a lip of the case. A fall flat down on a surface could result in a broken screen. The case is also semi glossy and at first does result in slippage out of the hand.Conclusion:As long as you don't rest your iPhone 4/ 4S face down on a regular basis, are not overtly clumsy, and you don't mind a semi glossy feel, this case will do right by you.Rating: 4 out of 5Recommended: Yes, but don't be a butterfingers.
summary: Great case unless it falls screen first

This screen protector is the best protector for your expensive Bionic!!!  It's well worth the $14.00!  You know the saying, you get what you pay for and I'm thrilled I paid to get this product!!! It comes with two screen protectors, but if you follow the instructions to the letter, you won't need the second one, but the insurance of the second one helps if you screw up applying the first!!

For the record I would buy this screen protector again only because of 3 reason: first is that it is almost perfect fit with <1mm around the edges. Secondly, the price is hard to ignore, and lastly each protector is provided with a lens wipe cloth.there are definitely things that should be considered before buying this item. I find it a bit unforgiving when it comes to creases.  A small but what seems to be harmless crease ruins it.  Bubbles have to be pushed out as it is applied or else you'll be wasting a protector. the plastic on the side that is applied to the screen is much harder to remove than the touchable side. In summary, this protector is sensitive so take it easy and be strategic when applying it but since it is an almost perfect cut lining it up is pretty simple compare to the more easier to apply ones out there.

reviewText: When I set out looking for a new windshield mount that would work well with all my phones, I wanted something that had a small profile, had a strong hold and could be used with phones of multiple thicknesses since my cases all varied. This product met all those guidelines.After my experience with iOttie's one-touch mount for bicycles, there was no way I would ever touch one of their products again. This was a complete 180 from that. The springs they have in this mount are great. They really secure the phone and because of the actual design of the holder itself, sliding the phone into the mount is actually really easy and it gives you the confidence that it won't be going anywhere.The biggest surprise for me was the suction cup on this. Aduro has used a slightly different kind here. It's sticy and seems a tad softer, and boy does it work. I could never attempt to mount this on my dashboard using a traditional suction cup, but because of the sticky material (no residue left behind), I have it sitting on the dash of my Edge and it hasn't gone anywhere. Works like a charm on windshields too.I'm very happy with this product and would definitely recommend it.

reviewText: In the past 4 years I have owned Android and (the now virtually redundant) Blackberry phones prior to buying an iPhone 5s in early December 2013. Overall I prefer the iPhone over the others and would recommend it, with a few minor reservations.The iPhone 5s is superior in these areas:1. The design is a work of art, finely sculpted and proportioned; a pleasure to hold and use2. The screen is fantastic; big enough to be really useful but small enough for the phone to be easily pocketable. The Blackberry screen was maybe too small for most applications except for email, and the Android too big and heavy for portable use. I particularly like the long narrow screen on the 5s3. A lot of thought has gone into the way a user can navigate around the screen through the different functions. I have owned an iPod Touch for a couple of years and have become a fan of Apple's clear and simple graphics: on the 5s, it's even better. The software never crashes, which it did with both my Android phones frequently4. For a user with larger than average hands/fingers, the on-screen keypad of the 5s is really well designed - especially true if you use the phone in landscape format which has the effect of widening the keypad. In comparison, the Android was frustrating and not very user-friendly and the Blackberry Storm completely hopeless - though the permanent keypad on the Curve was great5. The ring tone & speaker volume is louder and clearer on the iPhone than any of its rivals6. Phone reception is the best. I don't know how Apple manage this, but I have made and received calls in locations where other phones don't seem to work  - like travelling on the London underground and in deep underground car parks7. The camera is so good it's up to the standard of a dedicated Canon or Nikon compact, for the first time on a cellphone8. The memory (64GB) is vast, with a storage capacity so huge you're never likely to need more no matter what you download and store on it9. Siri, iMessage and Facetime are genuinely useful apps, not just gimmicks. They actually work well. The fingerprint scanner works too, though how much of a real security feature this is remains doubtfulGripes: very few -1. The battery life isn't great, but no worse than the Android Galaxy 4 and you can substantially improve it on the 5s by turning off power-hungry applications2. The unique nano-SIM means you can't swap the SIM over to another phone in an emergency, or for example if the phone is damaged and needs repair3. The price of the 5s is a bit steep, but here you really do get what you pay forOverall I have become a reluctant Apple convert. It's easy to see why they have become market leader with such an excellent product. Of course in another 2 or 3 years the tech will have moved on again, there may be a new market-leading manufacturer and the 5s will be an antique. But until then, the 5s for me is the King of cellphones.Finally, a lot of one-star reviews posted on amazon are from buyers griping about having been shipped locked phones by online sellers. This must be very frustrating but these are not really product reviews, they are complaints about the seller. The solution is easy: buy from an Apple store and they'll set up the new iPhone for you and transfer all the data from your old phone.
summary: iPhone 5s: state of the art and hard to fault

reviewText: I've been using Blackberries since a blackberry was thought to be something you would find in a muffin. The 8800 was the one I was using until I was given the Bold and, up until then, I thought of it as the best Blackberry ever. Then, the Bold came and it is probably safe to state that the Bold is now the last and the best classic Blackberry ever because the Storm, lacking a physical keyboard, probably deserves its own class.When the Bold and the 8800 are placed next to each other, what's striking is the similarities between the 2. The exact same size, similar keyboard, buttons placement, including the now familiar trackball. Even the ports are more or less the same, the same weight. Mine came with its own holster but I could have used the 8800's with the Bold.Then, it's the display. The Bold is what it says it is: bright, clear, vivid. You see it and you now know that it's an evolutionary step up on the ladder. In addition, you get the camera that shoots both pictures and video and the ability to add more memory means that you scan store more video and more music if you want to use your Blackberry as an iPod lite. The operation seems to be a bit faster, the battery life is more or less the same, the quality of the speaker phone is better but, overall, it's your familiar Blackberry, having learned a few new tricks and with a bright face.I am happy with the Bold because I am happy with Blackberries in general. I like the unlimited email and Internet browsing plan, the ability to use Wi-Fi when available and the security it provides. My Blackberry is tied into my company's email environment and it is now very much an extension of my office while I'm away. The Bold, with its high resolution screen and the same solid, functional build is a good tool, now with more 'fun' stuff (camera, video playing) added to it.
summary: The Best and Possibly the Last Classic Blackberry (with a real keyboard)

reviewText: I purchased this headset based on the top ranking Bluetooth headsets on Amazon. Plus I had already tried the newer model M165 and wasn't very pleased with it.First off, I like this headset so much that it's my second M50 purchase. I was an idiot and lost my first one on a business trip because I put it in a front shirt pocket instead of the travel pouch, which I also purchased from Amazon. At one point while taking out a business card or something else, the headset came out and I didn't notice.Everything has its good and bad. This headset is no exception. However the good is far better than the bad for me. I point out both so you will decide for yourself on whether it's enough for you to still purchase this headset. I won't comment on the visual elements of the headset. I.E. Looks, lights, ETC because I'm blind and such things don't bother me. I have also only paired this with an iPhone 4S, and an iPad Mini. However pairing it with other devices shouldn't be an issue.Pros:+ Easy to pair+ Small and light-weight+ Easy quick power on/off switch+ Good audio which supports A2DP+ Long battery life and quick charge time+ Uses standard Micro-USB charger - Not something proprietary+ Can wear all day with little or no ear fatigue in your earnow onto my issues. I have tried to keep them objective, but I of course realize that when making a product review, it's mostly based on one's own personal needs. I only mention this because the issues I describe below may not be issues for you, and so don't let my comments turn you away from this wonderful headset.Cons:+ Quality of calls. I can hear people just fine, and the volume is great. I usually don't have to set the maximum volume either. I'm usually using the mid-range volume and that's enough. However the people I've talked to have said that my voice is either too tinny, a bit distorted, or too digital. If the volume is set to maximum, callers report they can hear themselves echo. I suspect that when the volume is at max, there is a bit of feedback from the callers own voice which is picked up by the mic and that is what causes the caller to hear the echoing.+ The answer/hangup button. This button presents 2 problems for me. First, it's small enough, and located exactly in the center of where your ear is, resulting in an uncomfortable feeling when you press the button in to answer a call. Second, since this headset has A2DP support, meaning you can listen to music, podcasts, or GPS instructions while not on a call, I would have hoped that this button would, in addition to answer a call, also act as a pause/resume for the currently playing audio. I've had other BT headsets where the answer button doubles as a play/pause button as well and so find it rather inconvenient if I'm wearing the headset and listening to a podcast and want to pause it, I have to do it from the phone itself. To me, this defeats the hands-free experience. This may not be an issue for some, but if I didn't like everything else about this headset it would have been a dealbreaker for me.+ Built-in voice. There is a voice announcement when the headset is powered on or off, or when the battery is low. I find it a bit annoying that no matter what I have the headset volume set to, the voice is always at maximum. At least it sounds like it to me. Maybe Plantronics figures that if you are listening to something at the lower volumes you might miss the "volume low" announcement. I don't know.All in all, this is a good headset. If it fits well in your ear, if the lack of play/pause audio via the answer button isn't an issue for you, and if callers can hear you just fine, then you have made a good choice.
summary: Not the latest, but still the best

reviewText: After two days of owning the Galaxy S5, I quickly found that I liked my S3 more than this phone.For one thing, this phone feels bulky. I don't know if it was because I was used to the S3, but it just felt awkward and squarish to me. The HTC One M8 not only looks nicer but felt more comfortable to hold when I saw it in store. The HTC also sports front-facing speakers and has very clear sound quality, while the S5 seems muffled because its speakers are in the back (why they are in the back, I do not know).After powering the phone on and doing the initial setup, I opened up the camera. I took a couple test shots using the normal back camera, and then I tried out the front camera. To my surprise, the picture was distorted! It stretched the top and bottom parts of the frame and creates an odd, enlongated appearance. A quick google search revealed that other people are experiencing the same issue, and there seems to be no fix. For a premium, flagship smartphone, this is unacceptable. Perhaps for those who don't use the front camera this is probably not a big deal. But I couldn't stand looking at my stretched out face.Moving on to the lockscreen: Unlike the Galaxy S3, you cannot add lockscreen widgets such as Dashclock. I don't know why it was removed in this phone. The only thing you can change is the wallpaper and the unlock method. The finger print scanner leaves much to be desired. "Swipe faster." "Swipe slower." "Swipe the entire pad." are the messages that I received when trying to use it to unlock my phone. I eventually had to use my backup password.Overall, I was disappointed with the Galaxy S5. I didn't like how some features were taken out and replaced by gimmicky features such as the fingerprint scanner and the heart rate monitor. I'm in the process of exchanging it with either the HTC One M8 or the LG G3 (soon to arrive in the US).
summary: Not for me, but may be a good fit for others

I only bought these screen guards because they were offered in a bundle with an extended battery and charging set for my Samsung Epic 4G.  When I received the guards, there were no instructions first of all.  I know how to install them, but someone who has never done it may not figure it out so easily.The kit also includes a small microfiber cloth for cleaning as well as a small plastic squeegee to help remove air pockets when applying the guard to your phone.On previous phones, I have always used a specific brand of screen guard that you can find at better retail stores.  They are somewhat spendy but I have always been able to apply them with no problem.The problem with these screen guards is the protectors that cover the front and back that you have to remove to apply it.  Out of three of these, the tabs to pull off the protector plastic ripped and I was unable to remove the backing without wrecking the guard. It didn't matter how softly I pulled them, in what way, it was like the backing was glued to the screen guard.  Ruined all three screen guards just trying to get the backing off.You get what you pay for, and after ruining all three screen guards, I went to Best Buy, paid $20 and bought the brand I always use. Installed it in my car in the parking lot and was done in 60 seconds with no bubbles showing under the Shield.Thankfully I only spent a few dollars for these and you may get guards that the backing can be removed from, but I would look elsewhere.

The Tylt ENERGI2-T Energi battery pack is a stylish, if not slightly expensive, way to give your phone or tablet a little energy boost at the end of a busy work day.I personally find the Tylt ENERGI2-T pack to be a very thoughtful and well-designed product.  The case is a hard, glossy black plastic that looks like it can withstand being jostled around in a bag and even take a small drop or two without suffering major damage.  The two electrical outlet prongs fold in and out when you need to charge the pack, and there is plenty of good resistance on the prong hinge.  Once they are open, they’ll stay open, and once they are closed up, they’ll stay tucked away.  On the bottom and side is a continuous piece of durable rubber with a micro-USB plug at the end.  The rubber arm can be conveniently tucked away in the unit, or removed to give you around 2 inches of slack to charge your device.  There is a female, full-sized USB port on the bottom of the pack, and a single button on the face.  Even the button has a good amount of durable resistance.  Hitting the button reveals a circle with 4 individual green LED lights around the circumference, each LED light represents about 25% of charge loaded on the pack.  All-in-all, I love the sleek look and durable design of this thing.Depending on what you’re looking for, though, the performance of the Tylt ENERGI2-T Energi might not be enough for your needs.  The pack will fully charge in a little over an hour.  From there I’ve used it to charge my HTC 8X (the phone has an 1800 mAh battery) using the built-in rubber micro-USB arm.  During tests, I left my phone on (4G cellular signal and actively connected Wi-Fi) but did not receive any calls or texts.  I had one push Exchange account active and two other email accounts that updated hourly running in the background.  The Tylt increased my HTC 8X’s battery by 25% in the first 30 minutes.  It took 60-75 minutes to completely drain the Tylt and it consistently restored 50-60% of my phone battery’s power during five tests.  I also fully charged the Tylt and used it to power a completely dead Kindle Paperwhite (1st gen model).  Again, it took about 60-75 minutes for the Tylt to drain and it gave the Paperwhite a 50% full battery.  Depending on your phone’s battery, your mileage may vary.  If you’re using a Galaxy Note, or something with a huge battery, I would only expect to gain maybe 30% of charge after an hour.  For midsized phones, I think around 50% is realistic.  I’m guessing cheap flip phones are the only things that might go from dead to 90% power.I’m giving this unit a 4-star grade because I absolutely love the design and durability, but wish that there was just a little more charge capacity inside for this price.  If all you need is an extra 30-60% cell phone battery boost at 5 or 6pm to get you to the end of the day, this Tylt won’t disappoint and will deliver the juice in black, glossy style.  However, if you need something that will bring your electronic device up to full power away from an electrical outlet, you’ll need to find a charge pack with a much bigger battery.

As a cell phone, I would not recommend this device as you are going to be locked to Verizon. (Currently cannot be unlocked, rooted, etc.)  Get the unlocked GSM version where you can shop around for carriers and flash custom ROMs.  Prepaid plans from AT&T;, TruPhone, StraightTalk, etc. all beat the Verizon plans for the truly budget-minded consumer, especially when you consider the ability to swap SIMs with ease.If you must have a Verizon phone because of coverage, then why bother with this budget device when you can just sign a contract for about the same amount per month and have a top of the line phone with LTE, for example?However, if you just want something cheap to play with, then this is the ticket.  After hitting the auction sites for used phones that I could flash to Android 4.4, I decided this would be the better way to go for my projects.  This device is great for WiFi web cams, remote controls for copters, auto gauge clusters, etc.  The activation wizard is easy to bypass, just do a quick internet search.  Ships with 4.3, updates to 4.4 via a 247MB update.

After reading up on similar cases for the iphone 5 I narrowed it down to this case, the Incipio Stowaway and the Speck SmartFlex. I liked this case the best of all 3! It is a lot better than the Stowaway, though a tough choice over the Smartflex. The case itself fits the iphone 5 great! All the buttons match up and the camera is not hindered at all. The only thing I really didn't prefer was the glossy finish (on both Incipio cases). The matt finish on the Smartflex looked better, but the feel of the Stashback is just fine. The case does provide as much protection as I need in a case without feeling too bulky (I even found a leather holster that fit this case!). In fact the extra bulk makes your phone fit in your hand better. The Stashback does just what it claims, it securely conceals up to 4 cards plus a folded up bill with easy access to your cards. The design does not feel flimsy and there is no play in the cover (which was the big problem with the Stowaway)! The cards slide in and out quite easily as well. The reason I ended up picking this one over the Smartflex was because I don't like that your cards are viewable on the back of Smartflex, a little unprofessional if you have your phone sitting out. The balance of practicality and good looks in the Stashback is pretty hard to improve on (and the glossy finish is easy to overlook as a minor thing). So if you want to be free of your wallet, I recommend the Incipio Stashback. You won't find a more innovative iphone 5 case, and if you're like me, that's a big deal!
summary: Better than the Stowaway, or even the SmartFlex

reviewText: I ordered this not knowing that it had two in it, so I gave one to my best friend, and it was just perfect.

PROS(+) & CONS(-)+Comfortable in-ear for all-day use+Microphone sound when making a phone call is crystal clear (especially compared to a bluetooth headset)-Microphone sound when making a phone call is NOT a substantial improvement over the corded headset/microphone that my phone came with-Cord is too short*-Audio sound quality is not a "giant leap forward" like most Bose products-The cord design really stands out**+/-Volume won't allow you to turn it up to "Your ears will be ringing after listening at this high a volume" levels (compared to other earphones I've used with my phone)*I'm 6'2" (187cm) and like to carry my phone in my back pocket.  The cord is about 6" too short to do this without getting jerked out by head movements or putting pressure on my ear doing things like sitting down and standing up.  So, I put my phone in my front pocket, which isn't as comfortable and means I have to take my phone out and put it on a table when I'm sitting down rather than just leaving it in my back pocket.**While I know the black-and-white-candy-cane cord design is intentionally made by Bose to stand out and make their brand recognizable, it means that if you are going into a meeting and want to leave your Bose headset out in your car (I used to leave my headsets in the cupholder), the cord screams to anyone that might be looking for a reason to break into your car "I'm an expensive headset- Please steal me!"NARRATIVEI have a Bose stereo and a sound station, too, and have always regarded Bose as a leader in the audio-technology-to-save-space industry.  However, I have to say that this product just doesn't have the "WOW!" factor that the rest of their product line normally has.  This is, in part, because this is not a noise canceling headset (which I knew before I bought it).  However, the clarity of the headset is on par with what you can get for significantly less.  I think you're better off just getting a cheaper replacement headset/microphone with high ratings for comfortable ear buds... for about $10.00.In other words, if you hear that smack/thud sound while reading this, it is me beating my head against the wall because I made this purchase.  I'm seriously considering returning it.
summary: Priced too high... Save your money!

I know that paying less than $10 for a battery replacement for a smartphone like the iPhone 4S is risky; but since I've had great luck with Amazon in the past, and Amazon sellers are usually very good about refunds/returns, I took the plunge with this battery.To replace the battery in your 4S, you need a pentalobe screwdriver, which can be purchased separately. I'd also recommend getting a 'liberation kit' from iFixIt, so you can change the screws to standard phillips-head screws. Here's how to replace the battery:1. Remove the two screws on either side of the dock connector (bottom of iPhone).2. Push/slide back cover up towards top of phone (it will go up about 5mm).3. Pull back cover off the phone (this exposes the battery).4. Using a spudger tool, pry up the battery from the side of the iPhone, and carefully pry off the connector, being careful not to lose the little post that goes around one of the screws! (This is the most difficult part).Replacing the battery is annoying, but if the battery lasts twice as long as an old, worn-out battery, it's well worth it.Unfortunately, in my case, the replacement battery charged only if the phone was turned off completely, and wouldn't report back to the iPhone the correct charge level as I was using it throughout the day (it would stay at, say, 80% until I turned the phone off and on after a few hours--then it would say 50% until another on/off cycle). If I tried charging the phone while it was on, it would reboot itself every 3 to 5 minutes for no reason whatsoever. Very strange, and very annoying. I even reseated the power connector and that didn't fix it.In the end, I put the original battery back in, and even though it only lasts 3/4 of a day before needing a top off, it charges fine and doesn't exhibit any weird behavior.I contacted the seller, and they quickly allowed me to return the battery, so no sweat off my back. I'm guessing there are some duds, and some good ones--the cheaper batteries you buy, the greater chance you get a lemon. YMMV; good luck!
summary: Hit or miss; first one was defective, but refund was quick!

reviewText: My requirements for an iPhone 5 case are simple:+ Don't add too much bulk or weight to the phone+ Make all buttons and inputs easily accessible+ Raised edge on the front of the case to prevent the screen edge from scratches+ Complete encasement to protect the overall case+ Easily remove the phone from the caseI've been a fan of the Amazon Basics products and was pleased to try this new case. The first thing that came to mind when I opened the box was the strong resemblance the case had to my wife's olderOtterBox Commuter Series Case for iPhone 5/5s. The case comes in two pieces with a silicone wrapper for the phone itself that snaps into a hard plastic shell, which covers the back and sides.Overall the case met all of my requirements. However, I did take off 1/2 star from the case for a few reasons:1. Unlike the Otterbox Commuter Series Case, the bottom of the case does not flip open, so you may have problems using an older 30-pin to lightning adapter or some docking stations without removing the phone from the case.2. There was no screen protector included. TheAmazonBasics Protective TPU Caseis the low end of the price spectrum for Amazon iPhone 5 cases and it includes a screen protector, so I would have expected a screen protector with this slightly more expensive case as well.3. The hard plastic shell is somewhat slick, so your fingers may be prone to slipping off the back and sides.The only other comment I have is that the materials on the Otterbox Commuter Series Case feel more solid than the Amazon Basics case. I'm not concerned about damaging my phone, but there is a quality difference in the materials with the two cases. I didn't take off any stars for this though, since this case is about 1/3rd of the cost of the Otterbox case.********* I received this product for free as part of the Amazon.com Vine program. Nonetheless, I review the product in the same manner as I would if I had purchased it myself. *********
summary: Otterbox Commuter Alternative on a Budget (4.5 out of 5)

In a way, this is an odd little product - a mobile device recharger that also functions as an LED lantern.  In a way, it is an odd little combo. I mean, did the universe cry out, demanding a recharger / LED lamp? Well, maybe not. But that doesn't mean it isn't a bit better off for its existing. Comparable chargers that are just as good are 1) much heavier and 2) don't have the LED feature. I also haven't seen a recharger that is this small. All in all on a number of fronts, this is the best charger that I have come across. It also is a bit cheaper than the best rechargers.Even though I feel a tad odd about the schizophrenic nature of the gadget, there is no doubt that both of the things it does, it does exceptionally well. And let me add one thing about having a gadget do two things: we are beginning to be overwhelmed by gadgets. I have two gadget bags that I carry in two pouches in my backpack. They are both stuffed to overflowing. So combining two into one helps cut back on the number odds and ends. And gives you a really nice charger.
summary: Am extremely handy little gadget - two tools in one

They fit my ears very well, which isn't always the case for many earbuds I've tried. They are obviously a little bit bigger and heavier bud than your average wired ones, but they don't feel like it. Quite comfortable for me so far and seem to do a better job of blocking outside noise than most other earbuds I've had as well. As for sound quality, they are very crisp and sound quite good. Sure, the bass isn't what you would expect from an over-ear headphone or even some in-ear models, but based on some of the reviews, I expected worse and was surprised at how good they actually are. They pair easily and range is good; pretty much on par with any of your standard bluetooth stuff. Bottom line is, especially at this price point, if you're an audiophile and sound quality is your number one concern, bluetooth is just not going to satisfy you. But if you are willing to sacrifice a slight bit of bass for the convenience of a wireless connection, these are an awesome choice. I haven't taken any calls on them yet and I haven't worn out the battery from a full charge, so I can't speak to any of that, but so far I'm impressed.

I tried out 3 cases for the iPhone 5: the Speck PixelSkin HD, the OtterBox Commuter and the Otterbox Defender. I thought each of them was well designed and useful, but they serve different purposes.The Speck PixelSkin was my wife's favorite. It's very slim and unobtrusive, highlighting the sleek design of the new iPhone. However, I didn't think it offered very much protection. I was afraid that it wouldn't protect against the inevitable drops. If you're just looking for a minor amount of protection and a little extra grip, this is a great case.The Otterbox Defender is at the opposite end of the spectrum. You could probably throw your phone out the window if it's in one of these and it would be okay. But that protection comes with a cost -- it added way too much bulk for me. This case is big and thick, and probably more than most people need.I ended up going with the one in the middle: the OtterBox Commuter. It offers what I hope will be a sufficient amount of protection, without adding so much size and weight to the phone that it becomes unwieldy.It's not a perfect case. The plug covers are somewhat annoying (as they always are on cases like this), and the mute and sleep buttons take a little extra effort to engage. But I haven't found those drawbacks to be terribly significant.
summary: A well designed case offering protection without too much bulk

Overall this is a great phone. The resolution is second to none and the battery life is the best i've ever had on a smart phone. Additionally the touch interface is very responsive, more so than the previous Note 2. Moreover, it is also quicker than the Note 2 when bringing up apps and running apps. But, there are a few things that the Note 3 lacks in that the Note 2 had. One is that although the camera for the Note 3 is 13 megapixels and the Note 2, 8 mega pixels, the Note 2 seems to take better quality pictures. Further, the Note 2 had better low light visibility in the pictures as well. And, the camera view point seems to be more zoomed in at the furthest level from zoom on the Note 3 making me have to take a few steps extra backward to take a picture that I wouldn't have to do with the Note 2. Secondly, the video quality in low light lacks adjustment that the Note 2 had. In the Note 2, one could take a video without the flash and still decipher whats in the video pretty well. But, in the Note 3 even in a slightly dim room you cannot see what is going on in the video which makes talking videos from the phone quite frustrating. I don't know why Samsung took a step back on the camera on the Note 3 by taking away lowlight settings and replacing it with a auto adjust feature on the camera that is supposed to adjust to the different light conditions on its own. Which, it does not do very well might I add. But with that being said, the camera is not horrible, its rather on the better side of smart phone cameras. Another thing is the speaker phone isn't as loud as the Note 2's. That was something that I really enjoyed on the Note 2. Overall though, the phone is probably the best phone I've ever had and I've had the iPhone 4, 4s, and 5 along with the Note 2. The visual aspect of the display is awesome and the default storage is 32 gigs with additional 64 gigs addable storage potential. And, I appreciate the fact that one can take the back off and replace a battery or get extra batteries to charge on the side and replace when needed. In the end I'll rate the phone a 9/10 the only complaint being the camera functioning. Oh, and I have Sprint for my carrier for almost 10 years and I live in the LA area and have lived in many parts of NorCal and SoCal and in New York City and have never had a problem with reception.  I also drove across the country with a few friends who have AT&T and Verizon and I consistently had more service coverage than they did, as we had to constantly use my phone for GPS service in rural areas because their phones would get no reception at all. And they had iPhones so go figure.

I received my Q10 on 6/21 and after getting through all the activation issues, I'm still having some very basic, elementary lagging issues with my texting/BB Hub. We all know that texting is important and that it should be something that is very quick, especially nowadays, should be immediate. The issue I have is NOT NOT NOT with my network connection as it does this throughout the state and is solely within the OS. When I send a text, it takes about 30 seconds to actually show up in the conversation. I'm not referring to the time it takes to actually send, which would be fine, but physically show up in the conversation. On top of that, I can't send a text and then continue to my next text in that conversation until after the last text shows up. And all on top of that, I can't quickly move back and forth between conversations as it will keep going back to the last message I sent until the last message appears. I have spoken with AT&T; Tech Support and they couldn't do anything, now I'm going to have to do a full system restore and see if that kicks out any bugs in the OS. If that doesn't work, I'm taking it back to AT&T; and trying another Q10. If that still has the problems, I'm going to get a Samsung Galaxy S4.Please be aware that this is not just a personal issue, but blogs such as Blackberry and Crackberry, people all over are having this same issue and no OS update or resolution have been able to fix this problem. I will update if necessary, but if I don't, I've finally gone with a full touchscreen as I love the physical QWERTY keyboard. Its a disappointing problem as Blackberry was so confident with its marketing of the new 10s and multitasking through the new Hub software. Fingers are crossed for now that my issue somehow becomes resolved. Please heed this warning however because it may happen to you.***Update 6/25: I took the Q10 into AT&T; and they were as dumbfounded as I was. While there, I changed my mind about swapping for a new device and went with the Samsung Galaxy S4. I was hesitant to not only get a new device as I was worried it would occur in the future, but also with getting a full touchscreen keyboard as I have been Blackberry loyal for 10 years. I loved being able to feel the keys as I typed and not having to look down at the screen, much like typing on a computer keyboard, so it was an end of an era for me. Fortunately, the S4 was so much better in so many ways (ie, the keyboard is easy to get comfortable with and prediction is spot on but doesn't screw up your messages, and the S4 is so much more user-friendly and customizable than the bare bones Q10 - it seems like you can't customize anything with the Q10 like you used to be able to with the older BBs, and there are so many more useful apps available with the S4 - Gmail and Google Maps for two examples). So, with that said, in my review, I would definitely recommend doing away with a Blackberry and going with a more modern phone and be happier in the end after making the switch. This whole process was a huge let down and disappointment for me as I have been a big supporter of BB over the years, but this time they just fell flat on their face and let a lot of us loyal customers down. Still no patch or fix for the lagging of texts on the forums, so be aware.

I actually have the pebble blue gsIII so this cover gives it a more patriotic feel. Now this battery & cover does basically double the thickness of the phone - which is a good thing for me because it holds better in my hand now and doesn't feel so flimsy.Now there weren't any directions that told me this but I've read in various places that it is best to basically "exercise" the battery. Meaning, charge it up, run it down, charge it up, etc... instead of keeping it plugged into the charger all the time - which is what i would normally do while at work. The good thing is, I no longer HAVE to. And it seems like my battery life has actually improved since I started using the extended battery. I fully recommend this product.

My review is focusing specifically on Apple devices, i.e., iphone, ipad, ipod, and ipad mini and even more specifically 4th generation as my review was completed in 2013 and I have the latest and greatest from apple. Also note, I am using the term "adapter" and "charger" interchangeably in my review.I recently reviewed Belkin's new single-port charge:http://www.amazon.com/review/R1FSR5PG57WP5Y/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permBelkin Home Travel Wall ChargerI also wanted to provide information on the Ventev since it's just as powerful, has 2 ports, and is less expensive than the Belkin charger. I bought my Ventev at top dollar price at the At&T; store, then later found it on Amazon for a GREAT PRICE ($16) and free shipping.I have been confused over the years about the various adapters that come with my iphone and ipad and the charging rates. I wondered why it took so long to charge my ipad using my iphone adapter. Also, why is the adapter that comes with the ipad so big for the ipad vs the iphone? I did some in depth research to educate myself that I would also like to share with you.First thing you need to know is that it's not the cable (on fourth generation i-devices using the smaller, fire-wire connections) that makes the difference in charging speed, it is the adapter (the thing you plug into the wall with the USB port). The Ventev charger will make a difference on the iphone and ipad mini as I describe the reason why below.You need to understand wattage. Wattage (also know as power or amount of juice flowing to your device) equal voltage times amperage, so:volts x amps = watts.Not all adapters are the same or even labeled visibly, so really take a look at the technical specification before making purchases. All the apple products use 5-volt along with the Ventev charger which is also 5-volt.  You can also quickly look at the amperage if watts isn't listed, to tell the difference in speed.So, if you know at least 2 of the 3 (volts, amps, or watts), you can figure out the third. The iphone, ipod, and ipad mini all have the same adapter/charger and it list the volts and amps, but not the watts, but you can easily figure it out with the equation:5 volts x 1 amps = 5 watts (iphone, ipod, ipadmini)The ipad is printed loud and clear with the wattage: 12W. Apple does this since there's been so much confusion in the past since a similar looking charger was available in 5-watt and 10-watt versions.5 volts x 2.4 amps = 12 wattsThe Ventev  adapter I am reviewing is  2.1 amps or 10 watts so it is slightly slower than the ipad adapter and twice the speed of the adapter included with the  iphone, ipod, and ipadmini.5 volts x 2.1 amps = 10 wattsSo, what does this mean for the various apple i-devices as far as charge speed and how is this Ventev charger going to perform? Well, it all depend on how much the individual devices draw or pull from the power/wattage.For example, if the unit draws 10 watts and you use a 10 watt adapter/charger it will charge at it's maximum speed. If the adapter is slower, like 5 watts, it's going to take twice as long to charge. If the adapter is faster, like 12 watts, it's only going to charge at the unit's maximum speed which is 10 watt*.Here's the line-up of individual apple devices and their wattage.iphone and ipod:  7.1 watt (comes with a 5 watt adapter)ipadmini:  16.3 watt (comes with a 5 watt adapter)ipad 2:  25 watt (comes with a 10 watt adapter)ipad 3:  42 watt, the most power-hungry (comes with a 12-watt adapter)So, compare that with the wattage of your adapter/charger with devices wattage:The iphone and ipad will charge slightly faster with the Ventev 10-watt adapter (5 watts vs. 7.1 watts, since it will draw a maximum of 7.1 watts)The ipadmini will charge significantly faster with the Ventev 10-watt adapter (5 watts vs. 16.3 watts with the Ventev)The ipad 2 is identical to the Ventev 10-wattThe ipad 3 will charge slightly slower with the Ventev 10-watt adapter!Regarding your desktop or laptop computer USB port. At only 2.5-watt, it will take forever to charge your apple devices! Using your computer is the SLOWEST by far of charging any of your apple devices.Tip: always charge your ipad, iphone, etc. with the screen powered off since it draws power from the device. In the case of the computer USB port it really won't charge if the device is on since all of the 2.5-watt power (of the computer's usb port) will be going to the screen display.Also, as far as charge "time". In the case of the ipad, if you use the ipad charger that come with the device (12-watt) it will take about 3-1/2 hours to charge (divide the devices wattage by the wattage of the adapter/charger, i.e, 42-watt/12=3.5). If you use the Ventev charger (10-watt) it will take about 4.2 hours to charge (i.e., 42-watt/10=4.2)*Note: there seems to be some disagreement on the Internet about using an adapter with higher wattage than the devices wattage. In one place I read that it's okay to use an adapter of higher wattage than the device, but in another it could decrease the life of the battery (like using the 10-watt Ventev charger with the 7.1 watt iphone). I am not knowledgable enough to know the correct answer, so if there's any electrical engineers out there, please pipe in.That's my 101 on wattage and the Ventev adapter is a great addition to the all of the apple "i" products. I will use it for travel since it is a catch-all for both my iphone and ipad with not alot of wait time on the recharge, plus I can charge them both at the 10-watt speed, excellent!
summary: Speedy Charging, 10-watt on each port. Best deal going

The OtterBox brand has been around for long enough to be well-established. If you're just now getting with the program, like me, OtterBox is a tough case for your iPhone. Getting one is simply an experience in itself. I've had experience with other cases and this doesn't come close to comparison.With the OtterBox, there's actually two cases. One is hard and comes with clear window for the touchscreen, which means there's no need for a screen protector. The second case is an outer soft cushion that's textured for better grip. It also protects the ports with flaps that sort of snap into place. Sounds weird since this is a soft texture, but that's what it feels like.Inside the box--actually printed on the inside, are assembling instructions that are easy to follow, but it's a no-brainer putting this together. Common sense will pretty much guide you through.After putting on the soft case, I noticed the hole of the earphone didn't line up. I thought this was a flaw until I visited their website. Here's what was posted:  "Actually, the port cover is correct. The hole in the port cover is intended to leave open access for the noise-cancelling mic. To use headphones you need to open this port cover. This cover prevents dust and dirt from entering the device when the headphone jack is not in use."If you've never used an OtterBox, YouTube has so many bizarre demonstrations of iPhone users dropping their devices off houses, apartment complexes and buildings. One person even drop-kicked their iPhone a couple of times and the OtterBox held up and also defended the phone. I have no intention of doing anything that extreme. I just wanted a heavy-duty cover with a good clip--which is included--so that I can listen to music during exercising. Since I live in a humid climate where it rains a lot, I also needed something to protect the iPhone. The OtterBox case is that and more.
summary: The OtterBox is like no other...

At first glance, this looks like an extended battery that would clip to the back of a phone. But instead, it’s a conventional powerbank that allows you to recharge pretty much any device.The downside to this slim and sleek design is capacity – only 3100mAh. That’s fine for a single recharge of a typical phone, or a partial charge for a larger device such as a tablet.The overall build quality is very good. It feels very solid and well-made. There’s a single USB output port rated at 2.1A. The input is a micro USB port. It measures about 2.5 inches wide and 4.5 inches long, and is about a quarter of an inch thick. The edges are rounded to make it look even slimmer and sleeker. However, this elegant design is somewhat marred by all the logos and printing on the back. Really ruins the overall look. I won’t detract from the rating due to that, but it is a disappointment.It includes the typical “gas gauge” consisting of LED light that show the amount of charge left in the powerbank. It also includes a USB cable that is color-matched to the device (I have the red version). The cable is flat to make it easy to manage, and keeps with the thin and slim design cues throughout.Great powerbank – well worth a look if you want the slimmest one out there.[Sample provided for review]
summary: Novel (and practical) shape for a powerbank

reviewText: Like any new phone with a new OS, there's a learning curve. I've been on Android for four years, and I love it, and ICS is new to me with this phone. It's made some interesting, unexpected improvements over Gingerbread. But it's still Android, and performs as such (ie, well).This review is basically about the battery. Which is insane.My last phone was a Droid X running Gingerbread. Most days I didn't need to charge my phone until I went to bed at night, but I definitely needed to charge at night. Some days I'd come home from work and my battery would be just about dead (and die before I charged it at bedtime). Some days, if I was really hammering at it, I would need to charge during the day. This had become normal for me, and was only rarely a problem.The Maxx? I mean, I use it a lot, but I can't seem to kill the battery. One night, shortly after I got it, it was down to 30 or 40 percent when I was going to bed, so I played a graphics heavy game for a while, trying to kill it. After an hour of play, I backed out of the game to check my power level-- I had barely done any damage at all. Perhaps I should have tried downloading something at the same time.Yesterday I didn't use it much-- and I had it plugged in while I was using the navigation-- and 12 hours after leaving the house I was still at 100%. Any other phone I've had would have dropped some power in the interim, from processes and whatnot, but not this.Why all phones can't do this yet is beyond me. But this is magical, and now I look at other people's Android powered phones that are down to 20% battery at the end of the day and mock them with my 60%.
summary: No but seriously, the battery is ridiculous.

I rock them from sun up to sun down because the BATTERY LIFE & STANDBY TIME is SUPER! The sound quality is super for a non in ear, non noise cancellation option! I listen to a tone of music and have tested a tone of headphone options. WHY DO THESE SOUND BETTER THAN ALL THE IN EAR OPTIONS I'VE TRIED!? What takes the cake is that they have great sound, but they don't cancel out the noise around you so if you like to ride your bike in the city like me, you can mind your surroundings. The Bluetooth radius is true to specifications as long as you don't have a major object blocking the connection like multiple walls. The microphone is excellent at picking up your voice for hands-free calling and voice to text which also works better than most! As for what I bought them for, LOL they work flawlessly at the gym. There is a slight discomfort after about 45 minutes, but I have found that after about a month you get used to it or in my case it seems like it has adjusted to my head so I don't feel it. *Kanye Shrug* I wear them all day because when not in use I just lay them around my neck. reviewText: I'm really disappointed that this white case discolored after only 2 weeks of use.I loved the look, the kick-stand worked great, and while it is obviously a cheapie, it fit well and did everything I wanted it to do. Until it turned Yellow.I've only had the case on my phone for 2 weeks, and I'm a low to moderate user of my phone (it's not in my hand or on my ear constantly like many folks...). So I was very shocked, surprised and disappointed to notice that the sides of the phone case, where it is held by the hand, is discoloring yellow.Yellow, like curry yellow - not dirty-look yellowing from being handled by unclean hands, but curry yellow. Think of yellow curry at an Indian restaurant and you'll have the right color.It's very odd - why on earth would it go bright yellow where handled? Is it something I eat interacting with the cheapie rubbery plastic used? Maybe the oils on my skin gets on the case and it is interacting with a dye in my purse (where it spends a lot of time)? No one else has commented about the weird yellow color, so I can only assume it's me. However, I've had white cases before with other phones and none have turned yellow before.Likely I'll order the same case in a darker color (maybe red) and see if that works out better.
summary: Very disappointed - white discolored after only 2 weeks

reviewText: For a low-priced, wireless, rechargeable speaker, this mini Motorola speaker synchs up perfectly with just about any bluetooth-transmitting item.  The system is well thought out and is fully outfitted--with AC adapter, Motorola case, and mine even came with a Motorola cinch sack. Also, since Bluetooth can be temperamental, or erratic (especially with other Bluetooth-connected electronics devices in the near vicinity), a convenient audio cable is provided for a surefire connection between player and the Motorola speaker.The speaker is loud enough and should amplify the human voice sufficiently for efficient, unforced conversation.  But anyone who claims this speaker excells at musical reproduction simply has no use for bass frequencies, which for the most part are inaudible on the EQ5.  The Motorola EQ7, on the other hand, covers the entire frequency range, its four JBL speakers constructing a soundstage and providing a sense of life-like presence and vivid realism simply unequaled by any other bluetooth speaker.  Since the beginning of the year the EQ5 qppears to have more than doubled in price, making several other bluetooth speakers a better value--at least for anyone seeking full-frequencied music reproduction.  Logitech, Creative, and Spracht all make bluettoth speakers capable of rich, full-bodied, hi-fidelity music reproduction, though the Motorola EQ7 emerged a clear-cut winner in my side by side comparisons.  It's the first time I've heard a walkman-sized speaker practically equal the thunder of a "home theater" system.  If you think you could handle not a facsimile but Oscar Peterson's piano, Ray Brown's bass, and Bobby Durham's drum kit--or Joey DeFrancesco's Hammond B3--transplanted into your listening space, the EQ7 is the real "sleeper" among all portable personal speakers.
Bought for a friend.She said liked & has no complaints.It arrived earlier than expected too, so that's a plus.

It is a very thin, wireless fully integrated battery case that allows you to charge your iPhone 5S/5 simply by resting your iPhone on the charging pad and the charge starts immediately. And as the manual states, `With a 2000mAh built-in battery, the Aero is powerful enough to provide an additional 100% charge to your iPhone 5 and 85% to your iPhone 5S, which means more talking, texting, and browsing. In fact, the Aero can add up to 10 hours of additional talk time, or 270 hours of stand-by time.' The pad provides easy access to all functions, camera, and headphone jack.But given all the pluses of its use, the feature that is so compelling is the actual design. This is a very handsome device that is sophisticated and so beautifully engineered that it becomes an art piece! Easy to care for, easy to carry around (you should have several in various locations for ease of mind that you may need a charge...) and something that speaks of quality every inch of the way. reviewText: Did what I needed it to do.  Great product and even better price for it.  Helped me keep scratches away from the screen especially when i didn't have a case on the phone for a pretty long time.

I lost my Voyager Pro, which was the only Bluetooth headset I have ever tried that works well. I have had performance problems with the Jabra Wave, Samsung, and some others; the Jawbone and an older Blue Ant model didn't fit me well.Good news: The Voyager Legend is even better than the Pro! The most important thing to know is that, as with the Pro, it works well, with good audio quality under all conditions. Callers never complain. That said:My negatives are all positives (!):- The biggest disadvantage is that it is fairly large, with the microphone on a longer boom than most headsets -- but that isalso anadvantage, as the long boom brings the mike closer to the mouth and seems to greatly improve audio quality.The on-ear balance is great, so the size does not bother me in the least.- A common complaint is the charging cable which is a non-standard magnetic connection rather than microUSB, as the Pro was. On one hand, it means that when I travel, I have to carry the cable. But the cable is short, so not a big deal -- and for most trips, the unit has enough charge capacity (7 hour talk, 11 day standby) that I would not even carry the cable.And now that I have used it, I greatly enjoy the convenience of snapping the headset into the magnetic connector. Easy.- Another common complaint is the short cable, but I like that (a lot). I see Plantronics offers a longer cable for $10 which is a microUSB cable with an adapter on the end that makes it work with the magnetic connector. See:Plantronics Voyager Legend microUSB AdapterPositives:- As I said, first and foremost is the excellent call quality both on my end and for the people I am calling. Bluetooth connectivity is also excellent and consistent. I think it's even better than the Pro.- Comfortable for me. I much prefer the over-the-ear design to headsets that rely on the in-ear fit.- I love the toggle-style on-off switch.- Connects effortlessly to phone and computer.- Sound seems louder and clearer- Controls have been relocated. I find them very easy to find and use. I also like the functionality -- pretty easy to remember what the various buttons can do.- LOVE the sensors. Put the headset on and it answers the call if it's ringing; or transfers the call to the headset if a call is underway.

This is a really nice heavy duty looking charger. All the ports are universal so you don't have to worry about sticking anything into the wrong port.  I've used them all at once - charging 2 phones, 2 headsets, and 1 mouse.  It worked like a charm.  What I really liked most about it was that it isn't one of those charges that hang right on the wall.  It's got about a 5 foot length cord that you can plug into the wall and be able to move the charger where you please. I honestly can't think of anything negative.  It's a really good charger and I would carry this around when I travel.  I liked the fact that the LED light isn't too bright.  I remember I had this Bolse 4 port charger that had such a bright LED light that it was more like a night light then a charger LOL but this one is a much improved charger.  Great great improvement.  I received this charger for a honest review.
summary: This is a great heavy duty charger.

** Review when ordered in Mid November **At first glance you'd think this was a great item at a great price.  1) leather 2) shuts of the kindle when opening or closing  3) and at a great price... AND IN STOCK!  Ya right!  This item is a pipe dream and it NOT in stock. When I pressed the the company for a delivery time, they simply cancelled my order.  Buyer beware!** Review after ordering again and receiving it on 12/4 **After ordering it again, I got the cover and took a look at it.  One thing to remember about this cover there are only two positions you can watch videos in: The nearly flat position or upright.  For those that have had tri-fold covers in the past, this will be a slight disadvantage.The material is fairly good for synthetic leather, and its much lighter than leather.  I still have yet to receive my Kindle Fire 8.9", so I can tell you how it fits.  But I can tell you there are cut-outs for the speakers and all the ports.  It does have a magnetic closure, which is an advantage over the elastic ones.As far as initial value, besides the slight bump with the original order, I would say this is going to be a pretty good value.  No its not leather, but it looks like it, and feels fairly close to it.  It is really light weight.  It has a pen with a stylus for the Fire on one end and an ink pen on the other.I'll update when I get the Fire 8.9 in a week.** After having it with the Fire for about a week 12/12 **I decided to pitch this case and have lowered my rating down to 2 stars.  The man-made leather is VERY slick, it easily can slip out of your hand - which sort of defeats the purpose - therefore there is no point to this case.  If they made it in all leather, it would be a winner.  Further the man-made material does not work well in the standing low position; it might as well be laying flat.  Further the man-made microfiber material on the inside is very light in color, and shows dirt very easily.

These are reliable - I've bought about 15 of them and none have failed over the past 3 years. I thought about taking off a star because their labeling of the two inputs isn't quite right. The label "A" stands for "Apple" and the label "NA" is for "Not Apple". I've found some devices like the Motorola Droid X need to be plugged in the "A" input to charge right. So when you first get the charger test which input works with your device so you don't head off to somewhere uncharged. I've never found a device that won't charge from one of the two inputs but a few need to be in the right one.
