reviewText: Arrived early. Looks great, fits on my phone perfectly.  Love the different green color, makes it stand out and easy to find in my purse!

I decided to switch from AT&T; to Verizon after1) Becoming disillusioned with the quality (or lack there-of) of AT&T;'s network.2) Becoming fed up with the "walled garden" of the iPhone/iOS, and the poor performance of the iPhone 3GS in particular.3) Deciding to consolidate cell phone accounts with my partner, who has a Verizon phone.I did my research, and I decided that the Droid Razr met my criteria for speed, flexibility, expand-ability, not being an iPhone, and then the 4G totally sold me on the phone.  While I would have like to have had Ice Cream Sandwich out of the box like the Nexus has, I know a software update will come in time.  Anyways, I finally bit the bullet when I saw the phone on sale here on Amazon Wireless, so I grabbed it, and have used the savings to buy a dock on regular Amazon, plus an Otterbox case (which actually fits really well to the phone).The ordering process was pretty pain-free, though I had to "submit" my application a few times before it finally took.  I was surprised that I had two-day shipping; originally the phone was supposed to arrive via Lasership on the 16th, but to my surprise it arrived a day early on my doorstep!  Considering what I've heard about Lasership, I'll consider myself lucky.  The Droid box, SIM card, and bonus car charger (thanks Amazon!!) were all snuggly and securely packed, and the box was delivered in fabulous condition.Activating the phone was... Problematic.  Amazon Wireless tried at first to resubmit/activate my phone with Verizon, but apparently Verizon did not want to play well with Amazon.  The rep I talked to at Amazon, Emily, was extremely nice with me, and went out of her way to make sure I would still get the Amazon Wireless discount on my phone even if I had to go into a Verizon store to activate my phone.  Later in the evening I called Verizon Customer Service to get the phone activated, but they were no help and pawned me off onto the Telesales department, who also could not help me activate my phone and blamed the whole deal on Amazon Wireless.  So I called Amazon Wireless (at 10:30 at night!  These guys are awesome!), and Malachai listened to my situation and whooped some butt into gear at Verizon to get my phone activated for me.  You guys at Amazon Wireless deserve serious recognition for the awesomeness you all pull off every day!Once my phone was activated and it booted up, it was WOW!  The screen looks fantastic, Android OS is super-easy to navigate once you have the hang of it, and everything is organized in the logical and intuitive manner which iOS is not organized in.Now I've only been using the phone for a day, but here are my initial thoughts about the phone:Pros:-The screen is amazing.  It beats the crap out of the iPhone 3GS and iPad 1 screens in terms of brightness, depth, and ease on the eyes.  I would go as far as to say that it is almost a tablet-quality screen, but it fits in my pocket!-This phone is super fast!  Really this kind of speed/responsiveness is what I would expect in a bulky laptop, not a smartphone.-I absolutely love the "smart actions", and can't wait to play with them more!-This phone is built to take abuse, without a case on it.  The kevlar backing and gorilla glass are actually big selling points for me since I tend to be rough on small electronics.  Having a case and screen protector on it (the Otterbox in the Verizon Stores gives you both out of the box!) will just make it last longer in mint condition.-You have apps like Netflix, Kindle, and DocsToGo on the phone right out of the box.  I've maybe only downloaded four additional apps so far; you'd have to download all of those separately on an iPhone.-Once you experience data service (especially 4G) on Verizon, you will wonder why you did not get this phone (or a 4G phone in general) sooner.  It is like cable modem fast!-It is soooo much easier to move apps between screens on Android than iOS.-Price.  I got this phone during an Amazon Wireless sale for $40 with plan when it is normally $100.-Amazon Wireless customer service.  You guys rock!Cons:-Verizon customer service.  It seriously sucks.-This thing eats through battery like a hot knife through butter.  An hour of web-surfing on wifi will obliterate the battery; even leaving it uncharged over night will wear it down faster than my iPhone would wear down.-Maybe this is just the con of micro-USB charging, but this phone charges extremely slowly, much slower than the iPhone.-I know it will support the music files I have in iTunes, I'm just not sure how to get all of my music over just yet...-The web browser is different from Safari in several ways.  At least right now it appears that I cannot easily group bookmarks into certain categories or move easily between windows/tabs in Android as I can in iOS Safari.Overall my first impression is that this is a great Android phone for a disillusioned iPhone user to switch to.  Its great, really it is.  Just beware Verizon customer service.
Love this case. It is not cumbersome it is very light and it does not prevent you from swiping from the edge of the screen. Easy to clean also.

I ordered the 5-port Wall Charger a few days before a two-week trip to Japan, and wasn't sure I'd receive it in time to take it with me. But Anker got it to me in plenty of time, and I started using it at home and it was fine -- as advertised, it charges devices more quickly than just plugging them into an outlet. My Android phone and ,my wife's iPad were the main devices, along with a couple of Anker external batteries that I always use. The charger was just as great in Japan, where the current is a little lower and it usually takes noticeably longer to charge devices. Phones, iPad, iPods and batteries charged up fine. AT one hotel I had all five ports charging various devices. It was a lifesaver! Great product, and kudos to Anker for the stellar customer service!

This IMP99D is the best little charger that I have seen.  Right out of the box I was impressed with the look and feel.  It has a soft smooth almost velvet-like feel making it very comfortable to hang onto, it wont slip out of your hand when plugging devices into it.  It was fully charged in about 4 hours and it holds an amazing amount of charge.  It charged the dead battery on my HTC Evo LTE and my Kindle Fire BOTH at the same time in under 2-1/2 hours and it had only used about half of its charge.The IMP99D comes with several different adapters making it work for just about any device you have that needs charging.  It is simple to operate with just 1 on/off button (that you press and hold for 5 seconds to turn it on or off) and 3 charging ports; one port for charging the IMP99D and 2 output USB ports for charging your devices.  There are 4 neon blue LED lights that indicate how much charge there is remaining.  I really like the fact that the 2 USP ports and the charging port are all on the same side so that I can leave it in the protective cover while charging the IMP99D or charging my devices.After plugging a device into the IMP99D you have to press and hold the on/off switch for 5 seconds to initiate the charge.It is a little cumbersome having to carry the wall output plug with you instead of a standard USB plug but I can understand it with the juice that this little charger takes to charge up and the impressive charge capacity that it holds.The only negative experience that I have had with this super little charger is the first time I put it into the protective pouch and pulled the strings to close it, one of the little balls on the end of the string pulled off and I had to rethread the string and tie a bigger knot on the end.

I've been using this Lumia handset for about a month now and have been really, really pleased in almost every way. A review of a Lumia phone is as much a rundown of the OS as it is an assessment of the hardware, so I'll start there.Windows Phone 7.5 (Mango) is pretty awesome. Live Tiles are the perfect compromise between Android's resource-intensive widgets and iOS's bland, sterile home screen. The OS has yet to crash on me, I'd wager to say it's the most stable and speedy mobile OS I've used so far. You have a little less control over background tasks than Android, but whatever WP7 is doing behind the scenes is working because the OS never hesitates, never stutters. I would take serious issue with Bing navigation, put simply, it's garbage. It actually asks you to tap on the screen to hear directions out loud! Which would be illegal while I drive in my locality! Thankfully, Nokia steps in there with Nokia Drive (which now stores maps locally), and that app is a godsend (though, has a few rough edges). In any case, the OS has been a dream and I think Microsoft has a winner on their hands. I've loved Metro since my Zune HD, and no exception here.As for the phone hardware, it's really well constructed. In terms of build quality, it takes me back to the days of the Nokia candy bar phones in that Nokia phones still seem indestructible. I've dropped the phone flat on its face a few times now with no issues. I really like the feel of the back of the phone as well, it's a soft-tough plastic (that feels a lot like Incipio's Feather cases), which makes it light but substantial all at once. But the hardware build also brings me to my one serious issue with the 710: The buttons. They really are THAT bad. First off, all three buttons are conjoined, meaning you never "feel" a solid click, as you're really once pressing 1/3 of a big button down. The button is also difficult to depress and is cramped down towards the bottom of the phone. The button is also so close to the bottom of the screen that you'll constantly get accidental screen-input. I'm really surprised that a company with Nokia's design lineage would make such a rookie mistake, but it's definitely an issue and a good reason to look at an 810 or 900.The Lumia line is a last grasp for relevance from two once-behemoths in the smart phone space. And from what I can gather in my short time with the Lumia 710, they have the product, now they just need the press and mind share. The really shocking thing is that this phone is a low-end Lumia phone! Button quality aside, never once did it feel like I was using a budget handset. Which begs the question: How awesome is the Lumia 900? I may need to find out sooner than later.
summary: Excellent, speedy phone marred only by the worst buttons on earth

reviewText: In today's day and age, how it it that we are STILL walking around with cords dangling from our ears?! I must ask this question at least twice a week in exasperation to my gym buddies, my gamer pals and my coworkers.  But the fact remains, we're never truly wireless.I've tried a wide variety of bluetooth headset alternatives, all of which have had significant flaws.  The headsets with the wraparound headband either look absolutely ridiculous or sound like junk (or both).  The earbuds usually have some kind of gimmicky dongle or accessory attachment that merely shortens wires and makes the situation more awkward.  Or, they flat out don't work, don't chair and/or don't pair.None of these problems exist with these headphones-- finally! In fact, for me they are ALMOST perfect.  I want them to be perfect!The charging pouch, for me, was too goofy to use. It's very stiff and it's really tough to get the earbuds in and out.  So, I just tossed it in my electronics box and go without.  Otherwise, charging is simple and easy.  It would have been super if they went with a standard USB cable because I would have avoided yet another dangling appendage coming from my desktop.  But, oh well.  Small stuff.The headphones themselves are very nicely constructed and come with interchangeable earbud cones for varying ear sizes.  This is pretty typical for all earbuds.Pairing is a cinch.  Just press and hold the square button on the on-cord control dial.  Your iPhone (and, presumably your Android) smartphone will find it instantly.Sound quality is excellent (considering its wireless/bluetooth).  It's nice and loud.  Good depth, good treble.  Excellent and more than satisfactory!Now for my two gripes:1- The size of the earbuds themselves is 2-3 times the size of an Apple iTunes earbud.  They look huge and stick out horizontally from your ear canals and make you look pretty silly.  Plus, they are a bit heavy so they can fall out of your ear if they brush or catch something in your physical surroundings.2- The cord is stiff, inflexible and pulls the earbuds out even when you are walking in a straight line and otherwise not moving your upper body.  If you are in the gym and actually moving your head/body around, this problem gets exacerbated 500% and becomes rather irritating.  It seems like something so simple as cord design/material choice should not have gone unnoticed by the product engineers.  But, alas.All-in-all, I'm pleased with the headphones and unlike the other bluetooth headphones that have been retired to the box collecting dust under my bed, these stay out on my desk and have actually seen semi-habitual use!  I'm still waiting for the "perfect" earbuds.  Somebody, please!  But until then... these are definite winners!

So I wanted something that wasn't too loud but which was easy to identify.This is perfect!  I love green and black and yet the green is subtle enough to be okay.  Also - I was worried about the rubberized green getting dirty, but it really doesn't.  Has been in my purse almost a month and it doesn't look dirty at all.Case fits well - you do have to make sure that the green half circles fit well into the cutouts in the black, but it's easy enough and it sits well after that.  Sits up well enough from the screen and camera to offer a bit of protection (on a flat surface they are a few mm away from touching anything)  Case does not interfere with the camera, speaker/microphone, input ports or buttons at all....all good since that's always the worst flaw of any case that does so.  Do wish there was some green showing around the camera lens just to complete the look...case see the shiny glass a bit of the flat black of the phone (you'd see a strip of white on a white iPhone, I suspect though can't confirm).  Minor detail though.  Nice even margins on the green otherwise. Fairly wide around the face (lots of green border).The Incipio case had the two side volume buttons in the same cutout in the hardcase...this one has the hard case actually wrap around and separate them.  I thought this might interfere with their use, but it really doesn't at all.And cases like this where you've got the rubber liner in the hardshell are popular for a reason - they protect the electronics well - against both shock and pointed/rough impacts and surfaces.On the whole I think it's nice.  Bright and easy to see not just among other people's phones, but across the room or in my car when it falls down.
summary: Nice color, good construction, protects phone w/o interfering with functionality

All of the previous reviewers have stated the problems with this case, so I won't go through that litany again other than to confirm that - based on my experiences with the case - they're correct to varying degrees.I lost an S3 to the washing machine, so really wanted a waterproof case to protect my replacement. After receiving the case and finding out that it really DID have all those issues, I decided I would live with it, just to keep the replacement safe. Now I'm rethinking that; I didn't know what 'watermarks' were until just yesterday, when a big spot appeared on the inner side of my case. I opened it up, only to find the mark was gone. So I cleaned the glass and closed the phone back up in the case. This morning the spot was back, and brought his friends. The single watermark from yesterday has gotten MUCH bigger and now several more smaller ones are present. My touch screen barely works around them, and the 'back' button at the lower right doesn't respond to any amount of coaxing.To be clear, the grid of dots doesn't bother me at all - I can't see them when I'm using my phone (I can only see them when my screen is black and I look at a certain angle). What irks me is that MULTIPLE watermarks form in spite of them (and degrade the performance of my device so much).I wrote this review on my S3 to get a better sense of how the watermarks affect text input.  Glad I did,  because when I started the review my intent was still to keep it despite the watermarks. But when I saw just HOW MUCH it affected text input, I changed my mind and decided to return this case.My review title didn't include that last word when I started; that was added around the end of the second sentence in the second paragraph.

I'm using this device to pair my iPhone 5 with a Logitech S715i dock -- it's a great solution for using a sound dock with a 30-in connector with the iPhone 5. It took just a few seconds to pair the iPhone with the A2DP. The sound quality is fine for casual use and so far I've not experienced any problems with it. It's actually much more convenient to use this device than to dock the iPhone to the dock, since it allows you to use the iPhone while it's streaming music to the dock. And since it gets power from the dock, there are no worries with charging or batteries.My only nitpicks are that I dislike how every Bluetooth device has to blink a blue light when it's working -- it's a little distracting and I wish the light would stop blinking after it has successfully paired with the iPhone. Also, after it goes to "sleep" after use, the only way I've found to wake it up again is to disconnect and then reconnect it.

reviewText: First and foremost, you don't need to purchase a data plan from AT&T; to use the Lumia 2520. That's probably obvious to most people out there, but just like any other tablet, boot it up and connect to a WiFi network - then you're good to go. You have the option of connecting to an AT&T; HSPA+ or LTE network the same way you would any WiFi network, and when you do so it'll prompt you to activate the pre-installed SIM card. Otherwise, no monthly data plan required.Pros:- Screen is gorgeous. The 1920x1080 IPS display has magnificent viewing angles, the brightness is more than good enough for reading and browsing outdoors on a sunny day.- Performance screams! The Snapdragon 800 processor made me raise an eyebrow at first, but I suppose they went that route for the LTE capabilities. It's as good or better than any of the Intel counterparts. 1080p video plays perfectly without skipping a beat, games look great, screen animations and transitions are zippy and smooth.- The soft touch plastic the case is made from is great to hold. There's something to be said about the magnesium case of the Surface 2, or the anodized aluminum of the iPad air...but the plastic on the Lumia 2520 doesn't make it feel any less sturdy by any means. In fact, after using it for a couple days, I like it better than the Air.- Sound - I don't know where it comes from, but it's stereo, and it sounds as good as my MacBook Pro.- Battery Life is fantastic. The rated 11+ hours is dead to real. I spent an hour and half or more browsing the internet at 50% brightness with the battery at 7% before it told me to save my work and shutdown.Cons:- Windows RT. Nothing more needs to be said really. With RT you're limited to whatever apps you can find in the Windows Store, and it's slim pickins still years after release. Obviously the largest companies have really well designed apps that work as well as any other mobile OS's, but there aren't really any startups or independent software companies making good apps for this ecosystem. You don't even have to install a lot of apps to see that this is the case. The app icons in most cases are so severely lacking that you wouldn't even consider clicking on them to begin with.- Funny enough, the screen is also a con somewhat. For as gorgeous as it is overall, the one I received has really bad backlight bleeding on the right edge. On the bootup screen when it's entirely black, it's super obvious. When you reading in low light conditions it's also very obvious. I'm considering returning it because perhaps I just got a lemon.Other thoughts: I think the Lumia 2520 has a niche - and it fills it perfectly if this is what you're looking for. If you're always on the go and don't always have access to WiFi, or don't want to bother friends and family for their WEP/WPA passwords when you're at the their house, this tablet is great. Also, if you require access to Office applications on you tablet, the experience is second to none. If Windows RT will suffice for your needs, and you need a tablet with LTE, gorgeous screen, and great battery life, you can't do much better.
summary: One of the best RT Tablets out there! Don't need LTE Plan to use!

reviewText: Obviously, choosing a case for your phone is a personal decision. I assume you are reading these reviews because you like the styling of this product. I agree with other reviewers that the protection offered here is not on par with other cases that could be purchased but if you had a hard shell case you would look like an incompetent dweeb who breaks expensive electronics and should probably be wearing a helmet at all times. As such, you would not have made it to these reviews at all. Assuming this, you can be assured this is a nice case. It has a tight fit and keeps the slim lines of the phone. It protects both sides as you can see in the picture and leaves most of the top and bottom ends open but does overlap at the edges to provide a buffer against direct impact. Again, it leaves the face open but wraps around the edge on the sides so that if you leave the phone face down, the surface touches the case and not the phone directly, leaving a few millimeters between the surface and the glass. The holes cut for the front and side line up perfectly with the phone. I charged my phone with the case on and did not feel any increased heat as a result. For the money and styling this is a good looking case that offers limited protection for adult use.

I like phone cases with two-piece design. A soft inner layer and a hard shell. This case has the added benefit of a kickstand. I don't know if it will last forever, because the kickstand is just made out of the same material so I hope that the hinge will hold up.  But the price was reasonable.Every other phone case I have had has been square edged. The edges on this case are around. It does give it a different feeling your hand but it also makes it easier to get in and out of your pocket.Another nice feature of the rubber inner layer:  the ends of the case are protected by the silicone inner layer. This means you can stand up your phone and lean it against another object and the silicone will not slide the way a hard shell case would. Thus you stand your phone thusly in portrait mode or in landscape mode with the kickstand.
summary: Its edges are round!  Excellent case

I was excited to receive this Bluetooth headset since my aging Plantronics one will probably bite the dust soon.  Not surprisingly, given the low retail price, the Pure1 cannot compete with the Plantronics in voice reproduction, although other features can.  Voices are muted and distant sounding, although still clear, on both ends, and I find myself switching away from the Bluetooth to my iPhone if I'm in a position to hold the phone. It comes with a clear plastic ear hook, but I ditched that at once since, when I hook it around my ear, the actual earpiece is positioned too low.  By using this without the hook to place the headphone directly into my ear canal, I can hear, and, surprisingly, the earpiece stays in place.  Still, the voice reproduction isn't as clear as I'd like.  Don't even try to use this as a music listening device because the sound is just not good enough.Pairing and operation are easy, as they should be.  The pairing/power light is tiny, and I had trouble at first deciding whether the earpiece was on or off; however, once I located it, it was easy to read.  The detachable hook can be place for either right or left ear operation.  The rated talk time is 4 hours, and, while I haven't timed it, the estimate seems about right.This is a lightweight, budget earpiece that is best suited for occasional use.  If you use Bluetooth headsets a lot, you'll likely be frustrated as I was.  Note:  I received a sample for review.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Good Retail Price, Okay Voice Reproduction/Sound (4- stars)

I received this unit for review from the iFLASH people but I did not promise or offer to produce a 'good review' in return for a free product. It just happens that this version is all-around good and the very few negatives don't amount to a lot.So here it is why I like this model:✔ GOOD CAPACITY AND YET NOT HUGE OR HEAVY: at 5600mAh it can charge a phone two or three times. Once you fill it up with juice you can simply drop it in your bag and it's ready to use when you need it.✔ COMES WITH ITS OWN CHARGER: most chargers on the market rely on you providing your own wall charger, which is not hard but, still, the one included is a welcome frill and it just happens to be smaller than most third party so I'm glad it's included.✔ INTERFACES GALORE: read Amazon's description but, just in case you don't want to bother, the iFLASH comes with a modular system that has a USB Type-A at one end and it allows you to attach any of the supplied interfaces at the other end such as Mini USB, Micro USB, PSP (true), Nokia DC 2.0, iPhone/iPad (old style) and, of course, you can supply your own wire if none of these fit your device.✔ COMES WITH A BAG: this is very important to me. The nice blue bag can easily hold the iFLASH, the wall charger and the few wires and plugs you may need.✔ CHARGE INDICATOR RING LIGHTS: they light up when you press a button and 4 blue rings mean 100% full, 3 rings mean 75% full and so forth.✔ LITTLE LED FLASHLIGHT: just in case. Who knows, you may find yourself in complete darkness and this just might save the day.Output is 5V/1A which should make it good for charging phones, not good for charging tablets or anything bigger.The design isn't going to win any prize at an industrial design competition but even the looks are quite decent. If you are looking for a charger that works well and comes with everything you need, this one is very good choice. I didn't measure how many minutes it took this iFLASH to charge my phones but charged it did and it did it quickly and, once all I needed was in the bag already I didn't have to waste time looking for little wires or plugs.The negatives may or may not matter. If you have no idea how to use a an external battery to charge your phone you may not want this model. Unless you can read Chinese. The unit I received came with a Chinese-only user guide. The other issue is that fingerprints and various smudges are quite visible on the super-shiny, black finish. The two combined made this a four-star rating but this is still a great product as far as battery backups are concerned.

I've lost track of how many styluses I have been given, bought and lost or broken.  Yes, those funky little rubber tips can come off, but then they're only good for a spare pen, if they happen to double as pens.  These do not, despite their description as 'Stylus Pens.'  I've lost blue styluses, black ones, silver ones and even one stubby stylus a bit like this.  I gave stubby back when I realized the kind guy who gifted me with it needed it even more than I did.  I misplaced yet another standard stylus not long ago, and ordered this packet.  Why?It's cheap. It doesn't slip out of the earpiece port unless you take it out to use earphones.It's eye catching. If it tumbles anywhere in my purse of tote, I'm more likely to see it.There are enough of these to share with friends like me who need a stylus for their smart phones or tabletsThe extension makes this compact stylus more user friendly and cheaper than, say an Ollie's $3.99 stubbier model.I even get to pick a stylus to match my Kindle Fire cover.I have extras to spare on the off chance I lose any of theseThis does not have a pen point.  Pen points are a great idea in theory, but they spiral out and I find ink marks on my pillowcase or sheets.Cons (well, really only one)I wish my tablet had two earphone ports so I'd have one available for this stylus and one for my earphones. So far so good but if it breaks I'll update the review to keep potential buyers abreast of new developments.Ease of Use/Installation:Really nothing to it; just plug it in the wall and go.  I would comment that the USB ports on the brick are rather a surprisingly tight fit so plugging anything in in the dark will be rather impossible but that's fine because your phone will always be charged up.  On the up side of that though, nothing's going to come unplugged.Effectiveness:I tested this versus the Apple standard iPhone brick and found charging was approximately 2.5x faster with this brick than the standard one.  Results with the Kindle Fire HD are similar.Durability:This brick is quite hefty when compared to the standard plug.  It will make rather a tighter fit in small spaces but unlike many cheaper bricks it stays very firmly in the plug.In summary, this is the brick I always wanted but never knew existed before now.  Quite a deal considering I've paid the same amount for bricks that only charged one device at a time.
summary: It's that little 4-way plug you always wanted

I recently ordered a new battery from another seller for my friends G1 which was no longer holding a charge. The battery worked better than expected. I've been using it for a few days and I charge it fully each night. By the end of the day, which is around 5 or 6pm for me, it's down to less than 20%. I rarely use my phone during the day while I'm at work. I even tried taking off the autosync feature to save battery life. Last night as usual I fully charged the battery. I've checked my email and received/sent a few text messages. It's now noon and the battery is at 44%!I believe there are some lower priced batteries out there that actually work. I don't think this is one of them. Try at your own risk. I'm just thankful I didn't spend alot on this.

I bought this product in trying to find the best bluetooth option for talking on my cell phone when on business trips and away from my desk.  I needed a bluetooth headset that could be on my ear for hours and be loud and clear for listening as well as have a perfect microphone with background noise filtering for when I speak.  The Plantronics Voyager Pro is good, but not great from my experience with over 40 hours of using it so far.#1 The other reviewers are right, I had about a 1/4" long scruffy beard growing in and the microphone screen snags on beard hairs on your cheek badly, this was almost too painful to wear this device with even 3 day old scruff on your face.  The screen requires a foam cover if you have a beard.#2 the microphone is strong, but the noise filtering doesn't seem to work very well.  My callers can hear me fine but they can hear everything else in the background too, even distant noises like dog barks.  The wind filtering is medium and it gets pretty windy here.#3 the audio itself is too low, I had to switch to the lowest size ear buds so they fit deeper in my ear canal.  Even then with my phone at max audio volume, and my Voyager Pro at max audio volume the audio is only "just able to be heard" I really wish it could have pushed the volume louder to account for people who talk with soft voices.  I have had over the head 2.5mm headphones that provide louder audio volumes.Overall, the Plantronics Voyager Pro isn't a bad product, but for as much as it costs you would expect it to have better volume and to include a foam covering for the microphone for people who may want to grow beards.
summary: No Beards is Right and Audio Level Low

reviewText: I went camping last weekend up in the mountains, and I absolutely had to be able to use my phone to log in remotely to my work computer to do some work. The only other option would be driving down into town for better reception, which would have taken a couple hours and severely limited the fun during my camping trip.I barely had one bar of signal (this is AT&T; "4G"), and was barely able to send text messages. Forget about checking Instagram and Twitter. I brought the YX240 zBoost zForce Cellular Signal Booster for Automobiles with gooseneck power adapter (catchy name) along with me and plugged it in to a 12v power source, and put the included antenna on the roof of the truck. I put my phone in the cradle (iPhone 4S) and within 5 seconds, the signal went from 1 bar to full bars. I was a little skeptical that it was making that much difference, so to check, I loaded a webpage. It loaded up quickly, so I figured why not try logging in remotely. Remote login requires a pretty solid connection and it cannot drop or it closes the connection. So I was really trusting this device to work.Well, it worked. I was able to get all my work done remotely. The phone screen can be operated in the cradle with no problems. I was controlling my desktop computer hundreds of miles away from up in the woods, it was amazing.I can't speak to all locations or situations, but it definitely worked great for me, and for around $100, I think this booster is well worth the money.  I haven't tried it on a road trip across my state yet, but I know there are several places the phone service cuts out, so it would be interesting to load up Pandora or some other streaming audio and see if the music cuts out. I will update my review if I am able to do that.
summary: 100% improvement. I can't recommend this enough.

reviewText: So I've had the SGP ultra oleophobic screen protector on my iPhone 4s for over a month. It was great at first but then over the last few weeks, the fingerprints got harder and harder to wipe off. When I first got it, fingerprints would wipe off pretty easily but I guess after time, you're also wiping the oleophobic coating off also. I loved the clarity but couldn't deal with the fingerprints anymore. So I read the reviews for the PhoneDevil Matte Clear sreen protector and decided to give it a shot. For the price, what could I lose.I got the package in 2 days - Amazon Prime :) and was a little nervous about all that I read about matte screens and how they ruin the great retina display. Installation was very easy. I've installed screen protectors many times so I think I have the hang of it. Using the tape trick to grab little dust particles is always helpful. After the install there were zero bubbles and it was a perfect fit. After about 1 week of use, I've gotten use to the matte coating. It does take some time but I actually like the look of it. It just looks clean. It does take away a little bit of the display brightness but it's hard to explain. I don't mind it at all. You can still see fingerprints but they aren't as obvious. For any of you that have a clear protector or don't have one at all know how the fingerprints can be pretty nasty. With the PhoneDevil matte protector, those fingerprints don't show up the same way. That's also a bit hard to explain. You should really just try it out especially if the fingerprints kill you everyday. But do keep in mind that the matte display will take some getting used to or you'll either love it or hate it. I for one used to hate it, but love it now since I don't see the fingerprints and also no more glare!! I loved it so much that I bought a matte protector for my iPad 2!! Looks great on that also!!
summary: Great Matte Protector! As good as the expensive ones!!

reviewText: Update: Feb. 7, 2014 - I have moved this from 2 to 4 stars mainly because of the customer service. LugaLake has been incredibly responsive to my issues and the device is working. I am not going to give this 5 stars because of a few shortcomings:1) You cannot charge one device wirelessly and another plugged in at the same time2) You can only plug in an external device to charge when the LugaLake itself is not plugged in3) While the device has a fairly large area to place the phone it can be a bit finicky and just stop charging.I bought another wireless charger which has worked flawlessly and will use this one as a backup and for when I am travelling. Having the ability to carry around 3 full charges for my Nexus 5 is great.Original ReviewAt first this sounded great but it didn't last long. I noticed an issue about 30 days in where the charger would not fully charge to the green light. Now, 60 days in it has stopped charging all together. It won't hold a charge, it won't charge the phone wirelessly or through the additional USB port.Very disappointed and a waste of my money.

The colors are exactly the same! It fits perfectly and to everyone who complains about it being too loose there should be a little brown thing that comes with the case. You peel of the back and stick in the middle of the top piece of the case. When you do that it should stay put now. Also if it yours doesn't come with one just fold up some pieces of paper and stick in the sides.
I'm quadriplegic and unable to work on iphone when covered up whith this surface. Unable to press buttons to turn on nor can I take it out of second structure. Might work for others though.
I wanted the Original samsung earbuds, so I bought these. Price looked too cheap, so i decided t. Works ok, but not the same as Samsung part.
summary: Works Great but not original Samsung

reviewText: Eagle Tech, USA ET-NP056K-BL 5600 mAh external battery packI really like this battery pack.  It's smaller than my iPhone but its a little thicker.  I have the blue color, which is pretty, and it has a nice soft feel to it.The battery pack will charge my iPhone four or five times before I have to charge it. It has four blue lights on the top that show how much power is left in the pack. You can press the button and it will show how many lights are left (total 4).  I usually charge it when it has one light left.  It also has a flashlight that turns on by pressing the button twice. It's not the brightest flashlight but it certainly is helpful. It's supposed to work for thousands of hours without recharging.It has dual ports - one for charging phones and one for tablets. I don't think it has enough power to charge my I-Pad and it drained the battery pack when I tried to charge it. That's okay because I mainly use it for my phone. I can take the battery pack with me and not have to worry about charging my phone. It's small and will fit in your pocket.It comes with a little carrying handle that is flimsy and I don't know how to attach it to the battery pack. I wouldn't trust it to hold the pack, though.I use it all the time. It's easy to carry and it's perfect to keep my phone charged. I love it!

I really wanted to use this to charge my ipad - even a partial charge but it isn't compatible. It charges my iphone well enough tho. It's quite slim and comes with a variety of cables so you should be able to charge just about any USB chargeable device.
summary: Decent, doesn't work with iPad tho

I got Motorola S9-HD for a week now because I did not want to deal with wired headphones while running. The product I have received came in original box with authenticity hologram attached to the arm.The short of it is that when it works, it does the job great and sound quality is very good. Contrary to other reviewers, I have a pretty comfortable fit. Pairing is also very easy. I like the button placement etc. I had it paired with both my laptop and a iPod nano wireless transmitter (i10s (Luxurious White) Tiny Bluetooth iPod Transmitter for iPod/iPhone/iPad/iTouch).I have a couple other Bluetooth headphones but they were not suitable for active sports. While this one does better job of staying on my head, there is a big annoying problem with signal cut-offs. S9-HD frequently loose signal with the transmitter. I cannot keep the iPod reliably in my pocket. I have to hold it in my hand. I thought the issue was with my wireless transmitter but these headphones do the same with my laptop when I am sitting directly in front of the laptop and also my other Bluetooth headphones do not cut-off this frequently, at such a short distance.Edit: The cut-offs seems to be less when both iPod and S9-HD are fully charged. When battery starts to drain over time (say an hour or so) the cut-offs become more often. Either the battery is too small or not fully charging fully (or both). Perhaps, with a few more charge/discharge cycles the situation may improve. I'll update this review if I see an improvement.Edit2: The cut-offs are continuing after over a month use. It is such an annoyance and probably a flaw of this device as my other bluetooth devices does not have this problem. Unfortunately, besides Motorola S9 and S10, the other Bluetooth headphones are not suitable for active sports.
summary: Good for sports but cuts off frequently

reviewText: I have charged them all used them all, customer service is great, one of the batteries sent was too big (I bought 3 of them) The vendor sent me the replacement for this "oversized" battery as soon as I reported it. Great working with.All batteries charge to full charge and last as much as they need to. But I have had to replace them all in one day.. now that airlines allow phones in on mode on air....
summary: Perfect! Now I have extra charge to go

reviewText: I bought this product because I need something to charge my iPhone and View Sonic tablet on my trip to Europe.This is my second external battery pack I owned. The other is a 1,000mAh Duracell. Obviously, it will not work for a 12 hr flight and 2 devices. I needed something with more juice.I choose this model over other New Trent products because of the price and price/mAh. They have one that outputs 11,000mAh, but was outside my price point.The other model I considered was the  IMP70D 7,000mAh. I choose to go with the IMP880 because it had more juice. The main thing the IMP70D has over the IMP880 is dual usb output.Now with the review of the IMP880.Pros: 1) sleek looking.2) built well.3) auto shut-off - you can leave your device connected to it and it automatically shuts off when your device is fully charged.4) smart turn-on - meaning you must have a device connected to it in order to turn it on. You cannot accidentally turn it on.Cons: 1) I am only getting 6700mAh of charge. Not 8900mAh.  I figured this output based on charging my iPhone 4 using the % remaining battery indicator. The iPhone 4 has a 1420 mAh battery, according to cnet. [...] I was able to recharge my iPhone 4.7x and 5x. That would equate to 6,600mAh and 7,100mAh. I ran this test twice, and got about the same results.A few things that could make device better:1) increase surface area, and make device thinner. The device is not huge, but it is too bulky to carry in a pants pocket. It's about 2x as thick as my wallet, about the same surface area.2) a digital output of % remaining or mAh remaining vs the blue line that symbolizes 100%/75%/50%/25%3) charger for device could be smaller. The charger is about 1/2 the size of the battery. It would be nice if you could charge it with a USB like an iPhone or EVO.Overall, nice device...3 stars because of the 6,600mAh and 7,100mAh output when it says 8900mAh.<<<<<<EDIT>>>>>>I was originally a bit upset with the product because I thought I was being "shorted"  1900mAh or so; however, after reading the Technical Details for the IMP99D, I feel like I prematurely judged the product.  The IMP99D is 9900mAh vs the 8900mAh one I bought.  The technical details say: "Ultra reliable Lithium-Ion battery with 9900mAh, 500% iPhone 4 Battery life" - well, on my 8900mAh one I got 4.7-5x charges on my iPhone4. I also talked New Trent's customers service and they said storage does not equate to output. My point is: well, my charger works just fine.5 stars... upgrading to 5 stars from 3 stars because device works as advertised.
summary: nice,  after better understanding the product <review edited>

reviewText: I love the see thru back plastic. Like how the buttons are not recessed. It doesnt add much bulk. It is not heavy and look good. Feels sturdy but not too much.

I absolutely love these items.  This last purchase was for my father, this is the 3rd one I have purchased. I bought another 5600 for my bro-in-law and a 10000 for myself.For some reason these products are not as well known as others and it's a shame, they are excellent for camping, traveling and being on the go.I strongly recommend this product to anyone considering a portable battery back-up.

I've always respected Belkin products. They are moderately priced and well made. If you purchase foreign knockoffs you get a low price and often poor quality. Belkin does it right. This is no exception. I like the larger silver surface that makes it easier to insert and remove cable. The new slimmer apple ones are harder to grab. The cable itself is a slightly larger diameter which hopefully will keep it from fraying when I accidentally vacuum or step on it. So far it's perfect!
I love the hot pink and it protects my phone very well. I use it with a hot pink screen protector for a better look.

The Belkin Shield cases have been the first that work well with the 30 pin adapter (which allows you to use the iPhone 5 with accessories for the previous iPhones.)  It is a stylish white case with interesting pin striping effects on the back.  It is not textured in any way but gives a kind look of texturing.  The cutout allows the adapter to work and a second cutout allows great access to the side buttons.  I wish that Belkin had the better "grip" on this case that they have on other cases - it makes the phone easier to hold.I also wish that they had a version of this case which was black and silver for those of us who have black phones and want to keep that look in our case.  I think this white and silver case would look really nice with a white phone.  It doesn't look as great with my black phone but I put use ahead of fashion and am thrilled to have a phone that allows me to use my clock radio and speaker accessories around the house.I recommend this case to all and especially to those with a white phone.
summary: Stylish case that works with the 30 pin adapter

reviewText: I received my cable as a review sample and used it to charge up my Galaxy Note 3 for the first test. That went without a hitch, but the real test was when I used it transfer music from my laptop to the phone.Synching is where some of the third party cables I have tried fail. In those cases I am greeted with an 'USB device not recognized' message, and it's always due to the cable. This cable passed that test with flying colors. Note that I did not test it as USB 3.0 speeds because I do not have any host device with those ports. It zipped right along with the USB 2.0 port in my laptop.The best feature for me is the length because my living room is large and the wall outlets are quite a distance from where my sofa and coffee table is set up. If you need the convenience of a long cord this is a great deal because of price and construction. The latter is the final reason why I awarded it five stars: the outer insulator is heavy duty without being stiff. The connectors on each end are precision made, and strain relief on each end are beefy.It works as well as the OEM cord that came with my Note 3 and is way less than the price Verizon wants for a genuine Samsung replacement cable (and they do not sell any that is anywhere near this long.) Bottom line: it's a value and a convenience.
summary: Works as well or better than Samsung's cables

reviewText: I'm a tech geek and have used many mobiles over the years. I've used Palm, Blackberry, WinMobile, Webos, Ios, Meego, WP7 and Android. So I know the differences. Having used many of them, I have made Android my primary phone. The reasons for me are simple - I like to be in charge of my device. Customization is a choice, it is not mandatory. Many iphone owners will say oh you have to tweak your Android phone to make it useful. Nothing can be further from truth. It is entirely up to the user. There are many cool things you can do with Android that you never can on any iphone.- A proper file manager/USB storage: what is it and why it matters? If you used any USB flash drive, you know how it works. You just plug it in and it shows up as a drive and you can drag and drop ANY file in it. Android works the same way. There is no special itunes/zune-like software you need to manage your phone. It's sad that Apple charges so much for higher capacity iphones yet the storage can not be managed in any way YOU please. It's strictly designed to be a consume devices - music and video.- "AirDroid" - simple and free app for Android that allows you to do nearly everything from a browser interface without even touching your phone. this includes file transfer, app management, send/receive txts and much more. this is very convenient because you can have your phone in your pocket.- "mysms" or "mighty text" - these are also handy as they allow you to send/receive sms without even touching your phone as long as your phone has working signal. pretty awesome in office environment.Mind you, 90% of Android customization can be done by anyone irrespective of tech knowledge. There is no rooting(aka jailbreaking in Ios world) needed. Iphone users will tell you once you jailbreak an iphone, it can be made to work like Android. Again that's completely false. Jailbreaking idevice allows a little customization but it's nowhere near Android. And you still can't do anything you want. For instance- you still can't properly manage that storage on your idevice even after jailbreaking. Because jailbreaking doesn't change the core OS or how it behaves.Pros:Great battery life. Charges pretty fast. Mine charges fully in roughly about an hour.Highly portable. very lightweight.Openness + Customization of Android.Better reception - I've tried using my SIM card on my LG phone which drops signal but Sony was able to retain at least one bar.Stylish - sure it's not made of aluminum but still looks and feels great on hand.Cons:No expandable storage. Again if you are a light user, it should not bother you. Mind you all iphones never offered expandable storage yet they are very popular. So it really depends on your usage. I'm a heavy user and for me, the device must be flexible. And this is the only con I can mention about this device.Final words about Android. As Android is platform agnostic, you will find low end to high end Android device. You can't really judge an OS by using a crappy Android device. Xperia U is above average/mid-range phone. It's of course unlocked so you can use AT&t; 3G in the usa and worlwide.
Purchased for a Samsung Galaxy SIV.  Too small.  Waste of money.  Looks like it might be a great product for an Iphone, but wording in the description suggests it's universal.  Not Universal.

I've always been impressed with OtterBox quality and protection - owning six cases for various devices made by them, and this OtterBox Defender case with holster for the Samsung Galaxy S4 is no different. Purchased for a Mother's Day gift for a new phone, the case fit perfectly and provides a fairly slim (by OtterBox standards) case with built-in screen protector. My Mom loved it!A hard plastic shell case goes over the phone, then a silicon sheath over the hard case to buffer against drops. The screen is not negatively affected by the screen protector, and all the ports are easy to get to and buttons easy to use. The camera is not obscured at all, and sound from the phone is not muffled.The only issue we had was getting the case back off. In the directions is a 'tool', which did not ship with our case. A small, flat head screwdriver popped the latches so we could get to the phone, but it was tricky! We had to go to YouTube to look-up how to do it. Other than this - it's all good!
summary: Best case for the Samsung S4

reviewText: After many different kinds of Cables I have tried I do like these.. I have two of them so far for charging, I like the 6 foot in length (The electrical outlets are never close to where u need them). I have not tried to use them to transfer data from computer to phone/Tablet so I do not know how well they work in that department...

A few days after I ordered the amPen Hybrid Stylus here on Amazon,  my mother ordered this pack of 6. I compared the two when she mentioned she got the pack for about the same price as I bought the single amPen.  The lanyard/body is exactly the same  (except for the iDream logo), and they both feature removable, replaceable tips (although I can't seem to get the tip off the amPen at all... hrmm).  The iDream tip came off with a little effort.The tips themselves, however, differ greatly. The iDream tips are significantly longer and "grabbier". I can hear distinct squeaking of the iDream's tip across my tablet's screen and feel a almost reluctant, skipping resistance while scrolling,  whereas the amPen has a shallower tip yet smoother (and noiseless) resistance.In the overall scheme of things, yes, the amPen Hybrid Stylus has a superior tip with every other aspect of the two being the same.... except I paid pretty much the same for one amPen as these 6 iDream. Regardless,  I would still personally repurchase amPen's hybrid tip as the squeaking from this one got annoying very quickly.  :p
summary: In comparison with the amPen Hybrid Stylus

the filter is a good product for my iphone,works well with high quality, i bought this filter recommend by my friend,who is good at buying online, so i bought filter from eforcity, item arrived on time and in good conition, thank u so much, and will definitely buy again.

This charger provides 2amps charging total which is good for all smartphones and tablets.  Keep in mind though that since it is 2A, charging 2 tablets at once would charge a bit slow as most tablets use 2A alone.  But with that aside, this is perfect for me since typically I only charge 1 device at a time, but I have both android and apple products, which have different charging cables.  So with this charger, I can put one micro-usb cable for my Android devices, and one lightning cable for my iPhone 5S.  I use another one of these with a lightning and 30-pin apple charger, for my iPad.  I have a few of these placed throughout the house and have not had any problems with any of my devices including the Note 3, Note 2, S3, iPhone 5S, 4S, 3G, and iPad (3rd Gen).  I replaced the single chargers around the house with this dual charger.It also has foldable prongs which is a plus when travelling.  Construction wise, the charger feels solid.
summary: Convenient when you have multiple devices in the house.

reviewText: Very sleek study case I really liked it.  It shipped fast.  It is light weight and fit my phone snug.Thank you

Finally a wireless charging option for the iPhone 5.  Before I acquired the iPhone 5S I was using the Samsung Galaxy S4.  One of the many accessories I missed was the wireless charging capabilities the Galaxy S4 had.  You also were able to choose from so many different covers and cases that worked with the Qi receiver (wireless charging pad).  I checked what was out in the market for the iPhone 5 but nothing seemed to really "fit" what I was looking for until I had the opportunity to test the Unu Aero Wireless Charging Case and Pad.The case itself is soft to the touch and comes it two separate pieces.  It does a tiny bit of bulk and weight to the phone, but not too much to make much of a difference.  The case has raised buttons for the volume and power controls.  However, it has an open area for the mute switch.  Even though it does not have an open area in the bottom for the speakers, it  has two slots located on the front of the case for sound and microphone use.  The camera cutout on the back is quite large, so expect no interference troubles there.The receiver (Qi) pad is extremely lightweight and automatically begins charging you phone as soon as it makes connect with your phone.  Believe it or not, this charges faster the normal lightning cable.  I was so impressed with how fast it charges and how long it holds the charge, I ended up acquiring two additional charging pads to have in my office and another in my vehicle instead of using a lightning cable.  Keep in mind besides using the wireless pad to charge the phone,  you can always a  micro USB cable to charge the case as well in case of emergencies.  The only thing you really need to get use to is using a headset extension adapter.  Since the headphone jack sits far into case, a headphone plug will not be able to fit correctly.  I don't use the same headsets all the time, so I have to make it a point to remember to carry the included headphone jack adapter with me when I plan to use different headphones.One really great feature is the battery usage indicator located on the back of the case.  It has four tiny blue lights to tell you how much battery life is left.  It is pretty accurate too because I have the battery indicator on my phone and I am always comparing the two.When using it to sync to iTunes, you just need to use a micro USB cable instead of the Apple Lightning cable.  This way you don't have to take the case off.This is truly a terrific product and works great.  If you are interested in extra pads here is the link:uNu Aero Series Wireless Charging Pad (Single Mat). Like I mentioned before, I used one in my vehicle by placing it in one of the cubbyholes in my Dogde Durango - works great!UPDATE:Since I kept taking the case on and off to test and review other cases on my phone, I broke one of the tabs on my uNu Aero case and wanted to cry because this is my favorite and pretty much the case I use everyday.  I emailed customer service (services@myunu.com) and they quickly issued me a replacement.  So besides being a great wireless charging case, they have wonderful customer service as well.Sample provided for review.
summary: A must have for the iPhone 5/5S - you will LOVE it!

reviewText: Oh my god this is it for me this the perfect case for me so secure to have my phone in there super high quality with my kids and pet You can leave your phone anywhere nothing is going to happen your phone it is no t going to break great purchase so happy

The main charger in the front held my phone at a great angle. However you have to remove the phone out of your case in order to connect it, and I also discovered that the second/spare battery charger in the back did not work or hold my spare battery in place (which was the real reason I bought this in the first place - to be able to charge a spare battery the same time as my phone). So I had to return this. Too bad, because it would have been a great phone charger and holder had it worked. It is overpriced for just a single phone charger.

reviewText: These are great. Comfortable to the point you don't even know you're wearing them and they fit great. Fits nicely under the shirt collar. They block out the noise around you better than i expected. Paired with my Note 2, sounds great and very clear listening to music. Battery life as advertised and charging in very fast. Needs to come with a pouch for storage when note in use. Wearing them around my office, the range is about 30 to 40 feet even going in & out of different offices.Has to be the best headset out there for the price. Stack it up against those more expensive one and the big $$$ ones don't even come close when you match them up feature to feature. Grab them now.............

reviewerName: J. R. Francis "Music and Tech Fiend @paynomind"
reviewText: I tested in three cars, four different power cables, including brand new ones, two different phones. These plugs light up their own LED red to say they are "on" but none of my phones (iPhone 4 and Droid Bionic) ever charge. The charging icon is never indicated ont he phones. The batteries to not gain power.These are faulty. I bought 2 at once, neither works.
summary: Doesn't work. LED lights, but phone doesn't receive power.

reviewText: The Native Union MM031 Curve Wireless Bluetooth Telephone for the iPhone is a pretty neat product I have to admit. I was somewhat concerned after reading some of the negative reviews but I can honestly say connectivity and clarity have not been a problem at all for me. I am using it with my iPhone 4S. First thing I should mention that is packed and presently nicely in a very thick plastic box. The instruction book is extremely thick, but it comes in 10 different languages and the actual instructions to follow are only about 20 pages and that includes pictures. Comes with 4 types of multi country AC adapters in case you travel to foreign countries that use different type of voltage plugs. Two universal dock adapters and a Micro-USB/USB cable if you wish to charge the unit via your computer.The base has some weight to it and will sit securely in place. I got the soft Black Touch which is like a soft rubber and it feels soft and silky smooth and can easily be wiped cleaned. It stated in the handbook that it takes about 2 to 3 hours to charge the unit 100%, but it took about 1  until the white LED turned off telling me the handset was completely charged. Paring was a breeze - just press the MFB button for 2 seconds on the handset and go to your bluetooth menu on your iPhone. My iPhone found it and paired with the MM03i automatically with no code. You actually can program up to 4 Bluetooth devices according to the instructions, but it will only automatically reconnect the last devices connected in its memory.I use a case with my iPhone and do not like the idea of removing it. My phone fit perfectly fine in it's case and I had no connection issues if I used the base without a dock adapter. Using the "+" , "-" and "MFB" buttons pretty much allow you to use all the functions as you would on your iPhone. You can reject a call, control the volume, hold a call, redial last number call and even use voice command. I use Siri a lot and all you have to do is hold the "+" button for two sections and she will pop up and await your instruction.You also can choose a different ringtone. There are a total of 15 in all. Since I am using the handset in office, I set the volume at the lowest possible setting because some of the ringtones can ring quite loudly. In regards to clarity, I have had no complaints. Callers have heard me clearly and I have heard them fine. The handset feels comfortably against my ear and there is no hand or ear fatigue.I would like to mention that in the instructions it states the MM03i enables Bluetooth connection with any laptop, desktop (Mac or PC) to work with Skype, Google Talk or other VOIP services. I don't have Bluetooth Wireless Technology on my PC, but I thought it might be important to mention.The only negative feature is that it is hard to tell the difference between the receiver and earpiece, the both look identical. I would try to answer a call holding the wrong end to my ear. Sometimes instead of thinking the unit is charging I come to found out I put the wrong end where it is suppose to charge. Even though is will not sit perfectly flush when the right end is not in the right hole, it would have been nice to have some kind of marking showing the top of the handset.Overall this is a really neat product for Smartphone users. It is has the benefits of ergonomics and comfort-ability of old school phones but introduces Bluetooth Technology into the mix. Also makes a unique gift if you know someone who loves to gab!

Seriously... this thing acts like it's glued to the windscreen, and the design is genius. Solid as a rock. Easy to use. Exactly what you need - but it doesn't actually activate the docking mode for my phone (Galaxy S3). Granted, that's probably a thing Samsung keeps exclusive to their products, nor does this product say it can do it. But I'd buy another one of these and just use the right car app.
summary: The most solid car mount I've seen yet.

reviewText: At a minimum, a screen protector needs to provide protection, while minimizing the impact of the tactile feel on the screen as well as the clarity of the image. SGP continues to nail it with this Ultra Oleophobic Screen Protector by not only having an excellent, smooth tactile feel and crystal clear picture, but the oleophobic coating is nothing short of magic. Fingerprints simply won't adhere to the surface. And if you happen to have just consumed a bucket of chicken and get grease on the screen, it wipes off far more easily than the original iPhone glass.On top of that, the material really is hard stuff. I got a tiny bubble during installation (easy to avoid using the included dust stickers to pick up stray bits of dust!) and used my fingernail to push the bubble out. Lesser screen protectors would have scratched under the hard pressure of a fingernail. Not Steinheil! Not so much as a scuff.Like I said, this is the perfect screen protector. I couldn't possibly ask for more.
Purchased item for my niece....She is very happy with and she also ordered another color.  Case easy to put on.

So it is a case, probably unnecesary for those who have the free bumper included in the Nexus 4 purchase.- Power button will turn harder to press with this case on.- Larger volume than the free bumper included in the purchase of Nexus 4Probably the only plus detected in this "Case" is that you will be able to stand it up, horizontally, like if it was on a cradle, to watch a video or read something, if you try to use it with this stand up option, it will move because it will not adhere to the surface.It consists in 2 parts, you first have to put in the black soft bumper around the phone, then you need to put the 6 legged weird "spider" on top of the soft first part. This will make the first part, bumper, to be almost impossible to get out if you don't take out the "spider" looking part out.

I didn't want to ruin my nice new HTC EVO SHIFT with a crap case and pay for it later, so I purchased this case, but not without some skepticism.  I, like many Amazon shoppers, read review after review about this case.  Most were extremely satisfied, but some were the exact opposite.  After ordering the case expedited, it finally arrived!  And behold a case that actually works!It's assembly was simple, even though some people had problems.. Just follow the directions, they're the same as any other slide phone.PRO'sEasy assemblyFits perfectly (doesn't cover any ports etc.)Keeps phone protected with NO SCRATCHESCON'sNot much of a grip (it can slide out of your hand if you don't have big enough hands, which I don't)The silicone sides sometimes flip up but they stay attached and it gathers some lintOverall, it's a great case, I just hope they come out with more colors and grip.UPDATE!!The little clasps that keep the case attached to the phone broke off!  Every time I dropped my phone or grabbed it in a certain way the case would just fall off.  It had been only a few months of use (roughly 4 months) until a few snaps broke off.  Luckily, after an email and a few pictures, a new case was promptly shipped to me at no cost.  Yay for Otterbox customer service!

I have the new iPhone 3Gs and this works awesome.  It protects the phone really well in the leather case.  The inside is soft.  At first I thought it would be awkward in the horizontal position on my belt but on the contrary, it does not get stuck when I bend over or stoop down and the clip for the belt is nice an tight so it does not push up and fall off when you bend down like other do.  The magnetic flap is also a really nice touch. It is also very easy to take out when the phone rings.  Just flip up  the flap and push you finger from the bottom thru the holes in the case and it pops right up.  Puting it back in is just as easy.Remember that if you use a case it may not fit in this case as it is meant to be used with just the iphone by itself.  If your like me and want the best of both worlds I would recommend the the following case and screen protectot that work very well with this case.  This is what I own and what I use.  They work very nicely together and look awesome.  They protect the iphone without adding extra bulk and allow the natural look of the iphone to shine thru.  The only negative is that the case will not protect the iphone as well as a completly enclosed rubber type should you drop it on pavement.Low profile snap on case:[..]Front Screen protector:This works the best as it has both a front and back peel off layer to help you install it well.  It also is adhesive free and lays down really nicely right onto the glass making a perfect seal and stays in place really well.[...]Bluetooth Headset:This works great even in noisy environment.  I am picky about my headset.  I can hear really well and so can the other person even in noisy environment.  Finally a bluetooth headset that works well.  And it plays nice with the iphone.[...]Get all of these products and you will be a happy owner.
summary: Works Great.  Would recommend.  Review includes addition add on products.

reviewText: I love Nokia phones, their service has been great (needed it only once) their phones are always solidly built and have great features. The 5MP camera produces very nice photos though some photo's taken at different angles produced differing effects on color and exposure but it still did produce very clear photos.The GPS, Mapping, Here & Now apps are great utilities. I love the fact that I can download maps for most parts of the world as and when needed. With a caveat though, while most major cities are mapped you may need a map when going into rural areas going by my experience, I should add US maps are the most comprehensive.I miss having a radio, not sure why Nokia has not enabled this feature regardless of WP8 not enabling FM radio's, many websites have reported that the 620 will not have this feature enabled. Deal breaker? probably! I listen to FM often enough that I may have foregone this model though I do have older portable media players that do support FM now I have to now carry two items on walks/jogs!!! This sucks Nokia!I like Nokia music and the fact that you can download a set to your phone for offline listening but haven't used it much since I have to carry my PMP anyway so I end up using that instead since I switch between FM & music!!! Kind of defeats the purpose of the MP on the phone!!!! Nokia are you listening?The size of the phone is perfect (for me at least) since I do not watch movies/tv shows. on it, podcasts yes, for which the screen is large enough. WP8 has all the free apps I need for my use so no complaints there. Nokia has a bunch of various free utilities that will serve most needs.Overall a very nice phone for the price. I could have used a SIP phone utility within the OS without having to install a third party client that will expose my contacts! Definitely recommend if you don't care for the FM radio!
summary: Great Phone - Definitely Value for Money

Very lightweight and comfortable.And finally the sound is flawless. The bass explodes!I'm very happy with this product. Totally recomend it.

reviewText: Pros: USB charging, looks nice, has nice feel to it, sliding case makes putting the phone in it quite easy.Cons: Adds weight and size to carry; Function buttons are too recessed when phone is in the case;Audio adapter is necessary because of recessed plug and is just another small gadget piece to carry around and avoid losing;Occasional use of the USB charging requires swapping cases if you don't want to leave it in the case and carry around the extra size and weight. (review written by Mrs. D)

I bought this for a recent trip to Baja, as well as the iPhone 4 version for my sis. They both worked as advertised. She dunked hers underwater on at least one occasion and it was completely dry. Mine passed the papertowel test (in the kitchen sink) just fine as well, but I admit I was not brave enough to take mine underwater since my phone is brand new.The locking mechanism is fairly easy to figure out and stays secure. It was water/air tight. I put one of those moisture absorbers in the bottom to avoid condensation (never had any). I took mine on an all day ATV trip where it rained the entire time, and used it to take pictures along the way. The dust/dirt and rain stayed out, and the pictures came out great. Just make sure the camera spot is clear (I had a couple pictures where the neck/string attachment got in the way - my bad).  Great at keeping the sand out too while at the beach.  Just make sure you don't open it until you're some place clear of dust and sand, so you don't get any sand particles inside the case.One caviat: I took my phone out of its case the first time I used this, and the phone's ZAGG cover (scratch proof cover that I had professionally installed) stuck quite severely to the inside of this plastic case. During my attempt to remove the phone and separate it from the plastic, the ZAGG cover started to pull off and I now have a small bubble in it. After that, I made sure to leave my iPhone case on when inserted in the bag, and it didn't stick much at all (and was never difficult to separate after that).
Easy to put on. Actually came with 3 screen protectors. This is a great product and i recommend this to anyone looking for a protector.
This car charger has been great!  On a recent long trip, it allowed us to charge both of our phones at the same time, which is exactly why I bought it.  Can't say enough good things about it.
love it thank you

reviewText: So this was instinctively my first thought on getting an Xbox headset, because it's wireless. Why? Well - If in between a game break I wanted to walk away for a second - all I needed to do was put down the controller and go do. But like the reviews - This is a bad idea. The ear-loop is also terrible. Constantly falling out and off the ear! Some of the veterans laughed when I told them the type of headset I had. They quickly said sell it and get a nice Turtle Beach headset. If you'e going to game, 1 ear isn't enough - you need surround sound and good headset to deliver. The other thing is I have to talk very loudly to be heard. I can hear very well though :)
summary: Terrible ear-loop and you must speak loudly to be heard

reviewText: This is a very convenient gadget for my car. The dual port charger allows me to charge both my iPhone5 and my iPad2 in the car at the same time. It's very powerful and seems to charge much faster than any other chargers that I have tried. It's also very small and lightweight, making it easy to throw in the glove box when not in use."

There is a lot of garbage chargers around that are just straight up cheap. I mean seriously  how can you ship me something for free from China for $2.99 and still make a profit unless you are selling a really crummy product? NOT the case with this charger. It is very fast and its not some cheap fire hazard. Feels good and what more is there to say? reviewText: After buying and returning a crappy $20 plastic case from my local Verizon store, (I should have known) I decided to give this one a try. I was very pleased when it arrived because it was exactly what I was looking for. The "rubberized" feel of the product is perfect...it's not so rubbery that it's hard to slip in my pocket, but does provide adequate grip when holding my phone. The two pieces snap together well and there is no movement of the phone within the case, and it doesn't make any creaking noise like the one from Verizon did. All ports and buttons are fully accessible and exactly placed. The one problem I think I may have, which is not unique to this case, is it's a bit more difficult to use the slide down bar on the top of the screen. The best thing about this case is that it's cheap enough that if it breaks or gets damaged enough, I just buy another one.
summary: Solid, high-quality alternative to the overpriced in-store selection

reviewText: Compared to Galaxy or iPhone, I would give this an average rating (maybe 3 stars).But as a free phone (or 1 phone) for your Verizon plan, this is a slam dunk great deal.Kyocera makes a solid phone. Durable, can sustain being dropped, fairly intuitive.Obviously the big feature is water resistance (*NOT* water-proof). You can't go diving with this or anything like that. But if you spill some coffee or water on it, if it's dropped in a puddle, no big deal. Very neat feature.If you're undecided about operating system, do yourself a HUGE favor and get an Android phone like this one. It has way more aps, way more features, better browsing, etc, than Windows or any other operating systems.Speakers are better than average. Screen size better than average. If you've got a $100 budget for a new phone, check out Samsung Galaxy 3, the Note 2, or you might even catch the Samsung Galaxy Mega on sale. But for a free phone with plan, this is one of the best you will find.
summary: If signing up for Verizon, this is your best pick for a free Android phone
