Arrived earlier than expected. .. a gift for someone facing several hour bus rides on a regular basis- when his phone inevitably died-  this charger allows extended use, recharges quickly, functions as promised... no more carrying charger cords and plugs and maybe losing them... no more borrowing chargers... he's got it covered with this easily portable unit!
fits well, nice color, not cheaply made, bought for a friend they said they love it will buy more in the future

First Look: Arrived in a very nice box, unit is shining new, nice carrying pouch, USB cable. A+ for presentation and could be a very good gift for someone special. Unit came pre-charged but follow instructions... charge it for a minute or so before use. After that, it's as simple as plug it in. Fast charged my HTC EVO 4G from almost empty to full in a very short time... sorry forgot to time the charging time because I was overly excited over this new toy. After that I charged it using an AC-USB charger until all 5 green LED's are lit. Concept: Neat and Concise. The battery extender could also be charged by a computer via its USB cable. Then the same USB cable could be flipped over to charge the phone; in my case, I had to use an additional mini USB to micro USB charging adapter. So 1 cable, 1 bat-ext, 1 adapter, all in a single pouch. A+ for compact. A+ for simplicity and nice touch on the little status button that tells you how much juice is left. Industrial Design: Clean line and 'Apple' like although the enclosure squeaks a little when it's being squeeze. And because of the shining effect, expect fingerprints magnet! Buff the prints off using the soft case, and it looks marvelous! Overall, well built and no gap, which show excellent workmanship and attention to details. Markings are sharp and no blemish found. Don't know about how safe it is as there is no UL Listing Mark on it; could be a concern for a rechargeable Li-Ion battery, which is known to go 'Kaboom' when being over-charged. Has some weight feel to it...feel like it's stocky! Good, I am expecting beefy juice out of this bad boy!Since it's full charge 8 days ago, it now has lost one green LED without being used. Assuming that the unit discharges linearly, it would take 8*5=40 days to completely discharge... Recognizing that this a false assumption and theoretically at best, so don't go jumping all over me now! I will give the unit another 8 days to check if it would lose another LED. Then loading and cycling tests of the unit will begin. Stay tune.Update Jan 2013 - After 2 years of using this device, it has paid for itself many times over. The battery appears to reach it's life cycle so I have to charge it more often to ensure I have backup power while traveling. It's still a nice unit when it was introduced at the time... simple to use, just remember to plug it in the night before your trip to have a full charge ready for use.... today there are many similar options to choose from other companies, and there are newer models from the same company... worth a second look.

When I first examined the review sample of this charger I thought that it was just another charger like the dozens that I have tested. However, this one has some excellent features that many of the generic ones lack.What sets this apart from the other two-port chargers is the intelligent electrical protection. It has current overload protection like many other higher end chargers, but also detects overheating. Another safeguard that this has that many other chargers lack is when your device is fully charged the charger kicks down into minimal charging mode. That feature will help to extend your battery life, which for me in important because I own an iPad and a Samsung Tab 3, both of which have sealed internal batteries.The two ports on this charger are rated at 1 and 2.1 Amps respectively. The 2.1 Amp port charges my tablets as quickly as the OEM chargers that came with them, so I trust the claimed specs.Other features that I love are the fact that this is a sealed unit, so the electrical components are not exposed to the salt air near where I live. What I mean by that is other chargers, and especially generic ones, can be disassembled by unscrewing the contact tip. This is supposed to allow you to change out an internal fuse if it fails. Most of the quality chargers - like this one - now feature a completely sealed design with the more sophisticated electrical protections that I mentioned.Finally, this is compact at 1.2 x 2.4 inches. It will fit a lighter receptacle in even the tightest places.

When I selected the Kensington SoundWave iPhone 4 compatible sound amplifying car mount, I considered it an inexpensive gimmicky item.  When the package arrived, I quickly opened it and attached my iPhone to the Kensington SoundWave.  Immediately, I knew my first impression was wrong.The Kensington SoundWave sound amplifying car mount doubles the iPhone 4's volume without any battery drain.  The package contains both window and A/C vent mounts for selecting your vehicle's best option.  Flexible arms on the pivoting cradle allow for easy insertion or removal, while keeping the iPhone securely in place.  The cradle is also designed to allow the charging cable (not included) to stay connected during use.While the sound is significantly amplified, there is a small amount of distortion.  Some of the base is lost, resulting in a slightly tinnier sound.  However, this is the extent of the distortion as there is no additional grain or fuzziness caused by the amplification.In states like CA or MN, using the window mount may be illegal.  In these cases, using the simple to install A/C vent mount is advised.  Two spring locking vent arms on the top are pushed into the venting, while a third bottom bracket uses the mounting's weight to stabilize the A/C vent mount.  The cradle is snapped onto the mount and is ready for use.  The location of the mounted iPhone facilitates use for hands free applications such as using the phone on speakerphone or following a GPS navigation application's (application sold separately) directions.If you're looking for an inexpensive iPhone 4 car mounting bracket, the Kensington SoundWave mounting system is a worthy option with the advantage of amplified sound.  Install is simple, and Kensington's design does precisely what they claim it does.PROS:Amplifies sound from your iPhoneIncludes a window and A/C vent braceNo battery drainInexpensive useful deviceCONS:Amplified sound has a slight tinny quality
summary: Sounds Like a Good Idea: A Kensington SoundWave iPhone 4 Compatible Sound Amplifying Car Mount Review

It seems like everything that comes into the house now needs a USB port to power or charge it, so always on the lookout for good solutions. This is one of the smallest units I have ever come across, and it makes it easy to carry (and get carried off).=== The Good Stuff ===* The unit is compact. It measures 1 13/16" x 2 1/4" x 1 1/8", and weighs 2.4 ounces. It easily fits in a pocket, and I can pretty much palm the whole thing in my hand. It accepts 100-240V, 50/60Hz, so ideal for travel, and the plug folds into he unit making it a nice cubic shape. There are no LEDs, and there are two power ports rated at 1.0 and 2.1A.* There are no rough edges to the plastic, and the corners are nicely rounded. There is a little bit of a gap between the seams, but nothing major.* I was able to charge an iPhone4 and iPad3, and charging times seemed comparable to what I get with an Apple supplied charger. I charged both units at the same time, but didn't check to see if the total charge time slowed down.=== The Not-So-Good Stuff ===* The markings identifying the capacity of the power ports can be a little hard to read, especially in dim light.* As with all fold-in plugs, these are a likely first failure point. There is a cost for the convenience of not impaling yourself with the plug when you dig in your bag.=== Summary ===For a small form factor charger, I like it. It is easy to grab it and throw it in your pocket. The unit ships with instructions and a warranty card, but no USB cables. All in all, a nice little charger that comes in handy.

I purchased this from Amazon to insure I got a real Apple charger. There are many knockoffs and fakes (complete with Apple wording on the back) so I am glad Amazon now offers this themselves. I saved about $5 vs. an Apple Store and shipping was free.I thought all chargers were pretty much the same, until I read a detailed technical article which both tested and disassembled chargers from several name-brand companies as well as some knock-offs/fakes. Apparently the Apple has the "cleanest" power output of any phone charger, including those from such excellent rival companies as Samsung (only an HP tablet charger was rated higher). This same article also lambasts Apple for charging $29.95 for the classic cube charger - but you may have noticed that the Apple Store price is now just $19.95 and the Amazon price is even $5 less. So for the revised pricing, this charger imho is a "best buy".Note that this is rated to put out 5 watts, but tested as putting out 6 watts, 20% more. In addition, most chargers delivered less power as they came closer to full charge, but the Apple continued to deliver more power. Although reviewers note that this compact cube charger only puts out half as much power as an iPad charger (even less than the increased 12 watt output on the iPad 4 charger), I have easily charged an iPad 2, in sleep mode, with my 5W Apple cube charger. It really puts out! Charging times are naturally longer, and you WON'T be charging an iPad 3 or 4 while playing a power hungry game - you will barely stay even with the power consumption - but if you can accept the longer charging times, the Apple cube charger WILL work.I was hauling around a 12 watt iPad 4 charger for all my Apple (and non-Apple!) charging needs, until I read the article and realized I wasn't overloading the Apple cube charger by using it to charge bigger devices than the phone, Touch, and Mini devices it was designed for. It charges at half the rate on larger devices, but for travel that still means even an iPad charges up overnight. I also use the Apple cube now on my Google Nexus 4 phone etc. simply due to the higher quality of the power output. I haven't noticed any slowdown in charge time on non-Apple devices.I will link to the power charger reviews in the comments section.
summary: Amazon's is a REAL Apple charger & the Apple charger provides one of the cleanest outputs

This product works exactly as advertised. In fact, based on what I had read in the other reviews I would actually say that it works better than advertised. The suction cup works so well that the only thing I can figure is that the person that had problems with it did not understand how it worked. It is not the standard type of suction cup where you simply press it against the windshield and hope it holds. This suction cup works by placing it against the windshield and then turning the knob counterclockwise in order to pull the center portion away from the windshield. As it does this it creates a vacuum seal that so tight that you are more likely to dislodge the windshield than you are to remove this device from it.The iPhone fits perfectly into the holder and the aux cable is nice and thin. I actually used the phone in this setup when I wanted to have a conference call and the other person's voice coming out of the car stereo worked great for that purpose.The only caveat I would list is that if your car has a long sloping windshield you may find the extension not quite long enough to bring the phone within reach. You may be able to compensate for this by mounting it up higher. I drive a Jeep Wrangler and it has a pretty vertical windshield so I don't have this problem.

A common issue I've had with most external battery packs is that you never know how much juice is left inside-but this one fixes that problem with the simple solution of adding a small digital screen that tells you the percent of battery remaining. This 10000mAh battery pack is a well designed battery that would surely be useful to anyone who finds themselves running low on their smartphone batteries midway throughout the day. That being said, there are a couple of flaws with it that one might want to take note of.First off, the design-it's around the size of a typical wallet, and it's heavy enough that it would be uncomfortable to carry around in your jeans, but light enough that you wouldn't feel it in a bag. The entire battery is enclosed in a plastic shell, and there's only one power button, which you can press to turn on the device, or double press to turn on the flashlight. There are two USB out ports and one micro-USB input port for charging the battery itself, as well as a simple screen which displays the percentage of battery remaining. It also came with a charging cable with interchangeable plugs (for iOS devices & Micro-USB), and a nice handy travel bag. All of the above work well except for the screen which I found to have poor viewing angles. You have to look at it from a slight slant for the text to be clear. Nevertheless, this is only a small issue I have, and since the screen only displays the battery percentage, it doesn't matter too much.Onto the battery itself, it has a 10000mAh capacity-which should be able to recharge a phone multiple times. After a week or so of testing, it was able to charge my Nexus 4 phone around 3 times before I had to recharge the battery itself. This battery pack will definitely last long enough for most extended trips, and it's also great for people with multiple devices. One note though, is that it does take quite a while to recharge the battery. It took me around 8 hours to fully recharge it from 0-100%, so one does have to plan ahead.Overall, I really love this battery pack. I think it's just portable enough and it's large capacity allows it to last me around a week before I have to recharge it. That alone makes it quite convenient. I can just throw it in my bag and not ever worry about running out of battery. One thing I didn't mention much about was the flashlight, and that's because it's really just an average flashlight. It's not that bright, but it works. I suppose in some situations it might be useful to have, but I personally don't think it's necessary. I'd recommend this item for people who struggle with battery issues on the smartphones we use so heavily these days. There might be a couple flaws with this product, but it's still a very solid product for its price.SUMMARY==The Good==- Well constructed- Large capacity battery- Display shows % of battery remaining- 2 USB ports to charge multiple devices- Comes with a flexible charging cable capable of charging just about any device==The Not-So-Good==- Takes a while to charge- Screen has poor viewing anglesFeel free to ask any questions in the comment section below!
summary: The battery pack I've been waiting for

These Apple adapters have been around forever - in one version or another, although they all look the same - and there are now many adapters that do similar things for less money. That said, these truly do "just work" with Macs, and they provide a quick and easy way to add extra Ethernet ports to any Mac with a spare USB port.You can attach as many of these as you have free USB ports, and you'll gain that many Ethernet ports, although speed is going to go from marginal (10/100) to worse (10/100 spread over numerous ports) once the USB controller gets saturated.If you have a computer which isn't a Mac, buy a different adapter - it'll be cheaper. If you have a newer Mac and don't need more than one additional Ethernet port, get the Thunderbolt version since it's much faster. Otherwise, or if you want to add even more ports, get this. It's reasonably small, not unattractive, and fully functional without issue.
summary: Good buy for older Macs, avoid otherwise

I'm a self-admitted phone nut, and I've carried around a Nexus 4, Galaxy S4, Galaxy S4 Active, HTC One, HTC One M8, and iPhone 5S over the past year. I don't have a very strong allegiance to operating system or brand. So, without lots of conjecture:Things the Galaxy S5 Does Well:*It feels nice in the hand. Not quite as natural as smaller devices, but less slippery and heavy than the HTC One M8.*The "one hand mode" is a brilliant idea. Swipe side-center-side, and the active portion of the display shifts to that side at the same size as the iPhone 5S (a coincidence, I'm sure!). I can't express how wonderful this feature is on a device this size.*The fingerprint scanner is fast and reasonably accurate.*Sound quality from the speaker is decent. The personalized audio enhancement, on the other hand, is truly impressive.*USB 3.0 is speedy when transferring files, and charges the device incredibly fast.*The display -- while not professionally accurate -- is beautiful.*Build quality is excellent. There's no creaking or flexing here.*Bluetooth audio on voice calls and music is probably the best I've experienced.Things the Galaxy S5 Does Acceptably:*The camera quality is decent, but macro photos are exceedingly difficult to take, and taking a picture of something lit (a sign, LED/LCD panel, et cetera) causes the focus to go nuts.*Micro/Mini USB cables aren't going to work with the USB 3.0 interface, but it uses a standard USB 3.0 cable.*TouchWiz is dramatically improved, but after a few hours, I went back to Nova Launcher. (Seriously, Samsung... I don't understand why you think the sanctity of your product is violated by my desire to move the Applications button from the right to the center.)Things the Galaxy S6 Can Improve On:*While the camera quality is decent, it doesn't hold a candle to the iPhone 5S in terms of convenience.*The plastic feels nice, but it's still plastic. It's time to use better materials.*It's at the very edge of what you could use with one hand. Yes, I get "Bigger phones are the trend!" So were Walkmans.*As heavily as Samsung wants enterprise clients moving to their devices, they've continually overlooked simple features, like a physical "silent mode" button.*To date, the AT&T; version of this phone has a locked bootloader, which seriously limits your ability to customize the phone.*The current implementation of fingerprint scanning isn't acting as a surrogate for a PIN or password (as it does on the iPhone 5S). This means that if you're connecting this to an Exchange server, and the admin hasn't enabled biometrics in the security policy, you'll be forced to use a PIN to unlock the phone.So, is it better than the HTC One M8? Maybe. Personally, I like the way it feels, and how the current iteration of TouchWiz is closer to the stock Google Play Edition. And again, the "one hand mode" is a godsend. On the other hand, the M8 looks every bit as expensive as it costs.Personally, I matched my S5 with a Galaxy Gear Neo, and they're great together. If you're willing to buy in to Samsung's ecosystem, the choice is much simpler.
summary: Lots of benefits. Lots of shortcomings. Still a great device.

During a recent camping trip, this charger was invaluable! The case is plastic, and makes the overall size of the phone bigger slightly (may be too big for some pockets.)  The gray outer snap-in part of the case seemed flimsy (which cost this review a star), but so far, after a week in the mountains, it hasn't broken.  I left the case and charger on the phone the whole time, charging it at night when I was near an outlet.Spending 12 to 15 hours a day out in the field meant certain battery drainage, but this kept me charged and working the whole day!  You can turn it off (via a button on the back) when you don't need it to power the phone.  Four green lights on the back tell you how much your battery charger is charged. (Four green lights means full.) There is a fire wire slot on the side so that you can charge the phone AND the charger at the same time when not in use.Two thumbs up!
love it

This pair of cases for the iPhone 5 is incredibly good value. The transparent one doesn't look great on a black phone, but I bet would be fine on a white one.The cases are really easy to put on and take off. They improve the grip of the phone and have a slight raised edge that adds protection for the screen.Recommended for anyone who wants to avoid scratches and dings on the edges of their iPhone.Update January 16, 2013: I dropped my iPhone about 2 feet onto a concrete floor. I was scared to pick it up and see the damage. But the Belkin case protected it completely.
summary: Case adds a nice grip, without too much extra size or weight

This protector goes on wet and it is far and away the easiest to install I have ever used. In fact it is the first screen protector I have installed on any device, e-readers, tablets, phones, which has absolutely no bubbles and is aligned more or less perfectly. That is because you can slide it around to align it and easily squeegie bubble out while it is wet.I did follow instructions and took the battery out and let it dry for at least 12 hours after installation which was a minor nuisance. The results are worth the wait. I have had this on the phone for 2-3 months and although the film is self healing to a large extent I have managed to put some permanent marks on it. I can only imagine what the screen would look like by now without it. My phones live a rough life.

I wanted to minimize the stuff I had to carry on a two-week trip, so I was looking for something that would charge more than one USB device at a time.  This was the best compromise between size and price.  It has a very nice "grippy" surface that makes it easy to grab and hold.  It also charges whatever is plugged into it.  There is a port for Apple and a port for everything else.  I never bothered noting which was which.  I just plugged things in, and they got charged.

This Yubi USB charger is just what the doctor ordered. My wife and I travel quite a bit together and between the 4 iProducts we have, there always seems to be one that's dead. Now that we can charge two at a time, we've been able to keep them all going, which is nice. On top of all our Apple gear, it was also able to charge our Kindles, which came in handy.The unit itself is well-built and seems almost too slick for such an inexpensive item. It looks great in my car and I like the red ring light around it (see the pictures above).Ultimately, if you have a lot of devices, this will be a life-saver.Note: A sample was provided for unbiased review.

This car charger is awesome because it's about the size of a standard charger, but it can fit two USB devices.  One slot is 1A and one for 2.1A so it can do both larger devices (iPads) and smaller (iPhones.  Comes with a micro-USB cable which is useful for me, since my speakerphone unit from Jabra uses it.  Definitely worth the value and decently made.  If you dislike lighting, this does glow a little bit which means that there is a LED hidden inside.  The black one will glow blue on the end around the edges.  Not completely disturbing or anything, but if people don't like the lighting side, you've been warned. :)  Unsure what the white one glows as since I haven't plugged one in.
This is a very useful tool.The size is just perfect.I use these every day for my tablet.The pack has such nice colors .

This is my third Rokform case, for my third different iPhone, and I must say, it is very disappointing.I love the original aluminum case on my 4s, because it was thin, stylish, and protective.  That was the best iPhone case, but attenuation issues were somewhat understandable.I got the v2 for my iPhone 5, and as cool as the case looked, and as protective as it was, it was too thick and the charger port opening dug into my finger when using it one handed. That was a deal breaker, but I sold the case along with the 5 and washed my hands of it.So, for my 5s, I had already tried a few cases, but none of them were great, so I looked again at Rokform, hoping they had fixed the issues with the v2 (Seriously, why not go back to the original Rokbed aluminum style?). They did fix the bottom of the case, and it feels less bulky, but it also feels like they used the same cheap, tacky plastic Samsung uses in their phones. Don't be fooled! Good polycarbonate (5c, Lumia series) is not the same grade or quality, regardless of the name that is liberally used, as this (Galaxy series, Rokbed v3). Now I am stuck with this heap because it would cost me my expedited shipping ($15) to send it back, and it isn't worth the time or trouble.tl;dr: This is not a great case, and Rokform should feel bad and sell the remainder to some cheap case maker and start from scratch. Today they lost a customer.

First the Pro's:Useful dock: It has its advantages over simply laying it down on your desk/nightstand, I grant that! I like that the dock app turns the phone into a clock with some essential apps tucked into the screen.Well constructed: The dock is solid it seems and wont topple the phone - thats good!Audio  out: Good to have this if you use external speakers, however I'm not so crazy about the fact that the sound switches to the phones speakers if you happen to exit the samsung dock app with the phone docked to start up another music playerCONS:Major flaw: A flaw Samsung built int its app for the dock (app is specific to the dock/phone) is that it did not include the weather with the clock, not even a link to a weather app. in other words you cannot customise this screen. That sucks baaad! - Minus one major STAR for thisAudio out: I said it above - if you exit the dock app with the phone docked the audio reverts to the phone - Minus one major STAR for thisEssentially Samsung could have done a better job with this dock and the spp - since they do not work w/o each other! All said, I'd still buy the dock ... it has its uses, but I'd never pay the full price for it i.e. 39.99 or even 24.99. I'd prefer to pay 14.99 for a half hearted product!I must add that the seller "Alwayz-on-sale" has the right attitude though - I give them ***** (5 stars) for customer service!

I thought something was up when I was tracking the shipment from Almighty Wholesale, the seller.  The shipment came directly from China and mailed via China Mail to USPS.  When I plug my phone in, it does not show as charging.  It's either completely defective, or is charging at a rate much less than 2.0 amps.  The original charger that came with the phone is 2.1 amps.  Can't believe that .1 amps would make a difference, but. . . . . .Of course, to return this I am responsible for the charges to mail it back to China.  Why Bother.  This is what I get for buying off-brand items.  I was fooled as it clearly stated "Samsung OEM 2.0 Amp Travel Charger" which to me means "Original Equipment Manufacturer."Don't buy this item, and don't buy from Almighty Wholesale.Update 06-12-2013:  I would like to say that the seller Almighty Wholesale has been very accommodating since my post.  They are shipping a new charger, and did not require that I return the defective one.  Additionally, they tested the new one prior to shipping.  I will update on the charger itself when I receive it, but I would like to state that Almighty Wholesale has provided quality customer service in replacing the defective charger.

While I have been enjoying Samsung phablets for while now, it is clear why some folks stay will smaller format Apple devices. As a tech-savvy engineer and former wireless industry analyst and consultant, I haven't seen commercial software as bug-laden and user hostile as Kies.It would be easy to go on forever about ever problem with Kies, but suffice it to say it is such a bad product that only phrase used to describe the Yugo is fitting "quality reaches a new low."  Various iterations of Kies crash or hang during the synchronization process.  There have been constant communication errors with the device. Some items would mysterious only partially sync -- partial playlists or songs from the playlists would be absent.  It would hang on podcasts.With Kies 3.0, Samsung has eliminating most of the problems by eliminating virtually all of the features.  There is no synchronization or importation of Itunes elements (e.g. playlists, podcast). After a forced upgrade from 2.6 to 3.0, the user notices all of the functionality has been eliminated.  No explanation has been given and there is no telephone support.
summary: Samsung Kies synchronization software - quality reaches a new low, beware if you want to this phone for media

I have tested the case on my iPhone 5s, and have been using it for ~4 days. I have found the case to be ideal for what I have looked for in a protective case. The case effectively protects the entire phone and all of its ports, completely encasing the phone in its protective shell.The design is very attractive. The black case looks good even on my gold iPhone. The glossy portions of the case have maintained their gloss, and don’t appear to scratch very easily.The case provides very good drop and impact protection while adding very little bulk. I switched from a spigen slim armor case which was even slimmer, but this New Trent case offers more complete protection with the built-in screen protector and port covers.Additionally, the case still gives access to the TouchID on the home button even though it is protected. The unit I tested seemed to have a slight manufacturing flaw in this part, but it did not impact usability.I have greater peace of mind with this case on my iPhone than I have had with any other case that I have used. Anyone who is looking for a case that has just the right ratio of protection to minimal bulk, this is the absolute best case I have found.Overall, I would give this product 5 stars.

reviewText: This works great.  The volume controls are easy.  I have it set up toswitch easily between Skype on my laptop and my cell phone.

I'm not generally a big fan of screen protectors... I've never had much luck getting them installed without bubbles or getting them lined up perfectly square.However, I want to start running with my iPod which means it is going to be subjected to more abrasive conditions than my phone is usually subjected to.The screen protector is fairly thick and I get the sense that it will provide good protection.  Installation is pretty typical for screen protectors -- if you are really lucky, you'll get it lined up correctly.  They provide a "cardboard" piece to try to remove the bubbles but that piece is pretty worthless.  Your standard plastic loyalty card from the grocery store is more effective.The biggest problem is that this does cause the display to be "crystallized" -- so the beautiful crisp display that Apple has spent so much time and technology developing and for which you have probably plunked down HUGE bucks has just been reduced to something with the clarity of a blackberry from the 1990s.If you use your phone to watch videos or anything that is higher def than email, then you will be disappointed with this protector.  However, if you just want to keep the screen from getting hacked up and you don't worry the screen clarity, this will do the job...[NCJVR]
summary: fits well but interferes with clarity of the display.

Highly recommend not to charge your phone while it is in your jean or jacket pockets as any hard movement of your phone charging jack by the flex connector may/will ultimately mis-align the charging jack in the phone.I do like the portable size, ability to re-charge the unit with the built-in AC prongs, USB port to charge another phone and convenient (emergency only) micro-USB flex arm. It is not too rubbery and does not collect dust. The fit is perfect and all ports are exposed. The form factor make the Note 3 look a bit like an oversized iPhone 5 - only better, way better, which is not a bad thing at all.  The grip is good and not slippery at all. It also works well with Tech Armor screen protector, creating a perfect seal for the body and the screen. I highly recommend this case.

However, it is rather bulky and you have to move some protectors to charge the phone or to silence it.  I like the screen protector that comes with the Otter Box (one of the best in my opinion) but Gorilla glass is hard so I don't use a screen protector.This case is barely lager than the iPhone itself.  It has a nice cushioned and grippy feel.  I have no problems pushing or using any of the buttons on the phone.  To me, Apple spent a ton of money sweating the small details of how the iPhone feels so I enjoy that with this case it feels like an iPhone.Overall, if you bang the crap out of your phone, this is not really the case you want.  However, if you take care of your phone but want a modicum of protection against accidents then you will be very happy with this case.  I love the feel of the iPhone and in this case it feels like that is all that I am holding.I was provided a sample product for a fair and honest review.

reviewText: Awesome cover.  It feels great.  Its slim enough with great protection.  A great buy (if you like magpul products). Recommend it.

Ah, the Apple ecosystem, with its seemingly never ending pile of whizbang add-on products.  All those new devices have the new(ish) Lightning connector, so a whole new generation of those add-ons is growing.  Ok, yeah, as an Android user, I do get a little jealous.  But anyhow, everyone needs a charging cable, right?  Zeetron's offering isn't a simple cable with the right connectors on either end, but instead a cable that lights up to indicate it's plugged in, something is plugged into it and is charging, and/or or that something is now fully charged.  Nifty enough, but does it work?  To find out, I borrowed a pair of iPhones, a iPad, and an iPad Mini.  As I pretty much expected, the cable performed it's job just fine across all four devices.  And also as expected, given Zeetron's own admission to it, proper fit with cases was a variable.  The housing at the tip is just a little too fat for the opening in some cases.  That leaves a few choices - skip this cable, remove the case for charging, get a different case, or modify the case you have so the cable will fit.  I know which I would do (modify), but not everyone is going to be up for that.  As a unit, the cable is solidly made, and I have no concerns over its longevity and ability to take some abuse.  While I don't particularly *need* a cable with such a gizmo on the end, I admit I'd love to have a similar product for my pile of devices that use micro USB connectors.  Besides, nothing about the aforementioned ecosystem is about need - it's about want.*Disclosure: I was contacted by Zeetron and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of reviewing it.*

I like this stylus for a number of reasons. First and foremost, it performs superbly. The conductive mesh tip is picked up by my tablet every time I place it against the screen with no lag time to start sensing it. The tip is actually squishy, which I didn't expect since most of the conductive rubber-tipped styli I've used in the past had hard tips. This was a nice surprise, as it means using the stylus is a much more fluid feeling activity where slightly pressing or easing up on the stylus doesn't mean it leaves the screen. It also means this stylus doesn't make that awful tapping noise as you write, draw, or play games with it compared to most. It's almost dead-silent to use.Secondly, I really like the look of this pen. The two-tone color scheme gives it a really professional look, and the clip is functional as well as making it look like a higher-class writing device than your standard run-of-the-mill no-name stylus.And last but not least, I like the size of this stylus and the included ballpoint pen feature. The newest version of this stylus is a little longer than its original incarnation. It's still shorter than a standard ballpoint pen, but it's just write for carrying along with a tablet, and it's very comfortable to use both as a stylus and as a pen. The pen itself hides away with a twist of the pen, and the ink is easily refilled by pulling off the end of the pen and inserting a newIMP62R pen refill. Writing with the pen did take a moment to get used to, as the pen doesn't stick out very far from the stylus' rounded end, but after a few moments I found myself not even thinking about it.Extremely happy with this product, especially for the price paid ($8.95) and the fact that New Trent often runs Buy 1, Get 1 Free promotions on this item. Highly recommended!
summary: Great stylus that looks good and creates a smooth response

reviewText: I've purchased three (3) of these so far.  I returned one, which was definitely NOT an authentic Verizon cell phone charger.  Some of these marketplace vendors are sending out junk, and in addition to that many will sell the charger as new and you can easily tell it was used which happen to me.  But, I found a vendor on here that actually sells authentic Verizon cell phone chargers as pictured in the product details, and that's the only one I would trust which is WirelessWonderz.The one I had purchased that was not authentic and obviously used was sold by a marketplace vendor (I forgot the company name), but the charger was actually FULLFILLED by Amazon, and I have no clue how Amazon could send out junk like that without checking it out.  So, if its sold by and shipped by Amazon or WirelessWonderz I would buy it.I give the product a 5 star rating because it works just fine on my kindle fire, kindle keyboard and my HTC Incredible 2.  I think folks that are buying this charger should definitely leave some negative feedback on the merchants website that you purchased it from if you find that its an inferior product.  By the way, I purchased this product from Verizon originally back in 2010 when they were selling them in their stores, and I can easily compare mine to the ones I have ordered and quickly spot a fake or piece of junk. So, that's how I know the one I recently purchased is authentic.
summary: Authentic if you purchase from the right vendor

I have owned an Apple iPhone 4 for nearly three years.  I couldn't live without it and don't plan on upgrading to another iPhone anytime soon.  They are too expensive.  I have grown much attached to the pair of wired earbuds that came with my iPhone.  The earbuds are one size fits all and are extremely comfortable to wear; I don't have to worry about gels falling off or getting stuck in my ear, and the microphone and controller work great.  Unfortunately, the wires can become very tangled and may take up to five minutes to untangle.  This can become annoying, especially when I am preparing for a long, leisurely walk.Afraid that I might lose the wired earbuds that came with my iPhone 4, I requested from the Amazon Vine Program the TYLT TUNZ Stereo Headphones.  It has six pairs of gels: 3 sizes (S, M, and L) of Comfort Gels and 3 sizes of Active Gels.  The Active Gels have plastic fins that fit securely in your ear.  Believe me; you will need extra pairs of these gels.  Having reviewed numerous wired earbuds in the past, I've learned that after two to six months of constant use, the gels have a tendency to fall off.  Sometimes they have gotten lost in my car.  Other times, they have become stuck in my ear canal and I've had to carefully pull them out; this always scares me.  This is why I always prefer the one-size-fits-all earbuds.The medium-size Comfort gels were already installed on the TYLT TUNZ earbuds when they arrived in their lime green protective packaging.  I didn't bother removing the gels.  Once removed, the integrity of the gels will have been compromised.  In other words, they won't fit as securely the next time I attempt to install them.  The medium-size gels fit comfortably inside my ear.  They never fell out while I walked, jogged or cleaned my apartment when wearing the earbuds.  Operating the earbuds is very basic.  I didn't even have to look at the short, easy-to-read manual.  The controller allows you to pause a song or answer a telephone call with one click, skip to the next song with two QUICK clicks, and back up to the previous song with three QUICK clicks.  Unfortunately, the controller doesn't have a volume control like the earbuds that came with my iPhone 4.The small manual, the limited one-year warranty, all six pairs of gels, the cable clip, and the earbuds can all be squeezed into a tiny black bag.  The bag reminds me of the rubber change purse that my dad still has.  When it is firmly squeezed, the mouth of the purse opens up.  The bag that came with the TYLT TUNZ is solid black with some lime green writing and is made of sleek, rubbery plastic.  I tossed it inside my gym bag, which has a black interior, and had a terrible time trying to locate it.  Lately, I've been keeping the small bag inside the lime-green box in which it arrived.  I can't lose it now.The wires are very thick and flat.  I've had other earbuds with flat wires that didn't tangle but the wires on the TYLT TUNZ earbuds are the thickest that I've ever seen.  They don't tangle and frustrate me, nearly giving me a heart attack, like the earbuds that came with my iPhone 4.  However, the earbuds aren't marked L or R for left and right ears, respectively, like other pairs of earbuds I've owned.  I just assume the wire that has the controller goes in my right ear; this has been the case with the other earbuds, both wired and wireless.The lack of a volume control and the fact that the sound quality is average or a little above average prevent me from giving the TYLT TUNZ wired earbuds the highest rating.  If it was less expensive, I would have given it five stars.  However, the price is approaching that of the more expensive wireless earbuds.  (Normally, I don't wear wireless earbuds because they are not worth the hassle of keeping them charged, always fall out of my ears and/or have poor sound quality.)  Overall, I don't find the TYLT TUNZ earbuds an adequate replacement for the earbuds that came with my Apple iPhone 4.  My search continues.Joseph B. Hoyos
summary: TYLT TUNZ Earbuds are Comfortable, Easy to Use, and Functional, But Expensive for an Average Quality Sound

I have bought a number of these items based on the strength of other reviewers. Now, I will add my five stars to the other enthusiasts. This is a powerful, reliable charger that will charge two devices at the same time. The reason I say that it is a must for traveling is because you can plug it into either a 120 V outlet or a 240 V outlet. In America, all outlets are 120 V, so you do not have to worry when you plug your Apple charger into the wall. However, when you travel, you may encounter countries that run 240 V electricity in their outlets. If you plug your Apple charger into one of these, you will fry your phone. Getting an outlet adapter will not solve this problem, even though you will have to do this anyway. You also need a charger that will step down the voltage from 240 V to 120 V in order to charge your devices. That is what this charger does, and using it while you travel will make it safe to charge your i-devices and android devices.The first one that I bought was defective. It would charge an iPhone 4, but not an iPhone 4s. All the others that I have gotten have been quite satisfactory though, and I highly recommend this product.

reviewText: Summary: Not a headset for audiophiles - a reasonably priced way to get phone functionality into your "use and abuse" headsets.  Great for phone calls.The headset comes with small, medium, and large silicone inserts - I switched easily to the small inserts but for whatever reason the left ear piece kept falling out (I was moving around a lot)  I've since foundFor sound quality I'd say they were not on par with any other $20 ear buds or the ones that come with your standard MP3 player.  I found the bass (typically where ear buds fall short) to be barely sufficient.  The price point was good on these - I don't treat my earbuds very well and am not about to spend a lot of money on something that is likely to get stepped on, left on an airplane, etc.If you want good sound quality you really need to get the over the ear headphones with the larger drivers, and you'll probably need to go to at least 320 bps on your MP3's or switch to a less lossy format.The microphone is quite small - almost unnoticible.  It's well placed and picks up sound very well - the person on the other side I stop using packaging tape as it was way too loud.  They performed well in a windy environment - talking on the phone while walking.With my iPod Nano the integrated switch gives me a pause / play and a skip track feature.  That said, I almost never use these with my ipod because the sound is lacking for music.Disclosure: I received this through Amazon Vine.  If you found this review helpful or have comments or questions, please let me know!
summary: Decent compromise of features for a daily use headset...

reviewText: I like the look and feel of this product. It does increase the sound quality of my iPhone. I also like the fact that the handset on the device weighs very little, and allows long conversations. I call my mother every week (my father passed away recently) and this process smoothes everything by a factor of 10.  Perfect.....as all is fine with no issues with batteries, or dropped calls due to signal.....Perfect.  With this Naive Union device (second one I have owned), I'm able to rest the phone in one spot that I know works, and trust in the cellular gods.The packaging includes plug adaptors to make it international. It's also has a regular micro USB charger; a micro USB cable to hook up the base to your computer for charging; an adaptor to make it possible for the older style of phone to fit into the cradle; and a manual written in 10 languages.Setup is easy.  The handset has status lights which make it easy to tell the state of charge.  Another great product.

I purchased this on whim during a gold box sale. So glad I did!It mounts in your cd slot. It doesn't go in deep so no fear of damaging the cd slot. I am still able to listen to cd music while its in place, although you have to remove it to eject a cd. Once its in place it holds very well, I have a sports car with a  rough ride and even when hitting potholes it stays in place. Once the phone/device is mounted you can swivel it a full 360 as well as slightly adjust it up and down. I use it with my iPhone 5 but it is so adjustable about any phone should fit fine.Pros: It should fit on any cars CD slot without issue. Well made for what it is, doesn't feel flimsy or easily breakable. Works fantastic!Cons: well not really a con for the device but I wish my cd slot was higher, or there was a way to raise the phone up higher, its a little low in my car due to the placement of the CD slot.Overall: Great product, great price and I use it every day. Keep in mind that your phone will be above the CD slot, so make sure thats a appropriate location for your phone. Also make sure it doesn't block any important car information screen.
summary: Great way to add a mount with no suction cups or screws.

reviewText: It's a tight fit plugging it into the power source in my 2002 VW Passat, but seems to work just fine.  The "head" has a white ring of light that illuminates when charging.

The Commando screen protector comes in a cardboard sleeve which contains two pre-cut films for the front and back of the iPhone 4/4S; a cardboard squeegee; a tiny square of microfiber cloth, and terse installation instructions on a small sheet.You need to clean the screen with the microfiber cloth, then peel the film from the sticky side of the protector, and apply; you then push the unavoidable bubbles towards the outside.Applying the film is very difficult. You need to position it the best you can while not leaving fingerprints and avoiding trapping dust between the film and the glass. You always end up with bubbles that the manufacturer promises will go away within 24 hours... Yeah right.24 hours later, the bubbles are still there looking ugly (although to be fair they really aren't noticeable when the screen is on). The film is not as pleasant to the touch as the iPhone's glass, but it's better than other protectors I've used.This protector film, being so thick, appears to offer somewhat improved protection compared to standard screen protectors. It's not a bad screen protector, but I'm not convinced that it's really any better than the el-cheapo you can pick up on ebay for a few bucks. In my opinion, it's not worth the hefty premium it demands.
summary: Good protection, decent "feel," very thick, difficult to apply

reviewText: This is a great car charger that does exactly what you need it to do. It looks like a genuine Apple product, so it is not at all an eye sore to have plugged in. It will charge your iPhone 5 up quickly. Hopefully this nice little charger won't get lost in the sea of sub-quality products that surround the technology accessory category - it is truly a must-have.

There was a lot to be excited about with this case: decent form factor, nice materials, front speaker deflectors, 2-piece slide apart construction and price. Unfortunately this case has two huge flaws and I regret the purchase.First, unlike every other case I've seen this case does not require you to press-to-hold the power button to turn it on and off. It turns on and off with any brief touch of the button. That means in your pocket or in your bag, or just picking it up wrong, anything that touches the button can turn the case on or off. I don't need to be constantly worrying about whether something hit the button when I need my phone to be charging.The second issue is the 500mA charging current. Simply stated you can not use your phone while charging from the case and expect your case to improve the charging level of your phone. Your phone will lose ground, albeit slower than without a charge at all but it will loose ground.This means if you want to build your phone  charge back up you have to strategically time the use of the case to ensure your phone hasn't gone down too much so you can still recover the charge but use the device at the same time.In summary this case requires entirely too much babysitting and thinking. There are much better options.
summary: So much to like but two serious deficiencies

reviewText: This seems to be an actual, legit Verizon charger which is important because it is graded to work on all Verizon Wireless phones that require a micro charger.  This is important because after market chargers, especially really cheap ones, can damage phones by overcharging, causing overheating, or even damaging the charging port because they are too hard to insert or pull out.It is the older model, though, as the new ones have a USB plug so you can plug in an extra USB cable and charge two devices, but that's the only drawback.  A definite recommend for anybody with a phone or device that takes a micro USB and doesn't need the convenience of charging two devices.
summary: seems to be legit Verizon chager

This is a cute charger that fits easily into a purse, without taking up a lot of room, or perhaps a dash or console in a car. I used it to surf a bit while it charged and it took about two hours to get a full charge, which was about as fast as the wall for me, though my battery is getting older.The blue is a cute color and it does exactly what it is supposed to.  It's very basic- there's no flashlight on it and there's no charge indicator.  It would be nice to know how much of a charge is left - that is a feature on more expensive chargers that I have, but it's affordable and very mobile if you want to just be able to charge back up during the day.  It comes with a USB to micro cable.I received this as a sample for purposes of review.  I would recommend it if you need an affordable, very mobile, portable basic charger.

Let's face it, everything seems to have a USB charger connected to it now and, especially on car trips, everyone needs their phone charged at the same time or even if you are traveling alone you likely may need to charge your phone, tablet, iPod, iPad, GPS...you name it.This means no gadget has to form a line behind the other more important ones--charge more, charge at once.Unlike many other multi-chargers that cause interference with the stereo, this one did not do that for me so it gets an even bigger two thumbs up.Product provided by Liger.Review is my unbiased opinion.

reviewText: As usual, the packaging of the Skinomi Tempered Glass is very thought of and professional.  You really know you're getting a quality product.  In terms of installation, what can I say - you've done one, you've done them all.  As long as you follow the basic rules of installing screen protectors you'll be fine.  You really need to take your time and make sure everything goes where it's supposed to be.  Once you drop it on the screen it's going to be very difficult to redo again without having some problems.  The Tempered glass is indeed thin and has a nice rounded edge to it.  My only annoyance is that the glass has some sort of noticeable grit.  My fingers don't slide as smoothly as I would hope.  I've used other brands of Tempered glass before and never encountered this issue. It feels like they forgot to put the oleophobic coating.  I'm hoping Skinomi gets back to me and resolves this.  I'm giving them a 5 stars for now but we'll see how the glass feels after a week or so, and how Skinomi responds.  I'm hoping it's just my specific glass.  I would still recommend it.EDIT: After several days the glass is still not smooth.  Feels a little gritty but there's nothing there that you can see.  It's really weird.  I will have to bring the rating down to a 4 until this gets figured out.
summary: Excellent Tempered Glass for my HTC One M8

reviewText: I purchased this item because of the rugged-shockproof/water resistance.  I have 2 other New Trent battery packs, and they are excellent.  I could not get through my work day without this.  It charges both my Samsung Galaxy Tablet and my iphone at once, several times if needed.  Very few devices can charge the Samsung, due to the amount of power it requires.It's compact and easy to fit in a pocket.It is fairly heavy though.

When this arrived, I was very surprised at how high quality it was (since it cost all of $5), with thick plastic on the cord and a good quality build to the charger itself.  No issues in charging and a good fit into both the wall and my phone.
Somehow you can take your phone in and out of this case over and over and it never loses its form and ability to hold the phone perfectly.

reviewText: I use my iPod for just about everything, and so does my son. For some reason my charger just stopped working one day, which sort of caused a bit of chaos within the household. I found this charger on Amazon and the price was right, soI ordered it to give it a shot. Absolutely wonderful, as far as chargers go! The indicator lights are a pleasant addition, and it plugs in to the device just like the one that came with the iPod in the first place. So glad I ordered it, saved me a load of hassle. Definitely recommended!

I like pens. I've got desk drawers filled with basic Bicballpoints, Pilot Razor Points, Pentel Rollerballs, Magic Markers.I've got a sleek black lacquer Waterman ballpoint that someone gaveme as a birthday gift. I've got an elegant Montblanc Meisterstuckthat I save for really important occasions, like signing divorcepapers.I like pens. So when I bought myself a Nook HD tablet anddiscovered that my fingertip was about as accurate on a smallcapacitive screen as the tip of a baseball bat, and that it was alsoleaving behind, all over the screen, a greasy fog of unsightlyprints, I decided I needed a pen for the Nook. A stylus.So I bought a stylus that was very handsome, long and slim, witha cute little bulbous grey rubber tip. It was an improvement on myfinger. No prints. A bit more accuracy. But sometimes the rubbertip would collapse onto itself, catch on the glass, and then sort ofstutter across it. Sometimes, probably because I was pressing downtoo hard, it would actually jam up on me, and the software would stopscrolling.Then I got the New Trent stylus. It's slightly smaller than thefirst stylus, and maybe not quite so handsome. It's slightlythicker, too, but it fits as well as the first one did into theelastic band on my tablet cover. And, more important, it fits intomy hand just perfectly.And, even more important, it works a whole lot better. I don'tknow what the "micro-knit" tip is made from, possibly somemagical new element like Unobtanium, but it just swoops across thetablet's surface like Miki Ando across the skating rink of the 2011Olympics. It's terrific at drag and drop, smooth and supple. It'saccurate at tapping those tiny little icons, even when there's abunch of them all scrunched together. I've installed the SwiftKeysoftware keyboard on the Nook - the one like Swype that spells outthe words as you dash across the letters with your stylus - andthe New Trent has at least doubled my speed and output.Did I mention that I like pens? This thing's got a pen builtright into it. Turn the shaft clockwise, and a little ballpoint tippops from the rear of the stylus. I don't use my pens much thesedays, but I can't tell you how many times I've been working on thecomputer when I suddenly wanted to write something down, and I had togo fumbling through the mess on my desk to find a pen to do it with.I don't have to fumble anymore. This is a definite life styleimprovement.All in all, I think that the New Trent Stylus is terrific. I'verecommended it to my friends, and if the thing ever broke, which Idon't expect to happen, I'd just go out and buy a new one. It's awell-made, good-looking tool that does exactly what it's supposed to do,and does that extremely well.

A case, matching clip, stylus, and a screen protector! Good deal! The case feels real nice in the hand super low profile so it's not to bulky. The clip and the case look great together also low profile. The clip seems maybe a little flimsy so we'll have to see how that ends up working out. The stylus works exactly how it should, the only thing I don't necessarily like about it is the pocket clip on it is plastic, I think a little metal one would work better. Now this did suck a little, the screen protector doesn't fit the Galaxy S3, it literally just covers the screen not the border around the screen just the actual 4. something inch screen. I'm disappointed in that but I can get another screen protector that fits and still be WAY under retail price on this deal. Over all good buy. I would recommend this product to anyone with a GS3 just make sure you get another screen protector.I would also like to point out that I made my order on Thursday November 29, 2012 and received my package on Saturday December 1, 2012. That was with the FREE SHIPPING offered from the company. Kudos on a super fast delivery. This is the main reason this didn't get 4 stars. I am upset the screen protector fit but it's still a really good deal without it, so 5 stars! Will order from them again!***UPDATE***This case has remained very sturdy HOWEVER with the soft touch texture it has picked up a lot of dirt and grime...It also does not wash off so with it being white now its permanently dirty. This is why I bumped it from 5 to 4 stars. Still a good product I personally wouldn't recommend white so if the company has another color, I would say to steer away from the white...Thanks.Satisfied Customer

I love my Note 2 and wanted to get some protection for it.  I did not want a huge bulky case to make my phone any larger than it already is.  This case was perfect...around $10 and is low profile.  It's made of quality rubber and I like because it will absorb a lot of shock when dropped.  I have dropped it a couple of times from around 2' or less and the phone is still fine.  When it hit the ground I heard a gentle 'thud' sound and that was the case absorbing most of the fall.  This is not an OTTERBOX mind you but will give your phone some protection.  I would buy again.

I had my doubts when I first saw this projector. I didn't expect much from something so small, but I was pleasantly surprised by the image and the ease of use.The phone slides into the sleeve snugly, which means it must be removed from its case first. The controls are simple and easy to figure out. I would have liked to see a set of small speakers, but the channel built into the bottom of the case directs the sound from the iPhone's internal speakers and they're audible, but a bit tinny sounding.In a darkened room, the projector's image looks fine up to a distance of 10 feet or so. Beyond that, it begins washing out a bit which isn't surprising given how small this unit is. The Projector Sleeve gets fairly warm while operating for more than a few minutes, but didn't seem affected by the heat at all.I used the Sleeve with several video apps and had good success with all. I was a bit disappointed that it couldn't project the iPhone screen, but that's a very minor nit. My kids loved dragging the Projector Sleeve around the house and watching movies.Please note: The 3M Projector Sleeve is for iPhone 4/4S ONLY. After evaluating it with an iPhone 4 and 4S, I tried it with my iPhone 5 and the 30 pin to lightening adapter with no success at all. The iPhone 5 adapter doesn't seem to provide any sort of video out at least with the current cable. Since this is a Projector Sleeve for the iPhone 4/4S, incompatibility with iPhone 5 is a non-issue.
summary: Nice for sharing videos with friends

The Belkin iPhone 5/5C/5S and iPod 5G Charge and Sync Dock is a very nice docking station if you are looking for a simple stand to charge and/or sync your device. The built-in 4 foot USB cord is great added benefit because it makes it easy to place it anywhere you wish without the limitations of a short cable.Works great if you use thin cases with an open bottom for charging, but it really depends on the type of case you use if it your device will easily fit with the case on or not.Nice simple dock that comes in a variety of colors with no blinding lights or extra features. Perfect for charging your device and being able to view it at a perfect angle. I have my stand sitting on my nightstand next to my bed so I am able charge my iPhone every night and control my my alarm clock since my alarm is my iPhone. The USB wall power adapter is NOT included.
summary: Nice Simple Dock (Review for Purple 8-Pin Lightning Cable Dock)

reviewText: Right up front I'll tell you that I love Spigen products.  I've owned many of their cases and written glowing reviews of them all.  This case, unfortunately, falls way short of my expectations.The biggest problem is that you can't plug anything into your phone with this case, except the original Samsung micro USB cable and the smallest of headphones.  I don't know about everyone else, but I've been acquiring micro USB chargers for years and they're scattered throughout my house/car/office.  Not being able to use any of them with my S4 while wearing this case is extremely frustrating.  It means I have to carry around my Samsung OEM cable with me everywhere I go.As for the headphones, I use either Shure SE315's or Sennheiser HD280's and with this case, the plug won't fully seat into the phone so I can't get any audio.  Seriously?  So now I have to buy a little pigtail, or use a pair of Apple Earbuds?  I don't think so.And so, I'm returning the case.  Buyers beware!  Many of you won't care about these problems, but some of you will and you'll want to steer clear of this case.
summary: Great case, if you don't want to plug anything into your phone

reviewText: This is the best screen protector ever.  The ease of installation and the incredible durability makes the price well worth it.  The quality of the material is obvious the minute that you pull it out of the package.

After buying a cell phone with Bluetooth I was pretty excited to find a device that I could use to listen to music/books through the car audio system.  Turns out this device does not work very well for me.- Turning it on and off requires holding a hidden button on the back of the unit for several seconds.  This is not so bad the first time you do it, but becomes increasingly annoying over time.  I don't understand why the unit was designed to require such a long hold on the on/off button, and why the button does not have any tactile feel.  It has a slight depression where you're supposed to push, but I often miss it, requiring even more time to turn it on/off.- I find the FM modulator unusable.  I live in a congested area - there are only a couple FM frequencies that are open during my entire commute.  The unit automatically searches for open freqs - you can't set them.  All you can do is push the search button so the unit looks for another open freq.  I never could get it to find the truly open freqs, so would have to change freq several times during my half hour commute.  After a few days I gave up.- Due to the problems with the FM modulator I ended up using the built in speaker exclusively.  That actually works pretty well for audio books.  It is only slightly louder than my cell phone, but is easier to hear since it is on the visor near my ear.  Unfortunately, with some books recorded at lower levels, I sometimes have trouble hearing over the road noise, so this mode is only slightly better than just listening to the phone directly.- The phone function works OK.  Some people have complained about the sound quality they are hearing, but most think it is OK.- Since it is battery powered, every few days I need to recharge it which is a hassle compared to my previous fm modulator which just stayed plugged into the cigarette lighter.Today I accidentally dropped it with the charger plugged in and the charging connector broke, so my 9 months with this unit are happily over.
Fits the Lumia 928 great. Just enough rubber mixed in for shock absorption.Only negative is the opening for the USB prevents some w/ cords w/ blocky ends from fitting and charging.

Once you get past the current price of $34.99, which may be a fluke, you will find a great product.The build quality is very good.  This is a durable piece of equipment and took the beating my kids gave it with no problem. While the charging unit maintains a low profile, the plastic used appears and feels thicker than most other brands I used. It is a tight fit in the two ports I used with it, but that was absolutely no issue.  The cable itself is very rugged; thicker than most cables I have used and thicker than the OEM Apple cable. Both ends of the cable (USB and device end) fit perfectly and make very solid connections.  Of note, the cord is about four feet long, which makes it very handy if you have power ports located far away (typical with older cars).  The charger itself puts out quite a bit of power. It charged our devices perfectly. The only drawback some may complain about is the lack of an indicator light. However, we never rely on the indicator lights anyway.After a few weeks of use in numerous cars and with different people, the charger works fine in every regard.  It was even stepped on with no affect to the charger.

Anker includes everything you need right in the package, and it's all very well packed. 3 protectors, large cloth, and a handy sticker for removing dust after application (I just used blue painter's tape, but that's because I didn't notice it till afterward)The protector fit my Nexus 5 with impeccable precision - cutouts and edges are perfect.GENERAL NOTE: Use the "hinge" method with blue painter's tape; you can place it with perfect accuracy on your first try,  by far the best method I've ever used!
summary: BEST screen protector kit I've ever used!

reviewText: Don't be put off by the look of this Blue Tooth Headset, you may be forgiven in thinking it's a throwback in "chunky" style, but you can hardly tell you're wearing it.I have had many BT sets before, mostly Plantronics, and with the exception of the crazy priced jawbones, this is the best I've used.With the advent of Sync, uConnect and other in-vehicle software these days, earpieces seem to be a bit passé, but I was very impressed with this from Motorola.If you read the sales guff about boom mics and so one, it tells you how it keeps down wind noise, and has better clarity. Whatever it is, it works!I have used this outdoors, in a vehicle, and even in bad weather, and never had problems with call quality on either end.So far it seems to be holding a pretty good charge as well, and I haven't needed to recharge it after several days of use (I do turn it off when at home)5 stars, it will be interesting to see the price when it becomes available.
Kind of big and klunky for starters. Some of my USB device cables won't work with this charger - mostly Apple devices.

Do not EVER be fooled by the junk that LOOKS like a pogo sketch. Those pretty colors and cheap prices are going to give you heartburn. I learned this lesson well and can say that while I still think it's overpriced, it does do an order of magnitude better job than the knock-offs.Biggest thing here is that the capacitive foam is properly attached and rounded while others are not. Next, and more importantly, is that pogo uses a little black rubber o-ring between the foam and the aluminum stick so that when you apply pressure and as the foam wears, you do not hit the screen with the metal shaft. The others do not have this feature and when you wear out the foam, you smack your glass screen with a sharp aluminum stick. That's what makes these guys better.While this is not my first choice for writing (boxwave and alupen are) this is a great stylus for sketching and painting. The foam will wear down and change shape which scares you at first, but it in no way changes the quality of the product. I don't know how long they'll last before the foam gives up, but I've abused mine for over a month now. LIght, cool looking and easy to use. Good to go.
summary: Great for sketching and painting, decent for writing

The OXA ZLY-3000 Frosted Box power charger is a power charger for USB devices and PC laptops.  In the box, it has two cables with interchangeable plugs, one for USB and one for laptops, a carrying case, the battery pack, and an instruction manual.  The interchangeable USB plug has a 30-pin iPod plug, a MicroUSB A plug, a Samsung cell phone plug, and a Nokia plug. The interchangeable laptop cable includes plugs for most laptops including HP and IBM/Lenovo ThinkPads.Sadly, the OXA power charger is not compatible with Mac laptops.For the USB devices, I tested this on my daughter's iPhone 4S and a ASUS Android tablet.  It was able to charge both quickly and it has enough battery life to handle multiple charges without any problems.  For laptops, it couldn't charge my HP Envy laptop on it as the smallest HP plug that it came with was too short for the power plug.  I would recommend this with some caveats.  It might not work with newer laptops especially HPs and I found the single USB plug to be a hindrance because a device like this should have at least two as it has enough power to handle more than one USB port.Recommend with caveats given.

I've gone through my fair share of bluetooth audio devices in the quest to find the best gym headset.  This one didn't even make the first cut.  I sweat like there is no tomorrow.  I love to run on the treadmill.  But sweat is a killer to electronics.  I've got an iPhone 4 that I wear on an arm band and that has worked mostly.  But I would love to find something with the freedom to move more.  Hence, I keep trying bluetooth headsets without luck.The Jabra Clipper looks like it's got some give potentially in the clip itself.  Think again.  You are warned, right in the manual not to try to force the clip to give very much.  The unit that I received was so tight in the clip that I could not get it to clip to the collar of my thin gym shirt.  And since I was worried about breaking the stupid thing in the first place, back it went.  Seriously, the clip was WAY too tight.Pairing was simple.  That was no problem.  I did test the audio and there was no trouble on reception.  I can't tell you how this would work in the gym since it never left my desk.  One charge, one test and back it went. I have an iPhone 4s, and I have been having problems finding a good Bluetooth that couples with it. The Plantronics 975 that I have used, creates a gurgling sound on and off, that seems to improve for a day if I re pair it, but then comes back after a few days. Plantronics has been wonderful about sending me a refurbished unit and standing behind their product. Unfortunately the refurbished unit has the same problem. I ended up replacing my iPhone, and he continued to have the problem. It doesn't happen on my wife's iPhone 4. I bought this Bluetooth to see if there would be some improvement, and unfortunately there was not. Perhaps it's a compatibility issue with the 4S and current Bluetooth technology. As it turned out my wife really likes this Bluetooth and she adopted it. She has noticed that both the sending and receiving volume are very loud, and she needs to tone down her voice and have others speak more quietly. She also has others report occasionally that they lose several seconds of what she's saying, but overall she reports that she likes it. The only Bluetooth that has worked perfectly with my 4S without any gurgling, has been the Bose. I tried that for a week, and the fit was uncomfortable, and it seemed that I needed to charge it several times a day, where my Plantronics I only need to charge at night. I use a Bluetooth during the day so not feeling confident that my Bose would be able to have enough power to take the next call was problematic. I ended up charging my Bose after every call or two to make sure that it didn't run out of power. Oh well, there's not a perfect Bluetooth that I have found yet.

I purchased this holster for my new HTC Incredible as holster options are few and far between for this new model phone.  The part that fits to my belt is really good, the outer case that fits the phone is ok but there is very poor retention of the phone in the holster.  The innovative retention mechanism is the lip of the holster is suppose to keep the phone from sliding out.  However, if you use this in a horizontal position, I feel quite comfortable that you will loose your phone.  It slides out with hardly any resistance. For me, having the phone vertical is not comfortable due to the length of the phone but fortunately it does rotate at degreed increments and seems to hold that position fairly well.  Even with the holster canted at a 45 angle, the phone has the potential to come out of the holster if I run or jump...not a good thing. I don't feel the item is defective in any way but just lacking in some design details. The materials and overall appearance of the item are quite acceptable but it's unfortunate that they didn't make provisions for a retention strap or something better to secure the phone.I will try to make some modifications and live with it until something better comes along but just wanted potential buyers to be aware of the loose fit and potential loss of your phone.REVISION: 5-12-10I have found that I can improve the retention qualities of this holster by applying some tape to the inside of the two opposing guide lugs. This helps considerably.  It's a shame that this issue wasn't addressed during the initial design phase of this product.

reviewText: I have had this item for 3 day's now, and it does everything I expected it to do base on the reviews;  I give this SOLAR charger a 5 star based on what this unit is, and does, and not based on what I magically want it to do :) Yes I did take a chance on this purchase, but the option of returning an item is available. Take a minute and look and think about the item. This is a solar charger, you cannot expect an electrical charge out of it like you would right out of your wall socket. This item is $25 bucks, and I know that if you were to go into a Radio Shack to purchase this very same item it would run you, "oh I would say anywhere from $59 -$89 bucks". Yes the battery indicator does not indicate a green light for rechargeable batteries, so you do need a voltmeter, and I have seen voltmeters at the dollar store that work well or on this site for a buck or two. Of course your batteries will charge without a voltmeter, it's just so you will know when the batteries are fully charged. Just use common sense depending on the weather. This charger so far, works great, as long as you have patients and a little understanding for the still in process movement of solar energy. This charger charges four AA within a charge, or two AAA batteries within one charge, one charge can take up to 1 to 2 or 4 days, this all depends on your location, weather, and rechargeable batteries you are using. This device fully charged my HTC Touch just fine off of two AA batteries; you can charge a device with either 4 AA batteries in the charger which is nice! Or you can charge a device with 2 AA batteries in the charger which works fine as well; you can also charge a device with regular none chargeable batteries (single use batteries)! That is a big plus for those who travel a lot. Those who want the option of being able to charge their digital cameras, phones, or whatever device it may be that can handle the correct charge from this charger. The USB output is DC 5.0---350mA and the charging current is 200mA for 2 batteries and 100mA for 4 batteries. My unit did come in a package that was sealed, and yes it has a shiny finish, but there are some small scratches that make it look like it was used before hand (which I doubt, I think it's just the best finish they can come up with).  So far the unit is working good, I recommend it for either travel, or emergencies, because you can use regular none rechargeable batteries to charge up your devices successfully, make sure you test it out before leaving town, and yes you can use rechargeable batteries, just recognize the time it may take to charge it. The other reason why I recommend this device is for emergencies, or even if SHTF for those who know what I am talking about :) it will work great for flash lights and portable games for your kids. Oh I almost forgot, the other poster was right, the durability is not solid, but not that weak either (meaning it won't break as long as you don't throw it against a wall or drop it 50 times like some do with their phones. I will repost on here with updates, I plan on testing out outdoor solar light rechargeable batteries in this charger, and please excuse my grammar; I am posting this as a favor to you, and hope it helped a little.
summary: XTG  Solar AA & AAA Battery Charger With Multiple Options
