reviewText: I am using it to charge either two android micro usb, or mp3 and phone. Works great - word to the wise - if its a USB jack it will charge most anything.

I received these free for review purposes from the manufacturer. Given the low price point, I had low expectations. And in this case, I am glad that my expectations were met, and thoroughly exceeded.The sound quality from these, for the price, is nothing short of excellent. I would probably recommend this is the best sounding ear buds, at the least amount of money I would be willing to put on headphones. Generally you get what you pay for, but in the case of the iHangy, you get a great bang for the buck.The bass is punchy enough, treble good enough, that I don't need any EQ to be done on the sound at all to get a sound I like. Like all headphones though, unless you go to find a pair specifically built for neutral sound, there will be some "color" added. In this case, the added color over neutral, for me, is what these phones need.In terms of the utility of them, well, they make the assumption you will trust the plastic charger insert will hold your iPhone 3-4s safely when you are performing activities. Reality is, it does a great job and hasn't fallen out yet. It clamps tightly into the charger port and I don't feel as though it will fall out. I've put as much force as I am willing on the connection, and it had no issues holding the force of my pulling and keeping the phone connected. Good stuff.My only issue is that the cable included to plug into the headphone jack isn't long enough to just put your phone in your pocket and carry. Yes, that would defeat the concept, but having the option, as these headphones sound great for the price, would be a nice addition for the next model.If you're on the market for a pair of earbud headphones, and want the utility of carrying your phone around your neck, and want good sound quality for the price, the iHangy is a great addition to your music listening and iPhone carrying arsenalHighly recommended..
Acase makes a great 2 piece cover for the iphone.  Fit finish and protection are all great.  Be aware that the white outside does get dirty, but that was to be expected i guess.
summary: Case is great, but white gets dirty

reviewText: Out of the box, it took 30 minutes to charge the built-in lithium battery using the included USB cable. The User Manual is clear and brief with logical steps detailed to pair the speaker with phone or other Bluetooth capable devices like an iPod, iPad, etc. A short press of the plus or minus sign increases or decreases volume, while a long press either moves the song selection forward or back. A clicking noise is heard to alert the user when maximum volume is reached.  Pressing the phone icon button permits incoming calls to be answered.For a small speaker the performance is surprisingly good. Optimal sound resides in the upper and mid range with bass a bit weak -- with nothing sounding distorted even at maximum volume. The speaker works up to thirty feet from the device to which it is paired, and will run for four hours per battery charge. While in the shower, I tested it both with my phone and iPod and the sound was clear even above the noise of the water running, and I could easily carry on a conversation with the caller, although they thought it was weird when I told them I was speaking from the shower.The speaker has a large suction cup on the back which I stuck to the shower wall, out of the direct path, but next to the water stream. Water was definitely splashed on the device the entire time I was in the shower. It adhered securely, and stayed firmly attached to the tile even while control buttons were pushed multiple times. The silicone face of the unit provided a relatively non-slip texture when wet so no undue pressure was necessary to change songs or adjust volume.Water resistant with an IPX4 rating, which means the speaker should be able to withstand being splashed from all angles for at least five minutes but it should not be submerged in water. As I noted above, it was splashed on for a good ten minutes while I tested the music and phone capabilities without any problems.Small, attractive, and it did everything it promised.Sample provided without obligation.
summary: AQUACUBE - URGE Basics Water Resistant Shower Speaker

Ok guys, I had to this get this off my chest and review. Like many looking for extra battery charging solutions I looked at Amazon and saw the Anker 2 batteries and charger for $22.99 vs Samsung charger and 1 battery for $34.99. I really thought long and hard when i would need an extra battery and the rotation of 3 batteries if I bought the Anker product. First of all  from a battery analysis review Anker makes a good battery, but like all third party wall chargers the length of time is like 8-10hrs making it basically an overnight charger. The point of having an extra battery is either someone doesn't want to have to wait while their phone charges or they won't have access to charge phone at any given point and want convienence.People into technolgy want things to be fast and trouble free. If I had three batteries and it took me 8-10 hours to charge each one i think i would go nuts. For some putting a battery in before you go to bed is ok but there are times when you would be trying to get all three batteries charged for a trip or just getting to the hotel from a flight after all three batteries would need to be recharged, and for those times it would be hard to get the cycle of three batteries being charged at the same time again to troublesome.I would get so tired of waiting that I would probably just discard the Anker wall charger and just charged all three batteries from the phone itself ,  having to take off the cover of the phone to many times for me. So to save from the fustration I coughed up the extra money and got the Samsung charger and 1 extra battery opposed to 2 batteries from 3rd party. Granted i will have to pair it with my current charging cable for the quickest time but I think it is the best solution. I don't care if you had 5 batteries, if you have a crapy charger what's the point. Yes you could leave a couple here and there but that would get confusing.G2 battery is a beast anyways and an extra battery would be great, but 3 batteries with a 8-10hrs charge time each is mising the point. " I ain't got time for that!!!"
summary: I Ain't Got Time for That!!!!

reviewText: The Boostcase is essentially two different, but combinable items. The first is a solid, but slim and lightweight, standalone protective case for your phone. The second is a thin, stylish battery pack that slides onto the back of the case, giving your phone the equivalent of a full, second charge. You can keep the battery pack separate from your phone until you need it, which is nice...it allows you to charge the pack on the go while still keeping your phone protected by a case. The battery pack slides in nice and tight to the case... you don't have to worry about it coming off, the way I used to with my old Mophie on my iPhone4. That's also the big downside. It's hell taking it off. You almost need to get the jaws of life or a blow torch to do it. That said, I'm very happy with the Boostcase.

They ddint have to do that and I appreciate it.I give the actual product 4 out of 5 stars. Reason: The product is nice. Very nice actually! I love the screen protector! The holes and slots are perfectly aligned. The buttons push better with the case than they do without it. The reason I couldn't give it 5 stars is because the case adds a lot of bulk. This phone is very sleek and slim and with this case on its only most double the thickness.Bottom line is the shipping issue was probably an isolated indecent and the company did what most companies would have done and actually took ownership for the problem. I appreciate that and even though I don't use the case anymore I will probably order from them again. There is absolutely nothing wrong with the case, I just like them to be a little thinner.ONE LAST THING... The case looks great! I give it 5 out of 5 stars on looks.
summary: Its nice but I dont use it anymore.

This is the best windshield mount I have ever purchased. It holds any size smartphone. Maybe even the note, I don't have one and I haven't tried it but I'm assuming it will fit. Let me start out by saying this thing is awesome, I've had this over 8 months now and it's not lost any suction and I only had it fall off once because it was over 100 degrees outside and the car had been sitting in direct sunlight. I cleaned it with regular soap and water and the stickiness came back to about 98% which isn't bad. The arms actually have grooves on the top and bottom so it will hold on to the edges of your phone nicely and securely. My phone has not fallen out of the arms once and I am hard on my things which my wife yells at me all the time. I used to just slide the phone out without any care and I even let the plastic slap against each other more than a dozen times and its still held up well. Now it doesn't work on your dashboard if its got any grooves in it. I have yet to find one that has that type of suction. If I ever find it I will be very happy. If you're looking for something that will last over time then this is it. It will stay on your windshield at any temperature except 100 degrees but really when is it really that hot? Get the darn thing and attach it to your windshield and you'll be happy. I bet you you'll love it. It can even hold a soda can filled with soda and still not fall off. What does that tell you about this thing? Get it you can't go wrong or get the updates version of this. Either one should work well. Very happy customer.

reviewText: I am very glad I went with this model over the defender.  It is very sleek and keeps the iphone looking as it should without the extra tank bulk of the other otterbox models.  Of course you do sacrifice a bit of protection as it is not a 3 layer setup.The only gripe i had was also what other reviewers experienced, the top half of the case when installing will probably peel off your invisishield / screen protector.  What i suggest is that before it even gets to the edge of your screen protector, try to use a little card or one of your credit cards and try to slowly slide the top on while pinning the edge down so it doesn't catch on the "sharp" part of the case.The bottom was easy to slip on and lock up shut with no worries of peeling the protector off from that end as well.Would definitely buy again. Awesome case, even has little bit of velvet liner for the back of your phone (also to add in shock reduction from a drop i suppose)  Camera port and all side buttons etc are easily accessible and work without much effort. Don't hesitate to buy.

I hate to be one of the only people to not give this item a 5 star rating, but I can't after having the same problem twice! First off let me start by saying this is an excellent quality screen protector and MIME has excellent customer service! I purchased the ghost glass for my galaxy s4 from their website. I received it and read the instructions carefully. I then put latex gloves on both hands so that fingerprints wouldn't get on the glass. I first wiped my screen with the included cloth, and then used the purple sticky film provided to remove any remaining particles. As soon as I lifted that off my screen I peeled of the protector from my glass and I lined it up with my screen, but as soon as I let go of the glass so it could adhere by itself, the whole protector shifted. It was way off center which caused me to have to pick it up off my screen and try again. Unfortunately I had to remove and reapply it about 7 or 8 times, literally. It kept shifting on my screen every time I let go! Finally the last time it was centered, so I let it do it's thing and adhere to my screen. Afterwards I gently pressed down with my fingers. Then I noticed that there were many particles trapped underneath the ghost glass. I wasn't happy about that and it must be because I had to remove and reapply so many times. Second thing is that afterwards the top left corner of the glass didn't adhere like the rest of it and I can't explain it but you could tell there was something on my screen and it looked like that part of the glass had some kind of defect. It was very noticeable and driving me crazy. I contacted MIME and sent them a few pictures. They gave me a code for a free replacement protector! So my replacement ghost glass comes and I decide I'm going to install it in the biggest, most open room of the house because I thought that would be where there is the least amount of dust. I took off the protector that was on. I wiped my screen with included cloth, then I put the purple sticky sheet on my entire front of my phone and I pressed down on it with my fingers. I kept it on for about two minutes. I took my phone to the table where I had my ghost glass. As soon as I removed the purple sheet I inspected my screen and there was not a speck of dust. I immediately removed the plastic protector from my glass (had latex gloves on during entire process) and I was very careful to make sure it was centered with the speaker and home button and it was, so I let go and let it adhere. Then I noticed that once it adhered all the way it wasn't centered with my home button. There is much more space on the left side of it then the right. I figured the glass must have shifted again when I let go, but I didn't want to remove it once it was on there. So I gently pressed on it with my fingers. There is also two particles that got trapped under the glass, not sure how because there wasn't a speck of anything on my screen. When I removed the plastic from my glass, it was very close to my phone, so I don't know how there could have been enough time for anything to stick to it. So overall I'm very happy with the product itself, but the installation is definitely NOT a piece of cake like everyone is claiming including MIME. I've become a pro  at  screen protectors on phones, and other devices and I've never had a problem with them being off centered like this! It's hard for me to believe that everyone else said there's not one speck of dust or particles under their glass. I installed two screen protectors and both times had stuff trapped under the glass! If anyone thinks I'm not being truthful about how mine turned out, I would be more then happy to take pics of the front of my phone, showing the glass is not centered with the home button and hopefully it would show the particles underneath.
summary: Excellent quality item, installation problems both times!

reviewText: I always take care of my smart phones.  They usually look new when I am done with them.  My last phone was a Motorola Droid, which I housed in a TPU case.  It looked nice and protected well for scratches. However, when taking one of my walks I tripped. The phone did not fall far - but it was far enough.  Devastation!My new phone is a Samsung S4.  I love the phone - but it does not seem as sturdy as my old Droid. And that Droid shattered. So I need to protect my S4.  I purchased two top rated cases to see what is best for my needs: the OtterBox Defender and the Trident AMS Kraken.Summary:Both the Kraken and the OtterBox Defender were real close for my needs.  The one that I ended up using is the Trident AMS Kraken.My final choice was because I felt the Kraken to be somewhat better than the OtterBox.  I got quite frustrated by the proximity sensor not working correctly with the OtterBox.  This prevented me from accessing the phone after the screen turned off during calls.  I also felt that the body of the Kraken would protect the phone better.If interested in my reviews, I have another write up for the Trident AMS Kraken case.Detailed review of the OtterBox Defender case:Appearance:  I chose the blue color.  Very nice shade.  The case consists of a colored polycarbonate shell covered with a slab of black silicon. Of course the case made my thin phone look huge - but that is the price that one pays for protection.  I feel that the OtterBox Defender looks plain.Physical characteristics:The inner polycarbonate shell acts like a skeleton, adding strength to the phone.  The outer silicon liner cushions the phone and absorbs most of the shock.The inner shell goes together easily and has a good fit.  Taking it apart to clean the phone was at first hard.  After a few times it was not so bad.The silicon is stiffer than that used in many products because it is so thick.  It extends over each corner of the phone.  The silicon is easy to install. If you place the phone face down the surface is protected by the silicon.  This seems to be a very high quality silicon and will protect the phone against most small accidents.The silicon provides two additional features: the volume and the power switch are covered, and there are plugs for the headphone jack and the USB connector.  The volume and power switch are well protected, but they are also hard to use. The silicon is just too thick and stiff.  At least the odds are that the power switch being accidently pressed while in one's pocket is slim. Of course a substitute when the screen is off is to press the home button. But you really should be able to easily use the power switch as needed.  The headphone jack cover works great.  The USB connector cover fits well - but it is sometimes difficult to guide a USB connector into place.  This sometimes is frustrating connecting power to the phone.There are no cutouts or other consideration for ventilation.  Most of the time the Samsung S4 runs cool.  But at times it did get very warm.The polycarbonate front bevel extends enough to protect the screen, but not too much to obstruct any of the active portion of the screen.  Unlike other cases, the notification bar can readily be accessed without any extra effort.  No fear of hitting wrong buttons because there is not room for your fingers.The soft silicon outer shell makes it simple when you put the phone down on a surface.  It will not slip.  It will not damage the surface. Yet it is sufficiently smooth to easily slip in or out of your pocket.The silicon does not pick up pet hair.Other factors:Sound quality - phone calls:  The phone speaker worked quite well.  When talking on the phone you can easily hear the other party.  Now for the bad news. The microphone does not work well in this case.  The other party can hear you, along with echoes and muffled sound.  I got continuous complaints from people that could not hear me properly when on calls.Sound quality - phone speaker for music: no degradation of sound quality.  Not that the S4 speaker is that great in the first place .. but the case does not make it any worse.Sensor access: The S4 proximity sensor does not work with this case.  Once activated, the sensor gets stuck (confirm with the CPU-Z and AndroSendor tools).  Why is this important?  One use of the proximity sensor is to determine when to turn off the screen.  If you get a phone call and you put the phone to your ear, the proximity sensor will turn off the screen. Access to the touch screen is prevented so that you cannot accidentally press buttons. The problem is that the sensor does not detect when the phone is moved away from the ear.  When you move the screen away from your ear, the screen should become visible and you should be able to use the touch screen. With the proximity sensor not working, the screen does not free up until the other party hangs up from your call.  If the other person does not hang up you cannot use your screen again! During the call you cannot look up contacts, or do any of the other multi-tasking that your phone is designed for.  On some S4 forums, I read that black cases do not seem to have as much of this problem.  I also read that some people claim use of a black magic marker around the opening where the sensor is located helps.  I tried using a black magic marker and the sensor worked better - but still not consistently.  Carefully applied you can hardly see the black.Screen protector: the top portion of the polycarbonate shell has an integrated screen protector.  This is the thickest screen protector that I have used.  It seems quite rugged. It resists fingerprints and cleans up quite easily.  The phone's touch screen worked surprisingly well behind this plastic.  However, it felt different - the screen was close, but not as responsive as with other cases with more pliable films. I did feel comfortable that the screen was well protected.Support: I called OtterBox support because of problems with the proximity sensor.  First contact had a new inner shell that was shipped immediately.  There was no attempt to support beyond that.  When I continued to complain, they readily permitted me to return the case for a refund. So good news is that they took responsibility to provide a refund. Bad news is that they did not actually try to solve my problem.  If this was a unique problem I could understand.  However, looking at other forums I see that the sensor problem is fairly widespread. I would think that it would be more responsible of OtterBox if they would solve the problem.  That said, my son-in-law has an S4 with an OtterBox defender (grey case).  Works perfectly for him.Belt clip:  Sturdy and works.

I  charged 3 tablets (7" & 8.9" Kindle Fire HD & 7" Kindle Fire HDX) & my iPod Touch 4G at the same time using theBolse Newly designed 4 Port USB portable AC Rapid Charger - 20 Watt. I was surprised to find everything fully charged when I checked 3 hours later. (The 7" Fire HD began with a 25% charge, the HDX began at 37%, the 8.9" Fire HD began at 64%; I didn't record the iPod %).  My  prepaid LG Cosmos prepaid cell phone  needs to be charged slowly & cannot be charged using the Bolse Rapid Charger.I had some problems the first time I tried charging my Kindle Fire/s 7", 8.9" HD & 7" HDX. I plugged them in using their charging cables, but they weren't charging. I turned them off then back on & they charged just fine. I don't know why this happened, but thought I'd mention it.  The next time I charged them, I didn't have any problems.I'm charging my 7" Fire HD & HDX right now.In the 1 1/2 hours they've been charging,the  HD has gone from 15% to 70%;the HDX has gone from 11% to 72%.(They've been charging 2 1/4 hours now: the HD is @ 93%; HDX @ 96%)The HDX is charging faster...I'm using the iPad port & Frieq's High Speed USB cableFRiEQ Hi-Speed Cloth Jacketed USB 2.0 A Male to Micro B Cable (6 Feet)for the HDX which might be the reason it's charging faster.This Bolse Rapid Charger features:- 4 ports usb charger charges your iPone, iPad, Samsung Phone, HTC, Digital camera & other USB devices.- Orange LED shows when charger is receiving power.- Highest Power rating at 20W/4 Amps output 5V. Intelligent overheat, overcharging and over-current protection built-in.- Compact Design and Flip Down AC Prongs make it easy to carry on travel.- This charger charges tablets at 2 Amps and most phones at 1 Amps current.- Port 1 & 2(Universal) will charge almost all devices including Apple & Android devices.- Port 3(Universal/iDevice Legacy)  will also charge most devices including the iPad. This port supports legacy/old Apple devices.- Port 4(Universal/Samsung Optimized)  is  designed to charge Samsung devices(e.g.Samsung Tab). Many other phones can be charged as well using this port. This port will not charge an iPad.The Bolse Rapid Charger is not compatible With HP TouchPad, Asus Transformer, Motorola Xoom Tablet, & some Blackberry phones.It might not support charging / or slow charging with some devices...for example, my LG Cosmos prepaid cell phone can't be charged using this rapid charger.One-Year Limited WarrantyI received a sample for reviewing purposes & will update my review if my opinion changes.Excellent 4 port rapid charger.5 stars
summary: Excellent Rapid Charger!  Charge 4 tablets at the same time!

I knew what I was getting with this unit given the number of bluetooth and other wireless devices I've used over the years. Bluetooth 2.1 simply doesn't offer the bandwidth to support the type of audio fidelity many of us have come to expect, even over a wireless input. And I was right, there's just a bit of range, a bit of bass, a bit of everything missing as compared to when you're wired or even when using a Bluetooth 4.0 connection. I'm sure real audiophiles scoff at the idea of expecting any sort of quality from an MP3 file but even a layperson can easily tell the difference between using this unit and a more advanced input.But audio quality wasn't the biggest downer here, the bigger issue was that even at a range of just a few feet the unit would frequently drop the connection for several seconds at a time. It happened frequently enough that I eventually found little use for it and it sits in a drawer.I should've known what I was getting in to and hopefully this review confirms what others probably already suspect. On the plus side, it came with all the cords you might need and was neatly packaged and easy to set up for use with an Android tablet.
summary: Works ok for Bluetooth 2.1, lots of static and disconnects

reviewerName: The Taminator "There's no going back. You've ...
reviewText: I had low expectations of this headset. Every time I have tried to use a headset, the person on the other end complains that they can't hear me as well, and I have to switch back to my phone. With this headset, they could tell that I was using one, but they could hear me loud and clear. It's very comfortable for me as it is, but it comes with a couple of different clips to adjust the fit if you need. The volume was high enough for my slight hearing loss, but easily adjustable for lower levels for those who need it. It's light weight and after a few minutes I forget I have it on.The cord for the wall charger seems awfully short; I would rather not leave the headset on the floor while charging. However, it comes with a car charger AND an attachment to charge through any USB port on a computer! I love that I can put the USB charger in my purse, go anywhere, and not worry about losing power because I can charge it through my netbook or my computer at work. It was very easy to set up & connect to mySamsung Rant. When a call comes in, all I have to do is tap the button on the side of the headset, and when I dial out, it automatically connects.With so many other headset choices out there, it's hard to decide what to get. I highly recommend this headset for ease of use, EXCELLENT quality of sound and the three compact charging options included in the package. I am very pleased with it and I think you will be as well.
This is the shimmer i've been looking for to make my phone unique. The phone cases that fit the galaxy's need to catch up with styles offered for the iPhones.  This is a step up.

Every time I get a new phone I have to go on a quest for a case I like.  I'm pretty particular and I've tried several for my S3. I'm very satisfied with this one.  It has nice grippy, rubberized sides that would probably offer decent protection in a fall.  The best feature though is being able to remove the bottom quickly.  I like to dock my phone at home, work and in the car.  The problem is, very few docks will work with a phone that has a case on it.  This is the perfect solution.  I just slide off the bottom, and pop it into the dock.  When I need the phone, just slide the bottom of the case on, and I have a nice protective case.  Its seems to be well constructed and I expect it will last for the 2 or 3 years I keep the phone.  I've very glad I found this and can recommend it.Update:  I am changing my review to 2 stars. After a  couple of months of use, the rubber part separated from the hard plastic. It appears other have this issue as well. I have tried, with little success, to glue it back on. Given what I paid for this case, I expected it to last longer.  The case was a great idea, but poorly constructed.
summary: Ingenious Solution to the Case vs. Dock Problem (see Update)

reviewText: I have a couple of these charging banks. I first bought a cheap on that did not work at all. This New Trent  Powerbank is by far one of the better ones that I have had. I can charge my cell phone and wife’s cell phone at the same time. I also charge my iPod, Garmin GPS hand held, BN Nook Glow and iPad. I wanted it also for my PS Vita & BN HD Nook. At first it wouldn’t charge them at all. I contacted New Trent and got a very quick response as well as a solution. They suggested a little pig tale “Samsung Pad pig tale” that helps the power bank recognize the device. I got one of these pig tales and I am now able to charge and use both my PS Vita & BN HD Nook. I am very pleased with this product and the customer service that I received.  I will be buying from New Trent again.

reviewText: I love the case. It is a great looking well built case. The only issue I have is it is a little difficult to put o and take off. I am in the Army and find myself switching batteries often and this becomes a pain. But it is worth it. This case is durable and I trust it.

As most reviewers already indicated, this is an excellent screen protector for the new 5th gen iPod Touch.  I have installed other types of screen protectors on an older 3rd gen iPod Touch and the new iPad.  The Tech Armor has been the easiest.  Perfect alignment with the home button and camera opening.  Got it perfect on the first try and absolutely zero bubbles or lint.  The surface is almost like a glass finish and clarity is excellent.  This screen protector works just fine and remains perfectly flat if you plan to use a case for the iPod where the lip extends to the front.Just as a comparison, I originally purchased the Military Shield screen protector when I first bought the iPod and that was a complete waste of money.  The material is thicker, buckles up at the edges and requires water to apply.  Not only that but after a month or two, that material started to yellow. So if you are considering that one, avoid it at all costs.Would definitely recommend the Tech Armor, but only giving it 4 out of 5 starts because it doesn't come with a protector circle for the home button (as some other film manufacturers provide).
This was perfect for my iPhone 5s.  Great fit, not  slippery and the belt clip holds tight.  I also keep my belkin case on and slide it in. I don't use the hard case.

reviewText: This is a great little accessory that is a must have with any iPhone. As much as we are all plugged into our phones it's natural that we have battery life issues! I consistently get 3.5 charges- BUT-  I start charging at 21%. I never wait for the phone to get red.The unit charges fast, I just plug it in over night and throw it in my bag in the morning. I have no issues with heat or syncing. I'm charging with my original apple cord right in one of the three USB ports on the device.Great product!

The original blackberry headset & my first order, both have a very soft & flexible wire. But the one that I received from "The OEM Shop" has a very stiff & hard wire, not very flexible & it feels that it is going to break when folding it. I think it is a counterfeit of Blackberry OEM one. I will never buy from "The OEM shop". It is not worth to send it back. -----------------OVERVIEW-----------------Having an iPhone 5s, I have purchased and tested numerous all sorts of screen protectors. I personally am not a bulky/rugged/massive protection screen protector/case person because I do not like the added bulk. I am familiar with amCase/amFilm and they have quality products at an affordable price unlike their competitors.--------------------PROTECTION--------------------Like I stated in my overview, this is a screen protector to prevent glass scratching and possibly minor glass cracks and I did not expect it to provide military grade protection, or even small child protection for that matter. Don't expect or assume screen protection of any further degree with this type of screen protector.-------------------------------PRODUCT FEATURES-------------------------------- Compatibility: Specifically designed for Apple iPhone 5S, iPhone 5C, iPhone 5- Designed specifically for a fast, easy, 100% bubble-free application and made of the ultimate, high-quality invisible film- Protect screen from daily scratches, dust, scrapes, and normal signs of wear- Attaches quickly and smoothly with self-adhering surface, leaves no residue when removed- Includes: 2xBye-Bye Bubble Ultimate Screen Protectors, Micro-Fiber Cleaning Cloth, Squeeze card------------------------SLICK/SLIPPERY------------------------A lot of screen protectors I review can be rather slick and causes devices to slip from my hand more so than not protecting the device at all. I was actually surprise this was not an issue with this screen protector.-------------------PROS/CONS-------------------- 3 Protectors Included- Price- Quality- Ease of Use- Ease of Installation- Sufficient Protection- Works with virtually every iPhone 5s case- Customer ServiceCONS- None-------------DISCLOSURE-------------I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promised that my review is fair and honest with no bias.

If you're looking at this, the first thing you're probably thinking is 'A totally free 4G wifi hotspot? Sounds too good to be true!'Well, it is. Do a bit of research first. If not, look for one of these on sale for $15, which happens from time to time. At that cost it's not a bad buy even if it just ends up being a fancy little paperweight. The two big caveats with FreedomPop's Photon are:1. The device uses Sprint's 4G wimax technology.2. The device has no 3G fallback.First, a brief history. Sprint's WiMax network used to be a company called Clearwire, which they owned a large amount of stock in and eventually bought outright for some unfathomable reason. To make a long story short the rollout of their WiMax network was aborted- for 'financial reasons' Sprint decided to halt it and instead go with LTE. As such, the WiMax network is incomplete and has an uncertain future.What this means for you (as a FreedomPop owner) is:1. Coverage in general is terrible. I live in Silicon Valley and even here it is very poor. If you live in the middle of nowhere, just forget it. The coverage maps, by the way, are a pretty poor reflection of reality (those assume the towers are all up, broadcasting at full power, not throttled, and are being maintained- all very big assumptions).2. Even if you have coverage, don't expect LTE or anything approaching broadband speed. The hardware and software for this network was never fully matured and will never be. I suspect it's also throttled in some areas- sure seems so to me.3. In all likelihood, this service's days are numbered. And that number is not very big.A more detailed explanation: since the rollout was never finished, there are a lot of dead spots- in fact pretty much the whole Midwest is one, and even heavily populated cities like San Francisco have really spotty coverage. This also means if you're using it on the go, FreedomPop will drop on and off and the battery will die in no time from constant attempts to reacquire signal.If there was 3G fallback on this device and it was still 500 MB a month for free, it would be a great deal as that would solve the coverage problem. Ditto for 4G LTE at no monthly fee. However, neither of these will EVER happen. Why? Well, as long as it's only using the Sprint WiMax network, it's not eating up anyone else's bandwidth. Sprint stopped selling devices using that network 2 years ago, and in all likelihood most of those are no longer being used- making Clearwire perhaps the most under-utilized 'national' network in human history. WiMax uses a different frequency from both 3G and 4G LTE, so Sprint is losing nothing farming out this network at little to no charge. However, if FreedomPop plugged into 3G or LTE, that's a different story- now you're eating up bandwidth that is also being used by Sprint customers- many of whom are paying $70 or more a month for service. Yeah, that's just not going to go for free and is why FreedomPop's hotspots with 3G fallback charge a monthly fee for any service.What irks me most about this device and which I find unforgivable is the marketing comparing it to hotspots offered by Verizon and AT&T; showing you saving some $1200 annually. Well yeah, you'll save around that much- but they're comparing this device running on WiMax with no fallback to hotspots running on 4G LTE with 3G fallback. They're also neglecting to mention the little fact that it will be EOL'd in a year or two. At any rate it's totally misleading- pay no heed to it.

reviewText: Wireless charging....never thought I'd jump on board, but after ruining a couple of micro usb connectors for whatever reason, I thought I'd give this a try and I'm glad I did.  I love the convenience of plopping my N4 on this Anker charger and not worrying about a connector being strained or bent in the process.  Of course, for the Anker wireless charger to charge, it needs power that it gets from its own cable, but that's to be expected.  All in all its flawless in its abilities and before you ask, yes it has a sweet spot, but its pretty forgiving.  Just make sure the little blue light comes on and you're good.Would buy again (and will, as my mom's new phone is Qi-Enabled).

The top cover snaps perfectly on to my Macbook Pro 13" w/Retina (late 2013). Keep in mind that almost all matte/rubber finish hard case covers are grease and oil magnets.  No matter how much you wash your hands and dry them, your fingerprints will smudge onto the cover and it can be difficult to wipe off.  By the end of the day after I pull my laptop out of my bag multiple times, the cover is completely covered in smudges and fingerprints.  It almost got to the point where I gave up cleaning up the cover.  It makes you wonder because this was for 'protection' of my laptop, but the trade-off is that you took a sleek and beautifully crafted laptop and slapped on a grease/oil attracting plastic cover on it.  The bottom half of the case is not constructed very well.  It is slightly higher around the edges and is sharp.  So if you type and your wrists are laying in a certain way, you will get scratched/cut.  I decided to leave the bottom portion off.  Other than that, it's okay.  But I have just gotten to the point to leave the whole case off from time to time.
summary: Top cover is great. Bottom, not so much. Oh yeah, this thing is a grease/oil magnet.

reviewText: The 5-6-hour battery life typical of many cellphones is barely enough for heavy telephone usage, much less the texting, emails, location services, and apps that drain batteries. Since it's not always possible to be near an AC charger or car charger, an external battery pack is a necessity for many people nowadays. (The recent storms that knocked out electrical power to millions of people is further proof of the need for external battery packs.) In my opinion, there are four key issues to take into account when buying an external battery pack:1. Form factor. I'm including both size and weight. You'll most likely be carrying the charger in your pocket, purse, travel bag, or glove compartment of your vehicle. Smaller and lighter are better.2. Capacity. Rechargers come in a range of capacities from about 2,500 mAh to as high as 12,000 mAh. Figure that 2,300-2,700 mAh is about the equivalent power of a typical rechargeable AA NiMH battery, and that may give you some idea of a battery pack's capacity. Mobile devices will vary a lot in how much capacity it takes to recharge their internal batteries, with the larger tablets requiring considerably more power than a smaller cellphone.3. Reliability. As with any other product, go with brand names you're familiar with, or ones with reviews that you trust.4. Value. Battery packs with higher capacities will generally cost more than ones with smaller capacities. Figure on some tradeoff between size/weight, capacity, and price that fits your budget and gives the capacity you need.---------------------------------------Yubi Power sent me one of their YP520A 5200mAh External Battery Pack units to review. The device appears to be well made, and it was very compact (3.9" x 1.6" x 0.8"). Adapter plugs are included for Apple devices and other devices that have Micro-USB and Mini-USB ports, which include the majority of mobile devices sold today. The output is 5 volts @ 2.1 amps. There's also a flashlight built into the charger.The battery pack can be recharged with an AC wall charger or car charger that provides greater than 500mA. I gave it a full charge in about five hours using a Kindle AC charger (5 volts @ 0.85 amps). Alternatively, the unit can be recharged from the USB port of a PC. Although the battery pack does not include a charger, most users will already have AC wall chargers or car chargers that will work.I tested the Yubi Power battery pack on my Samsung smartphone and my Kindle Fire HD tablet. I was most interested to see how long it required to increase their charge from about 90% to a full 100% charge. With the Kindle Fire HD, it required about 45 minutes; with the smartphone a bit less than a half hour. I also tried recharging my e-Ink Kindle reader, and it recharged it, too.Overall, I'm impressed with the Yubi Power external battery pack. It appears to be well made, it's compact, and it works very well with all of our mobile devices. Considering the size and weight, the 5200 mAh capacity, and the price, it's a very good value.
summary: A very compact but effective battery pack

reviewText: I've literally owned 3-4 dozen bluetooth headsets, they are essential in my business so I was excited to try this brand that I am not familiar with. First, the ear loop was difficult to find in the packaging, at first I though it was missing. Once I got this charged, I used it for a good 3-4 days. It connects well, I can hear okay, but the other callers complained I sounded like I was in a tunnel, or underwater, or outside.. when each time I was in my vehicle. Absolutely no problems with connecting to phones and staying connected, but I think sound quality is the most important thing and in that area this bluetooth fails.

As I'm waiting to buy a new phone, I still need to keep my phone alive.  My previous battery, a Seidio 1800mAh, was dying too fast, and needed something that would last me past lunchtime.  Laza's battery extends my battery well enough to 15 hours to empty.  The backing is solid, but a pain to remove if I need to.  Would definitely recommend if you are trying to keep your Epic 4G alive a little longer for a cheap price.
summary: A decent battery extender for a cheap price

reviewText: I have owned this phone and a few other android phones over the last couple years and let me just say this one was quite a bit of a let down.  Let me start with whats good.  It looks great, and feels solid in the hand.Now onto the bad.  Motorola decided to yuck this up with their terrible Moto Blur skin.  What that means is that user interface looks ugly, and it does a bad job of adding to the stock android experience.  Next lets move onto Verizon's slow as molasses 3g speeds. In a nutshell, verizon has the slowest 3g data speeds of all major carriers in the US.  What this means is that AT&T; and T-mobile 3G phones can download and stream videos  nearly 4 to 5 times faster.  I know because I also have a t-mobile account and that 3g phone always beats this one in bandwidth tests. 1.5Mb's on Verizon vs 5.5Mb on T-Mobile.  Needless to say it's a huge difference.Also gaming stinks on this phone.  The TiOmap cpu/gpu that motorola used in this phone is very cheap compared to the CPU/GPU that Samsung uses in their Galaxy S phones.  At best, performace wise this phone barely has as much horse power as HTC's Nexus one which was released well over a year ago.So there you go.  Save your money and buy either a newer HTC phone like the thunderbolt (at least it has an LTE radio), or save up for the new Samsung Galaxy S II phones that samsung just announced.  Engadget said it was the best smartphone they have EVER tested.  Eat that iphone.  Currently Motorola's android phones all stink compared to Samsung, and HTC's best.Compared to the iPhone:  There's no comparison, the iPhone blows this hunk of junk away.  Anyone who says otherwise is simply in denial, and has never used an iphone.  The Droid X is for people who want a free smartphone, simply to get their feet wet.  This is in no way a powerhouse of a phone, and it's very buggy.  I'm a huge android, and have supported it from day one with my old T-mobile g1.  But sadly the Droid-X is all bark and no bite.
summary: Droid X - All bark and no bite.

reviewText: I bought this case to place a proxy key card in for my work so I didn't have to wear the card around my neck. reviewText: I've had a number of lanyards over time which always end  up knotting or breaking over time.I came across this by chance when I purchased some  media devil stylus's, they are well made and very very strong, they are  steel,so they are not as flexible as the nylon or rubber lanyards, but I have found this to be a good thing as I do not see chance of tangeling this up.I bought a few different lengths, I have seen a number of people like the 14" lanyards, but I so far have found the 12" lanyard to be plenty for the wifes KindleFire HD and for my Nexus 10.Over all this in combination with a good quality stylus is the way to go, highly recommended.

I love this charging pod!! I put it on my bedside table to replace my old alarm clock. When it's not in use and plugged in to the charger (which doesn't come with the pod, you just use your own charger), it has a small light on the back so you can see where to put your phone in the dark. There is nothing you have to plug in our out of your phone, it just rests in the pod and charges, and if you put the phone into "bedside mode" from the clock, it dims to just the right brightness so you can see it in the dark, but it doesn't keep you awake by being too bright in a dark room. When you plug the phone directly into the charger on bedside mode, the phone goes completely dark, but with the dock it's dimmed so it's still visible. I also like being able to pick the phone up and go, nothing to unplug. This is the best accessory for the Tour!

reviewText: I bought the Laza battery set with charger for my HTC Evo Shift simply because it was at such a good price.  To my surprise, these batteries blow away the performance of the stock battery that came with the phone.  On the first full charge, just to drain it down to 10% to recharge, the 1st of 2 batteries gave me at least 3x more use than the stock battery.  It should only get better with each drain/recharge, as rechargable batteries do.  No problems with fit or quality, etc.Buy them now, while they're readily available and affordable.  Technology changes quickly and parts go fast.  Highly recommend this product.

My son really liked the extra thickness and shape and feel to the case. Reviews do show some of these come with faulty batteries as ours did. Seller offered a return or to ship a new battery, so I will give them 5 stars for customer service. Also, we received earlier than promised. Worth the price if you get a good one.

reviewText: Can't go wrong AT ALL with this case. Fits precisely and snugly onto the iPhone 5. I was really impressed that this case doesn't add too much to the thickness at all. The iPhone 5's beauty is its slimness and this case just compliments that aspect perfectly. Has a nice lip on the front side for when the phone is placed facing down. Side buttons and lock botton operate perfectly. I've tried some cases where you have to really press hard in order for the button to function, but not on the Diztronic. Love it, and would recommend it to anybody that wants to keep the slim form factor of the iPhone 5 plus likes a really snug fitting case.

I'm always a fan of trying new iPhone accessories as there are so many available, so I jumped at the opportunity to review the Belkin Charge and Sync Dock. I have to tell you that I honestly did not read the product page very carefully because I thought a charge and sync dock would at least include a lightning cable. However, I cannot fault Belkin for that because they clearly indicate that no label is included if you read through the product page and the packaging also includes a sticker instructing you to use your own lightning cable.However, I don't know what value this product serves, especially at close to $30. Here are the functions I see it can perform if I had to really think about it:+ Keeps your iPhone upright.+ Manages the cables on your desk somewhat.So, you're paying $30 to keep your phone upright and organize your cables, but then even there it fails.- You have to use your own lightning cable, so if you need to take it with you then you need to go through the process of unhooking it from the cradle. In my opinion, that's more work than benefit.- Let's say you just want to charge your phone and forget that you have it on ring. If you don't have your headphones plugged in or are not listening to them then it's very likely someone can call you and you'll miss the call as you won't hear the phone ringing.Overall, I think this product is an absolute waste of money and not even sure how Belkin let this release to market.********* I received this product for free as part of the Amazon.com Vine program. Nonetheless, I review the product in the same manner as I would if I had purchased it myself. *********

I saw this headset on Jabra's website and was immediately attracted due to the physical design and the fact that you can charge it on the go.  So here goes:PROS:1. I think it fits comfortably on the ear and looks great when worn.2. It turns off when placed in the charger and turns on when removed.  Very thoughtful feature.3. More inconspicuous than other headsets.4. The lights are on the inside, and they turn on only when needed.  Again, very thoughtful.CONS:1. Too expensive.  This is perhaps the most expensive headset I've seen.  It's worth more in the $70 to $80 range, and that'spushing it.2. You can't just tap the headset to answer/end a call.  Jabra's manual states that these functions are done with a tap, butit also does describe it as a brief "press", which is what's needed.  This press tends to force the earpiece more into theear, which can be uncomfortable. So keep in mind, it's NOT a TAP.3. I had a lot of problems with increasing the volume. Lowering it was much more responsive and I used the same force and slidmy finger along the same area, and MY MAIN COMPLAINT:4. The speaker is aimed toward the side of the ear canal (in other words to the front of the device), and not to the insideof the canal.  This baffled me because a lot of the sound is actually muffled by part of the outer ear itself.  I wouldthink that Jabra would want to direct the sound INTO the canal.  This is like placing boombox speakers two inches from awall with the sound directed toward the wall.  Speakers should be place TOWARD their intended targets. Anyway, I pushedthe speaker little more to the inside of the canal and, lo and behold, the audio was excellent.  Unfortunately, the headsetpulls itself back out (normal fit), so the sound will be muffled.I actually WANTED to like this headset.  I would have kept it except it really makes me wonder why Jabra aimed the speakerlike that.  I could have certainly lived with the other CONS I listed.

The mount works very nice.  I was planning to use the A/C vent mount, but it does not fit my 2010 Accord. I use this in conjunction with an iPhone audio/charge connector (also bought from Amazon) which has a USB (to charge) and 3.5mm connector (for audio).  This cable/mount combination allow me a true quick mount/dismount for a real reasonable price and a much better music sound (direct connect always beats bluetooth or FM).  Additional bonus is I can still use my Plantronic 975 for a far superior call quality (and privacy) since it's not taking up the bluetooth connection.As with any goosenecked mount, it will have a slight "jitter" while the car is moving. Otherwise, not much to complain about...gave my iPad Air two full charges (from 5% to 100%) on a single set of 4 AA batteries - that's almost 20 hours of run time.Definitely worth keeping one of these in the luggage and cars for those times when you'd run out of juice otherwise.

IMHO this is slightly better than the Moto H700.  It's larger, and a bit heavier.  The boom is larger.  But if that's not an issue, then both are equal IMHO.  Both have the cheek problem!Now for the problem where people cannot hear you, or you sound muffled or away from the phone.  Wearing your bluetooth, look in the mirror and see how the boom touches your cheek or if you have a beard it'll touch that.  Note there is a very small hole on the inside of the boom that gets the sound.  Now anything that touches that will impede your voice....it's like putting a towel over a regular phone and talking to someone. Not you do not need puffy cheeks for this problem to happen.  Unless you have a very narrow face, chances are this will happen to you and you'll blame it on the bluetooth!TO fix this, get either Neoprene tubing or that sticky foam on one end (mole skin) and cut a small piece and put on the hinge near the boom then a smaller piece (if needed) on top of the other.  This will make a space between your cheek and the boom so people can hear you! With this fix, you will still be able to close your boom.

The technology couldn't be better. Bluetooth conecteivity is simple to establish. The overall physical design is excellent. Though it looks heavy, the unit is a featherweight and fits nicely around the ear. Long-term wearing is comfortable. Audio fidelity is excellent.Where the unit fails badly, though, is the controls. They do not provide enough tactile input. You cannot be certain of where the volume control is or which end of the rocker switch increases or decreases the volume. Since the volume defaults to moderately low setting, this means you are likely to miss the first words of whatever your caller is saying which in turn means a lot of asking "what did you say?".The Call Control button handles at least four different functions. On a phone equipped to handle all four functions, it is easy to mistakenly select a function. For example, on my phone, if I hold the Call Control button a fraction too long, the call is not answered, but the prompt to enter a Voice Speed Dial entry is actuated. No fun when you are trying to answer a call.Plantronics provides three earpiece inserts and it's unlikely that one of them won't provide a comfortable, snug fit.Overall, excellent technology marred by poor ergonomics.Jerry
summary: Poor ergonomics mar this otherwise excellent Bluetooth headset

reviewText: I've owned a lot of gadgets/devices and tried many many cases, sleeves and covers but diztronic cases are the best bang for the buck.  Solid, durable, good quality, sleek, pleasing to the eye and very competitive price.  Some people are okay with spending 30-50 dollars on a case....I'm not.  You will not be disappointed with a diztronic case.Back has a nice grip, doesn't get dirty, leave finger prints, smudges or oil stains.  Nice and tight, great fit and wont break the bank.  The front has a nice lip to it so the lcd glass is protected from scratches when placed face down on a flat surface.  Cut outs are big enough to accommodate most if not all plugs for micro usb or headphones.  Buttons are easily accessible.  Better than any other case at any other price point.

This specialty screen protector from 3M is no more or less difficult to apply than the usual screen protector.  It's not especially prone to getting bubbles or lint during application but the bubbles don't seem to dissipate thereafter as they do with some screen protectors.This film definitely affects the clarity of the screen and perhaps has a small affect on screen sensitivity.What it does do quite well is provide privacy for the display when seen from a side angle when the telephone is held vertically.  So there is a limited number of people who actually need to use this screen protector but for them, it is an excellent choice.  One caution:  when watching video or playing a game with the phone in the horizontal position, the privacy effect is lost.A cleaning cloth and an applicator card (that interestingly enough doubles as the package's hanger tab) are included.  I suggest using the unfolded cardboard package as a clean surface for the application process.Other versions available have a"crystal clear" finishor amatte finishfor glare reduction.
They do work, but definitely don't last long.  You get what you pay for, and that's the truth.  I do enjoy getting 5 packs though for that very reason.

The brand really describes the product well.  I managed to install the screen protector on my first try, with no bubbles.  I now have 2 spare ones.I love matte protectors because of their feel, this one is no different!  Great product!
I really love this cable it works great the quality is still their and its pretty cheap. I would recommend this cable.

This car charger is very discreet, with a 1 1/8 in. square face with nubby soft-grip sides that make it easy to insert and remove from the lighter port.  It stays in place when inserted and a blue LED glows from within to show that it’s powered.  The contacts are polished stainless steel.There are two 5 V USB ports that can be used simultaneously, one at 2.4 amps for maximum speed in charging iPhones and iPads and one at 2.0 amps for Android and other devices.Of course, it has smart circuitry to prevent problems like overcharging or overheating.A reference card is included and it has a one-year warranty.A sample was provided for testing and evaluation.
Good value , nice sturdy case. It can be difficult to take off though. The kickstand is a plus , and the price was decent.

I bought this T&S; Electronics Micro USB Host Cable so I could use my Galaxy S3 as a remote control for my Canon 5DII camera. It performed perfectly by using the "DSLR Contoller" app.What I didn't realize is that this OTG (On The Go) cable also lets me access photos, text and movie files DIRECTLY from an unpowered flash drive or card reader! I had no idea--they really don't discuss this stuff in the phone's instructions.As far as I'm concerned, this should be a standard item included with every smartphone purchase. The cord itself is tough and fits snugly, no chance of accidentally pulling loose on either end. A solid five stars!

For what I was expecting I should have ordered the hot pink (which I just did right before writing this review).2) The second problem that I had was that after the installation I had a massive amount of bubbles that I couldn't remove no matter what I tried. I had to scour YouTube for a solution, which I did eventually find (see my response in the Answers section if you're interested in how I resolved the problem), and after that I was able to smooth out what few tiny bubbles were left.The screen protector looks really pretty on the phone. You truly can't tell that I actually have the white Note 3 just by looking at it.  I know that I'm going to like the hot pink one even better.
summary: Second best thing to having the pink Galaxy Note 3.

While I understand the frustration of users that used this dock and the cable pulled out with the phone, I did as another reviewer suggested and tied a knot in my lightning cable and this dock rocks! I still have the original protector on my Blackberry and you can't even tell it's there.The texture/surface of them does seem to show a fair amount of grease-film (for lack of a better term) and is tricky to wipe off, but not much more than the original surface of the phone.  I'm thinking each protector will last a year, since I see no wear on the one I have on the phone.  Would recommend.

reviewText: I always say you can't have enough backup battery power for travel and/or power outages. This is a nice battery to have on hand. I really like how it has a special higher powered USB port for devices like the iPad so they charge quicker.The battery itself has a nice rubberized coating. I charged an iPad with it and it drained almost all of the battery, so it doesn't have enough power to get a second charge out of it. However, it still had enough power to run the flashlight. Yes, it has a flashlight, which is a great feature for power outages. It isn't a powerful light, but good in a pinch.If you are buying this for the wrist cable, forget about it. It is awful. The hole is too small. It took me ten minutes to get the strap through the hole and it was ruined by that point. Once I finally got it through the cable itself came undone from the plastic clasp that holds it together.For the price it would have been nice to have included a charger with the battery. Yes, it can be charged with any charger or computer with a USB cable, but an included charger would have been nice.

reviewText: These types of cases used to be so common, but now all I see are these big plastic cases that block the aesthetics of the +$200 phones we buy. Well, I was either going to buy something from ebay or amazon, and settled on this.I've had the iPhone 4 since the day it out, and along with it a case that was given to me as a gift. It looked gaudy, with diamond markings in the back. It felt exactly like this case, but a bit softer. I didn't buy a new phone since the 5s, and my 4 had been the same one since the day I received it. I've used plastic cases, the griffen survivor, and a slider/battery case but this type of case lasted the longest with me!For starters, unlike plastic cases, this one doesn't accrue dust/dirty behind the back plate. I've also been using these plastic cases to hold my ID and a single credit card long before those wallet cases.For the actual case, it isn't totally clear enough to always flash your ID out, but it still does the job. I dropped it a few times from arm's length above my head onto a stone floor, and it still protects my phone. It shows off the aesthetics as I would like so I'd rate this a must buy especially since it also comes with a screen protector!
Installed very easily and was afforable. Didnt run into any issue with fitment and worked flawlessly without any issues to this day.

reviewText: It did not stick on my phone right. I had to cut the top off because when I put my case on the next day the shield started peeling off and not sticking. One of the corners is currently peeled up.

This is my first external battery, but seeing positive reviews and the addition of the embedded micro-usb, I chose this one.  At $23, price seemed reasonable.  I really like the convenience of my Exhibit 2 but can't make it through the day without plugging in.  I use my phone as mp3 player and also light web browsing among other things.  Also I noticed my phone goes from 4G to EDGE and back to 4G depending on my location in the building, which can't be good for the battery.I've been using the Anker instead of plugging in for the last week and figured I can get a full charge and maybe half more, which is more than enough for a typical day.  I loaned it to a co-worker to charge her phone for 45 minutes and the battery went from 20 to 45% with light use.  I did notice that my co-worker could easily place the Anker behind her phone and still use it while I put alot of tension on the embedded usb.  Her phone has USB on side while my USB is on top of phone.  I would have liked the cord to be a little longer, but it works.  (Time will tell how durable the cord is.)  Even though I see no need for the USB port at this time, it does work and is a nice extra.  I have only seen a few phones that don't use micro-usb, and most of these are I-Phones.I do like the finish, but it's a fingerpring magnet.  The flashlight is more useful than I expected; not as white as the LED flash of my Exhibit 2, but lights about the same area.  (Never have too many flashlights.)Suggestions to the manufacturer:a) make the embedded micro-usb cord at least half inch longer so I don't have to worry about breaking the cord when back-to-back against my phone.b) make a larger capacity battery version (5000 to 6000 mAh should do it).Then your product would be almost perfect!UPDATE 12/07/12 Still works like a charm.  I usually charge the battery every day when I get home from work.  Have not used away from work yet, but plan to.  Showed several co-workers and they plan to buy one based on my good results.  The battery usually has between 25 and 50% charge and my phone still has about 80% charge.  The micro usb has not been yanked out of the battery yet.  The coil gets twisted the wrong way sometimes (just like a telephone cord gets twisted), but is easily fixed.  I will be very satisfied if the next 12 months are as trouble free as the first four.

This device quickly recharges your iPhone battery.  It proved to be very useful for a job where I needed to use my phone on 3G for 6 or 7 hours.  As soon as my phone got to about a 30% charge, I turned on the backup battery, and restored the battery to 100% without breaking stride.  Great product.

These headphones give rich, full sound, particularly with the iOS app bundled with them. The "Jabra Sound" app is listed as free in the Apple app store, but won't unlock unless you supply a code bundled with these headphones. I thought at first this was just a gimmick, but the sound does significantly improve with the Dolby Digital+ processing enabled by the Jabra app. The headphones are fine with normal sound sources, it's just that they do sound significantly better with the Jabra app.The Jabra app is fairly full-featured.  It imports all your normal iTunes playlists, does Shuffle and Repeat, and has a built-in 7 band equalizer, which is a step up from the Apple music app which hides equalizer functionality in the Settings app and only offers presets, rather than bands you can set yourself. Not that I'll likely ever use this ability myself, but I'm sure some people will find this a nice feature. The main thing the Jabra app won't do is let you set track ratings (1-5 stars).These headphones are significantly louder than my Bose headphones at the same volume, or an ordinary pair of earbuds for that matter. They don't offer as much noise isolation as the Quiet Comforts since they're on-ear rather than over the ear, and once the Quiet Comforts are on the difference is even more dramatic since those feature noise cancellation. Still, in ordinary environments (i.e. not on board a plane or using a snow blower) I prefer these.These are well constructed. I particularly like the nylon covering on the headphone cord, and the way the cord connects to the headphones via a 3.5mm plug rather than a direct connection. There are jacks on both the right and left earphones, so you can switch the cord to whichever is more convenient, and if you snag the cord on something it will detach from the headphones instead of yanking hard on them and possibly breaking.The controls are 6" down the cord from the earphone, probably because the small cylinder with the controls also houses the microphone, which needs to be close to your head. I'm using these with an iPod rather than an iPhone, so I didn't test the sound quality for phone calls.  A quick test with the Voice Memo app showed the sound quality seemed decent enough.The three buttons on the controls are volume up, volume down, and a center "multi purpose" button which handles receiving phone calls, pause / play, and track skipping. One tap is play / pause, two rapid taps is track forward, three is track backward. I found all of these worked perfectly with my iPod 4th generation, though two-three taps is a bit awkward.Overall, I'm quite pleased with these.

I have had better experiences with other brands. Frankly it's not worth the amount it's being sold for should be more like .99cents. - My take

I bought this to charge ipads, ipods, iphones, samsung note 3, samsung tabs, etc...  It is ok for an iPhone, but that's really about it. It has enough charge to recharge an iPhone one time.It is easy to use - just plug it into the phone and press the button and it starts charging the phone and you can see the phone says it is connected to a charger and it charging.It isn't heavy, but the shape is bulky because it is flat and square. Clearly if you had a powermat this would be more useful. As it is, I just plug it into a microusb and plug the other side into a wall outlet with usb or a charger and it recharges and lets you know with the leds that it is ready to go.  THen you find a place to store it *(purse, glovebox, console, wherever) and have it when you need a charge.Personally, this is way too pricey for too little charge unless you have invested in the powermat system in which case you would toss it on the mat and let it charge without hooking up. reviewText: Excellent charger.  I buy this one, to replace another one from other manufacturer.  The other one didn’t charge the batteries to 100% (not originals or replacement’s), but this charge do that.  It’s about 6 hour’s to charge an original one and 4 to charge replacements.  The difference in time it’s because the replacements are 3.7V and the originals are 3.8V.

We have the white version of this that has labeling for different devices. We use it for nighttime charging and it doesn't get hot or anything.This one improves on that by a huge margin by not requiring you to plug your device into any specific port - any slot will do and the device figures out the appropriate charge. That is a godsend late at night in the dark when you're trying to guess which port is the right one.Best of all, I travel frequently and this is internationally friendly. My collegues are very grateful to have an easy place to charge their tablets and phones when this goes onto the table. Plus, with 8 amps, it will charge an amazing array of devices, maybe not 5 iPad Airs, but I have yet to run into the 8 amp ceiling.Awesome device and no issues with either charger yet.
summary: Awesome charger, better than white one!

reviewText: So jealous of my friend who's using it with the new Unlimited everything (including hotspot) plan that just came out from Solavei. Runs off T-Mobile and at&t;'s 4G network for $49/mo and ends up bein free or making you money every month instead. It just launched in September and is taking the money that would other wise be wasted on the same old repetitive advertising and giving it to the people for sharing with others. $20 for every 3 people you enroll every month for as long as they have the service+another $20 for every 3 people they add as well... It adds up let me tell ya. Also coming to Europe next yearLearn more at [...][...]

I have a car charger for my iphone in my car currently, but it always seems like I'm giving it up to my daughter to charge her phone, then I'm out of luck. The Belkin Coiled Car Charger is exactly what I needed to remedy that. I keep this in my purse, and if my daughter needs to charge her phone at the same time I need to charge mine, I just give her this. It works great! I would keep it in my car at all times, but, this is also handy to have on those occasions when I'm in someone else's car and need to charge my phone. I can now just pull this out of my purse, and charge my phone using one of their extra charging outlets. Works as advertised, and it's just a really handy gadget to have around, which is why it rated 5 stars with me.
