reviewText: I have been skeptical about screen protectors, But this Brand really scored. It was not as hard as i thought to put it on as you have to wet the screen. but Once on, its amazing hot strong it is. It does not scratch as easy and its easy to slide the fingers as you type or play games. I would deff buy it again.
Gave this away as a gift as soon as I could.  She loved it though! I'm glad it made someone happy.
This mounting kit is awesome. Works with virtually anything. I have used it for iPhone 4s and now for my Galaxy S3. I would recommend this product for everyone.

The dual Rapiduo Plus USB chargers are AWESOME! I've purchased more of these items than any other electric gadget over the years, and their quality surpasses all the others. Here's why:1. Durability of the product. These chargers are made well, solidly assembled, and FEEL this way. The sleek design seems to fit perfectly into the hand for putting into the car charging port. Other chargers I've used are too short, don't fit well and/or feel flimsy. I've had tons of these fall apart.2. Flexibility of the product. While I've purchased many car chargers that have the cord attached, all of these wore out quickly. The combo of using your standard OE USB cable with the NT Rapiduo allows flexibility for both multiple devices but also allows for the OE USB cord to come out, thus avoiding overwear on a a cheaper third party cord. No doubt NT could produce an equal-quality USB cord but most name brand USB Cords don't hold up like the OE's, particularly Apple's.3. Functionality. You can't beat the "Dual" function: charging two devices out of one plug is great! But buying a two pack allows four devices in one standard car. My first experience using this was to charge my wife's iPad and my iPhone 5, something we've never been able to do in her car due to only one lighter port.4. Power. The greatest "plus" for the Rapiduo- it charged my wife's iPad 3 as fast (I actually think it was faster) than the wall port. It did this WHILE charging my iPhone 5. In about 20 minutes of driving, it charged each device more than 20%. After trying many charging options and getting fed up with low quality and /or slow charging, the Rapiduo is a sure bet for any average to heavy electronics user like me.I travel daily with a list of about 40 places to frequent, and look forward to using these devices regularly.

The price is right for this 2-pack styli from New Trent. Though inexpensive, the styli are weighted just right and the microfiber tips glide over your screens like butter. I've had these for 4 months now and they are still going strong, very well built, no issues.Very pleased with my purchase, and best of all, I can keep one at home and the other at work. I may get another pair down the road. I would recommend getting these as opposed to the New Trent IMP68B which I also own and have had mechanical issues with.
summary: Price is right, pens are first-class

reviewText: Having already bought the Alpatronix battery case for the iPhone 4S for my wife, I was expecting to like the case for the iPhone 5, and I certainly do.  A few things have changed, and for the better.The fitThe case is easy to attach, and improves on the previous model by also making it easy to remove.  The top of the case slides out and stops a quarter of an inch above where the top of the iPhone will rest.  Once the phone is in, the top clicks back into place.  I was worried that the phone would fall out, but days later it hasn't budged from where it should be.  I wondered if the brace would hold if the phone is dropped, but haven't had the nerve to test it.  This isn't specifically a phone protector case so I can only speculate. I will say, though, that the case does come with a screen cover to protect from minor bumps and scrapes.  I have removed my phone from the case and replaced it several times a day over the course of a week, and it has worked flawlessly, without any worrying cracking noises.LooksThe case looks great from the back, and does its best to stay out of the way in the front.  The sides are entirely open, giving easy access to the volume buttons, and the speaker, mic and camera are all unobstructed.  The lightning port is blocked, since that is where the battery booster plugs in.  The case is very thin and light, adding less weight to the phone than I had expected, and keeping the thickness very pocketable.BatterySo far, out of four battery state lights, I have never burned down more than 1 in a day, even working in a building with bad cell reception and cell data on, wifi, and playing games.  I'm not a power phone user, but I play a lot of games.  When my phone gets down to 68% or less, I switch on the battery and I'm back to 100% in a few minutes.Cons?I haven't discovered any serious drawbacks to the case, as of yet, only minor issues.  While charging at night, the indicator lights are bright enough to be a night light, which may be an issue if you require absolute darkness.  The openness of the case tends to mean that pocket lint collects in the crevices of the phone and case, though it's easy enough to clean.ConclusionOverall, I can't recommend this case enough.  It's reasonably priced (or was at the time I bought it), works very well as a backup battery, and stays out of your way while in use.  A real bonus is that the company, Alpatronix, is very responsive to customers, and makes dealing with them easy.  That's a rare quality in a gadget maker.
summary: Good follow-up to the 4s battery case

reviewText: I REALLY LIKED THE CASE AND THE SCREEN PROTECTOR AND I THINK I STILL HAVE THIS CASE SOMEWHERE IN THE HOUSE SO ITS VERY WELL MADE
Its nice to have a back up charger and also have it at home and work. You never know when you will need a charge n this one works great
Excellent cover .. very well made.  The storage slots in the flap as well as the cover are very helpful.  Also appreciate the ability to use as a stand.

The LG ENV touch was my first entry to touch-based screens (I'm still waiting for the iPhone for Verizon - let's hope for early 2011) and I have had it for a year because if I have given a review when I first got it, I would probably have written and raved about it.  But here is my feelings about the phone afterward.After I purchased the LG ENV Touch, it seemed in July 2009, it seemed that right after, there were a good number of better phones that came out right after.  Droid-based phones, new touch devices and granted, this is common and the fact that this phone did not need a data plan which was convenient.But if you are planning to get the LG ENV Touch, there are three things I do recommend. And if anything, you can learn from my mistakes as I tend to drop my cell phones and well, not take the best care of them, like I should.1.  Buy a screen protector - Had this in my suit jacket along with my keys and sure enough, big nice scratch on the screen (sigh).2.  Buy a case protector.  No, not the thin ones for aesthetics.  I'm talking like those Body Glove protectors that are thick because I've dropped this phone many times.  You could try your best and not try to drop it but things happen and in my case, it has created this warping around edge of the top right (obviously some screen damage).3.  Buy a micro SD card.  No you don't have to buy an expensive version, don't be fooled by "cell phone only" as Micro SD card is the same no matter what. With that being said, I've read people not having any success but using Sandisk cards which I do use and I purchased it cheap like $2.99.  Do not spend over $15 for one.  Shop around.POSITIVES:- Great for texting and also for those who use it as an MP3 device to listen to music or podcasts.  Great for those who need to store a database as you can read your excel spreadsheets, documents and PDF's.- Great keyboard, easy to use.- Not that hard to use bitpim on but much easier to load your ringtones on your Micro SD card.- Ease of use.  First time, it might take an hour but after that, you'll get the hang of it.- Connection to your computer via USB to transfer files (to the Micro SD card) is easy.- Quick charge via USB.- Love the speaker phone.- Easy to use apps.- Views .wmv videos quite fine.NEGATIVES:- Battery life - Like most cell phones, you may need an extended battery depending on your use.- This is where I recommend the case because I've dropped this and now the sensitive touch screen will not work that well, I have to flip it on to get it to work. To make things worse, I need to keep the lock on because it starts acting like it's possessed and starts acting on its own as if someone is trying to do several inputs.  Weird.- Photos are not as clear as my wife's Samsung touch phone- Views .wmv videos but very few formats and they have to be several minutes not long.  Tried to put a movie and video wouldn't work, just audio.Overall, The ENV Touch is a very good phone for the basic use having a cell phone and of course, bells and whistles to accompany it. It's not a smart phone, so no data service is required.Since mine is the first generation, one can wonder what LG will have next for the next generation of it.  But learn my situation and get the screen protector and a thicker holder/protector and also a Micro SD card (since they are cheap these days).
summary: I have had this phone for nearly a year and...

reviewText: Took a while to receive this product because the seller is located in Hong Kong, but they work perfect. I have used them on my tablet and iPhones. They work fine, but you can tell they're cheap, but who cares?

reviewText: I found this cable while searching for a video output solution for my Galaxy Note II. Brand name cables are in the realm of $30 to $40.00, so the price and overall rating of this cable was attractive.This cable will transmit a video signal to any HD TV or monitor with an HDMI input via the phone's micro USB port. It is essential to plug the male USB connector on the cable to a charging source rated at least 5v/1A. Most, if not all TVs and monitors with USB ports will not be able to source enough power to charge the phone for allowing use of the HDMI connection, so a standard USB wall charger will suffice as long as it provides enough power.It was packaged appropriately, neatly coiled up in a plastic bag within a padded envelope. The cable itself seems to be of around average quality, and is on the flexible [more "rubbery" than "plasticky"] side... which may or may not be a good thing. The actual micro USB, Male USB and HDMI connectors feel a little cheap, but it isn't especially glaring.I unplugged my Blu-Ray player which functions on the HDMI port I used to test this cable. This cable's HDMI connection felt a little less than confident. I did at first attempt to plug the USB power connection into my Samsung HDTV's nearby USB port [right next to the HDMI input], but it did not source enough power to charge the phone while it was connected and therefore the TV did not recognize my Note II.The USB power cord of the cable isn't very long, which lead me to believe it was designed to plug into the monitor's USB port as a power source, but does in fact need the juice from a wall charger. I eagerly dug up a surge protector and rigged an extension with a quality USB wall charger. The phone was not recognized via HDMI even after several reboots of both it and the Samsung TV [in different orders, as suggested by some users] and accessing/refreshing the TV's sources.I tried again with a standalone LG monitor. It was at a different location and I packed the cable to bring with me and try it out, thinking my own TV could be the problem. I plugged everything in, again needing to figure out how I was going to plug the USB power cord into a wall outlet, and... nothing. Upon wiggling the connectors and cables a little bit, a picture finally came up and my phone recognized the monitor.I spent a few minutes flipping through applications and generally embellishing the big screen experience, but the display would intermittently turn black, sometimes showing static momentarily between the connections/disconnections.I believe the problem lies in where the cables and connectors are fused. Things are a little thin overall and I wouldn't be surprised if just a few light tugs/pulls from normal use and rolling up for storage could result in a poor connection. HDMI cables in general need to be pretty thick and generally provide a robust connection; USB cables are more prone to damage even from coiling up or tugging associated with typical use.I am unsure if I will be trying another one of these as an alternative to a brand name cable. Even if the next one of these worked perfectly right out of the box, I doubt it would last with regular use and storage. I believe many negative reviews for cables like these are the result of user error [getting the wrong cable for a device, not setting up correctly, overall lack of troubleshooting, etc.] and don't reflect the actual experience with the product. Therefore, I am more inclined to purchase a cable by Samsung or other in hopes it is slightly higher quality.
summary: You get what you pay for.

reviewText: This cradle is great! It feels sturdy, the suction cup means serious business and very sticky (Not the gross, leave residue behind kind of sticky. The good kind, if such a thing exists).It is very intelligently designed. It can be turned and tilted in a bunch of different ways and then locked in place that way. It does not drift or droop at all which locked in an unconventional position.I really enjoy the way this thing snaps into place when you place your phone into it (I am using an iPhone 5)- it grips onto the device well enough that it does not slip. Clicking the buttons in on the sides to extend the arms so you can pop your phone into it is a breeze and sometimes I catch myself just doing that and putting my phone into the cradle just to feel and heard the satisfying "click" of the arms closing down on it.Also, the bottom of the phone is exposed so you can charge your phone while it is docked (For iPhones - all-/iPod touch at least)I purchased this because I bought a new car. Unfortunately (No fault of the cradle), the cars dashboard is kind of narrow so I can't really place cradle anywhere on the inside unless I place it on the windshield or on top of the dashboard, which would look weird since the dashboard is raised kind of high (2013 Chevy Malibu). If the suction cup base was smaller I could probably make it work- but no worries.I am actually using this thing at my computer desk now. I snap my phone in, plug the charging cable and i'm in business. But I may move it back into my car for long trips.
Works great, stays clean. Doesn't get too many fingerprints on it.Easy to apply and doesn't affect screen resolution. Will definitely be buying more.
Very easy to get the phone in, very solid, looks very good. Case is very smudge resistant.
It looks very cute once you put it on your phone. But it's not for someone who likes to change their phone case frequently because it is extremely hard to get off.
I always love to buy little gadgets to jazz up my phone and this was so cute I had to get it so far I am the envy of this little bear.

Nice case, light weight.  Arrived on-time like the yellow color.  Haven't dropped it yet, so don't know how well it will survive.  Has metal outer ring and inner plastic case.  Seems like it would survive a moderate drop.

I am changing my review because I ordered so many phone covers I was confused between the two.  This is the one I currently have on my phone.  It fits my Samsung Galaxy SIII perfectly.  I ordered others and will order more soon.  You may want to look into the color screen protectors too.  They are awesome and go really well with these covers.
Good reception. It fits OK on my ear but not perfectly. It seems sturdy. Price was better than most. The wind doesn't bother it much either.
Excellent fit and feels very durable. Fits the S5 perfectly and covers the whole edge of the phone. I love the built in buttons and the 2 tone color is nice in dark shades.
Good price for a decent product. These are hollow and feel very light compared to other ones I have bought with more heft. Just an observation though - they still work as well.

It's a perfect fit, has deep rich color, and feels good in the hand without adding any bulk. For the price, buy two. No, I wouldn't compare it to an Incase brand, but why should I?  It's a $2 case!  I had to buy a second one when the first one broke, but it only breaks if you are taking it off and on, repeatedly.  Just put the thing on a leave it there.  This purchase was for a child's iPod, and the "leave the case on" lesson was necessary for her age. ;)

TPU cases are great.  If you've never owned one before, they are basically a thin, flexible rubber case that hugs your device very close and keeps it protected against dust/scratches.  They are not really made to be super durable, so don't expect Otterbox-quality here (you can't throw your iPod at the wall and expect it to be fully protected!)The clear case shows off the beauty of your iPod touch and offers a great amount of protection against scratches and small dings.  My only complaint is how difficult it is to push the buttons with this case.  I had a different model TPU case before (I didn't like it as much because it wasn't clear) and the buttons were very easy to push.  Now, with this case, I have to struggle to hit them.  Overall though its a very minimalistic case, the iPod still slides easily into my pocket, all the buttons and ports are accessible (including a cutout for the lanyard holder).  I just wish the buttons weren't so difficult to push.
summary: Great minimalistic case - but makes it hard to push buttons

reviewText: I like these earbuds a lot. They are ultra lightweight, portable and convenient to use. Also, the sound quality is very nice.Only reason I gave it four stars only is because I wish the battery life was a bit longer. It the battery longevity can double, that would be best!I still highly recommend it!

reviewText: I love every color in here.  They all fit well and hold my phone securely.  I am very pleased with this purchase.

UPDATE: After over 3 months of regular use, i still like it, paired to my non-Motorola Sprint Palm Pre.  Never drops a call, and I constantly get comments that it sounds like i'm on my home or office phone when i'm in the car.  In fact, driving with the radio on and my son singing in the background, my wife couldn't hear it at all, so the noise cancellation seems to work great.  It does still bug a little that it's trickier to open one-handed when you get a call while driving.  And this one couldn't handle the washing machine (again) so I'll be ordering another one.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Very pleased with the H17 after a month of daily use.  Had an H715 which was great & sturdy, but couldn's survive the washing machine for some reason.  Overall, i'm pleased with it. Bought it from Amazon for thirteen $ LESS than current price (lower than free ship threshold), but it came in a plastic bag - no pkging.  It was all new, so for that price, i tried it and have been satisfied.PROS:-very small, very light-very loud, have to lower volume more than increase-noise-cancellation - people say sound quality is great, even when i'm driving or outside.-flip-to-answer is great - saves battery life-reasonably comfortable, as long as you find which of the included 3 ear clips fits best-uses standard micro USB charging and charges very fast-can sync to 2 phones, but i haven't tried it.-local Costco is selling it for $60 right now.-great range from phone - i can leave my cel charging and walk around the living/dining/kitchen with no static.CONS:(all due to small size & weight)-not as comfortable as H710/15/20 series - ear clips aren't padded-harder to slip on your ear one-handed quickly (eg driving), if you leave it in your pocket.-relative light weight feels like it might be easier to break down the roadAll in all, i'd get it again.  To me the only downsides are those that come with the convenience of a very small headset, with no downsides in audio function.  If i was only using it for driving, maybe i'd get something that's easier to slip on one-handed.
summary: Very Good, Very Small Headset (former H715 user)

reviewText: Fits perfectly, no need to trim them down like you do on other screen protectors. Typical screen protector though, for a good price. I would recommend it for anyone that needs new screen protectors for your iPhone 5.

UPDATE(11/4): So I repurchased the SIII shortly after iPhone 5 was announced as I realized that it would still be the best phone available for quite some time. I've had it (again) for just over a month now and I'm absolutely in love with it. I purchased an extended battery that I've also reviewed and it makes this thing a tank for long travel, etc. I don't know whether the firmware was updated or if my charging habits have adjusted but I rarely even use the extended battery getting satisfactory performance from OEM battery nowadays. This is an amazing phone. I also went with the Pebble Blue this time around and that's a much better color in my opinion. Not enough bezel to make the white look as good.ORIGINAL REVIEW: I owned a 16GB White Samsung Galaxy SIII for approximately 28 days before I reluctantly returned it. Previously I had owned an iPhone, iPhone 3GS, and an iPhone 4. So let's talk the SIII.The hardward design is fantastic. The device is super slim and very lightweight. Seeing the phone and it's magnificent screen, you initially think it's going to be very heavy and bulky but it's really light and thin. The plastic backing helps with the weight savings yet doesn't feel cheap or flimsy. The form will simply be too big for some, but for those that really enjoy using a smart phone the massive screen is a dream come true.The Android 4.0 ICS is great and really responsive allowing you to multitask and switch apps like a pro. I've noticed that implementation of some functions is not quite to "Apple standards." I use that analogy not because I think Apple is the gold standard, but because that was my previous experience. For example, the Bluetooth seemed much less relaible skipping much more while using my headphones. Additionally, the device seems to struggle with wired audio as well having playback loss when connected to my car stereo. I will say that I can't be sure whether the issue with these are hardware, firmware, or the particular app I was using. The beauty of Android is that you have more flexibility but that flexibility can make it difficult to identify a culprit when things are not up to expectations. Also some of the stock programs like the email and text message are not great but having Android allows you to easily enough swap them out with many of the free alternatives in the Play Store.The 4G LTE is fast. Amazingly fast. Faster than my home Wifi. A joy to use but I was surprised that you seemingly could not disable it where you were concerned about saving battery.The camera is worthy of point and shoot status taking brilliant pictures.So why on Earth would I return it? The answer is battery life. I'm not techie enough to know whether the battery itself is insufficient or the SW is not optimized to preserve battery. All I know is that the thing just drains in standby, even with all the background apps killed. I didn't think this would be a big deal as I always charge at home and have spare chargers at work and in the car. The last straw was when I fell asleep after a late night charge but without charging overnight. Both times the phone was dead when I woke up. Coming from the iPhone, which has its own battery issues but will usually last through the night uncharged, that was simply unacceptable to be left with a dead phone after only 7 or 8 hours of standby.So as much as I love and want to keep this device (and generally hate Apple as a company), the bottom line for me is that it's a phone first and nothing is worse than a dead phone. I may re-purchase the SIII if some attractive aftermarket battery options become available but for now I had to return it and preserve my phone upgrade for something that gives me a little more juice.
summary: Updated: A Clear Winner in a Sea of Smartphones

reviewText: As stated, this stylus works better than any others I've used in the past. It flawlessly maintains input/track with each of my devices. Many other styli that I have used constantly experience interruptions due to a loss of electrostatic input. It has a very comfortable feel to it, that is, in terms of using the stylus end. Additionally, it looks very nice and professional. The pen side is a little awkward for me to use - the grip feels odd due to the clip, and I personally prefer a finer pen tip. I gave this product a 5 out of 5 due to it's function with mobile touch devices; I consider the pen an added benefit.Likes:- Functionality: Works flawlessly - just have to keep in mind that a slight amount of pressure is required.- Stylus Grip: Feels very natural to hold and use.- Look/Design: Very professional looking.- Pen twist function: The pen tip remains inside until needed; that is, it doesn't ease it's way out unless desired.Dislikes:- Pen grip & fineness: The fineness is mostly personal preference, but I feel as though the grip would be odd for many people.- It would be beneficial to have some form of cap/protection for the stylus end. I could see the microknit tip becoming damaged semi-easily, especially with frequent insertion/removal from pockets.
summary: Excellent stylus. Works better than any other I've used.

reviewText: They are perfect.  i like the Friendly Swede long cord w the longer stylus & my iPad but I like the short ones for my iPhone
summary: Bundle of 12 Short 4" Detachable Tether Strings

reviewText: Won't work if you have a case on your phone, though. Otherwise, works very well. Charges iphone. Cord is retractable but rather short.
summary: Won't work if you have a case on your phone, though. Otherwise, works very well.

reviewText: Ravpower Bolt: 4 USB port chargerCurrently for 20 bucks on amazon which is a steal for what it does.So if your household is like mine where each family member is tied to their smartphone and/or tablet then you have dozens of chargers at every outlet in the house.  The living room has 2 chargers, the kitchen has a charger....its utter chaos!  Now with family visiting, its even worse!  People fighting for "prime charging outlets".  While family is over for the holidays I've counted 3 ipads, 3 android tablets, and a 10 phones (android and iphone).The convenience this little savior brings can not be put to words.  Being able to charge 2 tablets and 2 phones at 1 location is amazing.  Placing the charger on the side table really declutters the house.I decided to get a central charging station that anyone could use.  So here came Ravpowers 4 usb port charger.4 ports designed to charge iPad and tablets (2 x 2.1A)iPhone and Android devices (2 x 1A).Total combined output of 6.2A (Ports are specially designed for the labeled device but also charge many other devices at full speed).Compact, unibody design for added portability.Industrial-grade plastic outer shell and premium circuitry ensure lifetime reliability.AC 110-220V input voltage ideal for international travel.Package contents:RAVPower 4-Port Wall Charger, 3.84ft / 117cm detachable power cord, user manual.It's a pretty bare charger.  Power cord, central charging hub and a manual.  No frills to keep cost down.I ran a series of tests between:Iphone 5Nexus 5S3S2Droid BionicIpad 4Ipad 2Nexus 7galaxy tab 3All combinations of tablets and phones were able to be charged without a problem.  No hiccups or lags, everything seemed to be charged a normal pace.Build Quality:Very sturdy, with a good weight to it.  It's not too light where it would slide and shift around on our glass table.  Nothing creaks or seems flimsy at all.  It has 4 non-slip pads/feet at the bottom to prevent it from sliding around.The blue led is on the bright side as you can tell from the pictures.  It's ridiculous trying to look at it, maybe a soft green would have been better.While it did not come with any micro usb cables as all of us have dozens laying around.  It'd be a nice to have short cables like in the pictures so it doesnt get to messy around the charger.It gets warm but never too hot to be concerned about it.Value:For 20 bucks I really dont think you can beat it.  It's nice to not have a charger at every outlet in the house now.

Marware mini rechargable speaker is simple to operate and produces some great sounds for such a small speaker.  Plug this little guy into any 3.5mm headphone jack, twist the top and sit back and enjoy.  Recharging is done from the usb cable to the PC.  Well worth getting for those places where headphones are not needed.
summary: Easy to Use with Good Sound

reviewText: I love the look and feel of this case but I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because the side buttons are not exposed and it is a little hard for me to push them with this case.

This is neat little device. If you are someone who uses your phone as much as your computer, it certainly comes in handy. It fits like a case onto the back of the phone. Therefore, another case is not necessary and would not fit. The keyboard is connected magnetically and it slides out, but it is not totally connected and it can come off. Around 7:00 PM today I am like 75% so I turned on WIFI, 4G, GPS and Bluetooth to try and drain it.  8:30 I am still at 62%.*** One week later ***  They say you should drain this completely and recharge fully to get the best performance.  I have a hard time draining it.  In a whole day, I leave on GPS, WIFI, Bluetooth and 4G ... the phone is still at 70% as I'm ready for bed.I used to carry around TWO spares, one of them a SUPPOSED "extended life 3500mAh" battery I bought here for six bucks or so.  I felt embarrassed at customer sites asking for a charge during meetings.  I would run up and down Amtrak cars looking for a window seat so I could charge my phone.NO MORE !!!!  This battery changes my relationship to my phone. It changes my life for the better.

I have been applying screen protectors to devices since the original Palm Pilot came out.  I've even applied screen protectors using the identical three layer process.  I have never had a problem.  Yet I just spent an HOUR trying to successfully get one of these useless things on my Samsung Galaxy Note 3.  I'm on protector number two and will have to try my third and last, but I'm thinking I'm out 10 bucks and my time and I'm feeling frustrated and even angry.The protector is so thick and rigid that when I try to smooth the "1" backing down as I ATTEMPT to install the protector, the whole protector lifts off the phone (the backing isn't tacky enough to resist its desire to straighten), ruining the carefully placed alignment. I finally removed more than two inches of that backing so there's enough to actually stick to the phone.  I thought I actually got it but there were HUGE air pockets around the edges of the phone.  In error, I thought I could "buff" them out, but it's impossible (and no, they're not from dust).  And NOW, there's no protective backing so the entire screen protector needs to be lifted and re=smoothed with the whole thing exposed to air and potential dust.  I suspect this is design related with the protector being a bit too wide.  The slightly raised lip of the Galaxy Note 3 makes it impossible to get the protector flush against the sides of the device, so it lifts (air pockets).  You can try to smooth out the huge air gaps but they return again and again because you can't get the protector 100% flush against the phone.The first protector somehow got a hairline crease in it, so I had to try a second protector and experienced the same air pockets.  Now, dust has inevitably comes into play from my many frustrated attempts to fit this stupid thing (dust removal stickers are a sick joke - they do NOT remove dust from the protector's tacky side at all), so I'm going to have try the third - and I ALWAYS get protectors installed first try.  I've never needed to go to a second, never mind a third.Unless you enjoy futility, frustration and wasting money, AVOID.
summary: Would give it zero stars if it were an option

I've had this item for 4 months. I've been using it with an S3 equipped with a basic gel snap on case. I'm running CM 10.1, so I can't attest to any Samsung specific dock apps. I purchased the optional iBolt AMPS plate so I could attach it to a Proclip mount. I very badly want to like this dock...especially with the money invested in it and the AMPS plate. However, there are a few problems with it that give me reason to look elsewhere when it comes time to purchase a new phone and the associated dock accessories, etc.The USB cable/plug on the actual dock is too long and stiff for the S3. This necessitates pushing the S3 as far to the side as possible in the mount - in order to remove any slack in the USB attach point. If I center the S3 in the mount, there is then slack in the USB elbow...which makes it bunch up slightly...and with the stiffness in the cable....the USB plug will not sit flush in the port on the phone and it quickly pops out.Having to keep the phone all the way over to one side also puts pressure on the extendable feet on the bottom of the mount. Now the foot on the side of the mount where the USB plug is, will not stay retracted....causing the phone to loosen in the mount or sit at an odd angle.Based on the above two issues it appears that the S3 is on the extreme minimum size end of the phones that can use this mount. An S4 or more appropriately - a Note - would probably fill up the mount sufficiently to eliminate my two primary complaints.Unrelated to the size issues - the interference via the charging/auxiliary cable is severe. The static and cell signal sound can make listening to an audio book an exercise in mental fortitude (akin to having nails on a chalkboard in the background). I wish I had bluetooth in my fleet vehicle!

reviewText: I received this well-machined (metal housing of outstanding build quality), aesthetically pleasing, mid-range (5600 mAh), external battery with a handy form factor about 2 weeks ago and have been more than pleased with its performance while putting it through its paces since then.It's just slightly more one-half the capacity of another such item by a different manufacturer that I reviewed some time ago [OXA Juice Box S2 10000 mAh Safe External Battery 18M WTY Premium Samsung Cells Digital Screen & Flashlight All-in-One charger external portable power supply, (5V 2A and 1A USB Output) Mirco USB connector and more - see my review)], but is much more portable because of this and can be easily slipped into an available pocket for readily available on-the-go use.Although this LiBa battery comes with a USB cable and all the connectors that you will need on a daily basis, you will very likely find that the cable provided is a bit on the short side when used in combination with charger and a standard wall outlet. It's not long enough to let you either rest the battery comfortably on the window sill or place it securely on the floor with a bit of slack. Instead, it just sort of hangs there in no man's land. This will usually not be a problem since most people will have at least one longer USB cable available, but including such a cable in the package itself would be a nice touch.The device comes with 4 light blue LED status lights that flash while charging and are all a solid blue when the battery is fully charged. Each illuminated LED - when checking the charge - represents an approximately 25% increment of the battery's capacity. A handy little LED flashlight for spot illumination is also built into the housing; it can be turned on and off by twice sequentially pressing the single power/control button. If you follow the incorrect instructions for turning the flashlight on and off provided in the enclosed instructions (depress for 3 seconds to turn on or off) you will not accomplish anything whatsoever and eventually begin to think that the LED bulb or the battery itself is defective.Although the short USB cable provided may be just the thing for charging the battery via a USB port on your PC, I much prefer using an external charger which is much quicker. After this external battery was fully charged, I first used it on my Moto X smartphone which had been depleted to 55% of its full charge. It took this LiBa battery about 1.5 hours to return my smartphone to the 100% level after which all 4 battery LEDs were still illuminated. A second attempt with this same smartphone when it was at 25% of its full charge took 2.25 hours to return it to 100% after which 3 of the 4 battery LEDs of the previously fully charged battery were still illuminated.I also plugged my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 when it was at 56% of its full charge into a fully charged LiBa and achieved a 100% charge on my Kindle after 2 hours 40 minutes. The external battery lost at least 50% of its charge (2 out of 4 LEDs illuminated).A nice improvement to this unit would be the addition of a second higher rated 2A charging port for quicker charging of items such as the above-mentioned Kindle tablet. As it stands, the device only has a single 1A output (best for smartphones) for this purpose, but it does get the job done; it just takes longer to do so.I should also mention that the English instructions included - although short - are quite understandable, something that is not always the case with items manufactured in China. The aforementioned OXA external battery was quite atrocious in this regard.Certainly this LiBa 5600 mAh Cell Phone Portable Charger - External Battery Charger Pack holds more than an adequate amount of power in reserve for all those occasions when an AC outlet to plug in your cell phone or other charger is nowhere to be found and a car charger also is not a viable option - most definitely a recommended item.Note that the manufacturer provided me with a sample battery for review.
summary: LiBa - reserve battery power for those on the go

reviewText: It took me a while to decide what phone to buy - did lots of research. I believe in yesterday's technology when it is still good. This is. It does everything the new phone of today do. Only issue I have - and I've reaad about it in many reviews - is the camera. It is very slow to respond. But that is not why I have it. I have a good DSLR and it doesn't bother me that the camera in my phone is not that great.Everything else works wonderfully. Great reception....I can hear and be heard well. It finds my wireless very quickly. Lots (LOTS) of options in the settings menu. It is extremely highly customizable. There are seven (7) home pages to set up whatever you may need. I have it set up as one with my calendar, another with music/radio apps, another with oft used numbers, another with a sticky note and one with photos, one with navigation and map stuff and the last with misc apps including my Siri-like helper (works great by the way).The battery isn't great, but it lasts all day. I am used to charging it each night. I bought a second battery so it's there if I do need it.Get a case of some sort (even though it's a pretty device, you need to cover it) - and a screen protector. I have two different types of cases I got here on Amazon (the battery too). I also suggest you get a Bluetooth if you don't already have one - pairing is simple and fast.But back to the Droid X - it is great. I love my phone and use it for many things all day, every day. The fact that it is larger than most other phones is nice. I can see better with the extra real estate. Carrying it is no bother if you have the right case. It will fit in your pocket - but be careful you don't break it there.Great phone. If something happened to mine - I'd get another one.

reviewText: I am often running out of power on my iphone at various times, either from overuse or just forgetfulness. So, extra battery packs seemed just the thing. I got this plus the Overnighter (Duracell Powermat GoPower Overnighter Backup Battery, Power Bank for iPhone 5S/5C/5, Samsung Galaxy S4, Other Smartphones and Tablets), just for backup - as advertised. I had previously been using the "Energizer PP-IP4SB iPhone 4S and iPhone 4 Charging Case," which, unlike these Duracell Powermat devices, doubles as a phone case.  The only thing I didn't like about the Energizer, was that it added a  bulk and weight to my phone which i didn't particularly care for, so i thought i'd try out these other backups.  Well, after a few weeks of carrying this Daytrip around in my purse, and using the Overnighter on travel, I decided to go back to my Energizer despite the added weight and heft.  For me, it turned out that the convenience of having the battery already stuck to my phone outweighed the inconvenience of carrying the additional weight. Also, the Energizer gives me about a 90% charge up. I'll discuss the Daytrip here, and my review for the Overnighter under that webpage separately:The Daytrip charges my iphone 4S to about the 65-70% within an hour or so (pretty quick), but never goes above that amount no matter how long i plug it in for- it stays on 1 blue bar for nearly 10 hours or more, but does not add but a few percentage points or so more to my phone power after that initial hour. Additionally, it is a tad bulky (like a makeup compact) in my purse- i sometimes try to avoid carrying a purse, and the added "thing" to carry in my pockets gets a bit much to juggle. If you don't like to carry your whole house in your purse, or don’t carry a purse or murse (man-purse), you may find this an issue as well....but that's individual.  On the other hand, the Daytrip conveniently has the charging cords built into it, so that you don’t have to also carry around a separate usb cord. An additional plus is that after a few weeks of not using it, it still held the 4 bar charge, and charged my phone back to that 65-70% level just fine.Good:-quick charging in an hour-separate usb cord unnecessary-holds full backup charge for weeks very wellNot great for me:-another thing to carry and possibly lose or misplace-only 65-70% charge capacity for my iphone 4S from empty-relatively bulky in my purse or pocket

(Read revisions below)I pre-ordered my Galaxy S3 last year and still love it.  When new, the battery lasted 34 hours with moderate usage--meaning I could forget to charge it one night and get through the next day at work without having to charge it.  After a year, the battery was lasting 12 hours with moderate use.  I wanted a new battery, and the Anker 2200 mAh battery should have been slightly better than my original battery (2100 mAh).  It is not.  It lasts 13 hours with moderate use, which is BARELY better than my worn battery.Revision 1: The manufacturer has contacted me and is sending a replacement battery.  I will update the star count once the new battery arrives next week and I see how well it works.  I do appreciate them contacting me pro-actively.Revision 2: The manufacturer sent a new battery and it lives up to my expectations for how a new battery should perform.  The customer service from the manufacturer was very good.  They initiated the contact and followed through until I was satisfied with my purchase.

I think it is very important for you to know this information before moving onto the product review. Once you purchase the product, you will find an interesting disclaimer on the bottom of the box, here's what it says:IMPORTANT: This case is not indestructible and should be used with care. Case or phone may be damaged by drops less than tested height - particularly on non-smooth surfaces. We do not warranty that this case will protect your device in all circumstances - user exposes their device to hazards at own risk. User must follow all installation, maintenance, and operating instructions carefully for water, dust, and shock protection. Ensure all seals are properly closed before exposure to dust or liquids. Ensure complete closure and inspect case for damage after impacts. Under no circumstances will LifeProof repair or replace a damaged device. This case is not a substitute for regular backups or insurance.I know companies have to cover themselves from dumb users who always want to sue for everything, but the disclaimer pretty much tells you: Ok dude, whatever we said in our advertisement, may or may not work for you. If it does work, cool, you got lucky! If it doesn't, deal with it.Now, focusing on the product alone, I can tell you that upon receiving the product, packaging was awesome, I think they spent a big chunk of their money on it, looks good! Once I held the product in my hand, the quality did not feel much different for what I could get for a $20 case, I'm talking quality alone, I know this case has some features that cannot be found on a $20 case.This case is supposed to be water proof, dirt proof, snow proof, and shock proof (if you're lucky) but I was not going to risk my $600+ iphone for the sake of a review. I can tell you however, that it does look like it seals all the potential leaks. Overall, I think this case should not be any higher than $45 for the quality that you get and the kind of warranty that they offer.Buy at your own risk, I just hope that I got lucky with my case if it ever comes the time that I have to test it's features.

Power banks are becoming pretty common these days and basically all work the same: they house one or more lithium batteries which you charge via AC current, then use the power bank to charge a portable devoice, such as a phone, tablet, etc.Since the overall operation is so similar, power banks distinguish themselves mainly on design and ease-of-use features. In these regards, the Intocircuit does a very nice job.The power bank offers 11,200mAh of power which gives it enough capacity to cover a few charges of a small device (such as a phone) or one charge of a larger device (such as a tablet). In my case, I use it mainly to keep my Kindle Fire 8.9 charged, and it does a capable job - for example, it brought it from 30% to 80% charge while still retaining enough capacity to recharge my Samsung phone from nearly empty to full.But, pretty much any power bank of a similar mAh rating could do the above tasks. What I like about this one is the overall design - it looks nice! The case (I have the gray one) is metal with a brushed finish. The end-caps are plastic, but have a softness to them. The overall affect is that it feels and looks nice, rather than cheap and "plasticy."It's more compact than other power banks I've used in this power range. It measures about 4.5 inches tall and 2.75 inches wide. It's pretty thick - just shy of 1 inch thick. It also has some heft, weighing in a 9.9 ounces. Unfortunately, size and weight are the prices paid for more capacity, but this power bank does a good job of keeping things manageable.All the ports are at one end. It offers two outputs (1 is 2.1A; the other is 1.0A rated), an 5v in connection and a LED flashlight. The ports are well-attached with no wiggling or give even when I put a lot of stress on the cables. On the front is a decent-size, clear screen that shows a battery icon with the charge level. It also indicates which ports are in use. There's an on/off button, but it's not necessary to turn it on to use - it has an auto-on feature that engages the charging as soon as the cables are attached.You can use the on button for the flashlight (press it twice rapidly to turn on the flashlight). It's a nice touch since I'm often using this in a car and an extra light to see the ports is helpful. It puts out a decent amount of light - more than enough to see where what goes where when inserting cables.The power bank comes with an assortment of the usual attachments to cover a range of devices. I won't list them here since they are in the product listing. I only used the micro USB cable (which worked just fine and felt decently made), so I can't speak to how well the other attachments work.It also comes with a soft pouch that is large enough to hold the power bank plus a few attachments. I was especially pleased to see that it comes with an AC adaptor - other power banks I've used skip that. The adapter is compact and fits easily in the pouch. The amp rating for the adapter is not listed on the adapter nor in the specs.There are some misses:1. The lettering for the port power output (1.0 or 2.1 amp) is black on black and VERY hard to see unless there's bright light. I stuck an adhesive dot next to the 2.1 port so I could easily spot it.2. The on/off button is very small and feels cheap, unlike the rest of the power bank. While it is not needed much since this is an auto-on devoice, a larger button with a better "click" feel would have been nice.3. The screen is clear but the screen cover is thin and flexes. Again, it introduces a somewhat cheap feel to an otherwise solid device. The screen is also a fingerprint magnet (unlike the case, which is fingerprint-proof due to the brushed finish).4. No power rating for the AC adapter.I'll keep the rating at 5 stars since these misses 1-3 are mostly cosmetic; miss #4 is more of my curiosity than an essential issue. It's a decent power bank that is worth considering.[Manufacturer provided sample for review]

I ordered 4 of these OEM Samsung chargers for my Galaxy Nexus. The shipping was free, but it wasn't Prime shipping. It took just over a week to get. Packaging was very plain. No big deal, just giving a heads up. No doubt at least one was a used device. The others, could have been used or could have been acquired in bulk. They are OEM.Pros:- 3 of 4 worked. They are the actual Samsung chargers and they do rapid charge. They list as 5V 1A.- Mini USB cables are included.- Cheap, but I see the price almost doubled from when I bought them a few weeks ago.Cons:- The 1 charger that did not work, the internal pin was stripped and crunched all the way to the bottom. Only 3 of the 4 pins were serviceable. Very poor QAQC. Not only that, this device looked all scratched up and definitely was used. Very poor all around.- The included cables all worked, but came from different Samsung models. Only two were identical and labeled identical to the ones I got with my phone. This isn't that big of a deal, but wanted to point it out.Conclusion:I do not regret the buy. The working chargers rock. I have these chargers in place at several locations so I don't need to keep moving and misplacing these. They charge my battery hungry GNex quickly. If I had paid the current price for each of these, I'd be upset, but since I paid way less, it is easier to swallow and easier to focus on the 3 that work great. If I had all 4 work, I'd give this buy 5 Stars. I have not done a return. Returns through Amazon requires returning all 4 quantities. If Yellow Deals lets me return only the defective one, I'll return it.

I purchased other captivate batteries from eBay before, some gave much shorter battery life, some worked OK, but none of them will force restart the phone like this one. FYI, I use android stock 2.3.UPDATE: I flashed to ICS 4.0.3, same restart problem.Bottom line: if you're looking for a battery as a backup when you travel and you don't care about charging the battery using the phone and you have a separate battery charger, go for this one. If you'll be annoyed by the phone restarts whenever you plug in USB (e.g., you want to transfer data between your PC and phone), then I suggest you buy some other batteries. But for this price I don't believe you can get an OEM battery.

To its credit, the Speck CandyShell Amped case is ingeniously designed: it has a conduit bored through it, which serves to amplify the iPhone speaker output to audible levels. It's a useful perk for listening to music in a quiet office or room. Unsurprisingly, the audio quality and power isn't notable. The sound is tinny (just as it is coming from the iPhone's external speaker), and gets muddled with any complex music.The case itself is rugged, and would be great for hiking or outdoor work -- any environment that necessitates extra protection of your device, basically. The material is hard plastic, not slippery, and will provide moderate to high protection for your iPhone: bumps, drops, whatever, it'll be safe. The phone sits snugly in the case, and is securely held.However, it's also painfully poorly designed for pragmatic, daily use: getting a headphone 1/8" jack into the audio-out is impossible and requires removing the iPhone from the case. The charging jack is also more difficult to access. These kinds of issues are (frankly) inexcusable, given that the iPhone 5/5S has been out for a couple years now, and this type of rookie design error is unacceptable.
summary: Suffers from Design Flaws, Not Recommended

This very attractive OXA Bluetooth Speaker paired with any device that I attempted with no problems pairing..Note that this speaker has Bluetooth capabilities as well as audio in out (with a cable included) so that you can plug it into your radio, CD player etc when you don't want to use Bluetooth and just need the speaker part.In addition, it also has a slot for a MICRO SD card (no SD card is included, just the slot for it). Since the manual is small, I am giving you helps here on how to use this should you buy this speaker.Also, I am able to leave my micro SD card in the speaker's slot, I use the MULTI MODE BUTTON to change the mode and also play from this speaker while it is charging.**This unit uses a MINI charger port meaning that any mini USB charger will fit into the port and charge up this speaker. Since I had an extra Motorola Mini USB Wall charger, I plugged this into my unit and it charges it well and it charges very quickly.PROS:+ MULTI MODES AND USES ETC FOR THIS SPEAKER - Bluetooth, Auxiliary and Micro SD Card:1) MP3 Player/SD card mode - To keep the SD card in the unit when it is turned on it will automatically see that there is a card in the unit and play music from the SD card. If you want Bluetooth instead just press and hold DOWN the Play Button, then the Bluetooth with turn on (you will see the blue lights flashing fast so you can then pair and connect without having to remove your SD card.2) Bluetooth Mode. If you Do Not have an SD CARD in the unit, when you turn on the speaker (on the bottom of the speaker) it automatically turns on the Bluetooth mode so you can pair. You will know this because the blue mini lights flash very fast.3) Auxiliary Mode (this is for your Audio cable to listen to a radio or CD Player etc). Step one: Plug in your in and out cable to the speaker and your CD player, radio, etc. You will need to press the Play (multi mode) button and hold it down. The speaker will realize that it has an audio cable in it so it will be ready to play in regular mode in the speaker (like a regular non Bluetooth type of speaker). This means that you can now play your radio or CD player etc through the speaker (make sure that you have the In and Out Cable (included with speaker) plugged into the speaker and the CD Player etc).4) + Charging - This Bluetooth speaker came with USB Charger cable and charged very quickly (less than 2 hours for a full charge).Charging suggestion - This unit comes with USB charger that you can plug in to a computer to charge the unit. However, since I always have micro USB chargers lying around the house, I used one of my micro chargers and plugged it into the wall to charge. It charged much faster that way. Also, most any brand of micro USB charger should work fine on this unit and it charges very quickly+ Pairing/Connecting - The speaker very quickly paired with my tablet, phone and MP3 player in just seconds!+ Sound Quality / Loudness /Adjusting the loudness- For a very small personal speaker, I found the sound clarity excellent and the sounds of high and low notes good to very good. In fact the sound of this tiny speaker is VERY LOUD better than I expected for such a very small speaker!On this speaker, there is a volume control.  *To up the volume hold down the + Key, to lower volume, hold down the - Key.5)To go to next song, quickly press the + key, or to go to previous song, quickly press the - key.+ Phone Reception - When I had my phone paired and I was listening to music, then my phone rang through the speakers, I was able to use this as a hands free speaker. Very clear reception.Very highly recommend this personal speaker as it plays loud, clear and treble and bass sound great for a portable speaker!
summary: Best Personal Bluetooth Speaker that I ever used! Loud and clear, plays from Micro SD card--Detailed Review!

Very nicely made and conceived product.  Definitely recommend it for your phone.

reviewText: I spend a lot of time using handheld devices in places where there is not always a power outlet handy, so devices like this are of great interest.This unit is a nice size. It is a little wider and thicker than a deck of cards, but not quite as tall. It easily fits in a pocket.There are three ports on it, two output standard USB ports for connecting to devices to be charged, and one micro-USB port for charging this device. There is a 4-segment LED display which shows battery life and whether the unit is charging or discharging, and one switch for activating the LED display when the unit is idle. There are no other switches or ports of any type.===My Test Results===I tried this unit with three devices-A third generation iPad, an iPhone4, and a Kindle Keyboard (the slightly older model with the greenish screen).The Energizer unit arrived about 60% charged, and took about 3 hours to fully charge.From a fully discharged state, the Energizer unit needed 6.5 hours to fully charge.It charged my iPhone (from 20% to 100%) in about 2 hours, and used up roughly half of the capacity. The energizer unit was able to give two complete (20%-100%) charges of my iPhone on a single fill-up.It charged my Kindle in about 3 hours (from the point where the Kindle warns about battery life to a full charge indicator on the screen -see note below). Again, that seemed to take about 50% of the Energizer's capacity based on the status LED's)A full charge on the Energizer was only able to get my iPad from 15% charge to 40% charge, and that took about 3 hours.===The Good Stuff===*It works as advertised, especially for the iPhone and Kindle.*The status bar LED display is easy to read. It is sort of shaped like a battery, with a small square at the top. When the lights are flashing "up", it is charging, when they are flashing "down", it is discharging. The number of LED's that stay lit indicates the current battery level.*It is small enough to carry without a whole lot of effort.* The little magnetic wire holders are sort of neat, but I could live without them quite easily.===The Not So Good Stuff===* I am not a fan of the microUSB connector for connecting the unit to a power source. I am sure they did it to make it easier to distinguish the input from the output, but since I usually don't carry one, it is one more cable to add to my bag. There is a marking on the unit to identify the input port, but you better have good eyesight...I never noticed it until just now when I looked for it.* The display gets a little annoying. It is flashing when the unit is either charging or discharging. Besides chewing up a little valuable power, it is just one more LED trying to ruin my quest for darkness. My hotel room looks like a Christmas tree now.*On the iPad and iPhone, the unit shut off (LED's stopped flashing) when it was finished charging or ran out of juice. On my Kindle, the light on the Kindle indicated that it was still charging, but the Energizer LED's were shut off. The Kindle appeared fully charged. I guess a man with two charging indicators is like a man with two clocks...you never really know.*Would have been nice if it had a little more battery kick.* The two USB ports for charging devices have a limited use. Every device I tried slowed down when connected with a 2nd device...not sure what devices draw so little current that the Energizer unit can supply two of them. I guess it might come in handy if you want to let two devices charge overnight, and are less concerned with total charge time than having to get up at 4AM to switch plugs.===Summary===It works well enough that it will get tossed into my travel bag-sort my stamp of approval. More battery life would have been nice (as usual), but an extra two charges on my phone can come in handy.
summary: Works well enough, a little light on capacity

Recently LowPriceUSA provided me with a bolse product in exchange for an honest review. This review is my honest evaluation of this product based on my experience and without any reward or interference from others.The Bolse 5.4 Amp 3-port USB Car Charger is a small light weight plastic and aluminum product with short circuit and temperature protection and a built in fuse to prevent over powering devices and a LED indicator that lets you know when you device is charging.  It is .71 ounces (20 grams) and the dimensions are 22.36 by 1.46 by .79 inches.  It has DC 12 – 24V input and DC 5V, 5.4A total output.This device allows the user maximum charge speed for 3 USB devices simultaneously.  One port is labeled “2.4A – Tablet” that is compatible with iPad, Tablets and any other USB devices.  It has two other 1.5A input USB plugs.  One is labeled “Apple” that is compatible with iPhone, iPad, iPod or any other USB devices while the other is labeled  “Android” and is compatible with Samsung Galaxy S4, S3, S2, Galaxy Note 2, Motorola Droid RAZR MAXX, HTC One X and any other USB devices.I wholeheartedly recommend this inexpensive, portable, simple and easy to use car charger for those who are looking for a small, safe and durable device to charge multiple USB devices simultaneously.Enjoy!
summary: A Durable, Quality, Attractive and Convenient 3 USB port Car Charger at a Reasonable Price! Enjoy!

reviewText: I bought this for daily and extended travel.  I use a BlackBerry Bold and Playbook, with an active blue tooth Bridge - and frequently, a WiFi connection.  All of these can be an active drain on the batteries by the end of a normal business day.The power port instructions are not great, as indicated in other reviews; but, this is a simple device.  It does need to be fully charged upon receipt, which took longer than I had anticipated.  Definitely something to do starting early in the day or before retiring for the night.The plug tips provided cover a range of devices - some that seemed obscure, unless one has a Nokia, Samsung, or other non-micro/mini USB devices.  Some of the tips and cables seemed flimsy, but probably okay if not used in public places where they could be jostled.The charger has not been used heavily, yet; so this review will be updated after more use.  I am rating this a 4 due to the lack of use, the flimsy quality of the cables, and the poor instructions.  I assume the review will step up to 5 stars after use.

reviewText: UPDATE:I was impressed with the phone right out of the box--it fulfilled my cell phone/camera/Internet needs well in an inexpensive package, but after applications crashing constantly and a general lack of stability with the OS and hardware, I cannot recommend this product as anything more than a backup. I'll be upgrading soon.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I don't like to waste money. And that's exactly what I was doing when I had a typical phone contract. When I switched to the Google Voice/Skype/Gophone setup, I ended up saving about $40 a month and that made me happy. For the longest time, however, that meant enduring communication on a ghetto 1990s phone (the best value I could find for the Gophone). However, when my ghetto phone died recently, I was forced to review the market again and I came across a remarkable gem: the AT&T; Fusion.Not only did it fit well into my money-saving Google Voice/Skype/Gophone scheme, it also had a camera (score!) and was able to handle the internet like my iPod. I went from needing 3 devices when I went out down to just one. It's a testament to the free market that such a product is available for so little moolah. $130 for a small computer that can take pictures and upload them to Facebook. Oh yeah, and it also can make phone calls.There are some serious drawbacks, namely the fact that there's only 200 MB of internal memory on the phone, which is used for apps and text messages. Seriously, we're talking about tera a petabyte devices now; the last I heard of something at the MB level was my Commodore 64 from 1987). If you have too many apps, you can't receive text messages and that's excruciatingly annoying. You can move the apps to the SD card, but that requires some tech-savviness that most consumers don't have the patience for. Also, I had an issue moving my SIM card to this phone from my ghetto `90s one. Text messages didn't come in for a while and it was difficult to figure out what was wrong (AT&T; customer service was actually very good here). I've also had problems with receiving data over the 3G connection.The greatest thing about this device, however, was the brilliant GPS feature. A user can download navigation directions when connected to the Internet, then when driving around the middle of nowhere without a data connection, the navigation app will direct him flawlessly (evidently the GPS feature is free though data would cost).All in all, this is an excellent buy and will only cause a few minor headaches if you're used to more capable devices.
summary: It's Amazing What the Free-Market is Capable Of

If you don't know what this effect looks like, it's similar to what happens when you look at LCD screens through polarized lenses. At one angle, everything looks basically fine. At another angle, it goes dark. The idea is that you can see your screen fine straight on, but people who are a little to the side of you in either direction can't spy.The screen protector does distort the look of the screen just slightly. It's not enough to be hugely bothersome to me, but if you're really devoted to having a perfectly clear screen at maximum resolution, you're going to have to weigh your desire for privacy against your desire for perfect clarity.Other than that, you mostly need to make sure you're clear about how you're going to go about applying it. Most of us have probably had practice with this kind of thing by now, but you only get 1 so you do need to make sure you focus on doing as good a job as you can the first time.

reviewText: While extremely useful, I'm having issues where it disconnects periodically at the worst time, during mid-call. reviewText: Ok, I am adding comments to my original review (below).  Dock no longer works.  Put my phone in and no power.  My multimeter is not working, so I can't tell if it is the plug-in adapter that is not sending power, or if it is the dock that is not working, but either way it doesn't work.  Unfortunately, this is following a pattern of several motorola products I have owned, hence my skepticism in the original review.  Bummer, but at least I will hopefully be able to get a new one under warranty.This is a pretty neat dock.  It is very pricey, compared to the regular (non HD) dock, but the ability to hook it up to your widescreen TV is pretty cool, and the best part (reason I bought it) is that you can hook up USB peripherals.  I had my doubts about this USB feature, but I have 2 different wireless mouse/keyboard combos and both of them work flawlessly with this dock.  My laptop crapped out last week, and I had to research buying a new one using the bionic's webtop app (firefox browser), since I didn't have the laptop to surf with (obviously), and this worked great.  My new laptop should arrive in 3 or 4 days, but in the meantime, this will tide me over.  One big concern I have is the wall plug-in to this dock.  It is not the USB-type like the other docks I've had were.  This is a proprietary plug.  I assume they had to avoid a USB power source, as most USB sources don't have the amperage needed to power this thing, then everyone would return it as "broken" when their underpowered USB port fails to run the dock.  Anyway, the power connector is a tiny rod, smaller in diameter than a toothpick (by quite a bit), and it would not surprise me if that tip would snap off easily, so I try to be very careful when packing it into my luggage.  That's my only real concern.
summary: Works as advertised - for a few months

These Jaybird JF4s are designed for people who listen to audio while working out or otherwise being active, and are willing to pay a large premium for that.  Using Bluetooth wireless, there are no wires to get tangled in or get yanked out, they're sweat-proof (not waterproof--don't wear them in the rain or shower!), and they do stay in your ears if you set them up with the appropriately-sized extensive hardware that they come with to fit your ear size.  I wear them at the gym and they've never popped out.  The cord sits on the back of the neck.  It doesn't bother me much, although I'm not crazy about feeling a rubber wire rub on my neck every time I move my head.As Jaybird acknowledges, the range of the signal isn't more than a few feet--you can't use these while leaving your phone in one place and walking around the house.  But it's weaker than that: you have to keep your cellphone on your right side, on your waist or on your arm, for the signal to work.  If you keep it in your pocket, it cuts in and out.  That alone makes it virtually useless if you don't care to wear a belt clip or arm band.Some have said the sound isn't quite as good as the previous (and less expensive) model; I don't know because I didn't try those, but the sound quality of these is just OK. They're tuned with the treble relatively low, so there's little sizzle in the highs. Without question, if you're looking for anything close to audiophile quality with deep bass, full mid-range, and clear, crisp highs, these aren't designed for you.  For the price, there are other phones with much better sound, so I would recommend these only for people who really want not only the Bluetooth feature, but also the stay-in-your-ear, sweat-proof features, since that's a large part of what you're paying for.  I'm sorry to say that those who've complained that the sound isn't much better than cheap buds aren't exaggerating very much.These charge through a USB connection that uses a miniUSB port covered with a tiny plastic plug on the body of one of the phones.  I find that to get the plug into the port, I have to shove the plug away and jam the plug in, and the plug pushes against the plug.  I wonder how long that plug will last.The buds come with a very fancy little clamshell holder.The controls are tiny and confusing.  The features work, but rely on pushing tiny button controls on the right bud housing, and it takes some practice to, say, hit the right button in the right way to answer a call while you're listening to music.  It can be done, and it's convenient when you operate it as intended, but you do have to be motivated to figure out the multifunction controls and use them properly (those who already use Bluetooth headsets have a head start.) Pushing a button short, medium, or long causes different effects. I'd prefer a larger, simpler set of control buttons.  Not to mention better sound quality for this price.
summary: Just OK Buds Recommended Only for Working Out

reviewText: On a recent trip, I discovered that my older USB batteries could not keep up with my iPad's power usage. Despite being plugged in to my 1A output New Trent battery, power continued to drop because games are power hungry. I had to shut it down and let it recharge.Hence the Anker Astro3E. I conducted a test, and it did manage to recharge the iPad faster than a game depleted it.Whether you need something like this really depends on how long you're going to be away from power and what you're doing. My Ipad will often last 10-12 hours if I'm only reading, but games tend to deplete it after 6-7 hours. Which is much better than my iPod on both counts, but some trips are long enough that I still end up needing an external power source.

I received a sample for the purpose of testing and unbiased review, and all the presented information are based on my impressions.Tech Armor iPhone 4/4S Ballistic Glass Screen Protector instead of plastic is made of hardened tempered glass, it’s very thick so no one who doesn’t know you have an additional protection would not even notice that something is glued to the screen.The only way you can feel it is due to Home button at the iPhone bottom that feels like located a bit deeper than usual due to thickness of additional glass, though this situation can also be resolved with use of an additional button sticker which comes in a package.What I especially like is that after protector was glued to the phone there is not any difference in the terms of phone usability, the sensitivity of the touch screen or the sharpness of the display.The glass protector comes with a lot of extra stuff:- Suction Cup for placement and removal- Alcohol Swab and Cloth for dust removal- Tech Armor Home Button (2X – one white, one black)- Dust Removal Tape (4x)- Installation InstructionsInstallation is extremely simple and lasts 2-3 seconds by following the instructions that come with the protector, though there are also videos on their official website in case you need further assistance.All in all, this is a very good product that I’ve been using for a week and I am very happy because I feel much safer in case I accidentally drop my phone, and yet there are no cosmetic or functional flaws due to having an extra glass on your phone. Therefore, this protector can be fully recommended.
summary: Hardened tempered glass that leaves no cosmetic or functional flaws on phone while you’re feeling much safer

reviewText: This is working out very well as an entry-level smart phone for my wife. It's not as good as my Nexus five or a Samsung galaxy, but for the price you can't beat it.

reviewText: The cord is cool to light up, but the only issue I faced was the flexibility of it. Unlike normal USB cords, the lights made it difficult to maneuver it sooooo the cord ended up tearing away from the receptacle ends and stopped lighting up. This was all in a matter of weeks. I failed to read the review, my fault.Battery is not the one pictured, no "Near Field Communication" imprint on the battery.The GS2 requires NFC batteries for proper communication with the phone.Not worth to have as a backup as it might cause damage to the phone.This is not an ORIGINAL SAMSUNG PRODUCT! Verified by calling Samsung.All Samsung Galaxy S2 batteries were manufactured with NFC chips built in.This battery does not have the required NFC.Do yourself a favor and spend more on original equipment(yes it's considerably more expensive on Samsung's website @ $40.00). But original is original and is backed by Samsung in the event something should go wrong because of the battery installed.Pain in the rear to have to send it back, but Amazon did provide a paid shipping label and will provide a complete refund.Here is the kicker...I called my service provider after almost ordering the $40 battery on Samsung's site, and told them that my original battery wasn't holding charge the way it used to. They were happy to send me a replacement battery free of charge. No questions asked!Can't speak for all providers, but my provider mentioned that even if the phone was past warranty period, they would still replace the battery free of charge. NICE!!

Got this in the mail yesterday, with it's easy set up, it's practically ready to use! Love it, and it fits great, and the sound is perfect. Love Jabra products. Sleek design, and comfortable fit. Made for phones and tablets, this can be used on both. Great sound!

At first look, the Plantronics headset, you immediately notice the details in the packaging.  It's done with the utmost care and not with those typical gaudy, excessive packaging that screams "Landfill culprit!": this is an elegantly simplistic packaging.*** Contents ***Headphone with a gel hook!  On the right side, you have the micro-usb input, just below is the call/volume buttons.* Micro usb to usb plug* Micro usb to ac adapter* Extra earplugs* Beautiful, woven charge- case (w/ micro usb connector attached)--the unit also has a color-battery strength indicator.*** Testing ***This is my first pair/ time with Plantronics.  The "GO 2" is a simple, sports Bluetooth headset with a unique gel hook around the headpiece. I've never seen this kind of design before.But, the gel piece serves to close any gaps between the ear canal and the headpiece.  And, it works beautifully.  This fits snugly but not tightly.  But, unlike the Jabra SPORT which is notoriously famous for its thin headpiece that routinely works its way out of the ear canal,  the GO 2's feels very comfortable.The sound is VERY impressive.  Startlingly better than the Jabra's and equal to the Motorola "S-11" and the Jaybird "Freedom Sprint."  The sound is so impressive that I'm teetering on saying it's the best (by current, seasonal) standards, but I'm near to it.PlayingTrue Democracy--the Plantronics reproduced every track flawless.  No excessive bass, needed.  Every track, every vocal, every nuance sounds breathtakingly vibrant.The instrumentation on Enya's "My! My! Time Flies!!" is something to behold.There's nothing exaggerated about this headset:* Great sound* Great fit* Great price.
summary: A Sound as Pristine and Clean as the Packaging It Came In.  Plantronics's BackBeat GO 2: A Critical Review.
