This is the 4th Otterbox I've bought and this was a gift for an iPhone user.  I love the protection and grip that the Otterbox defender gives to the iPhone.  Yes, it does turn the sleep iPhone into a mini-'brick,' but even being a small-handed woman, I enjoy the weight and feel of the iPhone with the Otterbox on in my hand compared to just the iPhone alone.  Without the case, I always feel like I am going to break the phone.  I've also dropped the phone a few times and have had no adverse affects.  So I would recommend the Otterbox defender to those who are on the fence about it.  Just know that it does add bulk and weight, but is very good at keeping your investment safe and clean.  The screen is also very responsive with the case on, which is something I was initially worried about because sometimes screen protectors can cause havoc to touch screens.

First off, I received my case a day early (the day after ordering through Amazon Prime), which was great b/c my phone arrived the same day.As for the case itself, it's doing the job perfectly.  I was looking at the Otterbox initially, and decided to give this a go instead of spending $40-50 on a case.  It looks nice, is protecting my phone, and doesn't impede any functionality (from texting/emailing, to taking photos, adjusting volume, using headphones, and charging).  I haven't dropped my phone yet, so I can't speak to how it will hold up during a fall, although I'm sure it's just a matter of time.  The case is two pieces; the colored soft silicone inner piece, and a hard, rubberized external shell.  I feel like the internal portion provides a bit more cushioning and padding, and the outside shell is the protective part.It doesn't add too much bulk, but the inner portion does have a lip that comes up higher than the phone screen, which I think will help if/when I drop it.  As a precaution, I do still have a screen protector on it as well to prevent scratches.  The outer portion allows me to slide the phone in and out of my purse/wristlet easilt, but being rubberized prevents it from just slipping our of my hand.Overall, I highly recommend, and think this is a great value.
I ordered this case as a Christmas preset. I hope the recipient likes it as much as I do. Will recommend more.

I'll start with the positives: it's super light-weight, very flexible, buttons are very tactile and provide excellent feedback. I loved the diztronic case on my old galaxy s3 that I first opted for this case for my white nexus 5.Now for the bad: this clear case will DISCOLOR WITHIN A COUPLE OF MONTHS, LITERALLY. Yes, there is a disclaimer that it can discolor but I expected this to happen over a year or longer, not in 2-3 months! It turned from clear to a dirty, dingy and smudged looking case. It looked like I permanently smudged the back of my phone and it was showing that way through the case. I was truly disappointed in this. If diztronic knows the case may be prone to discoloring, I think they shouldn't sell it at all; a disclaimer isn't enough. The most I can do is warn others interested in this clear case to NOT BUY IT. There are many other alternatives to try. Or, if you love this style of case enough, definitely go with the all black version; it has all the pros of this case without dealing with the discoloring con.

Nevertheless, the hundreds of concave square cut-outs have absolutely no negative impact on the cover's use, and probably increase the functionality of one or more of the above issues (i.e., heat movement, weight loss or absorption of compression stress after an impact).Whatever the squares do (or don't do), I love this case.As an aside, Blackberry Bold 9000 now seems pathetically too small. Streak - just right.

reviewText: I have used quite a few backup battery packs, and this design from EasyAcc is one of the best that I have seen. First, it has a ton of power. At 5000mAh, it can probably fully charge your smart phone about 3-4 times. It's not enough to fully charge an iPad, but the USB port on it is recognized by my iPad and it does start charging slowly (1.5A instead of the 2.1A the iPad requires). The battery itself is insanely thin and will fit in most briefcases and pockets. A small power switch turns on the battery, and if there is a load, it will stay on until the device charges. It will turn off once charge is complete. Four blue LED's indicate the charge status, and if you double-click the power switch, there is a white-LED built in as a flashlight.  This was a great little idea.The battery charges through a micro-USB port, but does not come with a wall adapter so you will need to get one (EasyAcc has a nice selection on Amazon). In addition to the 1 regular USB port, there is a yellow cable that is permanently attached with a micro-USB connector. In other words, carry the battery and unless you are charging an Apple product, you probably don't even need to carry a separate charging cable.  This is a great feature that is missing from most other slim batteries.I have been very impressed with the EasyAcc products, from their USB chargers to their other batteries, and this is no exception - it is highly recommended.Note: I was provided a free sample from the manufacturer in exchange for an honest review.
summary: One of the best 5000mAh batteries I have tried - the attached charging cable and LED light are nice touches

I am using this charger whenever i am in my car. It is awesome and i dont find any problems after using it.

reviewText: This is a wonderful product for the price.. great value.  The battery capacity is huge, wonderful for recharging my cellphone (a large capacity Samsung Note 2) back up to full charge several times.  It is about the same size as my cellphone, so I can easily carry it in my cargo pocket of my pants for recharge. It has a four-LED indicator which shows the charge status, 0%-25%-50%-100%.  It is charged either by built-in solar panel or plug-in through a USB charger.  It is light weight, has a black plastic body with matt surface solar panel.. one button on the face, and two USB outlets on the bottom (one for charging the battery, one to plug in to charge a phone from the battery).Two things I would critique.  The curly cord that comes with it has a detachable head which lets you change from mini-USB to micro-USB head.  It works, but it is one more loose little part to lose.  And unfortunately, even though most cellphones and devices use micro-USB... the socket in the Opteka is a mini-USB port.. which means you need both, if you want to charge the battery pack first by USB, then use it to charge your phones.Second concern is the solar charging ability.  While it is technically possible, you will find that the solar panel is probably too small to efficiently and quickly charge the huge 4000mAh battery pack.  It took almost all day to charge it back to about 75% capacity.  If you think you will be able to set it out in the sun and have a full charge in a few hours, it probably won't happen.  Maybe this feature is good in an emergency situation, or where you might tie it to the outside of your backpack during  a day of hiking, for most people it isn't that practical.  Good backup feature to have, but I think you will find yourself more often charging it via USB and then using through the day for your devices. That is how I used it.For the price, this is phenomenal.  I would buy it again, I have been asked repeatedly when out where I got it and how much it cost and I definitely recommend it to anyone whose devices are power hungry and heavy use (especially during long commutes and trips).  BUY IT IMMEDIATELY if it fits your needs!!!!!!!I hope my review has been helpful.  Happy shopping!!
summary: Great product..  good battery capacity, slow solar recharge

I have purchased two Seidio extended batteries now, one for my Blackberry Tour and one for my Palm Pre Plus. Both last amazingly and get better with training time! I read a recommendation to charge 100% and keep charging for at least a couple more hours to begin the battery training, so this is how I started both batteries. I let them run down to the 20+ percent and recharged like the first charge for a few times. The Blackberry Tour battery has performed right from the start, and only improved from there. The Pre Plus battery held charge all day and I recharged in the evening overnight. Because of my Blackberry use (I just used as I normally would) I thought I needed to push the Pre Plus battery more by uber-using it all day; Pandora, texting, calls, browsing and playing games to run it down. The next day it performed better and each day has improved. Now I am using it as I personally would normally use my device. I really appreciate Seidio extended batteries! The back cover for the Blackberry added a little more bulk, but the Pre Plus back cover has definitely added more. Since I am new to Palm Pre Plus and I started with the extended battery within a few days of using it I can only say I don't mind the bulk. My daughter tried it and said it makes it easier for texting (she is the one who gave me a Pre Plus) and it made the phone a lot chubbier, but the cover looks nice on the phone. I think the Pre Plus cover looks nicer than the Tour cover, but only because of the latch on the Tour cover. Maybe Seidio should have made the latch black also on the Tour cover, instead of the "silver-ish" paint they use now. I would recommend Seidio extended batteries to anyone who can use them for their smartphones. I also use Skinomi Tech Skins on my devices. Both products are worth the money paid!
Received it pretty quick, I have the Iphone 5c. It came with 3 screen protectors. Easy to install instructions and the video really helped.

I read a review of the Jackery Giant, and I was first impressed just by the design of the device. I mainly use the charger in my car, or I stick it in my back pocket when I'm taking lots of photos with my iPhone camera. I also like how you can both charge the battery charger and your mobile device at the same time. While the Giant is a little heavy, that's not a huge problem for me since I don't carry around the charger like I do with my Apple devices. So far I only use the charger about once a week, and the device doesn't seem to lose much charge when not being used. It does take about 10 hours to fully charge Giant, but that means simply charging it overnight, and you're good to go. Most of all, the price for this charger is just right.

So basically this was a cheaper option than the official Samsung S View cover...and it came with more features...so I went for it as my first case on my brand new Galaxy S4. I still can't decide if I'm going to return it or not [UPDATE: I returned it, see below]...and here's why:PROS:-It looks nice. The leather-like finish and styling of the case add more class to the device. It's drawn more than a few compliments thus far.-S View works are promised, as well as I would expect from even a Samsung branded product. I really do like having the S View features...I will find it hard to switch to any other case that does not offer S View. I love being able to answer calls and see the time/notifications from the little window.-It offers protection for the back of the phone that the Samsung version does not. While this does add a little more bulk, it's not a big deal to me and I'm quite OK with it.-I love that the screen turns on and unlocks automatically when you open the cover...and then when you close it, it shows the S View time/notifications/battery/signal etc. for 5 seconds before the screen turns off. Not hitting the power button is something I appreciate often!-The "kickstand" functions perfectly for me. I have never had it slip at all when using it. I use it every night as my bedside clock, propped up with the case stand, and it never falls. I watch videos in this positions etc. and even when I adjust the angle, which is a nice feature itself, it seems very stable. I think some other reviews who have problems are propping it up incorrectly? To be clear, the front of the case goes face down on the surface and you place the left side of the phone on top of it, at an angle of your choosing.CONS:-FIRST AND FOREMOST - this is the DEALBREAKER (almost) for me. Sometimes when you have the flip cover open and folded back behind the device, [I believe] the magnet/sensor is still triggering the S View function. This happens VERY consistently when the phone is placed on a metal table or object with the cover folded back underneath it. The result is that you get stuck with the phone thinking the S View cover is over it and the screen is locked, showing you only the S View window...despite the fact that the actual S View cover is behind the phone, not on top of the screen! You then have to momentarily remove the flip cover from the back of the device to allow it to reset to normal...again: this happens sporadically in most cases but consistently when placed on a metal surface.-SECOND AND NEARLY TIED FOR 1st - this is another DEALBREAKER (almost) that I am frustrated with: the case messes up the compass. I cannot get a proper reading with the compass even when performing the figure-8 manuever to re-calibrate it. Once I remove the case, it starts working again.-The S View window is indeed a fingerprint and lint/dust magnet. You can clean it with varying degrees of success. I don't hate this, but it's a small annoyance.-The flip cover itself does not lock in place when closed over the screen...it can move about 1 centimeter out of place up and to the left or down and to the left and about 1/2 centimeter directly left. Despite this, it does not trigger any issues like the screen turning on (thinking the case has been opened) and has had no real effect on my usage...it's just an obvious little quirk. Unlike the Samsung flip cover that I used on my S3, it has no issues with the cover not wanting to close all the way after being folded behind the device.-As everyone has pointed out, when the flip cover is opened and folded behind the device, it partially blocks the camera, making it not an ideal way to take photos. Even if it didn't block the camera somehow, I wouldn't want to take pictures through the clear plastic S View portion of the cover...due to the previously mentioned fingerprints/dust/lint. When taking photos I just let the flap hang freely below the phone and it's not much of an issue aside from a small inconvenience.-The "spine" of the case blocks access to the volume buttons...so you have to open the flap.-A bit of a double-edged sword here: the power button. Upgrading from the S3 to the S4 I immediately felt that a power button I did not like before had gotten even worse (I feel it doesn't have enough tactile feel to it and is too hard to find/press and not clicky enough to let me know I really pressed it). The case has a cut out around the power button so you can access it...but it makes the button become recessed within the case, making it even harder to press than before. The other side here is that the S View flip cover itself makes pressing the button a less frequent need (see PROs above).OVERALL:If not for the magnet bugginess (CON # 1/2) this would be a solid 4 STAR review and I'd be quite certain to use this case for the entirety of my S4's life...I'm going to contact the manufacturer about that issue and see if it's a defect or a design flaw I'll have to deal with...I will UPDATE this review accordingly. Please post in the comments if you are also experiencing the inadvertent triggering of the S View display while the cover is folded behind the device and/or errors with your compass when the case is attached! Thanks.UPDATE:So far, excellent customer service from the seller, Rearth. I am replacing my current case with a new one to see if it's without the magnetic defects. I will update this review once I have tested.UPDATE 2: Rearth has been a good seller and helped me through this problem. They offered to send me a replacement case upon receiving my original, but I needed a case to protect my phone. I opted to purchase a 2nd case from them to compare and decide whether the original was defective or not. Unfortunately, the replacement case did not perform much better.It seems to me that part of the problem is that a brand new case still has some rigidity in the "spine" that keeps the phone slightly elevated from the magnet in the flip (when the flap is folded behind the phone and laying on a surface). After a few days or weeks of use, however, that rigidity is gone and the phone just lays flat against the flap. This exacerbates the magnetic issue...despite that, I was able to duplicate both defects on the brand new case.Anyways, I've posted two Youtube videos explaining the defects. Feel free to search for jeffr3ii and check out my "Jeff Howard" channel.I am returning both cases for refunds and looking for another product. I am sad to leave this one behind because I really do like it...the defects just ruin it for me, however.
summary: Lots of PROS and lots of CONS - 3 weeks of use RETURNED

Update: As of 2010-10-14, Motorola S305 headphones are available at a price that is approximately the same as these Sony 'phones. There is now no reason to choose Sony. The Moto 'phones are equal or better in every aspect. In particular, the Moto 'phones stay on your head easily.These headphones offer good performance for the price. As other reviewers have noted, there are significant problems with this gadget. I suggest a work-around for some of these problems.Sound quality: not great. I have a pair of Sennheiser PMX60 mini-headphones that have better bass and a more "detailed" sound. But these little Sennheisers are about the same prices as the Sonys: http://www.amazon.com/Sennheiser-PMX-60-PMX60-Headphones/dp/B00009LI55/ref=sr_1_45?ie=UTF8&s;=electronics&qid;=1264384037&sr;=1-45.Construction: these headphones are built light. They are suitable for doing chores around the house, brisk walks, and so forth. For use during all out exercise with sweat and motion, I'm just not sure.Fit: as other reviewers have noted, these 'phones fit the head very loosely. tilt your head forward, and they will slide right off. There is a related issue too. The drivers inside those big fat foam pads are tiny. You must position the drivers precisely over your ear canals, or the sound will be worse than "not great." It will be terrible.My suggestion: in light of the above issues with fit and positioning, I recommend the use of a jury-rigged "leash" to hold the headphones securely on the head of the user. Such a leash fits the back of ones head. I fashioned my leash out of a cut-up Croakies eyewear retainer. I uploaded two photos to this review to illustrate my work, such as it is. I have used this idea with other headphones and I have had good results in all cases.Compatibility and stability: I have paired these headphones with three devices. The pairing process was effortless. These 'phones work well with my Motorola cell phone, my iPod Touch, and my notebook computer. In fact, I have used these 'phones with my cell phone and iPod at the same time. Listening to music, when a phone call comes in, I can touch one button on the 'phones to answer. Very convenient! With the notebook computer, I can use the controls on the 'phones to do pause/resume, skip forward/skip reverse, and volume up/volume down. With the iPod Touch, I can do all of these except skip forward/skip reverse. By the way, you cannot use the microphone function with the iPod Touch either. Just Apple being Apple, I guess.On the subject of iPod, here is a trouble-shooting tip: while listening to music with my iPod Touch, I encounter frequent dropouts. What happens is that the sound ceases for about one half of a second. It is irritating, and it happens to me several times per hour of use. The solution is to disable WiFi on the iPod Touch. It seems that the iPod bluetooth and WiFi radios have trouble working together. The "dropout" problem is especially bad if the WiFi signal is weak. It seems obvious to me that this is an iPod problem, not a Sony headphone problem.Value: these are the only stereo bluetooth headphones I can find that are fit to purpose AND less than $100. Sony also gives you a telephone quality microphone. In fact, I got these for a lot less than $100, so I consider this to be an excellent value. Frankly, I wish that there were more choices in the marketplace. No matter. The marketplace is what it is, and this product is the best deal that I could find.I suppose that I have presented a rather conflicted view of this product, but I am getting a lot of enjoyment out of it. I like to wear it while doing chores around the house. With conventional wired headphones, I have issues with my arms getting tangled in the headphone leads and pulling the 'phones or music player out of place. These Sony headphones are much more pleasant to use.
summary: (No longer) Best bang for the buck

The Innocase is great if you want a slim case that offers full protection against scratches and some minor drop protection.  Because it is so thin, I imagine it will not absorb as much impact force as with other cases. But the thinness is great if you don't want too much added bulk.  The case adds about 1 mm thickness around the sides and the back of the phone.  The top screen is not covered by the case and so no addiitonal bulk is added there.  Also, the case is covered in a plastic that has slightly more grip than the phone's plastic.  It's grippy enough that you don't feel like it'll slip out of you hand, but it's not too grippy that you can't get it out of you pockets.One thing to be aware of is that this is a tight fitting case.  Thus, if you have a screen protector on that goes around the edge of the phone also, you might have a harder time getting the top half of the case on.  Also, once the top half is on, it won't sit as flush around the edges.  It's a very minor issue, but something to keep in mind.

This case is very nice if you choose to use it with the standard back cover (non-wireless charging/Qi charging capable).  However, if you choose to replace your back with the OEM charging back to do wireless Qi charging, the case NO LONGER fits onto the device. reviewText: I gave it some time before I reviewed this battery.  It seems to last almost twice as long as my oem battery. If you're like me and use your smartphone to death every day, then bringing along some extra juice for it is almost a necessity. To keep phones small the sleek, the internal battery can only be so large. Well a few hours of talking, someFruit Ninjaand a handful of emails later, and you're getting the pop up warning that your phones about to die. Being tethered to a wall outlet is not usually an option, and that's where this power bank comes in.With this Hipe battery backup, you can bring along enough extra juice that if you need to recharge your phone more than once, you can. It's small enough that you can keep it in a handbag, laptop case, tablet case, briefcase, car glove compartment or just about anywhere else. It's smaller than my iPhone 4s, but can charge it several times with one full battery charge. The cable that comes with it is USB on one end, and micro USB on the other. You charge it by plugging the micro USB end into the port on the battery pack, then the USB end into your computer or a USB wall adapter. Once charged, you can use this pack to charge up any of the devices that have a USB charging cable while you're out.The Hipe battery pack is light weight enough that I can keep it in my purse, that was when I'm out and my phone starts to go dead, I can just plug it in to charge right inside my handbag. No need to leave my iPhone in the car charging from the travel adapter, thus risking someone seeing it an deciding to try and take it, or even just missing phone calls and texts. With this pack, you're taking the power with you, and can charge your devices anywhere.A sample was provided for reviewing purposes.
summary: Affordable way to bring along some extra power

reviewText: This is (obviously) a gadget for the frequent traveler. Sliding or pressing the little slider control selects one of the three different prong configurations. reviewText: On my business phone, I have a plantronics headset and amplifier.  People hear me loud and clear.In the state of California you may not talk on the cellular phone (oh thank you) while driving, hence numerous bt speakerphones are popping up like weeds.  I bought the blue ant from amazon a while back and in my vine review they asked me to look at the plantronics.  Each has strengths and weaknesses.The blueant is clearly the winner here - it just sounds better, and in fact, being an audio snob, I do not detect the blue ant as being a speakerphone when it is used.  Everything sounds normal.  BUT there is a big piece missing - the blue ant is geared towards the newer i-phone / g-phone devices and leaves out the older designs by motorola with metal cases and ease of use.  The good part is that the audio quality is SOO good with the ant that you can actually speak to your phone and have it understand you - my plantronics earpiece couldn't be recognized by my older phones!Now plantronics has entered the world of visor clip, cig charger speakerphones.  They did some neat things - like having two microphones.  While I guess that is meant to improve the performance, sadly it doesn't.  The plantronics speakerphone sounds like a speakerphone, and not holding the phone to your ear despite all their magic dsp technology.  I was enthused that a company like plantronics would "get it right the first time" but it's a speakerphone - no doubt.It does have some features to access your telephone (again, i/g phone) directory quickly which seem to work, and it does have some neat features if your phone is dictating directions to you - you can press a button and listen to them on an unused FM station in the car.  Unfortunately  - by the time the phone synthesizes the voice, puts it over bluetooth 2.1, then the plantronics modulates it over FM - well - you know the rest of the story - it doesn't sound as good as using the speakerphone inside your phone itself.  It's just LOUDER.I own probably close to 6 BT devices and none of them live up to their reputation of being a crystal clear perfect audio link.  As for that - the latest version of the ant comes the closest because I don't yell at people using it that they are being cut off by the windshield wipers, etc.  I lament that the BT standard does not give us the quality we asked for in its creation.
summary: I've always loved plantronics, but amazon also sells blue ant

reviewText: Have you ever stood along a creek bed and picked up a good-sized river rock and felt its power?  Felt its experience?  Felt its longevity?  Held that rock and didn't want to put it back down?  Dropped it in your pocket to carry as your "worry stone" or your "pet rock"?  You have to check out the design of this U-Stone power bank--it has that feel, that presence.  Seriously.If you have spent any time looking to purchase an external battery for your devices, you already know that most of them are black, bulky and not so great in the looks department.  Along comes the Lepow company, whose motto is "Make technology more enjoyable" and whose designers are among the best in the world.  (This product won a Red Dot Product Design Award** for 2013.)  This U-Stone, with a whopping 12000 mAh of power and a convenient 1.8A output, is the best designed and most interesting-to-look-at external power bank that I have ever seen--or held.It feels (and I wish Amazon would allow italics, because that word "feel" really needs it in this instance) so very wonderful in the hand.  It has a matte, not-quite-smooth finish, that has a softness about it.  Its graininess looks like sandstone, but doesn't feel as rough as a sandstone would.  It is like a river rock, worn smooth from hundreds of years of rushing water experience.  And like a beautiful, worn river-rock, I want to pick it up, grip it, and hold it and hold it and hold it.And the design is not only on the outside:  This U-Stone uses lithium polymer batteries, and inside the case, those batteries are double-walled, plastic and flexible, situated in an efficient circuit design and space arrangement to allow heat to disperse evenly and to prevent leakage.  Even the packaging is a well-designed layer upon layer, and environmentally friendly, being made from 100% recycled materials.  Another very interesting design feature:  There are NO buttons to push.  Plug it in, it starts to charge.  Shake it, and the blue LED lights turn on to tell you how much power remains, (4 of them, each representing 25% of stored power).I wanted a high-powered external battery to charge my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9", and the U-Stone handles that responsibility with ease.  If I want to use the Kindle while it charges, I need to use my own, longer USB cable than the one that comes tucked in the recessed end of the case.  What comes with the case is a convenience only, I think, as it is only 6 - 6 1/2" long and the tabs are a bit hard to grasp.  It also charges our household's variety of iPhones and a potpourri of bluetooth speakers.If this will be your first experience with an external battery, you must understand that as the mAh increases, so does the weight.  Are you looking for something for your evening bag or to tuck into your pants pocket?  This is not what you are looking for.  This mighty power bank give you a huge charge; you pay for that convenience by carting around a case that weighs 11 ounces and is about the size--a little slimmer--of an eye glass case.  You can't fault it for being this size:  You want the power?  Then the size and weight are what you need to learn to live with.  Now, the day Lepow designs a powerful charger at half the normal weight, THAT will earn another Red Dot** top award!**What is a Red Dot Award?  The Red Dot Awards is a German-run non-profit organization.  Companies pay a registration fee to submit their designs to a jury of 40 well-qualified individuals.  There are many, many categories.  Lepow won a Red Dot Award in the Product Design category.  If you get nothing else out of my review, I hope you will at least go visit the Red Dot website.  It is enlightening and a revelation--to say the least.*I received a sample product from Lepow.
summary: Superbly designed with the powerful and comforting feel of a river rock

This was not good if I had long drives or would really need my phone later. So I needed something that could supply more power.This car charger does that. This is good enough for my purposes.Ill have to carry out more tests as in how fast it charges with nothing active and how it works with just gps. I will update the review then.

While so many Bluetooth speakers currently on the market are two-speaker systems, Etekcity has decided to mix things up a bit with their slightly larger RoverBeats T1, which houses a total of four speakers rated at 3W each. They've also opted for a very no-frills approach - there is no speakerphone feature, and the T1 doesn't have any built-in or SD card memory options for local music playback. It simply has one task, and it performs that quite well - playing audio from your connected device.Connecting via Bluetooth is a very simple process: you turn on the device by holding down the button in the middle, and then you hold down the play/pause button for a few seconds until the Bluetooth light starts blinking red and green. The speaker is then in pairing mode, and your phone/tablet/computer should be able to see it in the available devices list for its Bluetooth settings.Except for the power button, the buttons are touch sensitive. On the plus side, that keeps crevices and areas where gunk can accumulate down to a minimum. However, I still prefer analog buttons that you can feel positively press down. With touch sensitive buttons, I always feel like I have to pause slightly between button presses when turning the volume up and down. That's just a personal preference, though. The touch sensitive buttons are volume up, volume down, previous track, next track, and play/pause. Aside from the power button, the other buttons only function in Bluetooth mode. In wired mode, the connected device controls all playback and volume settings.The speakers sound good at all volume levels, though they start to get a little bass distortion at the very highest volume setting. My only complaint is that when not actually streaming audio, they emit a static sound while clicking through other menus, screens, etc. on my phone. It doesn't affect the streaming audio fidelity in any way, but it is a little distracting and annoying at times when browsing through my playlists for a new track.In Bluetooth mode, the volume can be set independently on the speakers and on the connected device, so you will need to set both devices to their highest volume settings to reach maximum output levels. Due to its upward-facing design, this speaker systems work best indoors, where its speakers can resonate and fill the room with sound.If using the speakers while watching videos or gaming, you'll most likely want to use them in wired mode. While the video-to-audio lag over Bluetooth isn't quite as noticeable as some other speakers I have tested, it's still present and may bother the more keen observer.The manual mentions USB charging, but the speakers actually come with 120v AC to 5v DC wall adapter with a round connector plug. It works well and has a long cord, but I would have preferred a more ubiquitous miniUSB or microUSB charging connection in case the included charger was ever lost or damaged. Plus, I already carry around a microUSB charging cable for my phone, so that would have made it so I had one less thing to carry around.I'd rate these speakers a solid 4 out of 5 stars overall. The static sounds over Bluetooth while navigating menus and the non-USB charging port are minor annoyances, but they aren't deal breakers by any means. If you're looking for a portable Bluetooth speaker system with more output than the standard "Jambox" two-speaker design, the RoverBeats T1 should definitely be on your consideration list.Review disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product for the purposes of examination and review. No review or particular rating was promised in return, and the opinions expressed here are my own following my fairly extension first-hand experiences with this product.
summary: Nice midtone fidelity in a slightly larger and more powerful portable speaker than the "jambox" types

reviewText: This is a fantastic case for wife's white iPhone 5. This is a slightly rugged for moderate protection (not the Ottobox type of ruggedness though). It comes with a quality screen protector for the front, a plastic squeezer and a cleaning cloth. The instruction sheet is minimal but it's pretty easy to figure out how to install the case.The screen protector has a protective mask on both sides with tabs #1 and #2. First, remove the mask with tab #1 and then apply it to the iPhone screen. Then remove the mask with tab #2 to expose the touch side of the protector. Any trapped air bubbles can be squeezed out with the supplied squeezer. The screen protector has precision cutouts for the home button, the receiver slot and the front camera. It is glossy and has a very, very slight purple tint to it.The case itself is made of black Thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) shell mated to a white hard plastic outer layer. Installation is as easy as putting the left side (buttons) of the iPhone into the case and then push the right side into the case. The elastic TPU shell of the case makes this installation very easy.The case is well built with precision. The black TPU and white plastic part are mated together without any visible seams. The back of the case has a big cutout in the camera/flash area that is designed not to effect any washout by the flash. Due to the thickness surrounding the cutout, the camera/flash is recessed enough to discourage any accidental stray fingerprints. The back of the case resembles some military gadget with black rivets in them. At the center is the UAG logo in a brushed aluminum accent.The case has a little ruggedness to it. At the four corners are slightly bulkier to absorb impact from small drop. The edges of the case are raised up such that when the iPhone is placed face down on a table, the screen would not be touching the surface.The case has a rectangular opening for the ring/silent button (button would be recessed in the case to prevent accidental switching). At the bottom are three openings for the headphone jack, the lightning dock and the speaker. The power and +/- volume controls are covered with raised buttons built in the TPU. Pressing those buttons are very easy with little effort needed.It's also interesting to note that the case has honey comb pattern in the interior of the case. Perhaps it is there to reduce the weight of the case while providing some ruggedness. The case is thicker than most cases in the market (except Otterbox and other bulky ones designed for extreme protection) but it still weighs extremely light.We like the UAG iPhone 5 case a lot. It is very light and provides moderate protection without excessive bulkiness. It fits the phone well with high precision. It also comes with a high quality screen protector for a complete protective solution. This white case matches the white iPhone very well in offering a black and white color scheme. I would highly recommend this case.
summary: A fantastic case for moderate protection

The NT90C is a solid device. If you need a second charger or want to replace the one that came with your device, this will do. I have tested it with the following devices: HTC One, HTC One X, Motorola Droid Max, Motorola Droid X, Nokia Lumia Icon, iPhone 5, Ipod Touch, Ipad, Nexus 7 (21012), Nexus 7 (2013). All devices charge fine.The size of the charger is ok. I was able to fit it in my power strip along with other chargers. I have had other chargers from other manufacturers that take up too much room.The folding plug on the charger is nice. This allows someone to put it in a bag and not worry about it breaking the plugs.

This car charger has quite a few things going for it:+ Short coil design keeps it from taking too much room in the center console+ Charges reasonably quick (about 1% per minute on an iPhone 5)+ The cable can swivel to come out from the side or the back of the plug+ Apple certified so it shouldn't stop working with the next iOS updateI do have a few minor concerns though:- The short length makes it uncomfortable to impossible to have the phone up to your ear while charging- The LED power light is a relatively plain looking rectangleOverall, it works well if you're using a handsfree device while charging or if you like shorter cables. If you need to talk (up to your ear) and charge then you'll probably want something longer. I think they could have styled the status light a little more, but considering it's usually buried, I don't think it's a big deal.
summary: Works well, it's short length is a pro and a con.

Contents:1 normal mono earbud/mic device w/clear earhook1 normal power charger/cable1 wired stereo earbuds that plug into that mono device through a mini-usb LIKE port.1 additional black mono earbud around the ear hook1 alligator shirt clip that looks like a tiny plastic wrench2 small open circled earbud cushions (the ones you see that look like it's got a loop for hanging it on a wall1 1.5" long mini usb to 3.5mm jack so you can use your own stereo headset plugged into the deviceMono Device:The mono device has a long, narrow volume rocker button, a tiny power switch, and a decent size talk button that starts the voice commands, answers the phone, etc.Stereo Headset portion:The stereo buds/cord w/mic plug into the device using a micro-usb like port (as does the charger). This means you still have a normal headphone wires that go down past the chest length into the device. The earbuds are the shape of the old rounded hard plastic style with a small round peice jutting out with a slightly larger then medium silicon cover on it. The peice tht juts out goes into your ear. I had trouble with the earbuds falling out, so I used them without the silicon. This made it rough, but I didn't really feel anything & at least stayed in my ear whereas with the silicon cover, even not moving the buds would fall out. Now you can use your own headset, but I'm not sure if you can plug in one with a mic or just use regular ones & not be able to use the mic. Again, the design of this is horrible.Using the buds/hooks:Are a bit of a pain to change. The hooks & 2 cushions do NOT work on the stereo earbuds, ONLY the mono device.  This makes no sense.Caller Sound:It sounded a bit distorted/far away, like talking to the person sitting next to the person you're on the phone with in a car, but dealable. The caller on the other end agreed. This does have an automatic volume regulator as if it gets really loud, the sound decreases for the caller. Once normal sound is on your end again, the caller will have a hard time hearing you until the device raises the volume again. This happens without hitting any buttons. If you have the stereo earbuds in, the call will come out of both sides.Videos/Music:Using the stereo earbuds for music/video sounds more clear then using it on a call, it's a bit tinny, but not distorted like on a call.Use with an Iphone:Though this says andriod, I got this because it says it works with all bluetooth devices such as MP3s even. This DOES work with an iphone with limits, even the voice commands work to dial, pairing was easy. When you answer a call, you get a choice on the phone to switch between the bluetooth, speaker or handset. I had trouble with muting, etc. voice commands during a call. Hitting the talk button on the bluetooth only automatically answers the call, no choice to ignore. I haven't tried call waiting yet, I could mute, but not unmute, etc.)Electronic details:It can connect to a phone as far as 33 feet it claims & lasts up to 6 hours of talk time OR 180 hours hours on standby on each charge.Has a 1 year limited warranty.LEDs: It blinks when on & indicates blue for good battery, purple for medium battery power & red for low battery power.You can mute a call by holding the volume up or down & will beep until you unmute it.You can switch between the bluetooth & phone itself by holding the talk button.Conclusion:Poor manual, not enough buttons to make using it easier, poor use of earbuds/hooks, poor design use when converting to stereo earbuds, a bit distorted on call sound.
summary: Samsung HM3700 - distortion & poor ease of use

I don't use the suction base that came with this, because the arm is very short, which doesn't work well with my setup (I suction my mount right next to my rear-view mirror, requiring an arm long enough to reach down below the mirror), so my review will focus on the magnetic portion of the product.  I was able to unscrew the plastic nut and remove the magnet from this mount and put it on another with a longer arm.The magnet works great.  It's seemingly rather powerful, pulling in the metal plates with a good bit of force, but not so much that you have trouble dislodging from the magnet.  The magnet also has a bit of a smooth, silky, rubberized coating, so there's not a loud snap or a worry of scratching.To get your phone to stick to the magnet, you have two options.  The first, which I use, is a round metal disk that you place between your phone and your case (thus, this method requires a case).  The disk is about the thickness of maybe 5 sheets of paper.  The second option is a pair of rectangular metal pieces with rounded corners that have adhesive pads on the back.  You can place these between a phone and case or adhere them to the back of a phone or case.  All of the metal is nicely machined and has no rough or sharp edges.In my case, I use this mount with a Galaxy S4 in an Urban Armor Gear case.  I have the round disk between my phone and case, which does interfere somewhat with NFC, but there's enough of the battery exposed that I definitely still can use NFC.  I just have to be aware of where NFC works on my phone.The case I have is relatively slick, being hard plastic, and it does allow my phone to rotate very easily on the magnet.  This can be mildly annoying, but is also kind of nice at times.The bottom line, though, is that the convenience of just stepping into my car, popping the phone on and then popping it off as I get out is magnificent.  Pairing this mount with Bluetooth in your car gives the absolute best experience.

reviewText: I purchased this item to go with my Virgin Mobile LG Optimus V.  The screen protector and case fit perfectly, and the charger works, however all are cheaply made and durability may be an issue in the future.  Of course I didn't pay much either.  This is the reason for the 4 start "I like it" rating versus the "I love it" one.This case will fit any of the LG Optimus phones as the S simply means its used by Sprint and V is used by Virgin Mobile.  Ironically they both use the Sprint 3G network!For the price, this package is tough to beat.  Just know that the case is lightweight hard plastic with a rubberized coating.  It's not overly thick which is good, and snaps together well, however it's not likely to offer much protection for your phone and I have concerns that the coating will rub off quickly with much handling.  The case doesn't block any ports, the camera or speakers.If you want a cheap cover and charger for your LG Optimus, this package is a good buy.  Just be gentle!UPDATE: 3/30/11The need to get the case off my phone has come up twice and despite being gentle taking it off n' on, the case is now starting to break at the tab portion - a flimsy plastic piece that if bent even slightly it will break off and or not connect.  I'm not overly surprised, but yes, disappointed.  Have now ordered a more expensive case by Otterbox to protect my phone.  It's a bear to get on and off, but previous experience tells me that my phone will be safe and the case won't be breaking.I'm still glad I purchased this package, but as expected durability of the case is an issue.
summary: Cheap, but it works for my LG Optimus V

I have an iPhone 4s and had been using an Otterbox Defender case, which I was extremely pleased with. However, I noticed that I could easily run my battery down to nothing on days when I needed to talk and use the internet heavily, especially when traveling. I had been looking for some kind of battery back up system when I got the opportunity to review the Spyder Battery Case.The battery case itself is surprisingly sleek - not really any bulkier than the Otterbox Defender I had been using. However, if you cherish the ultra-slim nature of your iPhone 4s, you may not like the bulk this battery case adds. It is heavier than a regular case because it has a battery incorporated into it. It's made of a rigid, satin finish, rubberized polycarbonate and fits my 4s perfectly. The cut outs for buttons, camera lens and speakers align exactly. The case has metal contacts in the bottom for using with the charge/sync dock and a mini-usb port for charging without the dock. There is also an on/off button on the back and 4, blue LEDs which indicate charging status and level of remaining charge.If you wish to set up the dock as a charging station without connecting to your computer, you will need to purchase a usb power adapter (the usb cable is included). However, you can simply plug the charging/sync dock into a usb port on your computer and eliminate the need to buy a usb power adapter. I LOVE that my phone inside the case sits securely in the dock for charging. Previously, I have been plugging a charging cable directly into the proprietary Apple charging port every night, but was worried as I have heard that it is easy to damage the port. This is so much better!So how well does the battery work? It more than doubles your iPhone's battery capacity!!! The iPhone 4s has an internal, 1432 mAh battery. The Spyder battery case adds another 2000 mAh of battery power to your phone. Fantastic! It is an A-grade, lithium-ion polymer cell battery for larger capacity and more charge cycles.Spyder recommends that you let your iPhone drain to 20% capacity or less before you turn on the Spyder case. My phone was up to 100% (from less than 20%) in a little over an hour and there was still juice to spare in the case!I am absolutely thrilled with this case and dock. It meets all my needs and more and keeps me from having to even think about my phone battery, no matter how much I use it in a day.The only negative I have is that I wish the case had an extended lip around the screen of the phone and was maybe a little less sleek and a little more protective. I am used to a Fort Knox level of protection with the Otterbox Defender. The Spyder battery case sits flush with the screen, so if I drop it on gravel or other rough surfaces, there is no protection for the front of the phone at all. Hence, I had to buy a screen protector. (My Otterbox case had a screen protector built-in.) But for more than doubling my phone's battery life and the convenience of a charging dock I can just sit my phone in, I'm thrilled and I am more than willing to be a little more careful with my phone.I HIGHLY recommend this item.

This is the best screen protector that I've " EVER"  purchased! I used to be a loyal Zagg fan. Every smartphone that I've ever had, even this one, has always had an invisishield on them. I had ordered a replacement invisishield for my Note 2 through zagg's warranty. Some kind of way I misplaced it and can't find it. So I wasn't prepared to spend another 20+ for another one. So off to reading reviews on Amazon. I narrowed it down to this and another one, Greatshield I think it was. I almost bought the Greatshield, had it in my cart and everything. Something said don't get the the Greatshield get the iSmooth. I think the Greatshield had a matte finish, can't remember.  Man, am I glad that I did! I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I've never been this excited about a Zagg screen protector, not even the first one I ever bought. This protector is just like glass, you barely even realize it's even on there it's that clear! I will admit that I wasn't adventurous enough to try the installation myself though. So I went to the mall and paid $5 to have it put on. Went on like a charm, iSmooth as silk (lol). The guy didn't even have to work out any bubbles. It was like the protector put itself on for real. Went on perfectly. Doesn't affect the screen clarity, or the s-pen functionality. It seems like it has improved the screen somewhat. Did I forget to mention that it's so clear that it doesn't look like it's on there, oh yeah, I did. There's no streaks from the use of the s-pen. You also get a lifetime warranty like Zagg. You get 3 protectors unlike Zagg. Only costs you $10, unlike Zagg. Zagg just lost one and iSmooth just got one. All of my future phones will be protected by iSmooth from now on, later Zagg. I definitely would recommend these to any and every one! Highly highly recommended 5 *'s. I'll do an update if I encounter any problems with it or if none at all. Will definitely buy again...

Capacitive styluses are not all alike.  Besides color, there are subtle differences in sensitivity, length, barrel size, weight, and attachment clips or lanyards.  Sensitivity depends on two things:  (1) whether the rubber capacitive tip is soft or stiff, and (2) what device you are using.  I find that a stiffer tip works well with an iPad, and a softer tip works well with a 1st Gen Kindle Fire or a Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet.It isn't necessary to pay a lot for a stylus.  Some inexpensive ones (e.g.,3 pcs Aqua Blue/Black/Red Capacitive Styluses) work better with my iPad than more expensive ones (e.g.,Marware Capacitive Stylus for Kindle Fire, Black).  Unfortunately, when you buy "generic" styluses like the ones in this listing,  you don't know exactly what you'll get, even if you are reordering from the same seller.  On the other hand, if you buy generic styluses, you can easily afford to replace them when the tips inevitably wear out with use.  (The rubber tips soften, and sometimes the tips will loosen and push back into the metal ring and barrel.)These generic styluses are an incredible bargain, but the tips are mushy (very soft) out of the box.  When I use them with an iPad or Nexus 7 tablet, it feels like the tips are flattening out and allowing the metal ring to contact the touch screen.  This isn't really happening, because the rubber is still between the ring and the screen.  However, I don't like the feel at all.The 10 metallic styluses are attractive: you get 2 each in aqua, black, red, pink, and purple.  They are 4-1/2" long, have a comfortable-to-hold barrel, and include a nice pocket clip.  They ship from Hong Kong, but mine were dispatched immediately and arrived within a month.  Because the tips are so soft (and will only get softer with use), I rate these styluses at 3 stars ("It's OK" on the official Amazon scale).  However, at the price of three dollars for 10 styluses (the price when I purchased mine), you can't go wrong by trying them.In case you're wondering, as I was, what a "capacitive" stylus is, it is a human interface device (e.g., a mouse) that uses "capacitive sensing" to measure changes of position on a touchscreen.  It works just like a human finger on a touchscreen device, and you can often get more accurate navigation using a stylus.  Wikipedia has good articles on capacitive sensing and capacitive devices.
summary: Great Bargain, But Capacitive Tips Are Very Soft

Again, once you find out, it's easy.-Gets a little hot when charging after awhile, typical- it's converting 120V to 5V, and all that current. I tried the Jaybird Freedom 3 earbuds, the Plantronics Back Beat GO 2, and the Motorola S10. Ultimately, I kept the Plantronics. Although the sound quality was decent, I found the Motorola S10 the worst fit of the 3 I tried. The rigid band was very tight on my head. I may have a somewhat larger than average head (7.5 hat size), but it's not that big. The arms on both sides of my head really felt like they were squeezing my head. The ear pieces were also tight around my ears. The ear plugs were very large and none of the sizes fit well in my ears. They are labeled as earbuds, but the whole assembly is too big to fit into my ear canals.But, the worst problem of all is I could not wear these with glasses while running. The combination of the earpiece and my glasses was very uncomfortable and very tight. I have to take off my glasses and clean them during longer runs and I could not put them back on while wearing the headset. I had to pause my run, take off the headset, put my glasses on, then put the headset back on. When combined with being very uncomfortable, these just weren't worth keeping and I sent them back after just two runs.

I'm usually a big fan of greatshield.  The TPU case I got for my Evo 4g LTE is really high quality.  This pouch, and the TPU case for my Galaxy S4, are not.As other people have said, the pouch is barely, and I mean barely big enough for the phone on its own.  Just the phone, no case and you'll still have to work to get the phone out.  The case being leather, I figured maybe it'd just need to stretch, so I stuffed a pair of decks of cards in there to help stretch it out in the hopes my phone could fit with the aforementioned TPU case.  The decks of cards ripped the inner lining.At that point I just tossed the case in the trash.  I have no idea what logic went into making a pouch that is a hair bigger than the phone itself.  Wouldn't it make more sense to be a little too big than barely big enough?  My guess is they had a lot of these pouches already made, and advertised them as fitting the GS4 to sell them off.If you use your phone without any case, this product might work for you.  Otherwise I'd recommend looking elsewhere.
summary: Not functional for the purpose advertised.

You have many different types of cases. Some cover the entire phone as to protect it from accidents that may occur to it, or from unintended misuse. Others wrap around so that they cover the parts that can get scratched most easy but leave the screen bare as to not dilute it too much. This Belkin case takes more of the latter but minimalizes it as much as  possible.The case is transparent (visibility about 8.5/10) and has a more hard rubbery-plastic feeling outer shell. Installation is simple as all you do is 'snap' the case on the back. It is so simple that you really do not know when it is fully on because there is no 'snapping' feel or sound. You just know it is on when it does not fall off when you pick up the phone. As easy as it is to apply this case to the phone, it is as just as simple to take it off--or get it knocked off.The Belkin sheer keeps scratches off the back case and does not make itself appear too bulky. The Galaxy III is an already sleak phone and the shield sheer does not hinder that really.While making itself have a more 'small' character, it sacrifices a bit because if you hit the phone, bump the phone, or hold the phone the wrong way, you will have a case that is barely hanging on. Other than the latter, it works well as a simple case that does not take away from the natural appeal that the SIII has.

I purchased this because I use multiple phones. Upside it does charge all the different batteries I have.  It changes sizes to adapt to different batteries and does so easily. There probably are a few cell phone battery sizes it can't adapt to but it does my BB, Motorola and Samsung.  Downside is moving the contacts to the correct positions. Even though you are supposed to be able to put the battery in and make sure one contact is on negative and one is on positive and it will charge this always isn't the case. I have had to flip the battery sometimes and then it will work.  It has a light that changes color when the battery is charged but if the battery is almost charged and you are just "topping" off it may already show blue/charged when you put it in. On a couple occasions this has happened and when I popped the battery in it's device it had never fully charged. This charger is a good back up if you have more than two different types of batteries you need to charge but if you only have one or two devices stick with spare chargers for that battery. It loses a star for not charging a battery that is almost full to it's capacity. (sometimes) It loses a star for showing that a battery is charged when you put it in even though you know it is 88%. I like it but there is a margin for error that makes it only 3 stars.

I ordered this because I have discomfort with the usual plug-in bluetooth headset, and this one was well reviewed.  It's important to put it on the closest part of the visor to your face, because the pickup fades if you put it far away, but my listeners have said it was good sound quality, and I can hear them well.  Sometimes I have to turn the volume down because it is so loud it gets distorted, but when I turn it down, it's fine.  The controls are very easy: just press and hold the big button at the base until it beeps to turn it on (blue light flashes when on) and the same to turn it off (red light flashes).  The volume controls say "+" and "-", and there's a mute button on the side.  You put it on the visor holder to speak, and you can either put in in the window holder to charge, or swing the visor down and face the unit's solar panels toward the sun to charge (if your state doesn't allow the windshield mount, or if you have problems with thieves breaking into cars with windshield mounts).I bought a second unit for my mom because she gets confused by complicated equipment... not the I blame her, having accidentally turned off bluetooth headsets by pushing on the wrong part when they were in my ear.  She is also hard of hearing, but she has no problem hearing me when I call her on this, and I can hear her very well too (better than when she's on a regular phone, in fact).I charged it once on a cord, but since then I just put it in the sun with the solar panels up sometimes, when I think of it.  So far, no problem with the charge (it's been two months since I got the first one).  I'm so pleased, I'm considering getting it for friends whose built-in bluetooth in their vehicles is so bad, I can't hear them.
summary: Very easy to use, good speaker and microphone

reviewText: As with all of the Bluetooth speakers I test, I first make sure that everything as advertised works, and this is the case here. I have to borrow a friend's Samsung cell to check out the NFC one touch capabilities which is something I personally just don't care about. But, it does work. The hands free calling is as good as any and that IS something I like as a feature. It's nice to crank up the tunes and be able to take an incoming call (of course if you don't WANT that don't pair with your phone, duh).I also have aSony SRSBTX500which has twice the wattage (40 watts vs. 20 watts) but for the life of me I couldn't notice a difference in the audio quality between the two speakers. That isn't a surprise since they're both Sony products. The 20 watt output of this speaker is honestly just a number to me, but it fills up my main room with no problems and without having to put on maximum volume. The fidelity is great with incredibly clear treble and bass - the separation of the two leads to overall top notch clarity. I tested this with the Beatles LOVE album and it handles the array of soft, hard, orchestral, and mixed arrangements seamlessly. I can hear individual instruments perfectly, rather than the mush some portable speakers I also own. I don't know how Sony does the stereo separation in such a small unit, but it's pretty cool.Finally, I charged this speaker fully, turned up the sound about half way, and did get over 7 hours of play time (I had to go to bed). Though light and portable, this makes a nice party speaker for even a midsized apartment.Sony's a good brand for a reason. Very easy 5 out of 5 stars for a nice premium product.
summary: Everything works as advertised, sound is awesome

The slots have not expanded to the point of my cards falling out, which was an initial concern, so I am happy about that.  There is a limitation to how many cards you can carry (for me I have four cards including my ID), but if you don't need or want to carry that many cards, this case will be perfect for you.

It makes for a clutter-free charging experience.The battery has a power button on top.  It is used to check the charge of the battery, based on four blue LEDs on the side.  Also, when you plug your phone in, you will need to hit the power button in order for it to start charging.Note--the battery does NOT come with a micro USB cable or charging block, which is required for charging.

So far so good, capacity seems to be on par with the stock battery. Shipping was extremely fast and the product was well packaged. I've read a lot of the reviews of aftermarket batteries on the tech forums and Anker seems to have a good established reputation. I avoided QCell even though it has NFC because it is full of blatantly fake 5 star reviews. It may or may not be a good product but I refuse to give a seller that relies on deception even a single dollar.I haven't had the phone long so only time will tell if it will maintain its capacity for any appreciable length of time. It comes with a 1 year warranty so I guess that is time enough to tell. If it maintains its current performance and declines the way the stock battery normally would, then it is well worth the price. It makes no sense to me to purchase $30 batteries that claim a dubious additional 200mah when you can buy 3 generics that are just as good as stock for the same price.NFC is not that prevalent right now so it is a non-issue for me. Maybe once the deal between Google and the ISIS consortium goes through it will be more widespread. However, to me it makes no sense to have to unlock my phone and swipe it, enter a password, and pay rather than to just pay with my credit card. What happens if you run out of batteries? Also, it just puts your phone more at risk of being dropped it situations like drive thrus. I think by the time it gets wide spread enough, it will be time for a new battery or phone.P.S. When looking at reviews, especially for generics that come from Taiwan/China, look at the reviewers history. Often times, they will have just one or two reviews and if they do have more than 1 review, they will all have been made in a short amount of time to give their account a little more legitimacy. The verified purchase means nothing as that is easy to game by the vendor.Edit:Well, it is now April 14, 2013 and one of the batteries has died. The battery has swollen up a tiny bit in the middle. The big problem is that the phone will become unstable and shut down when indicated power level is 40-50%.I drove the battery pretty hard so I'm only going to knock out 1 star as I feel I've gotten my monies worth.

I had one spec of dust that gave me trouble but the supplied catcher strip got it on the second try! reviewText: As this is the second Native Union handset I've reviewed for Amazon's Vine program, I thought it would be more useful to compare the advantages and best uses for the MM02t and the MM03 handsets.TheNative Union MM02T Handsetis plug and play with no Bluetooth technology set up required. The noise reduction technology and the retractable system in the MM02T model makes this model particularly useful for use in a noisy and crowded environment. However, multi-takers will not like enjoy being tethered to the handset.In trying to picture how this model would best fit a specific customer, I settled on Grandma. She visits with children and grandchildren via Skype or Facetime (a more solid connection). She prefers to sit in front of the screen and, more often than not, does so alone, which means the corded handset is a comfort rather than a nuisance. She appreciates the luxurious soft touch black finish and the universal mount that allows her to charge her iPad and iPhone at the same time (the handset isn't a charger).On the other side of the line, the children and grandchildren are more likely to use a speakerphone as they gather together in front of the video camera. Individually, theNative Union MM03 Moshi Moshi Curve Handsethas an advantage for multi-tasking users with its Bluetooth 2.1 multipoint technology. However, there's another tradeoff as the MM03 sound quality isn't as good as the MM02T model.In summary, both handsets win significant style points. Each has its own merits, which will be championed by users who prefer corded to cordless and plug and play to Bluetooth. Choose the model that best fits your needs.Rating: Four stars.
summary: Great for noisy, crowded environments...and for Grandma

After upgrading my iPhone 5 to IOS 7, my battery life went to - well you know where.  I don't stream a lot or use the internet excessively.  My battery would show a 40% charge, then die within seconds when using data services.  This battery WORKS.  Keep in mind, it does add some size and weight to the phone, but for me knowing I have a dependable battery, the compromise is worth it.  I can now have my phone on all day, watch a video, surf the web, listen to music and still have battery life into the evening.  When connected to you phone, the battery uses its juice first, then your phone's battery last.  It uses a standard USB charger which enables you to charge your phone and extended battery at the same time.  I do usually charge them separately at night in order to make sure both are charged to capacity in the morning.

The articulating arm which pivots from almost vertical to almost horizontal does not have enough friction to hold the phone in position. reviewText: The product looks like its pictures.  The case fits over the iPhone 4S perfectly. I'm a long-time Bluetooth headset user. I've been a big fan of the Motorola H-series headsets, having owned pretty much every iteration. I really tend to prefer the headsets that wrap around your ear for support, because it means I don't need to have something digging deep into my eardrum.I've generally not been very impressed with Jabra's Bluetooth headsets. I own a couple of Jabra Supreme Bluetooth headsets, both with surprisingly varying call quality, and a Jabra Stone, with questionable battery life and mediocre call quality. For reference, my current favorite Bluetooth headset is the Motorola H730. Or should I say - it WAS my favorite.The Jabra Motion UC is in another league to all the above headsets.The phone I tested it with is an iPhone 5s.First, the box for the Jabra Motion UC is insane. While it pretty much guarantees your phone won't be damaged, it's perhaps rather unnecessary - a giant plastic hard case. It does look pretty swanky, though! Once you get into the box, you're presented with a smorgasbord of bits and bobs:1.) The Jabra Motion UC headset itself2.) A tiny Bluetooth receiver for your laptop/desktop computer3.) Two different-sized ear pieces for those of you with larger/smaller eardrums4.) A micro USB cable5.) A separate micro USB wall adapter6.) A cigarette ligher charger8.) Zip-up travel case (with room for the micro USB cable)9.) Quick-start guide.I have to give Jabra a LOT of credit for the absolutely complete package of accessories this headset comes with. Well done, Jabra!Moving on to pairing the device... A very simple affair. Press the talk button on the headset while flipping the boom down, and the headset goes into pairing mode. I was then able to pair it straight away with my iPhone 5s. Opening the boom mic connects it to the phone, and closing the boom mic disconnects it. Simple. (For those with other devices, this thing even has NFC, which was a surprise to see)An added bonus for iPhone users is that the Jabra's battery life appears on the iPhone bar at the top next to the phone's battery life. As far as I'm aware, this is a feature that only works with Jabra headsets.I did some call-quality tests with a friend of mine across the country, and these are our results:1.) There is absolutely no crackling or popping on my end or his end at any normal distance. I was able to move a full 30 feet away from my phone before even a hint of crackle entered into his end of the call.2.) The noise canceling works absolutely brilliantly. In my bathroom, my friend could not tell whether I was using the iPhone 5s itself, or the Jabra Motion UC. Switching to the Motorola H730 my friend could easily hear the echo of my bathroom. The Jabra performed better than any other headset at noise canceling.3.) Call quality is excellent on both ends of the conversation. My friend said the only minor difference between the iPhone 5s itself and the Jabra Motion UC is that the Jabra lacked just a teeny bit of low-end.4.) I was concerned that the mute button being on the end of the mic would cause issues with people hearing the click or rustling when I mute or unmute the headset. I can happily report that after testing this thoroughly and repeatedly in a quiet room that my friend simply could not tell that I was pressing the mute button.Some other things to note:1.) I have a little facial hair, but there was still a nice gap between the mic and my face. I imagine if you have a decent-sized beard this may be an issue, but it was not an issue for me at all.2.) If you wear thick glasses, the wrapping around your ear might not be amazingly comfortable, but I imagine this is very subjective. I wear thin-frame glasses, and the comfort level is good.3.) If you tap the "Call" button, it will tell you your battery life in your ear (starting at 7 hours). After about an hour of use, I pressed the button and it told me I had 6 hours battery left. Half an hour later, it told me there was 5 hours and 30 minutes, so it's at least pretty accurate!4.) A full charge takes just 2 hours.5.) Motion-sensing auto-answer is set to on by default, but you can turn it off if you're not interested or it's just "not for you." Just download the Jabra app from the App Store and disable that function. I like the feature, but only after practicing putting on the headset within 2 seconds of picking it up!6.) When people call me, the Jabra speaks their name, and I'm able to answer the phone by simply saying, "Answer." There's a bunch of commands, but you'll want the manual to see them, which you can get here:[...]7.) The earpiece can be pulled down a little (it's on a stem) from the wrap-around part, which wasn't obvious to me until I read the manual.8.) No annoying flap or cover over the micro USB port on the headset. Just grab your cable and charge the headset without having to fiddle around.Overall, this is by far the best Bluetooth headset I've ever used, and it works fantastically with my iPhone 5s. The only concern I have with the device is that it's not cheap, but considering you get a really nice bunch of accessories - that does help lessen the sting at least a little.Overall: 5 out of 5. Highly, highly recommended.
summary: The best Bluetooth headset I've ever used.

reviewText: I like this product for the length. Although, it does take much longer to charge my phone. But, that's what i expected since it's not really an apple brand. It's more of a knock off. But, it still gets the job done!

I bought this phone off an auction site to use as a backup phone. My regular phone is a T-Mobile HTC Radar 4G. I had come from the iXX and Android worlds and I really like the Mango system so much better! I'm not technical at all but I find Mango easier to use and the tiles just much easier on my eyes, too! The Lumia 800 looks just awesome in person; I'd say it's the best-looking black-color phone, ever! Its slightly elongated shape and super light weight and solid feel make it feel perfect to hold, whether for surfing or calling! The screen is bright and beautiful, and the touch screen works really well. I do need to get a screen protector, though!Two things I don't quite like, though: 1) it uses a micro-SIM card which is very difficult to find at low prices, I had to search around hard for a reliable seller; 2) the camera, while it has superb optics as it's a Zeiss, gives incorrect white balance under artificial lighting, while my HTC Radar has very good auto white balance. Outdoors, the Lumia 800's camera works wonders. Oh, one thing I don't get, which is not important for me as I don't use Tango and currently Skype, owned by Microsoft, is still not available for Mango, is there is *no* front camera. My HTC Radar has a VGA front camera but its picture quality is abysmal!The Lumia 800 does have quite a bit of storage. If you want to load a lot of media files, you should consider the HTC Titan. If you just want to download apps the Lumia 800 has enough storage for you. WinPhone's games are definitely so much more sophisticated than those on the other platforms, so the XBox Live titles do take up quite a bit of space. Mango feels fast with multitasking, and the Lumia 800 has a fast processor so everything I do on the phone feels smooth and elegant.
summary: Awesome hardware that makes Mango even better

reviewText: OK, this battery pack is great for keeping extra juice around for my HTC Sensation 4G, but how about my iPods??? Read the description again: it clearly says compatible with the full line of Apple products including iPhone, iPad, and iPods. BUT, it doesn't come with the Apple connector??? WTF? So, of course, I go back and read the description, and yes, AT THE VERY BOTTOM of the description, it does say that the Apple connector is not included. OMG, seriously?? C'mon Anker. I've been so happy with your higher capacity batteries, but you really need to not mislead people with your description of your product. A real bummer.EDIT 10/28/11: OK, I'm softening my stance on this because I like Anker products. As their customer service has noted, you can still just use your own iPod cable attached to the Powerpack to charge. I still think the title of this product is misleading, or that the fact that no Apple plug is not included be put in the title. Also, another suggestion would be that a small pouch or case be included to hold the power pack and all the various adapters you would bring with you.
