I ordered this to charge a Droid X in the car.  It does the job well. Great value compared to what other retailers are asking for a similar device. The 12VDC plug end of this cord is approximately 4.5" long tip-to-tail and may present a issue in some vehicles. I ordered this directly from Amazon and received it quickly using the 'super saver shipping' option.
Bought this item for my son's Samsung phone, he has not complained he loves case, he gives high marks & recommends this seller thank you very much

This review is of both the smoke and clear cases made by Brightech. Both are very slim and lightweight cases that look great on my iPhone 5S.The cases are easy to snap on, and relatively easy to take off, but not so easy that they end up coming off unintentionally. The cutouts for all the ports and buttons are generous that you won’t find any issues with bigger cables or headphones. It is also very easy to access the volume buttons, mute switch, and sleep/wake button.I personally prefer the smoke color because it adds a little bit of a tint to the iPhone, but the clear color is great because it shows off the color of your iPhone the best. I have the space gray color, and it looks great in either case.In testing, I tested the shock absorbing and scratch resistant capabilities of both cases. Dropping the phone from a normal height to a hard floor resulted in no injuries to the phone, as long as it didn’t fall on its face. There is a slight “lip” around the front of the case that ensures the screen does not touch the surface when it is placed face down. Both the cases protect the phone well, and importantly, they do not show scratches on the case even after intentionally running keys over the back. I also like that it keeps out a decent amount of dirt, which cannot be said about other cases.Overall, both are excellent cases that protect your phone while still keeping it relatively slim. I highly recommend both!I was provided with this item as a sample in exchange for my fair and honest evaluation. If you have any questions, feel free to comment below or contact me in my profile.
summary: Smoke and Clear Cases are slim, light, and durable!

reviewText: First off, let me say. This phone is amazing. It's lightning quick, never hangs on any tasks and consistently gets the best benchmark when I test it on any of the benchmarking apps available on the marketplace. Oh yea, and the camera is otherworldly, I will never need to bring my point and shoot camera with me again...Now, let's get to the review.I picked this phone up for $299 at an AT&T; store after Amazon had problems processing my order. Almost as soon as I walked out the door I had regrets (let me explain). Windows Phone 8 is amazing, it's so smooth, capable and polished; it really is the best mobile OS, that being said. If you've had a Windows Phone 7.8+ device before then WP8 on the Lumia 1020 just feels stale, not unlike any other OS at this point, the difference between the 1020 and the other devices is the price tag. $299 is just too expensive for me to recommend this phone to people who already have a high-end WP 7.8 or WP 8 device, aside from the camera there really is nothing different...Windows Phone 8 PerformanceAll that being said, if you don't currently have a WP 7.8 or WP 8 device, by all means go for the 1020, it's a wonderful device and Windows Phone 8 will make you smile at every turn, the Lumia 1020 has a whopping 2GB of ram, easily 4 times more than the ultra-efficient Windows Phone 8 needs to operate, this means that there really isn't any task the 1020 can't handle, and background tasks won't weigh you down. Like the 920, 928, and 925, the Lumia 1020 has a 1500mhz Dual Core processor which is more than enough to run Windows Phone 8, you won't get the satisfaction of saying "I've got a quad-core" like some of the android phone owners, but when they go head to head I have no doubt in my mind the 1020 will be faster than any android device you pit it against. The beauty lies in the software; Windows Phone is slim and professional, while most Android offerings are bloated and laggy...Build QualityThe build construction of my Lumia 1020 is exactly what you'd expect from a high-end Nokia device, top of the line, solid construction. Although my 1020 will wear a protective case for its entire life I have little doubt that this phone could withstand a few unprotected drops and suffer only a few scratches on the case, Gorilla Glass 3 gives you that added piece of mind that your screen isn't going to crack after one drop.Pictures/Videos"Second to none" is the phrase I would use to describe the Lumia 1020's camera. Nothing else even comes close (including my Sony Cyber shot), night time pictures without a flash, though still worse than what your eyes can see (obviously) are the best I've seen on any phone, or point-and-shoot camera. If you somehow have a tripod for this phone you can have it leave the shutter open for up to 4 seconds, giving you extremely bright night time pictures (and blurry if your subject is moving). The delayed shutter function does allow you to set the phone down after telling it to take a picture so you can minimize movement while taking a night time picture.Video on the Lumia 1020 is spectacular as well, smooth HD capture and clear audio recording are high points of any phone, and like the 928, the Lumia 1020 dons multiple microphones to make audio recording in hectic environments possible.On top of the physical pleasantries of the 1020's camera, there are a plethora of apps that make use of the camera. My favorites so far are Photosynth (lets you capture a spherical image around you) and Fresh Paint (think "Take on Me"). Instagram or not, there is certainly no shortage of cool apps you can use with the 1020's awesome camera.Storage SpaceLike the other unibody Lumias before it, the 1020 has no way of accessing its battery compartment, and no way of adding a micro SD card. What you see is what you get (actually it's about 5GB less than what you see); with no apps installed the Lumia 1020 will have a maximum of 27 GB of free space. 3 GB lost to formatting, 2 GB lost to the OS. In a battle of fortune, the 1020s full res pictures are almost 10MB a piece, that's great because you really are getting full quality pictures but not so great because you will eat into that chunk of free space alarmingly quickly if you take a moderate amount of pictures. When you add apps, music, and videos into the mix, that free space gets even smaller. To combat this, AT&T; is offering a free upgrade to their 50gb of cloud storage through AT&T; locker (limited time offer they say), and as always SkyDrive offers 7gb of free cloud storage (I'm still on the 25gb free they gave me for being an early WP user). Even with those two free cloud storage options I long for expandable memory. If I could, I would throw in a 64 GB MicroSD and carry around tons of music and videos. Cloud storage, is not the answer to phone storage in my opinion...Battery LifeA key question people seem to ask me all the time is what kind of battery life they should expect. The Lumia 1020 is on par with any other modern smart phone out there. It has a large 2000mAh battery and lasts me an entire day using it for email, web browsing, the occasional game and of course picture taking. If you do data heavy tasks or talk on the phone a lot you can expect your phone (any phone) to run out of juice much faster. Comparing the battery life of my 1020 to my 900, I'll say that my 1.5 year old 900 still gets better battery life than the 1020, but I hear that Xenon flashes use a lot of juice.PriceLike I said, the Lumia 1020 is expensive, currently ranging from $266 on Amazon to $299 at the AT&T; store. The Microsoft Store also sells the Lumia 1020 for $299 but includes the camera grip free of charge. I mean, sure it's a free grip, but I can't see anyone using it on a daily basis or ever taking it with them, it's huge...The only way I have been able to justify spending $299 on the Lumia 1020 coming off the Lumia 900 is by realizing that this will replace my point-and-shoot camera, so if you think of it as paying $150 for a good camera and $150 for a great phone it feels a little better.IssuesI have to disclose the fact that I am on my second Lumia 1020. The first handset I got was plagued with a few issues. The phone had reception issues and would drop calls when I was standing still in places my Lumia 900 had full LTE coverage and call quality was genuinely poor, on top of the signal problems that first 1020 had issues where Bluetooth would disconnect every 5 minutes or so. My phone says it has the Amber update which is supposed to mean BT 4.0, so I originally chalked the BT problems up to that, but my new handset has none of these problems (and does have the Amber update). AT&T; swapped out both the handset and my SIM card to cover all the bases on the reception issues. My new handset has yet to drop a call and seems to get a much more solid connection; call quality is still nothing ground-breaking however.There are a couple minor issues that both my handsets share.The first issue is that when looking at the phone in a completely dark room with brightness on auto, I noticed what appear to be streaks or irregularities in the black back ground of the screen. Both 1020 handsets had this problem and although you can't see them with any external light on, or the brightness turned up, it makes me wonder what those irregularities are, and if they will be a problem further down the road.The other issue that both handsets I've had share, is that the loud speaker on the phone is quiet, disappointingly quiet. There is really no comparison between the 1020 and the Lumia 900 when it comes to loudness of the speaker, the 900 takes the cake...ConclusionThe Nokia Lumia 1020 is a great phone, easily worth 5 stars. If you don't currently have a Windows Phone 8 or 7.8 device and you want to take amazing pictures, by all means go out and get this phone. It will be 100% worth its expensive price tag. However; if you do have a Windows Phone 8 or 7.8 Lumia I would seriously think about how much you value picture/video taking. Aside from the camera the only measurable difference between this device and even my Lumia 900 are the few WP8 exclusive apps and .2 inches of diagonal screen width. I haven't noticed any real improvement in performance over my 900. If you currently have the Lumia 920, the ONLY differences between it and the 1020 are the camera, and the fact that the 1020 doesn't have built in wireless charging, it really wouldn't be worth upgrading from the 920 to the 1020 unless you are a true camera nut in my opinion.Perhaps what the Lumia 1020 has shown me most so far, is just how amazing my Lumia 900 was/is; dated camera aside, that 900 can still go toe to toe with the 920 or 1020 on most tasks with ease. In addition to the best cellphone camera ever, the 1020 does offer something the Lumia 900 never will, future proofing.
summary: Great phone but Im not so sure it's worth the hefty price tag

So, apart from the fact that i could not use the power on/off button or volume buttons or charge the phone, this case was awesome.  I have to say that apart from these openings, it really was a great case - it was solid, looked nice - but maybe I just got a defective one.  The seller was great, refunded me immediately - took me ages to pry the case off my phone, ended up having to use a screw driver and scratching my phone (DAMN, it's brand new) but I just can't keep it on.  I don't even mind the power button and volume buttons, but to not be able to charge the phone?  real shame.  But good sellers, good customer service.  Just wish it hadn't had these problems.  this is for the Samsung Galaxy S ii D710 phone for SPRINT - lousy case but good seller and great customer service.

I bought two of these on sale, the 16,800 and 8,400 mAh models.I also have a RavPower element 10,400 mAh, Anker Astro E5 15,000 mAh, and Anker 2nd Gen Astro 2 9000 mAh, plus a bunch of smaller capacity battery packs like the K3 flash 3,000 mAh and Solar Restore 1,500 mAh. My wife thinks I'm obsessed with these things for some reason; can't imagine why.Straight up, I'll be forthright- there is no way I'd pay MSRP for these batteries. They're about double the price of Anker's, and not appreciably better for the capacity. This is why no matter how much I like them, I just can't give them full marks- they're just prohibitively expensive at the current going rate here ($120 and $70 for the 16.8k and 8.4k respectively, as of this writing). If you had to choose between one of these and two Anker packs of nearly identical capacity, I'd say you would have to be some fool to go with the Gorilla Gadgets no matter how nicely packaged they are.That having been said, these are very nice battery packs. They have a smooth, slightly rubberized texture finish and well thought-out design. The power buttons are recessed, so you won't accidentally push them if you store them in a bag. The larger of the two (16,800 mAh) has a backlit digital charge display showing % remaining/charged, and they both have LED lights (8,400 mAh has a dual LED, 16,800 a single). Both have a 5v/2 amp output and 5v/1 amp output that can charge simultaneously. They come with a cable with an interchangeable lightning and 30-pin Apple connector, which makes these useful for Apple devices if you don't want to carry the OEM cable with you. They both seem to be very efficient, on par with the 2nd gen Anker Astros and a good deal above some of the el-cheapo packs out there.I do happen to own the two closest Anker counterparts to these two models, so it's worth comparing them for prospective buyers:Anker Astro 2 (2nd gen) vs. Gorilla Gadgets Uhuru! 8,400 mAh:---Anker---Input: 5v 1.2AOutput: 5v, 2.3A, 5v 1ACapacity: 9,000 mAhIndicator: 10-stage LEDOther: shake to wakeCables: 1.5 ft USB-microCurrent Amazon list price: $37---Gorilla---Input: 5v 1AOutput: 5v 2A, 5v 1ACapacity: 8,400 mAhIndicator: 4-stage LEDOther: 2-LED lightCables: 1 ft USB-micro/30-pin/lightningCurrent Amazon list price: $70The Anker battery is more narrow, has more tapered sides, but is taller. They have the same depth and about the same general bulk and weight. I like both of these batteries and they're both pretty portable and handy. The Gorilla with its lights can be useful if you carry it around in the dark, but the Anker fits a lot better in pocket since it's less square. I'd say either of these is about the biggest pack you can comfortably carry with you in a pants pocket.Anker Astro E5 vs. Gorilla Gadgets Uhuru! 16,800 mAh:---Anker---Input: 5v 1.5AOutput: 5v, 2A, 5v 1ACapacity: 15,000 mAhIndicator: 4-stage LEDOther: LED lightCables: 1.5 ft USB-microCurrent Amazon list price: $50---Gorilla---Input: 5v 1AOutput: 5v 2A, 5v 1ACapacity: 16,800 mAhIndicator: blue backlit digital displayOther: LED lightCables: 1 ft USB-micro/30-pin/lightningCurrent Amazon list price: $120The Anker battery in this case is considerably smaller- about an inch shorter but about the same width and depth. This is probably due to the lack of a digital display, which is certainly a nice feature on the Gorilla. The Uhuru's display also shows which ports are active. It stays backlit for a few seconds when the power button is pressed, and at other times the display remains on but not lit. I imagine this doesn't use much power since it's just a LCD, and the tendency to accidentally press the Anker's large button probably gives it at least as much drain. They are still roughly the same weight despite the disparity in bulk, and neither of these two is comfortably pocketable. These are good if you're going off-grid for a few days, but other than that I'd say their utility is a bit limited on account of their sheer size and mass. I typically leave them on my bed stand where there's no outlet within reach, in case I need a phone charge overnight.Bottom line: these are very nice battery packs, though I'd say Anker's equivalents are extremely competitive in terms of function. The really big disparity is cost, but that is of course very subject to change. In case anyone's wondering, I got these Gorilla Gadgets batteries off Woot for $40 and $25 respectively, which is actually less than the Ankers. At that price, I'd without hesitation recommend these batteries over the competition, but not for what they're going for here.
summary: Powerful, if expensive external battery packs

I got the Droid X in February 2011 and signed with Verizon.  The phone kept rebooting. (This is apparently a common problem with the operating system).  Verizon replaced it with a 'refurbished' X.  They replaced it two more times in 2 months before they apologized and upgraded me to a Droid X2.A week after I got the X2, I tried using the camcorder - it pixelated, the image froze and turned off the phone.  The only way I could get a new, not refurbished Droid X2 was to extend my contract for six months and do a trade-in.  The new Droid X2 worked fine until today, October 12, 2011, when I upgraded the software to Android 2.3.4.  This upgrade is supposed to improve the video quality and stop the keyboard from freezing (I never had that issue).You probably guessed it.  After the update, the camcorder began to freeze while recording.  And when customer service had me wipe the phone and reload 2.3.4, the keyboard now began to freeze.I am now considering filing complaints with the FCC, the FTC, the State Attorney General's office and asking to be let out of my contract.  5 defective phones (operating systems) in 7 months is a little too much.

First Impressions: They are pretty simple and straight forward. They look like a pen with a microfiber tip.Pros- Looks and feels good- The microfiber tip glides easily on the surface of the tablet/phone without catching like rubber tips- Very responsive- Just the right size- You get two!Cons- None that I can think ofOverall: These are great little styluses that are great for anyone that wants to keep their screen cleaner or needs more precision and accuracy.My Mother-in-Law also has long finger nails so a stylus works great for that too. I've had the Xlink Bluetooth Gateway for over a month now. I had been eyeing it since I heard about it on a tech show. I finally decided to take the leap since my wife and I bought our house a year ago and I can't hear my cell phone ringing when I put it in another room or more commonly, forget to turn the ringer back on after coming home from work. My wife has had to reach me about important, time-sensitive matters numerous times and I checked my phone hours later to find I had missed about 10 calls from her. The device connects to up to 3 different phones at once, but since it is only my wife and I, we only use 2. Each line has a priority, so when dialing out, it will start by trying the phone in slot 1, then 2 and finally 3. If you don't want to dial out through line 1, then you can dial *2 or *3 and then dial normally and the gateway will dial out through the respectively connected phone (all explained in the instructions).  We both use the Blackberry 8330 Curve, which each use Bluetooth version 2.0. We keep our gateway in the bedroom since that is the most convenient place for us and we get a full strength tower signal throughout our house. There is a usefulness of placing it in a room that gets the best tower signal and then connecting your phone line from there (i.e. bedroom 1 gets no signal, but bedroom 2 gets great signal from the cell towers).You can connect your landline handsets to the gateway in 1 of 2 ways. The simplest method is to plug your phone right into the gateway and since most cordless phones come with multiple handsets, it's very easy to then disperse the extra handsets to convenient places throughout the house. The other method of landline connection involves disconnecting your home from the phone company and then plugging the gateway into any phone jack, which then gives all other phone jacks in your house a connection. I haven't been successful in accomplishing this method, but the telephone we have had 3 different handsets, so it was not a big issue. The disconnect process is not explained by the Xlink company (for liability reasons), but if you search for something like VOIP my house, you'll find it. It is the same process.Since we keep our phones in the same room (approx 6-8 feet) from the Xlink gateway, we have no sound quality problems. If we have our cell phones in a different room than the gateway however, there will be crackling & distortion until we put our cell phones closer to the gateway.One of the great features of this device is it allows my wife and I to be on the same cell phone line at the same time if we need to speak to the same person at the same time.There are a few quirks I've found, but don't really bother me and I still give it a 5 star rating.1. When your cell phone is out of range of the gateway, the corresponding light/button on top will blink until it is back in range. (You can click the light/button and it will shut off, but that means it will not reconnect when the phone is back in range, unless you click it again)2. While you can use a built in address book feature to dial out on land line handsets, it will only work on the first cell phone connected, so consider which phone should be connected in slot 1, 2 and 3 (i.e. Phone 1 can dial out using built in address book, but phone 2 can't dial out using the built in address book when phone 1 is in range, you have to dial *2 then the phone number (manually) to dial out when phone 1 is connected).3. The light buttons on top are a fairly bright blue. That may bother some people, but not us.

reviewText: Jabra makes, by far the best hands-free devices on the market. The EarWave Boom is a good model that will satisfy 90% of people who need hands-free functionality for their cell phones.Jabra has gotten away from the full molded ear gels for this model.  I personally prefer them to the mini ear gels, but this unit fits fine in your ear with the ear wrap-around.  It's comfortable and works fine.As for the hands-free jack on your phone, you have to make sure you have a 2.5 millimeter jack. That is the one with 2 stripes on the plug. Calling this "Universal" is a little bit of an overstatement, but with a little research you can verify which model fits your phone.  Unfortunately, a specific compatibility list is hard to come by. Look at the specs for your phone and give it a try.The microphone will capture sound just fine.  For those who experience a lot of interference or muffling, I recommend you try the version with "Noise Cancelling."  It's about $7 more but for certain models of phone the difference can be worth it.The Jabra EarWrap has a slightly better wraparound attachment and a slightly longer arm. For those who don't like the microphone arm, the Jabra EarWave Bud doesn't have a microphone arm, but instead has the small mic on the cable with a clip to attach it to your tie or shirt. Personally I don't like those models.I have not found much difference in sound quality between the different Jabra models.  The differences are mainly in comfort, style, and ease of use.  This product is decently priced, but I think it could be more affordable.Try other higher end models if you are more demanding, like I am, and are willing to spend the money.  This is a pretty good model though, definitely enough to satisfy most users.
summary: Good middle of the road earpiece from Jabra.  Enjoy.

reviewText: As a child I had a Pet Rock. It was round, firm and had a name written in ink on it: Fred. I bought Fred of off a kid down the street for a nickel because Fred was advertised as a fun and loyal companion. Fred was not. Fred didn't run, he didn't talk and I'm not convinced he was all that loyal. In fact, Fred was pretty useless- almost like a, well, a 5 cent rock.I've recently come into possession of the Belkin LiveAction Camera Grip with Application for Apple iPhone. I downloaded the app and messed with the hardware and feel the product is absolutely worthless. You attach the Belkin "camera handle stabilizer thingey" to the business end of your sleek iPhone 4, encumbering it to be more like a camera. Nevermind that some newer cameras are about as small as the attachment itself - but with the push of a button (or two) you can instantly snap some pics - just like a REAL camera! That is, if you've already had the attachment on your iPhone and you haven't snaped off the male end of the attachment when you sit with the phone and attachment in your pocket. Having to carry an extra accesory with you also renders the point of a small, sleek and mostly compact iPhone very moot.If, by chance you didn't have the Belkin Camera Kung Fu grip attached to your handy iPhone 4, it'll be much quicker to unlock your iPhone and call up the resident Camera app than fumbling with the gadget.The Belkin app itself is a wonder to behold. A line or two of code above bloatware. After taking pictures with the proprietary hardware and software, your pics have dissappeared into, yes- a Proprietary Gallery.  HOW AWESOME! Gallery is accessible only through the Belkin app itself. Suh-weet!Well, I could go on and on, blasting this product but it'd be like beating a dead horse.I still have the Belkin Camera Grip in my possession. I named it Fred and it sits on my shelf. My $32 Pet Rock.

I bought the headphones based on all the good reviews.  I did not like them at all, so they're going back. I used them mainly to listen to music and audiobooks, and to take an occasional phone call.  They had several good features as amply covered in other reviews.  Here are the two problems that combined to cause my dissatisfaction.1 - Poor sound quality.  Maybe it is due to the shape of my head/ears, but I got no low end as compared to my other headphones (Sennheiser PX100, AudioTechnica ATH-M50).  Even my Plantronics P590 headset, which makes no pretension of high fidelity, sounds much better.  I could improve the sound significantly by holding the headphones tightly against my head,  but otherwise very poor sound.2 - Optimally poor isolation.  There was not enough isolation to provide good fidelity per point 1, but I found there was too much isolation to comfortably use the headphones to make a phone call.  I felt odd talking without getting the normal acoustic feedback to modulate my voice level, plus I would find the person I was talking to commenting on noises around me that I could not hear.Maybe it was just me or my odd-sized head, or maybe they were defective, in any case they are being returned.

The design of this stand is excellent. Perfectly weighted with a modern, attractive design.The magnetized base and holder are an excellent concept - the two pieces slide together easily and perfectly and the magnetized force holds them firmly together.Placing your iPhone 5 on the base is simple and easy to do - you can easily do it with one hand. Holds the iPhone perfectly upright.If you do have it near an audio device with a matched audio input, that process works well too!The Lightning cable situation is really the only issue with this base. Lack of variety in available Lightning cables reduces the practicality of this base.First of all, you need your own cable, since one's not provided with the base. Second, currently available Lightning cables tend to be short, so you're very limited on placement of the unit - it needs to be very close to a power or USB outlet.For example, I'd love to use it next to the 30 pin iHome clock radio I used with my iPhone 4. However, Apple]s 30-pin to Lightning cable is about 6 inches long, so it can't be used. I haven't seen any Lightning extending cords offered. Yes, you can have the base next to your computer and use it that way - or place it near a power outlet. However, both these options greatly limit your use of this excellent base.I don't like it when a manufacturer takes the position of "Well, that's not our problem. We make the base, not the cables." If you make a base that needs cables, you should be sure that cables are available that will make use of your product easy and versatile.If I start finding cables that do this (from Apple, Belkin, or another quality supplier), I'd certainly take it up to a full 5 stars.
summary: Excellent Stand Except for the Cable Issue

reviewText: I bought this case because from the images it seemed to offer a good amount of protection over the back and edges while still looking really nice in its own right. I've put my thoughts below on different criteria for this case.Fit: It fits very securely around the nexus 5 and shows no signs of give once put on securely. It consists of two pieces - a main rubber back that covers most of the device and a 2nd more rigid (but still flexible) outer "ring" to hold the case tightly to the body of the phone itself. I think this system works well, and inspires confidence with a snug secure fit. The only thing that isn't quite so snug are the buttons on either side, with a little bit of looseness on the volume-rocker buttons of the case. Not a deal-breaker, and certainly hasn't at all impacted usability.Protection: It offers very good protection from drops and just every-day usage. I would say that if I dropped this onto a hardwood floor or just outside on the ground - so long as it landed on part of the case I'd expect the phone to be unharmed. The problem is if you drop the phone and it lands on the screen - there's pretty much minimal protection there. The case does offer protection when you place the phone screen facing down on a flat surface by raising the screen up a little. But beyond that you have no real protection. Conveniently, spigen sells glass screen protectors for exactly that reason which should work very nicely. I plan to buy one soon actually.Finish: I just think this is a very classy looking case - and certainly far better looking than the rubber nexus one that google is trying to sell directly through their store as the official case. It just feels like a quality product, and certainly worth the $20 asking price that I bought this at. The one downside is that the backside of the case and just along the edges - its a bit slippery. The Nexus 5 phone comes with a nice soft-touch rubbery finish that feels easy to grip. You definitely don't get any of that with this case. So while the case itself looks and feels nice on its own, it does make the phone a bit harder to get a firm secure grip on for me at least.Verdict: I think this is still the case to beat right now for the Nexus 5. If you too are worried/had a bad experience with dropping your phone or just want something that looks nice and will keep your phone feeling new - the spigen neo hybrid case is one I'd highly recommend. It does have some short-comings, but overall it's still a great case and out of the ones I've seen being sold on amazon is the best one to go with. You have to decide how much protection you want and what size you're willing to go with, but I think the spigen is a great balance of protection and good looks.
summary: Currently the nicest looking and frankly best Nexus 5 case IMO

The mount can rotate 360 degrees as well as tilt up or down quite a bit.  You can also insert the mount upside down if you prefer the phone below the cd slot instead of above. reviewText: This product is everything I expected after reading the Amazon ad. It securely holds the phone in plain view. The locking mechanism for the phone is very nice and feels well made.The only difficulty I had was that the product would not mount to the center vent in my 2005 Chev Suburban. The vent louvers were too deep. So I had to put it on the left passenger vent. It's just a little bit further away than I would like. Also, my Samsung Galaxy S3 is a little heavy, so it was swinging when I took corners. However, this was easily corrected by wedging an o-ring into the vent gap. The o-ring provides enough resistance to movement, while still allowing the phone to be positioned as desired.I'm very happy with this mount and highly recommend it for road warriors. In fact, it is really nice when paired with the Motorola HX550 bluetooth earpiece and the corresponding MotoSpeak app. With this setup, you can make voice calls and texts without having to touch the phone. The mount allows you to see the phone so that you can get a visual on what you are doing. Very nice setup. Thanks Amazon.

- The rugged case is less-bulky than expected.  Typically "ruggedized" items add a significant amount of bulk, and while this unit is slightly beefier than the NT120C, it's not excessively large, and that was a pleasant surprise.- The button and indicator lights, while not obvious at first glance, are well-placed and clear.- The door hatch seems to close solidly and make a good seal, although I question how the closure snap will wear over time.  It seems like the kind of thing that could wear down and allow the door to flop open after an extended number of open/close cycles.- I like the included strap and carabiner.  I don't see myself wearing a battery pack attached to me very often, but I can see how a hiker or outdoor enthusiast could make good use of that capability.  I'd be more likely to use the carabiner to hang the unit from a nail on construction, just to keep it safe and out of harm's way.  I really wouldn't want to drop-test the unit unnecessarily.- The compass was relatively accurate.  At first I thought it was off based on my sense of the local geography at my office, but I compared it to another compass that I trust and it was pretty accurate.  I guess my brain was the faulty part!- Of course, as the main purpose of the unit, the NT120R charges devices as expected.  The power button is a little small, and I had to check the screen of the device I was charging to make sure that I had pressed it correctly, but everything worked well.  Capacity and charge times were accurate for the devices I was using.  A 12000mAh battery is a lot of juice, so it had no trouble topping off several devices, more than once on a single charge.- I did not perform any drop testing, but toting around on a construction site, the device got bumped around and still worked as expected.- The Amazon listing shows it to be water-resistant, while the packaging says that the unit is waterproof.  I was very surprised that the back of the box said that the unit is in fact submersible.  I'm a little skeptical that the rubber gasket attached to the door would completely keep water out of the USB ports.  I did not throw the unit in to the pool to test it, but I'm confident that it'll certainly keep out rain, drink spills, and other random moisture.  I'll have to take New Trent's word for it that I can take it swimming.- Overall it's a really tough little product that works well and should provide an excellent portable power solution for those who work or play in any kind of harsh environment.  This is a 5 out of 5.

So turned it in and exchanged it for the Razr Maxx.  What a GREAT decision.  This phone holds a charge all day long (8+ hours) with heavy use.  With light use while studing for an exam, I timed it and it lasted 74 HOURS before recharging!  ARE YOU KIDDING ME???!!!  NO!!!!!!!  That is the ABSOLUTE TRUTH!  Never even heard of a smartphone lasting 2 days, let alone 3!  And my previous 2 smartphones I added extended batteries to them but none lasted this long.  I suspect Motorola has optimized the software with the imbedded extended battery for primo extended use.  Have owned this phone for a few months now and have not regreted it at all.  Love it.

I use this unit with my Palm Treo 700w, which has a pretty lousy BT radio, so that may explain part of the reason why the range is so awful with this headset.  Max range with clear line of sight is about 6 feet, but usually less then 24 inches.  It is barely usable if the phone is on my waist in its holster.  Major disappointment.  My Jabra BT250 is better with the Treo, but not hugely so.My biggest problem with this headset is that people are constantly telling me that they can't hear me.  I have to lift the mic boom away from my cheek and then they will say "Ah! Much better!".  When that is only the case while I stand there like a dork with one hand holding the mic boom away from my cheek and the other hand holding the phone within a foot of my head.  This looks pretty silly walking down an airport terminal, and rather defeats the purpose of having a headset in the first place...I'll say this, though - the H700 performs the feature that I was looking for which was so bad with the Jabra BT250 - it actually stays on my ear.  I have small ear lobes, and the Jabra won't stay put - if I lean down it falls off.  The H700 stays on very well, and you hardly notice it is even there.  Very comfortable!Too bad the mic gets blocked by my cheek, which makes it worthless about 50% of the time.**Update 5/11/2006**- solution to muffled sound problem...I trimmed a tiny piece of adhesive-backed felt (the kind you put under bowls/vases, etc. you will have on your coffee table)and placed it on the little gray bump on the boom, just behind the tiny mic opening. This creates an air gap between the mic opening and your cheek - problem solved!A great headset with pretty good reception and wonderful form factor. 5 stars if they fix the mic hole clearance problem!
summary: Nice small package, good features, less than perfect performance

I bought this glass to repair my girlfriend's (Verizon) Galaxy S3 after she dropped it once and the glass had shattered from one corner to another with other smaller hairline cracks in between. I know my way around tools and small electronics decent enough that I felt just confident enough to tackle this project, but I wouldn't recommend it otherwise. The glass we received was protected well enough and it had a film on both sides to keep the dust off and prevent scratches. Upon inspecting removing the film off both sides, it appeared clean and looks just like the OEM glass; the build quality may be another story but I didn't have a brand new OEM glass to compare it with!As for the replacement procedure if you're interested... There's a ton of videos and write ups on this sort of thing on youtube and throughout the web that go into greater detail but I'll give you a quick run down of how it went for me:I set up a well lit work station with a heat gun, gloves, an OLFA blade, a plastic pry tool, a razor blade, and the broken phone of course. I heated the glass up on low heat with the gun until it was hot to the touch. From there I used the OLFA blade to get in between the glass and the casing starting from the top. The heat will soften the adhesive and allow easier removal of the glass but make sure not to apply so much heat that you risk damaging the other components (again, not recommended for the weak hearted). The plastic pry tool was used to apply light leverage on the glass once the OLFA blade lifted it enough to get it in there. You don't want to apply too much leverage or you'll break the glass into smaller pieces. That's pretty much it for the rest of the process. When you get to the bottom, gently remove the touch receptors from the glass and take care to not damage them. Once you're done removing the glass pieces (be careful with the smaller ones to not scratch/damage the digitizer below it!), you'll have a bunch of residue on the screen part of the phone to remove, this stuff comes off just by rubbing it with your finger no need to use harsh chemicals or rough motions to take it off. I kept the adhesive on the top and bottom and replaced the adhesive on the sides with some off of a 3M roll I bought on Amazon at the same time. When the digitizer is cleaned, head the adhesive back up with the gun and apply the glass. That's was it. We booted up the phone and opened up a sketch program to draw around the screen and tested taps and gestures as well. Everything was working on the phone was as good as new. Again, look for the other tutorials online for greater detail, I just thought I'd provide a brief rundown on what to expect if you're trying to do this yourself.

The Transformer only works with its own charger, and the Note charges much slower with the Anker charger. I tried mix-and-match cables, no luck there.ORIGINAL REVIEW:The specs do not matter, it's the empirical truth that matters. I tried connecting this charger's Ipad (2.1A) ports to my various tablets (only 1 port out of 5 is used, so no overloading), and it always charges much slower than my other 5V 2A chargers (some factory, some 3rd-party). In the case of Asus T100, it cannot charge the tablet AT ALL, which further proves that it cannot really output 2.1A.

reviewText: I bought this hoping many of the stellar reviews would trump the many poor reviews, but unfortunately it turned out to not be the case for me.I ordered the item to be able to charge my new AT&T; Inspire 4G, by HTC. It's a battery hog, so having a portable recharge would be great.I opened the box, and was really excited because the product is sexi to look at... it's not one of the dark black boxy electronics you usually associate with this type of product. It's curvy and nice looking.Initial read of the instructions proved to be a challenge, as it's clearly a manual that was written in Chinese and then translated and converted to english for North American sale. It was a bit contradictory and vague in a couple aspects, so I went online and watched the how-to, just so I could say with certainty I was using it properly.I charged it initially for 24 hours (it recommends 4-6 hours), and the instruction manual that came with it said one light will flash when it was completed charging. After 24 hours, TWO lights were still charging. I went onto their website and it states that when charging is complete, the light should remain on and solid. However this was not the case for me.I decided based on the specs, 24 hours should have been more than enough to charge it (by technological spec 5 hours from complete drain to full charge is all it should take). I plugged in my device, and immediately all 4 lights lit up on the battery pack indicating full capacity. After 5 minutes, it dropped to 3, then after 10 minutes it went to 2...At this point I contacted the manufacturer. They were quick to respond that it's likely defective. I questioned if they see this a lot and they said yes. I asked why they don't resolve it and they said (in broken english) that it was what people expect for half the price of the competition. Seems a bit odd of a response from them. To me I'd want to put out the best (usable) product for the price, or not put out a product, but hey, whatever.BOTTOM  LINE: Amazon is issuing me a refund as I'm sending this one back. Normally I'd give the benefit of the doubt and re-order another one, but given the less than impressive response from the manufacturer, I'm planning on returning for a refund.  I'm going to order the Zagg Sparq 2.0, which gets great reviews. At almost 2x the price, I'll have to suck it up and pay for it, but I suppose if I want a product that comes with warranty and support, that's the cost of it. I also learned that Amazon doesn't have a lot of flexibility in their marketplace seller practices, so they said their hands are tied. I'll stick to ordering direct from Amazon going forward.  :-(
summary: Defective on Arrival, Bummer I had high expectations, not worth the risk

What I like the best is the amount of adjusting that it allows, I can position the phone exactly how I like it.What I don't like is the spring loaded mechanism that must be activated every time you sit or remove the phone.the fact that it is a solid unit, not a cord that hangs off the windshield, that makes it very resistant to the engine vibration.

reviewText: I used to have the "best" phone for GoPhone service - The ZTE990 Avail.  A nice phone with many nice features, but in the end the 3.5" screen was difficult to use and the battery began to malfunction.  All great excuses to upgrade to the Galaxy Express.  GoPhone service is the best choice for me; the unlimited text, minutes, and 2GB data is enough for me.  I struggle to understand why people will pay $100+ a month for the exact same service via a contract plan???  Now AT&T; gives me a cool, functional phone.  Also, I won't look like an old nerd standing around the airport on my dinky Avail anymore.  I'm finally cool!Anywho...The 4.5" screen is beautiful and easy to use.  The resolution isn't as high as other Samsung Galaxy products, but when I compare them side to side, I really can't tell the difference.  Especially after I turn up the brightness a little.The processor is fast enough to make use fast and no delay between apps, etc.Calls are clear and 4GLTE!Browsing and watching videos are smooth and no hanging up.The backward facing camera is low res (same as iPad 2), and the forward is only 5MP.  Not that high, but O.K. for Facebook.Very few bloatware apps.Feels sleek and light.  I don't like a case, because I carry my phone in my pocket and cases seriously add to the bulk of a phone.Does not come with SD card. (the Avail did) but it transferred easily.  I imported my contacts from my old phone to the SD card and then exported them to the Express after switching cards.  Look for the video on YouTube to do this.Uses a microSIM card which means the SIM from every other GoPhone phone will not work in it. YOu have to call AT&T; to make the switch.Other than that...I lovin' it!

I love this Car mount. I had previously ordered and used the Blackbox car mount which i was very disappointed with. This one is great. You can lock the swivel to your liking and the suction cup is locked in place where it will not become undone or come loose. One thing that is worth mentioning is that I used this with my Galaxy S4 that has a some what thick case. It fits but is opened to the max. overall this is awesome. buy this for that great price!
summary: REALLY RECOMMEND THIS CAR MOUNT!!! LOVE IT!!!!!

reviewText: This charger has magnets to help you align your Nexus 5, which is good, because it can be difficult to get it right. I also own a much cheaper 3rd party charger which is larger and charges my phone more reliably. This charger works, but I wouldn't buy it again, especially at a price premium.
summary: The cheaper 3rd party chargers are better

reviewText: This was brought for a teenager 15 years old. She wanted her own phone. Since she received good grades I thought this would be the perfect way to reward her. This phone is nice loaded with apps and easy to use. The music sounds excellent on here as a mp3, or even when you hook it up to a portable speaker, I do not think its that sturdy one drop and its over for the phone. I am going to get a good cover to help protect it. Overall my daughter loved it and I like that it is a prepaid phone.

With all the mobile devices we have, an external battery is a must when going out and about when charging in a car or with a wall plug is not feasible. Not only that, but with up to 6 devices when we travel, a high capacity external battery is necessary.This is an 10000mAh battery, the highest I've used to date. Note however that Julian from Maxboost says in one of the comments that all high quality battery chargers have a 30% energy conversion loss and the net power available is 7000mAh, which is in line with my experience.The charger itself is quite compact for its power and very well designed. It's mono-colored with an LCD readout showing the power left/used in percentages. This is great because most batteries only have lights or colors to show usage but this is more precise. There are two outputs, a 2.1A for larger devices and 1.0A for smaller ones (such as phones).The battery works as well as expected. We've used this to charge iPads, iPods, e-readers and all different kinds of phones and have no problems. Using it to recharge 3 phones during a day out, we weren't able to exhaust the charger so we're very pleased with that. But using it to recharge an iPad will use up most of its charge. Still, I would expect this charger to be able to charge an iPad and one phone several times from one whole charge.The battery also comes with a small LED light, activated by pressing the button twice. It's not very strong and some of the light leaks out through one of the USB ports!One of the best things I like about this charger is that the charging cable comes with inter-changeable heads. It has the mini USB, micro USB and Apple iPod head so you can charge devices need those heads. The carrying pouch is another nice inclusion to prevent the battery from getting scratched.Bottom line, this is a high capacity battery charger at a very decent price. On long day trips or traveling, I would recommend the highest capacity charger possible and this would be a good choice.Note: Sample was provided for review. Though this was only a sample, I have to agree with what some of the AVP reviewers say, Julian at Maxboost is very helpful with any questions and customer service is great.

This case is awesome but has one minor flaw. There are sometimes watermarks or bubbles under the screen. Good news is that it very easy to fix!You can use almost anything to clean the screen of the otterbox and iphone screen.then use a blow dryer on a low setting dry off both the otterbox screen and the iphone screen. Keep the blow dryer about 12" away from each and it doesn't get very hot at all. Do this for a minute or so.Then when you put the otterbox case together there will no NO bubbles at all.I used windex to clean my iphone and otterbox screen. Worked perfectly on both phones I tried it on.
summary: THE BEST FIX FOR THE BUBBLES UNDER THE SCREEN!

reviewText: This screen protector is clear and effective in protecting the screen against scratches. Simple to put, simple to remove with no trace.

I decided to purchase this New Trent, 10W 5V/2A Dual Port high-speed USB AC wall charger (NT90C/IMP90C) over two months ago and so far it held up well.What's included in the box?* New Trent USB AC Wall Charger (NT90C/IMP90C)!After searching through a dozen chargers, I decided to go with New Trent due to the name brand familiarity and the average reviews for this simple device. It should be no brainer. Connect the device to the wall and charge either at 5V2A or at 5V1A. For those who aren't technically inclined, you'll want to make sure your USB AC Wall Charge have at least a 5V2A USB port available for either faster charging speeds or high wattage demands for certain tablets to charge. 5V1A port can charge any smartphone, but for tablets it'll just power it but not charge it from my experience.That information in hand, the first thing you need to know about this USB AC Wall charger is that it has two outputs. The top output is 5V/1A (can charge anything except tablets with 10W demands). The bottom output is 5V/2A (Charge tablets with 10W demands and anything else a bit faster). When I refer to the top and bottom ports, this is with wording right-side up, so you can read them properly. The charger basically splits the 10 Watts delivered from the outlet. So in a nutshell, expect reduced charging speeds with two devices connected to the charger.As for which device it can charge...as long as your device can be charged with a USB cable and doesn't require a separate power adapter, it'll work. The Samsung Galaxy tablets may require a separate USB adapter to get it charging. I do agree with many other reviewers, they should have been more clearer about which ports has which amperage. But since the unit is compact and doesn't cover 2 outlets, it's a keeper. This unit works as advertise. I'll post any future comments if this device malfunctions or breaks down.

A 2200mAh battery pack is what most people have dubbed a “lipstick” pack, most likely because of its compact size. OXA has tried to pack a bit more into this battery pack by offering up a TF reader, something I’ve only seen in one other battery pack. A bit extraneous for most people, but it does work and is a nice bonus.There are three USB connectors included with the package, including a Lightning connector. I couldn’t get the 30-pin connector to work with my first generation iPad. Admittedly, it’s fickle, but if it doesn’t work, there’s no port for using your own cables. The Lightning connector immediately connected and worked on boosting my iPad Air’s charge.Speaking of iPads, if you are looking at this small capacity OXA, you may wish to take a pass and head on up to something with at least 10000mAh. For example, some of the iPads can be power hogs and the iPad Air has a capacity of 8820mAh. If you’re looking at the OXA for your iPhone, you’ll do well and get a full charge. The battery capacity of the iPhone 5 is 1440mAH. That will give you a good idea as to the capacity of this pack.Another nice extra is the lanyard, a convenient one if you are an on-the-go person. There are three blue LED lights to indicate charge, a built-in 5-pin micro B USB cable (I like this), and a small flashlight. The flashlight won’t light up a room, but will get you where you are going in the dark.FEATURES:► Designed with advanced and intelligent microchips to ensure safe operation, over 500 recharge cycles test► Integrated battery capacity status LEDs provide a visual indication of the battery life► Includes a high intensity flashlight and 1 micro USB cable(5V/1A output)► Stylish brushed metal anti-slip surface ensures light weight, scratch resistance and durability► Built-In SD Card Slot could be used as a portable card reader for your convenientSPECS:~► Size: 90*26.7*24mm~► Capacity: 2200mAh~► Output: 5V =1A~► Input: 5V=1A~► Working temperature: -5 ~ 50C~► Support: iPhone, Mobile, PSP, iPadSample provided for review.
summary: Sleek small capacity battery pack with a Lightning connector that works with my iPad Air ...

reviewText: This gadget really came in handy on a recent family vacation that took 4 hours driving to arrive.  Having 3 teenage kids in the vehicle playing with their smartphones and iPods I knew they were going to crying to recharge their electronics.  Since most cellphones and MP3 players only use about 1.0 Amps to charge, using the Etronic dual 12 Watt USB charger was the perfect solution.Since the car charger is only 2.1 amps it can only charge either two smartphones, MP3 players or even a digital camera since they require less amperage.  The iPad and most tablets require a least 2.1 amps and 10 watts to charge at a decent rate.  If you plan on using the charger for your iPad or tablet, do not connect any other device to the other open USB port or it will charge both devices at a very slow speed.The blue lights that indicate where the USB slots are located are not overly bright and make it easy to find during night driving.  The charger does not sit flush to the socket, but it does not stick out too bad.Overall great little gadget to have.Sample received for review purposes.

A power bank is your extra battery on the road. The PB10000 is rated at 10000mAh which can fully charge your iPad2 and most tablets but a tad short of fully charging your latest iPads. It can charge your smartphones about 5 to 6 times on a single charge. I particularly like that it charges with a microUSB cable as I often misplace or mix up an AC adapter with other gadgets' adapters. The charger gets overloaded and auto shut-off to prevent damage.Sample item provided by the distributor for evaluation review.

reviewText: We purchased 3 for company phones as well as an Otterbox. With the protected corners protected by the rubber I feel this will offer superior protection. I was really hesitant when ordering this case, but the reviews were great and I thought why not? It's only $7.It arrived today, and I absolutely LOVE it. I would've easily paid $20 for this case at Verizon, and not gotten a screen protector and stylus.Pros:The sides of the case are textured, so you can hold onto it easily without the stickiness of the silicone.The silicone shows through on the back and sticks a little to surfaces so your phone doesn't slide.The buttons on the side are easy to press, unlike other cases I've gotten.It's cheap, and by cheap I just mean price. The case doesn't feel thin or flimsy but it's also not bulky at all.It's super cute.The power button doesn't stick out too far on the side, so I'm not accidentally hitting it like I was with my Otterbox and Incipio.Cons:A little hard to get on at first, but nothing compared to other double cases I've had.The stylus is a little too big but I bought this for the case, so the stylus was just an added bonus.This case probably won't provide the kind of protection an Otterbox would, but it's also not anywhere near as expensive and it gets the job done. I've already dropped my phone three times since putting the case on (once on concrete) and the phone is fine, and the case isn't even scratched.Seriously, BUY IT. It's definitely worth it and I honestly couldn't be happier. Will probably buy another one in a different color as well.

This Slim Armor is a very simple anti shock design that comes with three different colors of button cover, orange, black and white. It could have been a complete kit if they had added a clear screen protector. Its nice and tight against the Iphone and the black body has a sleeve that can be changed out that comes in many colors. Mine is gray and doesn't show dirt or scratching. Its hardly noticeable, we like it.
i dropped the GS4 on to a concrete floor. only a few feet but landed on a bolt that secures a chair to conc floor. the sharp bolt edge scratched the film but it protected my phone screen.
Just what I needed for my daughters phone. These are sooooo much better than the regular phone screen covers. The others make it hard to scroll on the phone, these make it smooth.

I have wanted a sidekick for a couple years and finally found this one for under $50, and I didn't have to extend my contract. I opened the box, put the battery in, my sim card and SD card and it worked.Over the past couple days I have made a list of the pros and cons.Pro:It has a real cool screen with awesome color that swivels open and made everyone at work say Ooooo!Cons:* I think there are more buttons than you need, many are repetitious, but they look impressive. Most of the functions take several steps. I work with computers and accessories all day, I am not intimidated by something different. But this was not a well thought out design.* A tiny button on the top opens the camera. It's a very tiny black button, flat to the surface and the same color as the phone so its hard to find and difficult to push, I used my fingernail when I found it. You can take both photos and video. I somehow got the camera into video mode and it took a while to get it back to photo. The picture it took was good quality.* There are no one step calls as with other phones. There are several ways to make a call which I won't go through, but it is neither easy nor convenient. The swivel screen is in the way when making a phone call. The basic function of a cell phone should be making calls quick and easy. The Sidekick gets an "F" for that. And the same grade for reception. My last phone, a very basic and inexpensive phone, gets reception in places this one can't receive or make a call, like in my house.* I don't think this phone should be categorized under slider, I have a slider and closing it is a simple one hand move. This doesn't slide, it swivels.* With all the functions they have available, there is only one alarm.* I had TMobile turn on data so I could download features I need like another alarm, but The phone was never able to access the Internet so I cancelled that service.* It makes loud annoying sounds for whatever you do, opening the screen, keystrokes and just about everything. So I adjusted the settings to silent and turned the ring volume up, a multi step process through the menu. When I am at work I turn the volume down, then later when I turn the volume up, it resets all the sounds back on.* Texting is not easy to access, another multi step process. Getting texts is in a whole different location than writing a new text.* There are many buttons, and some just duplicate what others do. It looks impressive, but that's all.* The screen and buttons are not customizable so there is no way to set up one step shortcuts for features you use often.Everything that other phones do with a simple one or two steps, this phone requires attention to what you are doing and has multiple steps many starting from the menu. Doing almost anything with this phone is like carrying your PC around, and trying to get into programs without shortcuts on the desktop.This is not a phone you can hand to a friend and tell them, here, use my phone. You either have to dial for them, or hand them the users manual. Which in this case is a DVD.
summary: Not at all what I expected--

Pros: Read the reviews about this battery and it does work but it does not fit securely and the door that comes with it doesn't help at all.  First the battery is ridiculously large but i could deal with that because the battery lasted a long time compared to the standard, I even let it charge for overnight like some ppl said to avoid issues.Cons: The door was almost impossible to get on because it didn't quite fit so had to force it with alot of pressure.  It literally reboots several times a day which at first I was ok with because if you were careful picking it up or sitting it down it wouldn't reboot.  Now after 3 months it reboots 5 or more times every single day and I just cant take it anymore.  It reboots because the battery doesn't fit snugly and the door doesn't help in that department so then the connectors between the phone and the battery loses connection if their is any movement.  Because the battery is not a snug fit the connectors can disconnect at anytime and the phone will not turn back on, you have to open the door then push it back in with extreme force then the phone will turn back on.  I don't recommend this phone unless you don't mind it turning off when you put it in your pocket or purse or case or even when you take it out.  I'll be in the middle of a call and it just turns off, extremely annoying.  Just stick with the regular OEM Extended Battery and keep the standard battery charged as a backup if you travel, no it doesn't last as long but you won't have as many issues.
summary: Last really long BUT REBOOTS PHONE CONStANTLY!!! :(

The E200 is a petite, low-cost, nicely designed Bluetooth ear piece that will meet most needs for most people. I remember some years back when people with cell phones would walk around with these little devices in their ears. Today, that is less common. Wired headsets have become more the standard for walking and running while using a smart-phone and, like many others, I prefer to use a Bluetooth speaker-phone in the car rather than having something stuck in my ear. Non-the-less, there is still a place and a need for Bluetooth earpieces like this one.It paired easily with my iPhone5. I found the reception volume a bit soft for my liking and hearing, but it was audible. People on the other end said I sounded pretty much the same as I do using a speaker-phone. (NOTHING sounds as good as holding the phone to the side of your head!)The unit is quite small and unintrusuve. I did not need the over-the-ear plastic hook, but simply attached the smaller of the two available covers, and inserted it into my ear where it stayed firmly until I took it out. The controls are minimal and work as advertised. I especially liked the fact that this E200 charges with a standard USB-MiniUSB charging cable. It also comes with a USB AC adapter, so can be charged from household current or from a USB port on a computer.It reminds me of the old Samsung WEP200 series that were great but do not work well with newer (BT3) devices. About the same price, but this one works - and is about  the weight and does not need to sit in a charging case. Good product at a good price for those who still find use for a small, Bluetooth earpiece.

reviewText: I drive an 01 Audi A6. It's quite a popular model, yet I have trouble finding solutions to advancing technology that fit my vehicle AND wallet. This dual charger is exactly the type of simple and elegant upgrade I was hoping to make and luckily, Griffin and Amazon were there in the clutch as usual.The outlet in my A6 is hidden within a hide-away drawer at the bottom-center of my dash (below radio). Normally, car chargers are large and long. This not only fits perfectly within my hidden outlet, it also allows me to leave this dual charge in the outlet at all times - even when I need to close the drawer when the charger isn't in use. As others have mentioned, this may or may not sit flush with your outlet, but in my case (01 Audi A6) it fits perfectly, leaving just enough space for my pudgy fingers to pull the dual charger out with ease.Overall this is a fantastic charger and these days, it's a must.NOT TO MENTION THE BONUS CABLE!!!! I SAW A SIMILAR DUAL CHARGER FOR $3 MORE ON AMAZON THAT DIDN'T HAVE THIS CABLE. THIS IS THE WAY TO GO! YOU CAN NEVER HAVE TOO MANY IPHONE/IPOD/TABLET/CELL PHONE/ CABLES.

I bought the Q-cell 2 battery/charger package about 2 weeks ago, it shipped quickly.  The batteries do indeed have NFC just as the OEM batteries, and I use NFC daily.  They fit exactly as the OEM batteries and seem to have similar battery life.  I can't quantify it, but I don't notice a difference on battery life whether using the original battery or the Qcell, in fact, I usually don't know/remember which battery I have in the phone unless I look.  I would say 2300mAh is probably not accurate, I would say they are probably 2100mAh, same as the stock battery.The charger does take a long time to charge the batteries, about 8 hours from 10% to 100%, but it does charge the batteries completely.  There are no instructions in the package, and they are just in plain boxes.  I did find the the charger LED is purple while charging, and turns blue when the battery is fully charged.  The wall charger has a USB out to allow you to use a usb/micro-usb to charge your phone directly, however based on how long it takes to charge the spare battery in the charger, I haven't tried to charge a phone directly, seems like it would take forever.Overall, I think this is a great value for $25.
Used this to fix my screen on my galaxy s3.  Did the job and work as designed, the screen never came off.

While this headset is unique and quite sleek, I can't say too many positive things about this.  Here are the list of reasons why this headset is terrible:1) Fidelity - The sound quality was on par with a set of Coby earbuds, all mids and no highs or lows.  I had the earpiece properly inserted into my ear, sounds horrible.  Don't understand why some reviewers are saying the sounds are great, it truly lacks bandwidth and frequency response.2) Charging - Looks like the "charger" was an after thought or their attempt at recycling old stock.  You get this whacky, what I guess is a cell phone charger, but only a few pins on the charging are used, so only one "latch" out of two of the connector on the charger-side is used.  The charger looks Mickey-Moused.3) Lack of Volume and Next Track/Previous Track - Ok, no volume control I can deal with, no skip track or previous track?  That renders it unusable.  A while ago, I figured out that making playlists were really a waste of time, so I like to randomize my entire mp3 library on my iphone.  No next track/previous track means I have to whip out the phone.  The default corded iphone earbud with remote allows me to skip to next track, adjust volume without having to whip out my phone.  This feature is what garners this product a two-star.4) Wrong Material Choice?  The rubber on the ear bud fittings are of chalky, "dry" feeling rubber, as such, it will not grip the inside of your ear.  The slightest movement will make the ear bud fittings work itself out of your ear.  I miss my AcoustiBuds by Burton Technology.  They seemed to have gotten this part right, why can't a corporate giant like Sony/Ericsson get a simple material selection?  Did they not test it?  Did they test it on their own moist ear and said "good enough" and called it a day?  This is a piss poor selection of material, these in-ear buds have been around since they started handing out headsets on airplanes some 30 years ago.  With today's wider selection of all sorts of exotic rubbers, they couldn't get this little detail correct?5) The remote (if you can call it that) seriously is in a wrong place.  It's too high up.  I think this length was design for people with shorter necks.  It just wasn't well thought out.6)  Accessories that came with this earbud - the little clip that came with it is a joke, and removing the clip damaged the insulation on the wires.  The protective bag is just a cheap cloth bag you find in gimmicky audio accessories from generic manfacturers.What ever happened to Sony?  This brand has really gone down the drain.  Their TV sets suck, their audio accessories suck, their video game console sucks, everything from this company as of late really sucks.  This company is a joke.  And partnering/absorbing/merging with another dying company like Ericsson isn't really helping Sony developing good products at all...
summary: Last Sony product I'll ever buy

reviewText: I bought this brand, because of the rave reviews. This was a bad idea! I think mine must have came from a bad batch.  I applied 2 of the 3 protectors i received in this purchase, and on both installs the holes did not line up at all.  If i get the bottom to lign up, then the top cut out does not lign up.  Even though both sides and top and bottom of the protecter are perfectly ligned up around the edges, either one or the other cut outs will not line up.  I realized after the 2nd one that i installed, that my entire purchase was defective and came with bad cut outs.  The install was simple, and quite easy (but then again, ive done this many times before)  I would suggest going on ebay and spending .99 cents for protectors if your looking for poor alignment, because i did not get any use at all out of this $7 purchase, due to poor alignment of the cut outs.  I would have sent them back, but have already tried 2 of the 3 i received.  I threw the 3rd one in the trash, once i realized they were all defective.  Total waste of my time and money, and i would not recommend this product to anyone.  Sorry, just being honest.EDIT:  I GIVE 2 THUMBS UP TO ANY COMPANY THAT STANDS BEHIND THEIR PRODUCT, AND OFFERS OUTSTANDING CUSTOMER SERVICE, SUCH AS THIS COMPANY DOES.  THEY SENT ME ANOTHER PACKAGE, AND THESE PROTECTERS ARE PERFECT, AND THE CUTOUTS ARE FINE.  I MUST HAVE RECEIVED A BAD BATCH THE FIRST TIME, THESE ARE PERFECT.  THANKS TECH ARMOR FOR YOUR OUTSTANDING CUSTOMER SERVICE, AND FOR ACTUALLY TAKING THE TIME TO READ ALL REVIEWS.  OUTSTANDING SERVICE, 2 THUMBS UP A+++IF I COULD CHANGE MY STARS ON THIS REVIEW I WOULD CHANGE IT TO A 5 STAR REVIEW.  OH WAIT, I CAN CHANGE IT, AND I JUST DID.  5 STAR SERVICE HERE, AND I WILL BE BACK FOR SOME IPHONE CASES.
summary: BAD CUTOUTS BUT OUTSTANDING CUSTOMER SERVICE!

reviewText: i like this case, but when i received it the rubber was slightly roughed up, but then after using this case in and out with a rotation of a few other cases, the rubber border around the whole case started to become unglued, i recommend the otterbox commuter, its ever so slightly thicker but has better quality and last longer, plus if anything happens to it, you just call up the service team there and get it replaced.

Not a bad case as my phone has fallen many times while inside it.  Not wow though.  The stand on the back can be difficult to open, even after many times.  It's a two part case (rubber sleeve and outer exoskeleton), and because the exoskeleton isn't solid (it resembles a star shape), it likes to pop off easier.  The belt clip portion is big and bulky and it allows the whole thing to wiggle around a ton, which can allow it to snag on thing as you put them on or pass by them (phone has been pulled off numerous times by walking passed things like door knobs, countertops, seatbelts...).  I quit using it early on.  The rubber sleeve is easily gripped and held, but the exoskeleton is slick with something akin to a waxy feel on it.  Overall, it does a really good job at saving your phone from a big drop, but next time I'll use a slimmer profile case with a full exoskeleton.  Belt clips are useless anyways on phones this size unless you have a belt pouch.
summary: Not the best solution, but it's cheap and works

Glad it arrived safely.

reviewText: .It sounds like a well built 2-1/2 inch mini-speaker, which may delight or annoy you.It's missing a few features that other Bluetooth speakers have. See "OKs" below.It looks and feels like quality.An inexpensive improvement on laptop or phone speakers.PROs:- Beautiful, clean design. A pleasure to look at and hold.- Excellent fit & finish. Feels like quality.- Microphone & phone call capability- Volume is impressive (see Note 1)- Nice price (when selling for $16)OKs:- No volume control or mute button, but the control button will pause music.- No wired connection. Works only with Bluetooth devices.- Not stereo- No significant delay (matters when watching video)(It's 0.08 sec)- Background hiss is very faint, and cuts out when source is paused.- Charging cable is Micro-USB (the most common type)- 4-6 hours playing time per charge- Tip it over (on flat spot) for directed sound- Bluetooth range is as expected. Some dropping out at 25 feetCONs:- Sounds bad when compared with larger speakers or medium quality headphones- No warranty info enclosed with product or in amazon listing.- - - The Sound - - -I listened to a challenging tune on this and 3 other small speakers many times over. The sound is a notch or two better than laptop speakers (including my MacBook Pro 13"). It's better than my golf-ball sizedXBOOM Mini Capsule Speaker. It's a notch below the largerPLEMO Magic Cube.Of course it's much worse than your average headphones or large stereo speakers.For mid-range vocals, podcasts, or your average movie, the sound seems good enough. For tunes with significant bass and highs...you might wish for a larger speaker.The volume seems adequate for a 10-20 foot listening range in a quiet outdoor setting (depends on the music), or in a large quiet living room. (See Note 1.)- - - Tip - - -Set it on its side for directed sound. (A flat spot was maybe designed for this.)- - - Disclosure - - -The manufacturer gave me this item for review. I believe my review is impartial.- - - Notes - - -Note 1: Volume - It's as loud as the largerPLEMO Magic Cube(also 3 watts). Impressive. From your computer, remember to check both your system volume and the app (for example, iTunes) volume.~~~ Comments & questions welcome ~~~
summary: Impressive, given its size and cost

reviewText: These are really inexpensive factory refurbished batteries. They differ from regular Samsung batteries in that they seem to have an "LZ" instead of a fancy barcode on the back. I ordered a pair of these and when one was dead on arrival, the seller quickly sent me another one.One thing to note is that some of these aren't pre-charged, so you'll need to have your phone off when you initially charge them up if you're charging by plugging it in over USB to a computer or have a dedicated standalone charger. Otherwise, the current draw to charge the battery is too much to keep the phone on and it'll die.These things are a great deal at the price and have the same life as the battery that came with my phone. Handy if you're using a lot of GPS or WiFi on your phone.

I received a review sample in exchange for a review and have been having a blast with this simple-but-cool lens.The instructions discuss screwing the lens into a "slim-line protective case" when in fact that case is actually the clip and mine came  in the sealed package already installed. A few things you need to note:- If you are using a protective case for your phone (I am using aEvecase Leather Wallet Case with Stand and Credit Card Holder for Samsung Galaxy Note 2) you need to remove your phone before you can clip on this lens.- This is a true fisheye lens that will capture a full 180 degrees. I took a shot of my music room, which normally takes three shots to fully capture and the one shot managed to include all of my amps, drums and instruments.- There is NO magnification. This is a straight through lens with the fisheye effect as the only feature.- Your photos will be framed in what will look like a black mat over a porthole. Sort of like a spy shot, and also ultra cool for some unique views of wide areas.I am concerned that the clip extends over my screen on my phone. There is a soft plastic patch with a slight texture that holds the lens in place and seems to protect the lens from scratching. On the other hand I had to reposition the lens to get to my camera icon on the screen. Since this is a new tool I am sure I will discover convenient workarounds. If so I will be sure to update this review.The package itself is simple: it comes with the lens pre-screwed into the clip, a small cloth bag and a lens cover. The latter is a nice touch. The price is nominal considering the quality of the photos I have taken with this already. In fact, I have been able to shoot some interesting pictures. It's a shame that Amazon has eliminated the customer-supplied image feature because a few pictures are worth thousands of words.For the price you cannot go wrong. Especially if you are used to shooting multiple times to get an entire subject. The best thing I can say is had I not been provided with a review sample I would purchased one of these anyway. They are that useful in certain situations and very high quality.
