I have had a lot of trouble getting decent quality with voice calls, however.  If you are looking for a bluetooth device to be used primarily for music, this is likely to be a good choice. I originally purchased this unit for a trip I was taking to Las Vegas.  With 2 iPad’s and 2 iPhones as well as a few other devices, I knew that I needed a powerful unit to keep all of them running.  After using it during week long trip and in other situations since then, here are my impressions.Design:I like the look of the unit, since it is square not rectangular it is easier to fit into small pockets.  In fact it is small enough that it will fit in the smallest pocket of my laptop bag which can’t be said of some of the other chargers.The finish on this device is perfect.  It is matte and not shiny at all.  I have had batteries in the past that have had more of a shiny finish and they attract fingerprints which just make them annoying.  If my fingers are really greasy it will show on this unit, but it is not a constant struggle as it can be with other units.The unit is plastic, but it doesn’t feel like a cheap plastic.  I am not afraid that it will crack apart after a small drop.I do really like the fact that it comes with a cloth bag.  Since this unit is used for travel and mobility, there are times where it is thrown into a backpack, laptop and I it is nice to have it protected from scratches.Function:This unit has performed amazingly well.  I was able to charge 2 iPhones at the same time, as well as my iPad and have never had problems with not having enough power.  This really is the end goal, to have power when I need it and not have to worry about running out.  The large battery makes this unit a necessity for travel or to have when I am not around an electrical outlet.The fact that it has 2 USB ports is great as it makes this device a lot more functional that it would have been with 1 port.The micro-USB connection for input is very easy to use to charge the device and I have not had any problems with charging the unit.Overall this is a great charger for any mobile device!
Easy to apply and makes the galaxy s4 idiot proof. The curves edges and slim glass makes this product feel like it isn't even there!

The only complaint is that the plug-in and USB ports are on opposite ends on the length of the device, roughly 1 3/4inches without anything plugged into the USB ports; it could have stuck out from the wall half the distance if they had been placed differently.
summary: Works great! Just a bit long...

This is a fantastic device! I have seen so many reviews of this phone that I wanted to just specifically address something ignored or not noticed about it by most of the people I have known who have one.  The headphones are special to the phone and they come with a tiny mic in the cord that hangs down by your neck. You can raise or lower the volume here (look for the plus and minus signs) but you can also hang up a call by pressing the center between the volume buttons.  Also, if you hang up a call and then want to listed to some music, you don't have to touch the phone you can just hit that center button again and a song will start playing (using that center section)using the play/pause!I have heard the newest model are shaped differently and smaller too.
summary: Fantastic device, the headphones are special not the same as ipod!

reviewText: I normally love Logitech products and have in the past been almost universally impressed with their design and implementation... remote controls, headphones, computer keyboards / mice, wireless speakers... you name it, if it's Logitech, it's quality.This time, however... doesn't seem to be the case.On my Galaxy S3 smartphone I can easily pair this device. Sound quality is great. I could go into specifics about the design, but I'll skip that because right now this device is unusable for me.During every call, about 30 seconds in the speakerphone starts to get crackly. The person on the other end stops being able to hear me and their voice takes on a distorted robot-like quality. This goes on for about ten seconds, then the call ends. If the robot voice happens and I quickly turn off Bluetooth and begin using my phone normally, things go back to normal.I have used and reviewed many other Bluetooth devices with this phone (today I used a Philips bluetooth headset to listen to music at work, and a Belkin bluetooth adapter to listen to music here at home) so I know the phone itself functions fine. I have to believe there's an issue with this device -- perhaps the firmware? I know it's not the connection quality, because my phone is only a couple feet away and every call starts out fine.I wish I could give this a better rating but have to give it 1 star for now. I invite a Logitech technician or helpful Amazon viewer to help me try and get this resolved; if I can get past this issue I'll re-review/rate.
Charged completely and discharged 3x then tried solar had it on a white ice cooler and melted the solar panel .

This Samsung Bluetooth headset is a good choice for someone looking for an inexpensive wireless solution. The packaging is easy to open, and includes the BT headset, charger, instructions, warranty,  and enough ear gels (3) and earhooks (2) to fit your needs. I like the standard Micro USB port for charging which makes it pretty universal in case you ever misplace the charger. The headset is lightweight and very comfortable (I hardly noticed it was there) and can be used on either the left or right ear with a simple swap of the earhook. Those with smaller ears my find it a bit uncomfortable though since the speaker is fairly large. It is also easy to use and paired almost instantly.The sound quality is a toss-up. On my end it sounded pretty good with clear sound, however, a couple other callers complained of the sound quality; one person said it sounded like I was in a wind tunnel with an echo. This could be a problem with the network or other caller's phone though.All in all, it's nothing fancy but I would say this is a good choice for someone who wants a simple and inexpensive Bluetooth headset.

I bought this case for those nights when I want my Note 3 to match my glammed up style.I love that this case has a window pocket for my ID. It is able to show all of the necessary information without having to remove it. It also has slots for my credit cards and MetroCard. The pretty white flower which is also the "lock" keeps everything in place. The gold color wrist strap feels secure on my wrist without being annoying. The pink color is true to what is shown on the site. The quilted shell keeps everything safe (don't have to worry about water damage) while I am enjoying the event. I like that the vendor (HandHeld) sent a mini stylus with my purchase - it really does work with my Note 3.Highly recommend when you want a special upscale look for your Note 3.

I was very excited to pick up the EHS71 headset. As I took them out of the box the first thing I noticed was the way they are constructed. The aircraft aluminum earbuds with tangle resistant cord. The ear cushions fit well inside my ears. The zipper carrying case was also very nice.When I plugged it into my iPhone, things were just not right. I heard static just moving my head around.  Calls could not be answered with the headset, it had to be done manually. After a few calls I was getting complaints of my voice breaking up while hearing some background noise. It was very disappointing using this with my iPhone.Streaming music was a good deal better than using the headset for calls. I was very impressed with the quality. While sounding very good, it still could have used a little more bottom end. These headphones will be great for all activities that include my  music.If you are looking for a good set of headphones/earbuds for music then these could be for you. If you are an iPhone user then I would look elsewhere.

I love these headphones for noise canceling and wonderful sound. The pairing worked seamlessly with my electronics and the battery life is excellent. The carrying case is perfect for travel since I can also slip the cords into the side pockets. It's not a hard sided case so I do have to pack them carefully but they are worth it for the noise canceling!The only problem I encountered with the headset is that it's slightly too large for my head. I've figured out how to perch the top so they don't slide anymore. But the earpieces hang a little low and press into the the side of my neck. They expand to be bigger but unfortunately can't go smaller.But overall, I think these are excellent headphones and are top quality. It seems to be very sturdy and haven't had a problem with them yet.
summary: Wireless Headphones with a Great Sound!

reviewText: I like to take care of my stuff, so when I got a new iPhone from work, I immediately purchased a Speck Candyshell Grip caseSpeck Products CandyShell Grip Case for iPhone 4/4S - 1 Pack - Carrying Case - Retail Packaging - Blackto protect the phone should I drop it. While I find the Speck case perfect for that task, I also wanted a holster to keep the phone at my side when not in use so I wouldn't leave it somewhere.I searched Amazon for a larger holster that could accommodate the iPhone in the Speck case. After reading the description and reviews, the Reiko seemed like it fit the need. Several reviews said the Reiko worked with their iPhones in Otterbox Commuter cases which appears to be a similar form factor to the Speck.Bottom line, the case is almost perfect for me. The things I like about the case are:- Inexpensive, under $10- Belt clip is very secure- Belt loops for both horizontal and vertical orientation- Well made, no loose strings or unfinished edges- Big enough to hold iPhone in Speck case- Padded for extra protectionThe only thing I would change would be to have the holster ride lower when clipped to my belt.  It rides high in the vertical orientation with the top of the holster a good inch and a half above the top of the belt. Because I'm a big guy (aka heavy), when I sit down my sides hang over my belt and the holster digs into my side. Not an issue when I'm standing or walking and also not an issue when using the horizontal belt loop.  I can't knock a star off, because I could also fix the issue by losing some weight.By design, the Speck case I use is very high grip,  anti-skid with raised rubber grips over most of the outside of the case. That feature, combined with the initial stiffness of the holster, made it a two handed affair to extract the phone from the holster. After a couple weeks of use, the holster has "relaxed" and I can remove the phone with one hand when I need it.

For the price they should be ready to use without having to download an app to each device separately. The app is what gives you the sound quality, otherwise they are just another pair of earbuds. Actually I have a cheap pair that sound better (not using an app).Note: update 11/13 price has dropped considerably from when I wrote this reviewFirst the positives:1) they don't tangle2) they have volume control3) if you use the app, the sound is adjustable to your preferences4) interchangeable size buds, extras providedSecondly, the negatives1) the link provided on package to download the app didn't work2) the scanbarcode didn't either3) had to call service for a link to download the app4) cannot download to any device that is not Apple or that does not have internet access (such as an iPod Classic, or Kindle-Fire)5) You must set the Jabra app as your default music player6) the "left" and right" printed on each bud is too small to read without a microscope and is in red cursive letters, making it necessary to mark them.7) You can't adjust the equalizer while the music is actually playing (at least we couldn't on the iPod-touch) so one has to guess; extra steps to go back and reset if it is too much bass/treble or what. If there is a way to do that,while the music is playing, maybe someone will let me know and I will block this portion from my review8) Overpriced.
summary: Better if app weren't necessary, and if they cost less

I forgot about this screen protector about a day after I put it on. That's exactly what should happen. There is a slightly different feel to the screen now -- but I think I actually like it better. The materials included made for an effortless installation.I got this for a used Droid X I picked up.The two additional steps I'd recommend are cleaning the screen with something like rubbing alcohol to get off the oils and before removing any backing laying the protector down on the screen to see what sort of margin it affords you at the edges. This combo Bluetooth Speaker is great for listening to FM Radio or Songs in the shower. It has many advantages that I list below.PROS:1) Pairing/Connecting - Once I pressed the correct function from the multi-purpose Power Button, it did pair with my tablet and my Android phone just fine.*Helpful hint: Be sure to turn on your Android device's Bluetooth FIRST before you attempt to pair/connect it with this Bluetooth Speaker. Then turn on the Bluetooth speaker and let your phone or tablet search for devices. This makes it so much easier to pair/connect. Once it is paired for the first time, the next time connecting is so easy!2) Sound Quality / LoudnessLOUDNESS - For a smaller speaker, in the shower even with the water on full force, the sound is VERY LOUD (can be turned down).*Helpful hint for you about loudness: First, if you plan on listening to songs from your Playlist from your phone on this, adjust the phone's sound FIRST to your liking and louder than you think because you will need it kind of loud in the shower. Also you can turn the volume UP OR DOWN on the Bluetooth speaker by using the top or bottom (on the left side)buttons.SOUND QUALITY on this speaker:The sound quality is very good to excellent for such a small unit. So I compared this to a larger Bluetooth Speaker that I own and use (that is not waterproof one like this one is) that I have and the sound was very, very close in sound quality and loudness. The overall Treble is quite good and for me, the Bass is pretty good as well. This is a huge plus for this Bluetooth speaker!3) FM Radio - Since I live on top of a hill and near a mountain and lots of trees, usually I cannot get FM that well in Bluetooth types of devices/radios. However, this one was able to CLEARLY pickup two of my favorite stations loud and clear and they stayed on while in the shower.CONS:1) The device's Power On has many multi-purposes on it. Personally, I would have preferred to see a dedicated BLUETOOTH ON/OFF button and also a POWER ON/OFF Button. As it is now this ONE BUTTON does all of these:--Turns on the device--Turns on Bluetooth.--Turns off Bluetooth--Turn on the FM Radio.--Serves as a charging indicator (when you turn it off and then plug in the USB cable, then the light changes to a NON BLINKING RED. This unit took some patience on my part because of the Power Button doing too many things at once, but I was able to get it working fine and this is just a very minor thing really for me personally.Overall, I like this speaker OK, it is loud and clear, but there are two things I really DO NOT LIKE AT ALL:1) The charger that came with this is propriety, and should I misplace or lose this, I cannot charge this speaker.2) The unit is really too loud in my opinion. It always begins VERY loud and does not keep the level of loudness where I last set it.
summary: Works OK but has a proprietary charger

reviewText: I'm a headphone buff and I've also had more than a dozen Bluetooth headsets over the years.  However, I haven't used many Bluetooth stereo earphones, so I was very excited to give the BackBeat GO 2 a try.PROS:- Very good sound quality for Bluetooth- Good bass response- Easy to pair and use- Sweat/water resistant- Pair up to 8 devicesCONS:- Poor battery life- Cable can snag on your neck during workoutsCOMFORTThe BackBeat GO 2 (BBG2) weighs just 14 grams and is reasonably comfortable to wear.  My ears did ache a little and felt itchy after wearing them for a couple of hours straight, but that's not unlike most other earphones.  The BackBeat GO 2 uses rubber "stabilizers" to help keep the speakers safely in your ears so if you wear them during your fitness activities, they won't fall out.  They're similar to the design used in some of Plantronics' Bluetooth mono headsets.  The BBG2 comes with the medium eartips installed as well as another set of small and large tips.SOUND QUALITYFor a Bluetooth earphone that doesn't support aptX, the BBG2 sounds very good.  I enjoyed listening to music with them, including lots of modern music that have lots of bass.  Movies were also fun to watch and the good bass response helped in scenes with lots of special effects and explosions.  As with any earphone, it's important to get a proper seal to get the best sound quality and the BBG2 is no different.  Plantronics stresses this point frequently in their literature.DESIGN & FEATURESThe BBG2 isn't completely "wireless," per se, because the left and right speakers are attached via a short cable with a remote attached.  However, you aren't tethered to your computer, phone or tablet, which is especially useful when working out at the gym.  The BBG2 is sweat-proof and water resistant, but I found the rubbery cable would snag on the back of my neck during workouts.  It's not a huge deal and myAudio-Technica ATH-CKP500BL SonicSportsdo the same thing, but thought it was worth mentioning.Pairing the BBG2 is easy and done via the inline remote.  Conveniently, it can pair up to 8 devices, so you can have all your computers, tablets, and phones paired up and ready to use at any time.BATTERY LIFEThe battery life on the BBG2 is really its only downfall.  Five hours of talk time and 4.5 hours of stereo listening is not very long.  On the bright side, it fully charges via micro USB in only 2.5 hours.  You can also download a battery meter app for iOS or a battery life widget for Android.  There's a version of the BBG2 with a battery case for about $20 more, that adds an additional 10 hours of life.  I really think Plantronics should've made the battery case standard for the BBG2.  Even if you have your own external battery charger (I do), you may want to save its charge for your phone or tablet, not your earphones.CONCLUSIONThe Plantronics BackBeat Go 2 is an excellent stereo Bluetooth earphone that's hampered only by poor battery life.  It sounds great, is easy to use, and really convenient.  If you're willing to charge it frequently, the BackBeat Go 2 is definitely a stereo BT earphone worth trying.
summary: Great sound and easy to use

reviewText: The color is more dark in person, and this isnt the best protection case. I get a lot of compliments on the case, and it was easy to put on.

Wow lately Spigen has been disappointing at every turn and this case just adds to it's downfall.I used to be a huge Spigen fan and always recommended their cases and screen protectors but lately all I have are issues with the protectors and the cases and this one so far is the worst.Here's what I like:It's like a sophisticated otterbox case for your note 3 that will protect your phone from falls, even those nasty corner drops.-The s view does work but it lags and you may need to apply a bit of pressure.-Case is actually assembled in 2 parts so you can remove the door and the plastic that holds it together to have a silicone cases that is not too shabby-Camera hole is the perfect shape and does not allow surfaces to touch so the lens is always protectedWhat I hate:-Your phone will be protected but the case will not survive the falls especially the door bc its made out of cheap plastic-The s pen is a pain to get out-The headphone is not easy to access-You have to remove your phones original back to use this case (otherwise s view will not work)-The s view windows does not always work and may at times cause your phone to be stuck on s view lock screen mode-The door hinge is poorly made and will not last long-Since the case is assembled in two parts, expect the plastic portion to break-The door does not open as easily as you would expect-The s view door home button sticks (it will turn on many times when its in your pockets)-Matte finish so fingerprints and smudges will remain and give off a wear and tear look within months (gloss always leaves fingerprints but its easy to wipe off)I preordered this case and it took a while before I got it due to supply issues but when I received I was very happy and pleased. Unfortunately that did not last. The part of the case that holds the door and the hinge together snapped off and essentially the case came apart.Luckily for me Spigen announced that they would cover this cases for an extra 2 years or so with their new cases and I was told on twitter that it also applied to their past cases (I forget exact coverage years). I was able to get a replacement by sending them photos via twitter and email and I honestly expected to get brand new case but no. What I got was a replacement door. I contacted them again and sent them better photos and told them that the door is not the only thing broken. They apologized and sent me the plastic cover that holds the hinge and door and goes over the silicone portion of the case. At this point I just gave up and used what they gave me since it worked...for a month.That same plastic part of the case broke and the door continues to pop out now but they have not responded to my twitter complaints and frankly I am tired of their slow service so a negative review it is.I have never dropped my phone, banged it or let if take any damage. All I do is put it in my front pocket and attach it to my car dock that is all and yet the case does not last.
summary: Plastic portion of the case will eventually break from common use

AmazonBasics offers these combination silicon/hard shell cases for the iPhone at a reasonable price (probably in direct competition with Otterbox Commuter Cases).  While it doesn't seem as safe or secure as an Otterbox Commuter Case might be, it's not half bad.  The silicone case fits snugly around the iPhone and the outer hard shell case (although not as stiff as an Otterbox shell) holds it in place.  Holding the phone, it doesn't feel as slippery as an Otterbox shell, so that's one nice feature.  For aesthetics, the back has a couple of open holes in the shell that exposes the silicone part, but it doesn't feel as safe having those, should the phone be accidentally dropped.  I do like that AmazonBasics seems to offer more variety of colors than Otterbox, but I still think Otterbox offers a better product.  If you want something cheaper, though, and a good value, AmazonBasics PC/silicon cases seem like a great option.

I've owned several of these portable chargers and this is really one of the best, size wise. It's small enough to fit into your pocket, which is really nice. A lot are kind of big. Great if you carry around a large purse or briefcase, but not so great if you don't.It has the little "universal" port built-in. Awesome for your standard Android phone or Kindle. It charges the phone really fast too! If nearly everything you own has the universal port, then you're in good shape here. All of my stuff does, so this is perfect for me. The problem becomes if you have an iPhone or something that uses a different port. You then have to use the USB cord. Not a huge problem except now you have to carry around this great little charger AND a cord. It kind of defeats the purpose, I think.So, this is a trade off. For me, it's perfect. It's small and has the charger connector built in that I need. I can charge two things at once by using a cord. The phone charges super fast, but my tablet took a little longer.It really depends on what you need. For me, I'd totally slip this into my pocket/bag for an evening out when I wanted to pack light. For a multi-day conference, I'd likely bring a larger one with a little more power and multiple ports (more than one iPhone friend has borrowed some power from me!)

What do you look for in a phone? Do you want a sleek, sparkly little sliver of plastic with "apps" and a screen that does tricks when you poke it? If so, run. Run back to your cozy little Starbucks and...blog, or whatever it is you people do. This is a phone for men and hardy women. This is a phone with which you could bludgeon a wolverine. You do not text with this phone. You do not Tweet. You call people and tell them how it's going to be. True, you can do that with lots of phones--but with this one, you can do it while fording the turgid waters of the Nile. You can use its horrid little camera to record new and grotesque species in the depths of the Amazon Basin. You can make dinner reservations for two at that Hungarian place on 34th while galloping toward the airfield pursued by a mysterious hitman. You'll deal with him later.Oh, and it's really not that hard to get internet, etc.--See D. Henry's review for directions.The one thing I don't like is that you have to set the clock again every time you swap out the battery. That gets kind of annoying.6 MONTH UPDATE:Having now owned this phone for half a year, I stand fully behind my initial review. I moved to a different continent, and it welcomed the new SIM card with open arms--and I got the internet working here, too. I've capsized with this clipped to the straps of my kayak and watched most of my equipment ripped loose as the craft was scraped over partially-submerged trees by the torrent. When I caught and righted the kayak, the phone demurely informed me that I had a voicemail awaiting my leisure. Just last month, I hit a patch of black ice on my bicycle and the phone ground into the asphalt under me as I skidded from the crash. It came out in far better shape than I did, exhibiting only a slight scuff on the screen protector I made from packing tape.
summary: A phone for people who don't mess around.

The Mophie Juice Pack Air Case and Rechargeable Battery effectly doubles the battery life of your iPhone 3G or 3GS.  It unavoidably beefs up the iPhones sleek dimensions, but can be a better alternative for some than the battery packs that plug into the bottom of the iPhone and afford little portability and encumbered use out of the iPhone while attached.If you are the type of iPhone use who normally carries around your iPhone in a protective case or jacket, then you probably won't mind the added bulk or heft.  The only annoying part of the size increase is that the depth is increased by about 50%.  This can make it more difficult to fit in your pocket, especially if you're wearing tight jeans.  However, taking off the case and putting it on is not much of a chore and thanks to the easily accessible port on the bottom, there's no need to regularly remove the Mophie Juice Pack.  LED indicators for the battery level round out the package.Overall, the Mophie Juice Pack is a great battery add-on for those who need it in a more convenient package than otherwise available.  It doubles as a case, which may be a big plus for some iPhone owners.  My wife uses a similar case (matte finish and obviously slimmer) when she's not using the Mophie Juice Pack.  So, when we are travelling away from home, she's glad to trade a little extra room in her purse for a lot of extra battery life.  For everyday use, she'd rather have her iPhone handy in her pocket.

summary: A must have for iGo users!

reviewText: I bought this case with the expectation that I would get something better than a $3 case I might get on ebay. Needless to say I'm disappointed. I wrote the manufacturer in hopes that the product I received might be defective, but after endless promises that someone would contact me I have given up.  Here are some things to consider...1.) The case does fit the phone, but no better than a generic case. My specific case has extra space and visibly wiggles around the phone loosely.2.) The rubber around the case (the material that gives the case the rubberized feel) wears off with easy rubbing.3.) The case will scratch the sides of your phone. Had I known this I would have simply gone with a ghost shield or zagg.If you're buying this case with the expectation that you're buying something premium, you'll be disappointed. There are a lot of positive reviews about this product, but notice that almost all are from people who 'just bought' the product. There are several similar cases that can be found on Amazon for under $1, this case offers no more protection than one of those.
summary: No better than a $3 case you can buy on ebay.

reviewText: We have a variety of tablets and smartphones in our family both work issued and personal.  When we travel for work or go on vacation someone always forgets or doesn't have enough time to charge at least one of their devices and so we were looking for a backup battery that could be used with most of our devices.This battery not only fully charges an Ipad 2 and Blackberry Playbook, it can also charge our Samsung Galaxy, Kindle Fire, Nook and our Iphones, Blackberries, Samsungs, HTCs and Nokias.  This battery is able to charge an Iphone approximately 3 times or an Ipad 2 one and a half times.  While this packet only comes with Ipad and Blackberry charging dongles, any USB cable for any of the above electronics fit into the battery.We really love how easily compatible this battery is with our devices for both work (Blackberry and Samsung) and personal use (Iphone and HTC).  An added plus was that we could even charge our ereaders.  Plus, traveling for over 2/3 of the year for work and having to carry all the weight of electronics we need for both work and personal use, being able to have one battery instead of several is a true relief.Recommended for those needing an affordable intermediate backup battery that is compatible with most devices.  Highly recommended for road warriors looking to simplify and consolidate.
summary: Easy to use. Works on Ipad 2, Blackberry Playbook and Samsung Galaxy.

This case is super-sleek; very thin, form-fitting.  The back is soft-touch, it doesn't feel like it'll fly out of your hand at all times.  The case has a bit of a lip on the front, meaning if you place the phone face-down, you won't scratch the display...the aluminum buttons on the side are perfect; they feel like they're a part of the phone.Something to look out for with this case...it's not very protective.  The case is a combination of TPU-like material and polycarbonate.  Unlike the Slim Armor cases, which have a polycarbonate insert, the "shell" here is essentially the "bumper" around the perimeter of the case.  It's very sleek; but it won't protect the phone from anything other than a short drop or light bumps; if you're looking for a rugged case, definitely look elsewhere.  The other thing to watch for is the cutouts for the charging port and headphone jack are fairly deep and small; anything other than fairly slim plugs will NOT fit using this case.  A headphone extention might work; but anything but slim-profile USB plugs won't fit.
summary: A gorgeous case...adds only to the already sleek lines of the phone

The choices in external batteries can be bewildering, and it's not always easy to decide which one to get.  First, it's best to determine your likely use (multiple devices, a power-hungry tablet, only a single smart phone, etc.) and how often you expect to need the extra power.  This Bolse power bank fully charges my iPhone 5 two-and-a-half  times, which really equates into three or four sessions since I plug in my phone when it gets to 25% or so.  While it will charge an iPad, it doesn't have enough power to charge the 3rd-gen iPad more than a third or so.  The 5200 mAh size is perfect if your often run-down your phone, if you travel, or if you want to to give your tablet enough juice to, say, finish watching a movie.  A larger battery is a must for frequent tablet use, and a smaller one might be in order for infrequent smartphone use.  This size is a good intermediate one -- not too large to be bulky but with a large enough capacity for a variety of devices.  It takes about 7 hours to charge the battery using a wall adapter.The dual ports are great to have.  When I'm on vacation, I can charge both my iPhone 5 (with my own cable) and my camera at the same time.  This battery will charge anything that can get power through a USB cable, although, if the included connectors/adapters don't fit, you'll have to use your own cable.  The battery feels and looks solid, with comfortable curves that fit in my hand.  It measures 3.75" x 2" x 1" at the widest points of each dimension.  (Note:  I received a sample for review.)-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Nice Size With Dual Charging Ports

reviewText: I have a Nokia N8 that I wanted to upgrade and since Nokia's build quality speaks for itself I went for a Lumia.I wanted a phone with expandable memory as my music and photos are on the MicroSD card and I also wanted a phone with at least 1GB of RAM.So I got this Lumia 820.So far the phone has been great, save for some basic features I really miss like FM Radio, Flip to Silence, select a custom message alert, the ability to set separate volume for alarms, music, ringtones, etc., notification center, some kind of visual alert that I have missed a call, alert or a sms so I don't have to turn the screen on to check, have the phone ring and vibrate at the same time, and some other things I already have on a 3 years old phone but missing on a phone launched 5 months ago.The battery life is not as great as with the N8 but then again it's a 680 MHz 3.5 inches vs a 1.5GHz Dual Core 4.3 inches phone.I'm liking the phone so far as the UI is very fast but untill I get back all the funtionality I now have on my 3 years old Symbian phone, the N8 will stay with me as my primary phone. Maybe I can retire it for an Android phone as it has nearly all the features and functionality Symbian has.

reviewText: Sleek.... slim... streamlined.... Are all words that will never be used to describe any Otterbox product ever made. If you know anything about Otterbox then thats not what you were expecting anyway. This is a hollowed out brick, painted black, and attached to a belt clip. It is rough and rugged. It is as sturdy as a bullet proof vest (not suggesting that you should shoot your phone). For the type of outdoor tough jobs/activities I do on a daily basis this thing is a GODSEND... The only reservations I had about this was the almost cheap and ill thought out design of the cover/flap. It like taking a tank and realixing "Oh we forgot to cover this thing.... Well lets throw a tarp over it and no one will notice". YES... Exactly like that. Great case. Solid and Secure. With an odd ill designed rubber flap closed with magnets. When I received my "Jabra Extreme Bluetooth Headset for PC with Skype" I was immediately impressed with the packaging, it comes incased in medium size box made of a higher quality plastic, the package was quite sturdy and took some effort get into. After opening the box the first thing I noticed is the weight of the headset, it feels solid in your hand but not heavy. It seems to have the feel of a well-made product, not a super light cheap feel you find in some Bluetooth headsets.I found the instruction manual to be clear and concise, following the manual was a breeze. Charging the device is simple, it has an indicator light that changes colors as you move through the charging process, red for charging, yellow for medium charge, and green for fully charged.The controls on the device are conveniently placed, the on/off switch is placed on the bottom away from the other controls. The volume controls are placed on the outside of the device with volume down control near the bottom of the outside and the volume up near the top of the outside. Both are marked accordingly with "-" for volume down and "+" for volume up. The answer/end call button is located on the outside middle of the device; it protrudes out so as to not confuse it with the volume controls.  Answering and ending calls is easy, one push to answer and one push to end call, or one of my favorite features,  two quick pushes to refuse an incoming call.The headset fits comfortably in my ear, the ear gels and the ear hooks keep it snug and in place. I am impressed by the volume on this device as well, at low volume you can clearly understand the person on the other end, and at high volumes the sound doesn't become distorted.I don't utilize Skype very often but set up was fairly quick, and my calls have been problem free.This is easily the best Bluetooth device I have owned, I highly recommend it.
summary: Best blue tooth I've ever used by a long shot

My wife actually one of these and paid for it in October. I had just got thePlantronics M155 - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Whitefor myself. I tend to never be any "power user" in any way but do like to use it for riding my motorcycle and this review brings out the biggest flaw with this headset in that area. I know, no normal person uses this on a motorcycle. But as far as MY use, that is about the only time I need it....I use it to take a call and also to listen to GPS instructions so I don't take my eyes off the road & traffic. I have other brands that do this well with NO problems. Not so with this model.The  background noise on this set is simply horrible in MY circumstances. And on some calls I also get intermittent "cut outs" in conversations. For general home use I would give it possibly 4 stars but for MY use, only 2 stars. So I try to be fair here and give this 3 stars overall. I know it s a nice piece but I simply have other sets I use that serve MY unique purposes a bit better. If I give this more use in a home setting I still find the above problems just not to the same To me the purpose of a call is to clearly HEAR. This simply does not do as well as my other headsets.UPDATE Dec 17, 2011: I have now spent a couple weeks trying it in my car. I simply still can't find myself like this. Still, even in my car, it is muffles, garbed, doesn't fit me well when I don't have a motorcycle helmet holding it in place.....I simply can't find a single thing that makes me grab it as opposed to ANY other headset I own. Given it's price and poor performance in so many areas, I am downgrading this to 2 stars.
summary: The Wife Likes It, Me not so much....

reviewText: I'm not going to pay the Apple retail price for a new phone charger when this little guy is available.  But it charges at about half the speed of the real-deal charger.  That's a little frustrating at times.If you regularly get home from work and want to throw your phone on the charger for 20 minutes to have it powered up for a night on the town, look somewhere else.  If you just want something to recharge it overnight, go for this one!  It's obviously cheaply made, the connecter is clunky, and the cord is viciously short.But it will charge your phone for $5.

VSONIC'S Pro R-02 may be considered budget, but they don't skimp on eartips.  There are almost as many eartips on this set as in their higher end GR07's and GR01's.  I counted 14 sets.  Wow!  I dare anyone to not find a set that fits.In addition to the eartips, these earphones come with an elegant pouch, the same one as their high-end cousins, and a little clip to keep the cord in place.Each earphone is clearly marked left or right.  Before I started using earphones, it never occurred to me that there is a left and right, it's often so hard to see.  They protrude out of the ear a little more than some other earphones, but I don't think most people would mind.The sound is richer, more bold than my cheap set of earphones.  Cord thump is minimal.  Clarity is good, and sound separation is adequate.  If you're searching for good sound separation, it can be found in VSONIC's higher end models.  For the vast majority of people, this is a good budget earphone.This product was provided for review by GateShop.

I purchased the headset to replace an older H710 version.  For the most part, most of the features carried over from the older headset, but a few features changed for the worse.  The headset is paired with an HTC TouchPro 2.Pros:1. Pairing is easy and quick and I have had no issues with losing the pairing or having to reconfigure the bluetooth settings.  Very easy setup.2. Voice quality remains strong as in the previous model.3. I like the fact this is an over-the-ear headset.  I don't like sticking something in my ear.4. Voice commands work well and are very smooth.  Of course, there are times when my phone doesn't understand, but that could be background noise or just poor voice recognition on the phone's part.  For the most part, it seems to do better than the previous model.5.  Range is much better than the previous model and I get a audible signal when I get in or out of range, which is a nice feature.Cons:1. Button on the side of the headset has been moved too far back and is "softer."  It is probably just a matter of getting used to pushing further back than on the previous model, but I find that if you don't press it directly on the center of the button, it won't activate the commands, so I end up pressing it several times to get a response.2. Even though it is almost identical to the older H710 version, the ear clip doesn't fit on my ear as well.  The older version would wrap right around my ear and feel snug.  This one takes a bit more work to get it to feel like it is on firmly, otherwise, when I move my head quickly, I can feel it moving off my ear.  I may switch out the older ear clip.For the most part, the headset works well.  It provides all the basic features, which many headsets (and couldn't we say smartphones these days?) fail to do.  Voice quality is good, range is strong and provides solid voice commands.  I have tried 3 or 4 other headsets in the past few years and keep coming back to this line of Motorola headsets.
summary: Some Good Features, Falls Short on Others

Hello,I bought this pen almost six months ago, and I think it's due for a review. First off I want to say that I have used to many styluses. I have used the free ones that come with cases and ones that I have bought for few dollars and for tens of dollars. However, this is one stylus that I feel is well worth its value. For less than 10 dollars the price of a standard meal in the US, you can purchase a stylus that will work for quite some time. The stylus itself has a pointer inside the silver metal lining. This increases the accuracy of the pen placing it with the very best. I sometimes wonder how New Trent was able to pull off such an amazing stylus. Furthermore, this stylus comes with a pen. The pen is one aspect that could be improved, especially holding it upside down it's just not very ergonomic. I would have loved to have the G2 ink instead, as that one is much more flowy and the ink comes quicker. However for those quick notes it's perfect. Overall I really like this stylus. I have tested it with phones, tablets and even the new Chromebook Pixel. It works just as good if not better than the finger.I cannot however compare with the Wacom pens, as I have yet to experience one firsthand, so as it stands this is the best stylus that I have ever used. As such, this easily deserves my commendation and my buy rating. Thanks for reading and I wish you all the best.
summary: The One and Only Stylus Pen I Can Use

reviewText: Have an iPhone? want to keep it in one piece? BUY THIS!! As a trucker i find myself in rugged conditions every day. I have dropped my phone on asphalt, concrete, and metal surfaces. the case might get a scratch or a lil dirty... but that phone looks as shiny as it did the day i bought it!Convenient belt-clip makes for carrying it easy and nice. The added protection allows me to have piece-of-mind. And the added 'bulk' makes it easier to hold and use. I cannot say enough about this case. If you want to protect your phone... Invest in this case. Seriously.It does have 1 downfall however. the built in "screen protector" seems to get an 'oil slick' effect, or air bubble or two. this is due to a semi-adhesive texture on it from the mfg process. OtterBox recommends you use powder and compressed air to reduce or completely remove this problem (before putting it on your phone of course). Check out [...] for full instructions.I had to repeat this process about 5 or 6 times before i fixed the problem.... but remember this thing will keep your phone protected in even the toughest "everyday" hazards you will find.[...] has "success" stories, or as I call them "horror stories" one of which includes a guy whose phone got caught by the charging wire, outside the car, and was drug along, bouncing off the pavement, for 1 mi at 35mph and the phone it self was undamaged.THIS IS WORTH IT!
summary: Suit of Armor ... for the iPhone!

I've been using this charger for a few months now, having received one for review in November '13, and I like it more now than when I first got it, which is often not the case.Superficial things that initially put me off: the gigantic logo on the back (which other reviewers have noted); the fact that it looks like a cell phone, for no good (functional) reason that I can think of, but isn't (it could have the same form factor without the glossy black side that looks like a phone's screen); the "manual" has absolutely no information at all about the use or functioning of the device, just promotional text.Those were all irritants, but once I began using the charger, they faded into inconsequentiality.First, I love that the device comes with its own usb cable (a short one), since sometimes I don't want to carry one of my regular long cables with me. Second, the included cable is flat, which means that it's very easy to "spool" up and it doesn't tangle in your pocket, bag, briefcase, or wherever you keep it. Third, because it is about the same dimensions as a typical smart phone, it slips easily into a pocket in my purse or my computer bag -- you could even carry it easily in a jacket or jeans pocket. Fourth, and perhaps most important, when it is fully charged, it can charge my Samsung phone from 20% to 100% and still have a lot of charge left for other devices. I've even charged my Kindle eReader using it. It is slower than charging the Kindle from the wall, but it works.As well as being convenient for travel -- even for everyday outings and running errands -- it is handy to have in the event of a power outage. I also have a larger external battery charger, but although it works well, it isn't nearly as convenient, since it is much heavier and about 6 times larger. I have a smaller, more flimsy external charger that charged ONCE, giving my phone only an extra 10% before it ran out of juice, and which thereafter did not recharge.It does take a full 7 or 8 hours to charge this battery charger after it's been depleted, but given how much charge it holds and how many hours devices (such as a phone or portable bluetooth speakers) can run off of this battery once it is charged, I don't see this as a drawback. I simply charge it overnight. If you need to have one ready at all times, you could get two of them and alternate which one is being charged.I have to say that while I found the huge logo and the glassy "looks like a smartphone but isn't" appearance somewhat off-putting, this battery charger functions extremely well. If I were shopping for one of these, its looks would have put me off; since I was given a sample and tested it over months, I found its size, capacity, and functionality more than made up for the off-putting logo and the manual-that-wasn't-a-manual (after all, what kind of directions do you need in order to plug one end of the usb cable into the charger and the other end into the charging device or recharger?), but the case and manual do need a redesign.I'd recommend this charger to anyone who needs a handy, pocket-sized but sturdy, high capacity charger and doesn't want to spend an arm and a leg on one.

reviewText: $50 for this thing?! Check out the other reviews and you'll see that mine mirrors theirs. First, it took me five minutes to figure out how to open up the case. I tried prying it apart every which way, and then finally realized it was a simple matter of pushing up the latch on the right side to open it. There were no instructions either inside the package or on the box that gave details on this very simple function. Very poor!What instructions that were included showed how to mount the case on your bike handlebars. There was also information (in 11 different languages) on how to use the included foam strips so that the iPhone 4/4S wouldn't rattle around inside the case. Well, maybe so, but my iPhone 5 with a small bumper surrounding it would not fit inside. There is no way I'm going to take off the phone bumper every time I want to use this thing. A little green "flag" on the package states, "Easy to Use". Hardly!Like others, I was excited to get this product and use it with the Runtastic app. But the fact that my phone won't fit inside it renders it totally useless. As such, I cannot comment on how well it works on the road. Don't waste your time or money on this.

reviewText: This is a great case and another well made case by Otterbox. I use this case specifically for when I'm out snowboarding or if I'm traveling and I need a little extra mental insurance for my phone. I can definitely say this isn't an everyday kind of case as it is quite bulky and heavy too. If you work at a construction site or do a lot of manual labor then this is perfect however for the cubicle commandos out there, this is a bit overkill. Fortunately, I've already dropped my phone in this case even after only having the case for a few hours however, the case and, especially, the phone have held up perfectly. The included holster is nice and the case fits securely in there so no worries about it popping out or accidentally falling out; it actually clicks into place very firmly. If you're in need for a beefy case to protect your dandy new iPhone 4, look no further.

I was very skeptical about ordering items from Hong-Kong thinking it could be a replica.This Motorola bluetooth Stereo headphones came with a charger, extra earplug and mannual but without a box.Works perfectly with my smart phone blackberry bluetooth. I use it mostly for jogging and they fit me very confortable.  I did read some of the reviews that claim that does not fit large head and I can see why. It is not very flexible.The shipping was a little bit long, but it was understandable since it was from Hong Kong.  I did noticed that it was shipped the next day after ordering, because of the stamps, but it was held in U.S.Custom for over a week.The battery last for over 6 hours..I have 4 hours worth of music in my phone and I have listen to all of them and still have enough juice to jog and listen to it some more.I have not used the microphone to speak but I can get my e-mail and text signals while listening to music. It just pause a second and continues with the music.

reviewText: This case is nice and fits well. It has a bumper that sits around the phone and then the leather back slides on. The pocket is nice and can certainly hold a few credit cards etc. I'm happy with it and use it occassionally when i'm going out and don't want to carry an extra wallet.

I purchased this for a Galaxy Note 3 as a temporary solution until Otterbox releases a Defender case. Overall, it's a good deal for $20, but not on par with Otterbox's (OB) products. The fit and finish are nearly as good as OB, but the materials aren't as durable and the design of the holster is severely lacking.The case itself is pretty nice looking and fits well. The silicone is rather soft, meaning it picks up dust and lint like crazy, but it has a comfortable feel. The hard case portion also fits very well and combined, they protect the sides and back of the phone pretty well.The holster on the other hand, leaves much to be desired. The phone slides in from the top, causing the soft silicone to drag and rub on the holster. It takes two hands and quite a bit of effort to remove the phone from the holster without tearing the silicone skin in the process. Any call received when holstered will go to voicemail by the time I manage to get the phone out.Overall, for $20 it's not bad as a backup case or a purely pocket phone. Not a daily driver if you use the holster.

reviewText: When you attach this to an iPad 3 you get message not charging. It is in fact charging but at a very very slow rate. Took overnight to go from 46% to 100%. Also will not even maintain charge on iPad 3 when plugged in and in use. I was using the standard large block(10W)  that came with my iPad 3 and has been working perfectly. None the less I was concerned it was my iPad so I took all three pieces of equipment to an Apple Tech and he confirmed that the 30pin plug on this cable is NOT configured to do the fast rate charging for iPad 3. The extreme slowness is also not related to the fact the that cord is so long, it is definitely the pin configuration. Charges perfectly at fast speed using an Apple cable. Unfortunately Apple no longer makes a long cable. Apple told me when buying from a  non-Apple vendor always look for the "Manufactured For" attribute not 'Compatible With" . Techie told me you will often find the Manufactured For attribute on Griffin and Belkin products, but always check..

I have used XtremeGuard screen protectors for a long time and I only get them when they have deals. Which is very annoying. Comes with a nice case so the screen protector doesn't shatter in the mail.2. The cloth it comes with is very top quality.3. Extremely easy to apply the screen protector. I usually hate doing this but it was so easy and no dust or air pockets.4. CRYSTAL clear. This screen protector is amazing. Like it is not even there when using it.5. Anti-fingerprint. This glass screen protector does a really good job of reducing the amount of oil and finger print marks. My old glass screen protector was really durable but I had to always wipe it off BC it had so much oil on it. With this one I almost never have to do it. And when I do a few scrubs with a shirt work.
summary: best glass screen protector for the price ! love it

reviewText: The Spigen SGP10089 Slim Armor case for iPhone 5 is a great choice for those that love the slim lightweight iPhone 5 but want to add a little protection from day to day bumps and scratches. With an internal TPU shock absorbing wrap around all sides and back your iPhone 5 is safer from corner and edge drops. I have not done side by side testing, just an intuitive feeling based on the shape and the material which has some give and bounce to absorb shocks. The polycarbonate midsection adds stiffness which helps lock the case on and gives a solid feel to what otherwise could be a squishy slippery case. All parts of the case are fingerprint resistant and easy to clean.The TOP wraps around the front and offers just enough of a lip to provide a small air gap if the phone is laid on a flat surface face down to protect from screen scratches. If you are protecting your phone you should get a removable/replaceable screen protector sheet. I was disappointed even a cheap one wasn't included with this case.Volume buttons are the TPU material going through holes in the poly wrap and easy to press offering the same ease of use as no case at all.  Holes for mute, charge, headphones, camera/flash and speakers are all well proportioned so they don't interfere with operation and use of the phone. The mute is going to be a little harder to use, but not much.I have to say I don't understand the purpose of the included "Jelly Bean" home button stickers, but to each their own....  As I said I would have preferred a screen protector.
summary: Super Slim and lightweight while offering basic protection

reviewText: The Screen protector looks real good on My phone I really like it,But I screwed up the first 2 my fault I didn't take my time,the 3rd time was perfect no bubbles or dust.The packaging was good no complaints.I'm very happy with the service. reviewText: This is no imitation. I bought a knock off because it was $15 vs. $30 locally. The knock off died in a month. I saw this, at this price, and figured I had little to lose. Another reviewer (thanks Troy - crackberry_com) had mentioned that the Otterbox Commuter Case worked well with the Seidio Innocase Lock Holster for BlackBerry Bold 9700.  I can confirm these statements. It's almost as the Seidio Innocase Lock Holster for BlackBerry Bold 9700 was designed with the Otterbox Commuter Case in mind. It fits perfectly.With both the Otterbox Commuter Case and the Seidio Innocase Lock Holster for BlackBerry Bold 9700, I can access my mini-usb for charging, my headphone jack, volume rocker, my "special" buttons on the left and right and the lock and stand-by button at the top. Plus with the Otterbox Commuter Case, I can record video and takes pictures. The locking mech. works great with the case too. Nothing but good things to say about this combo.UPDATE:So, I've been using this setup now for like 2.5 months and it rocks.  I still stand behind my purchase and review.  I also read bad review for the screen protector not fitting right or not working right because of how the 9700's screen kinda drops at the sides but, I took my time and put it on and it looks great still, no air bubbles, nothing.  Maybe they updated their screen protector when I purchase MARCH 2010 who know.  But so far so good.  The Bold 9700 also has not disappointed and I'm loving that tether app.UPDATE:It now been 8 months as of 11/27/10 and can't complain.  Otterbox Case and Seidio Holster combo still working nicely together.  I've had no issue with either.UPDATE:It's now 01/30/2012 and heavy heavy usage.  The head phone jack plug and the charger plug are ripping on left and right side a bit.  I can still plug/close those ports though so it seems basically a cosmetic issue as oppose to a functional issues.  Again, heavy heavy usage.  Would I buy the case, would I buy this whole combo again, YES!

I received this product at no cost from the manufacturer in exchange for writing a review. I really like this. Here's why.1. I own lots of electronic gizmos--iPhone 4S, iPad 3, Kindle paperwhite, Garmin 405 CX GPS watch, Jabra Play bluetooth receiver, etc.--so power banks have become a travel necessity for me. Typically I plug the power bank into an AC outlet so it is charging at the same time it is charging my gizmos. The problem is that most of my power banks have only 2 or 3 USB ports, so I need to bring multiple power banks. No more now that I have this product.2. This has a whopping 5 USB ports. What's more, they cover the whole charging range--.5A, 1A (two), 1.3A, 2.1A. Yet this is a very slim and compact unit: 3 11/16" x 3 1/16" x 1 1/16". Plus it is attractive looking and has that "Apple look."Note: A common misconception is that you cannot safely charge a device that requires only say .85 amp (like my Kindle Paperwhite) from a USB output with greater amps. You could use a 2.1 amp output to charge a Kindle if you wanted to; the Kindle would use only what it needs. Conversely, you could charge an iPad from the 1 amp output, but it would take a lot longer than from the 2.1 because an iPad needs more power to charge.3. This charges with a micro USB cable. Included are 8" and 27" USB cables with adapter holes onto which you can put the included mini USB, micro USB, and Apple tips. A fourth "plug" tip is included for other kinds of gadgets.4. There is a power button and four indicator lights to show you the status of the battery charge. I like that these four lights are each no bigger than the end of a thick paper clip, so in a darkened room they don't give off much light and also are easy to cover because they are spaced out only a total of 1/2 ".Bottom line: This is a sleek and attractive way to charge lots of gadgets at once without the need for multiple battery packs. With its 12600mAh rating, I have no problem charging multiple products at once. However, in order to avoid draining this quickly, I keep it connected to an AC power source.Update: August 21, 2013: With some battery packs the ports are always "hot", i.e. once you turn the battery pack on the power on the port stays on at all times, whether or not any item is in the port or is finished charging. So if, for example, you plug your iPhone in at night to charge, it's the same as plugging it into the wall via a USB AC charger.Other battery packs, including this one, shut the power off to the port even if the battery pack is on if nothing is being charged, or if an item is done being charged. This serves to conserve the power of the battery pack. So if, for example, you plug your iPhone in at night to charge, the USB port will no longer be "hot" (i.e. provide power) once your phone is fully charged.In addition, just plugging an item into the port will not start it charging. To make the port "hot" you have to press the power button on this pack, even if (as I do) you leave the pack on all the time and have it plugged into an AC USB plug.I discovered this the first time that I plugged my Kindle Paperwhite in to charge, and came back a couple of hours later only to discover that no charging had occurred even though the battery pack was powered on. Lesson learned.
summary: One of my favorite power banks

The Lepow Moonstone Series, 6000mah is very compact and extremely light at The dimensions are 3.2 x 3.2 x .75This fits in the palm of your hand and is extremely portable. It has 2 charging ports, one for phones and one for tablets.The unit is very modern and cool looking, nothing like any of my other plain vanilla white chargers.The 6000 has many features.One of the best is that the charger starts and stops automatically. You have the option of an on/off switch however.The unit came in a very cool felt pouch (4.5" x4.5" when folded) that has two pockets, one for the charger and the other for the cord and whatever you can fit in there. ;-)Another nice surprise is the unit comes with a flat micro USB cable. This means less chances of tangling. The cable is 2 feet long.The box contained a bunch of little surprises in the box, including a cord keeper, a stylus, a USB thumb drive, home cover buttons, a suction cup to hold the unit, a cool pouch and lots more neat things.The pack can charge my IPhone 5s almost 2 times. The unit does not come with a lightening cable.This is the nicest battery charger I have ever seen.If my review helped you, please click on "Helpful" below. Thank you! :)

Recently I got the New Trent PowerPak Ultra: 14000mAh External Battery Charger(NT140R-B) for my Apple devices, I am tired of having devices loose battery power and not be able to do anything. My kids watch movies and play games all the time, and having the battery pack to charge the iPhone or iPad mini on the go (like their stroller) is awesome and reduces the stress of trying to get them to understand why they can't finish their movie (I have toddlers). Having the 2 charging ports is great, I don't have to pick the most important device first I can just do both at the same time.As a teacher, I can see this being helpful and useful for the classroom, having wires across the floor can be a safety issue not to mention the number of plugs needed for charging, New Trent PowerPak Ultra could sit between the desks or center of a table charging kids iPads used in the classroom, completely safe and effectively. I rate this product a 4, its simple to use, just charge the PowerPak and GO, its a 4 only because it is a little heavy to carry in your purse/bag, it does charge devices quick, 2 at a time, and waterproof and durable, the weight was my only issue for pointing out.

Undisclosed mystery charges made to credit card.  Device was dead on arrival. Wouldn't receive 3G or 4g signal of any discernible strength Foreign based tech support who couldn't answer simple questions. I live in the middle of a huge semi-urban coverage area for both types of networks.  Took two weeks (5 phone calls & 15 email exchanges) to get an RMA number for a product that wouldn't receive either a 3G or 4G signal out of the box on day one.  The kicker is that I signed up for their "premium" level of service and still had terrible service.  A customer only gets telephone technical support if you buy a premium or higher level service, but I've only been able to reach telephone support twice out of ten attempts over a period of two months.  No one answers the phone and there is no voice-mail option.  They finally sent me a new replacement device (after I paid shipping to return the failed one) which also diddn't work.  Since I couldn't get through using the "premium" telephone support I then tried email support.  It takes 3 days to get a response (at the earliest) and the tech support replies are maddeningly ineffective such as "turn the device off and then turn it back on; update the firmware; hit the reset button, etc." All of these were tried in the three day period waiting for a response to my email request for technical support.Burying notices of significant credit card charges four pages deep in a user agreement and hiding links to customer support deep in the bowels of a web-site are strong indicators of outright unscrupulous conduct towards consumers.  Hiding behind the slogan  "The Internet is a right, not a privilege" only makes their lame customer service more frustrating.Been buying electronics via the internet since 1997.  This is the worst experience I've encountered. The team at Freedompop.com win the prize for incompetence in dealing with both customer and technical support.2-24-14 Update:  Three months after buying this, the technical problems remain unresolved through FreedomPop support.  They were supposed to send out a different model three weeks ago, but I haven't seen it in the mail.  I'm guessing tech support dropped the ball again.  I've decided to give up on this and try the Karma 4G wireless hotspot as an alternative.  If it's too good to be true, it usually is.
summary: Don't know why tech sites are helping this scam by publishing fake stories

reviewText: The Kraken case is ridiculously huge. The slim RAZR MAXX practically triples in thickness & weight by adding the Kraken case.TheTrident Case AG-XT912-BK AEGIS Case for Motorola Droid Razr MAXX (XT912) - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Blackcase is more reasonably sized. It hugs the phone with the silicone case and a substantial ABS Plastic "skeleton." The grip on the Aegis is pretty good. I have big hands and it fits fine, the Kraken is a different story. With all that ABS on the outside, the Kraken case is an accident waiting to happen; it is just too slippery.I like the kickstand on the Kracken but theSeidio CSK3MTRMK-BK ACTIVE with Metal Kickstand for Motorola Droid RAZR MAXX - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Blackfeatures a nice kickstand in a smaller, easier to handle case.I do like the color choices offered in the Trident line of cases. Easy to see the bright color when you are looking for your phone when you can't remembver where you left it.I will give the Seidio case a try too, again - I like the color choices and they seem lighter and not as bulky.I will also try theTrident Case AG-XT912-BL AEGIS Case for Motorola Droid Razr MAXX (XT912) - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Blue. I have this case for another phone, after I saw how big the Kraken was, I went with it and I really like it.As for grip, nothing is as grippy as theDiztronic Matte Back Smoke Flexible TPU Case for Motorola Droid Razr Maxx [ONLY FOR MAXX VERSION] (Verizon & Rogers) [Diztronic Retail Packaging] but I don't think the TPU case will protect as well as the double layer cases. TPU cases will do a good job with cosmetic protection, they are the lightest and thinnest, but they offer no "shock absorbtion."Trident cases come with screen protectors, which is a really nice feature.If you go with something else, try out theFosmon Crystal Clear Screen Protector Shield for Motorola Droid Razr (XT910) / Droid Razr MAXX (XT912) - 3 Pack. They work very well and they are inexpensive. Clear & distortion free.

The Note is the newest in Samsung's Galaxy series. Chances are, if you're looking at this review, you've already checked out this product line, so I'm not going to get too specific about the specs...you know it's got a nice processing speed, a great screen, a good amount of onboard memory (16GB's), and the Android operating system (2.3 at the moment, but hopefully an upgrade to 4.0 comes soon). I will, however, talk about the two things that sets it apart from the other phones on the market right now - it's size and the S-Pen stylus.The screen is humungous...the 5.3" screen is beautiful, but could be a detriment to some. It's thin, so I could easily drop it into my work pants, but jeans...that's another story. The size is great for viewing email, watching movies, or texting, but is a hassle to use as a phone and walk around with.The S-Pen works pretty well. It's a magnet based stylus technology that allows you to take screenshots and mark them up, process signatures, draw on pictures, etc. I wouldn't use it, but I could see why people would like this. The pen is small though, and could seem uncomfortable for normal use. It easily slides into the phone for storage.Bottom line, if you're going to use the S-Pen and don't mind a giant phone, pick this one up. The screen is gorgeous and the performance is nice and fast.
summary: Gigantic...but is that good or bad?

reviewText: I wanted a case that didn't detract or bulk up my new iPhone 4, and this case, one of the freebies Apple offered to iPhone users with reception problems, is simply perfect for my needs. I had purchased a temporary case, Premium Soft Silicone Gel Skin, that served the purpose well, but this case is much, much better. It has a hard, slightly recessed back that hugs the camera lens and soft, comfortable silicone sides to aid your grip. The back edges have a silicone lips to keep the phone from sliding off a surface. The case is held in place by the silicone lip, so any tears might compromise it; however, the edges fit so perfectly that they don't easily pull away, something my temporary case did. Although the silicone areas make certain parts tacky, I have no problem pulling it in and out of my pocket.Except for the silicone lip, the entire front is unprotected, and except for the camera cut-out, the entire back is covered. The lock/power switch is covered by a raised nub, which allows you to use the button without its being uncovered. Even better, the mute button is easy to reach and use, something that has always been a potential problem with iPhone cases.As of this writing, the price makes this case a great deal for any iPhone owner, even if you're reading this after Apple has fixed the infamous "death grip" issue. Early cases were expensive and untested; this one is both relatively inexpensive and solid, a good choice for those who want a low-profile case.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Love it! (One of the free case options for early iPhone 4 adopters)

reviewText: Raise your had if you have gotten up in the morning when your alarm went off and picked up your phone only to have it fall from your hands as you forgot you had it plugged into the charging cord and it was too short to reach over to your pillow. This product solves that problem by giving you a base right at your bedside where you can drop your phone to charge and pick it up when done. It also includes an extra battery which can be charged on the base and taken with you to charge your phones on the go (any micro USB or Apple connector phones).This is a much better design than the Duracell product from 2 years ago which had an ugly metal strip charging base and a bulky iPhone case. With a partnership with Powermat Duracell has come up with a sleeker design of the case and the charging base mat. They also added an extra battery which can charge iPhone on the go.The case is much sleeker and lower profile than before so it's actually usable this time round, however, like with many similar devices the Apple connector is inside of the case and the external connector is a micro USB. A special syncing cord is included to connect it to your computer for synchronization with iTunes. However, this adapter case makes it impossible to use your iPhone on music docks, on other charging docks that use the Apple connector. So you may have to constantly take it out of it's case if you use those devices. Also the case is a bit slippery, and not the prettiest case around but you have to live with it if you want to go wireless when charging.One other thing I found was that the case needs to be aligned correctly with the base to charge properly although it tells you with a chirp when it is correctly placed and then charged and lifted off. But if you're doing it in the dark as I often do you may not place it correctly and the phone will not charge.The on-the-go battery is a smart idea as not everyone may want to use the case, but may just want to use the on the go battery. However, if you just want an on-the-go battery there are cheaper products available that charge with a wall charger or even your computer. So at this price point unless you're using the iPhone case you may not be able to justify the cost of this system.It all depends on how you use your iPhone. In our home, we have several iPhones 4/4Ses, so this is a useful system for us simply because Apple power cords have a way of disappearing but the powermat stays in its place. However, like some other reviewers mentioned these products will be truly useful when Apple launches devices with integrated inductive charge batteries, so there is no need for an additional case.My Overall Rating = 3/5Design -> Powermat and Battery = 4/5, iPhone case =3/5Build quality given current competitive products -> 4/5Convenience -> Powermat and Battery = 4/5, iPhone charging with case = 2/5Charging time -> Approx. 2 hours with on-the-go battery, or a little less with the case and powermat = 5/5Price -> Given that it is not super-convenient to use the case and you may just go with the on-the-go battery = 3/5
summary: Sleeker, better than earlier versions, but still not as useful unless you use iPhone case.

I have had 20+ bluetooth headsets.  I know lots of people write this in their review, but it's really true for me.  I started back when the first BT headsets came out.  First one I owned was a Sony Ericsson BT headset back in 2001 and I've gone through some great ones and horrible ones.  Best I ever had was the Plantronics 510 except for looking like a borg from star trek.  More recently I had the Blueant Q1 and settled there because I had spent so much on BT headsets.  After awhile I gave up on BT headsets completely and went back to a wired headset (Palm Pre headset).Well, I own a Motorola Photon 4G (sprint) phone and my headset jack just went out on me and I didn't want to bring it to the Sprint store so I bought this little nifty device (Samsung HS3000) not thinking it would really help me.  I need to use a headset at the gym for music and I'd like to have a good headset for talking on the phone in the car.  May I say, this item does NOT disappoint!  It is a really awesome device, probably one of the only BT headsets I've ever loved using.  Why is that?Things I love about it:*  It's sleek and clips on really well*  It pairs easily and stays connected whether you are listening to music or on the phone.  Nothing worse that when a BT headset loses connection.*  The mic is really good quality.  Let me emphasize that it is HARD to find a BT device with a good mic.  This is quality!  I had this little guy clipped onto my belt (MY BELT PEOPLE) and my friend heard me fine on the phone.  I've also tried recording myself to see how the mic sounds near my chest, at my hip, farther away to see how it was.  There are differences (quieter as it gets farther), but it's clear and you can still hear me.  Great noise cancellation.  I'm impressed!*  So cool to have the ability to talk and listen in stereo when on the phone*  Volume is great even with one earphone in my ear when I'm driving.  This is what really bugged me about other BT headsets - they aren't always loud enough when you need them to be.*  I can use this for skype, google hangout, audacity, etc.  Very cool!*  Sound is good for listening to music.  I'm not an audiophile but it fits the bill for listening to music at the gym.*  you can plug in any 3.5mm device - can you say wireless music to any speaker system?*  Loved the voice feedback for when it turns on, connects, and turns off.Things I don't like:*  The supplied earphones not so great, but eh, no biggie - we didn't buy this for the earphones, we bought it for the device transmitter.*  music buttons are a bit smallAnd that's it!  I'm really surprised I love it so much for what it is. I thought to myself "Why would anyone need a bluetooth device that is semi-wired?  That's not wireless!"  But I have to say, I really really do like it.  Get one, you won't regret it.
summary: Wow!  And I mean wow!  You need to read my review.

reviewText: So, a few weeks ago I received one of these chargers from Maxboost as a free sample so that I could test and then review.  I have tried more than two dozen different car chargers, and each one of them has failed within a few weeks.  This charger actually still works, and works very well.  Some of the aspects that I really like are as follows: it lights up so you can see the ports - great for people like me who work nights or those who have to travel at night, multiple ports for multiple devices - great for couples or multiple people in the vehicle, small - uses very little space and does not interfere with anything in your vehicle, and the actual plug is long enough to make contact with deep-well power sockets - both my past truck and my new car have deep-well power sockets that most chargers cannot contact.  My car has a USB port, but it only really works properly with Apple products.  I am an Android user, I do not care for Apple.  That presents a problem for charging on the go.  With this charger I can easily, and quickly, charge my phone and tablet.  I actually expected this device to be a "dud," but I have been (and still am) pleasantly surprised.  I would highly recommend this product to anyone who needs a car charger.
