I've used a lot of power banks recently, from brands like Duracell and EasyAcc.  They all get the job done at various price points, but none of the designs really stand out... until now.The PBS Smart 5000mAh External Battery Pack Portable Power Bank Charger is unique in that it comes with a USB 2.0 to micro USB cable that conveniently fits on the edges of the battery (blue color in the photo).  The cable is thick, and stays securely in place as it connects to two ports on the top of the bank charger perfectly. (You must put the USB end in first to get the right fit.) The same two ports can be used to charge devices, or the bank charger.  Very smart design!The literature that ships with the battery pack indicates it can be charged via AC adapter.  The box I received did not have an included AC adapter, but the charger did ship with an attractive carrying pouch.  I'm sure I could use something like this: Zeimax (TM) Home Travel Wall AC Charger USB White for iPhone 5 iPad Mini iPod Touch 5th Gen to get the job done, if no USB port was handy on a charger or PC.My first attempt to charge this device was in one of my desktop PC's front USB 2.0 ports.  I couldn't get this to work as the USB/cable connection on the PBS's included cord was too big to fit.Eventually I did manage to get it to work on a charger I have with several USB ports that are widely spaced, but this may be an issue for others when using the included USB cable in tight spaces.  It charged itself very quickly and did the same for my iPod touch 5th *using a not-included lightning cable adapter and my iPhone 4S using the included 30-pin adapter and USB to micro USB cable.In addition to the included cable's cool fit, there's a hidden compartment on the battery that houses a 30-pin to micro USB connector. I'm not sure why the company didn't just put a 30-pin connector on the battery?  While this is a neat feature, the small adapter could get lost or fall out (seems secure now...), and then what?  As it stands, this adapter allows you to connect the included cable's USB end to the charger, then the micro USB end of the cable to the adapter and finally the 30-pin into an iPod or iPad with the 30-pin connection.A suggestion to PBS: It would be great to see a lightning connection adapter and/or port added to subsequent power banks, as that is Apple's new standard.The predicted life of this battery is equal to or less than 500 recharges.  The company has a Return/Exchange policy that's included with the User's Guide. They stand by their product and I applaud that, but I did have to laugh when I read: "...Items must be returned with all original packaging and in new condition".  What's the likelihood of that if the battery dies after a few uses and you've hauled it around in your school bag for a couple weeks?Overall, I really like this bank charger for it's innovative cable retaining design - one I've never seen before. While the inclusion of a 30-pin connector in the design is unique, the adapter could fall out or get lost, so it would be great to see future versions of this product with both 30-pin and lightning ports on the device instead of an adapter.I recommend this product to anyone looking for a compact, powerful, great looking portable power bank charger with features that are bound to spur other companies to step up their game.I give it 4 out of 5 stars ("I like it") because of the issues I had with a large USB/cable connection being unable to fit into a USB port on my PC, and the 30-pin adapter (while a smart design...) potentially getting lost or over time falling out of its compartment.NOTE: I was contacted by the maker of this portable power bank and asked to do an unbiased review for Amazon, in exchange for a sample product.
summary: Innovative design makes it a winner

reviewText: I bought the Anker as a replacement for a New Trent battery that had failed. The initial quality on the Anker is a bit better than the New Trent - the cables fit into the charging ports very snugly. The charging port is what failed on my New Trent so I'm very sensitive to that. The Anker also comes with an 18-month warranty, which is a big bonus over the New Trent. If you're comparing products from the two companies (Anker and New Trent) there really is no comparison - Anker actually has customer service and New Trent does not. I tried to contact them about the charging issue and they were nowhere to be found.I'll come back and update this review after I've had more time with the battery but my initial experience is very positive. It's a little bit bigger than my cellphone (Razr Maxx) but has the same form factor so it actually fits in my pocket with my phone, for charging in a pinch. The 10,000mAh capacity means I can recharge my phone at least three times without having to recharge the Anker. For anyone who travels and likes to use their phone or tablet on the plane, don't even think twice about it - buy it. For $30 you can have enough battery life to get your device from coast to coast with non-stop use.You can charge two devices at the same time (although you can't actually charge a device with it while the Astro3E itself is being charged). The only downside to it is that you'll need your own USB power plug with at least 1.5A of electricity to charge the unit since it doesn't come with its own plug. Or you could plug it into your computer's USB port to charge it. Although you'll need to be patient. Due to it's size it could take up to 10 hours to fully charge it.

First day I had issues because the touch sensitive volume bar would constantly detect touch against my skin even through clothing. This meant constantly the thing's volume was going up and down unless it was pinned to a work shirt's front pocket facing outwards (two layers of cloth seemed to prevent accidental input.The location of the rewind/play/stop/fastforward buttons, their size and shape made it very hard to click the right one without actually looking at the device. I think I skipped a song or podcast more almost every single time I wanted to just pause (VERY annoying with podcasts or while in the middle of a cool song in Pandora.)I would had still rated the thing 3 stars if it was not because about 3 weeks ago the thing broke down. I don't know if its no longer charging, or if the power button broke, just that it does not power on anymore (I have many charges to test with, none work, and all were working for my multiple android devices and tablets.) It barely worked for 2 months before just dying on me.Seriously recommend you look elsewhere.

I've ordered two batches of these batteries with mixed results.1) Seller1ON1 sent me the wrong battery at first (completely different battery)... but then corrected the error and sent me the correct batteries: EB-L1A2GBA with the words Near Field Communication on it.2) Beast Deals aka Communicative Trends LLC whose orders were "Fulfilled by Amazon" (whatever that means as far as products) sent me EB-F1A2GBU batteries instead. These are batteries for the European SGS2 and although they provide the same voltage and capacity as well as actually WORKING in the phone, they do not have the words Near Field Communication on them. From what I understand Samsung placed the NFC antenna inside the AT&T; SGS2 batteries. I had to assume the EB-F1A2GBU batteries would not support NFC.From the battery tests and user reviews I've read on various web sites: OEM batteries are the best and are likely to be closest to the rated capacity. I've tried a non-Samsung batteries for my AT&T; SGS2 and although they claim to be of higher capacity, they do not meet or exceed the capacity of the OEM ones.
summary: These are the best batteries for your i777 SGS2... if you get them

reviewText: I have always used the long iPhone / iPod cables. I would nott buy the short ones. Long lets you use them while charging.

If you are a somewhat frequent phone dropper, or your work necessitates your phone be well protected, I can't imagine a much better case than the Commuter.  It offers a nice balance between not being obscenely big, while at the same time, it's two part construction offers great protection.The inner silicone wraps around the phone first.  Its function is twofold: first, because it's what is in immediate contact with your phone, it's nice that it's soft, protecting from scuffs and scratches.  Secondly, when the case is completely assembled, it offers a fair degree of "shock-absorption" for falls from reasonable heights.  There are nicely fitted high quality rubber plugs for the USB and headphone jacks.  Button overlays for the power and volume rocker are easy to depress, and have a nice tactile "click" to them when everything is all assembled.The outer shell is a hard plastic which is mostly smooth, but does have a very subtle texture on the back.  Overall, it has a very nice feel to it.  It requires a bit of gentle maneuvering to get it to fit correctly over the silicone inner piece, but once on, everything fits nice and snugly.  Very nice fit and finish.  The cutouts are all very precise.  This is a very high-quality case.The main drawback is that there is a fair amount of bulk added to the phone with this case, making it difficult for me to carry in all situations.  Getting the phone in and out of dress pants or jeans pockets when it's in this case can be somewhat challenging.  Also, as others have mentioned, the inner silicone layer is a lint and dust magnet.  After having this case on my phone 24-7 for about a month, I ended up switching for a lower profile case which was more suited to my every day use.  I still turn to the Otterbox in certain situations, as the protection it provides is certainly second to none.A final word about the extended battery:The case will not fit correctly with the extended battery in the phone.  To me, having the extended battery was a must, so I looked into how I could have the best of both worlds.  There are a couple of ways around this.  1) You could put the phone in the case without the battery cover on, or 2) you could modify the standard battery cover so that it can accomodate the extended battery using a dremel tool (several guides on the internet if you Google it).  I opted for option #2, and with some careful dremeling, I was able to use the extended battery with the standard battery cover, and the phone perfectly fit in the Otterbox Commuter.
summary: Nice balance of aesthetics and protection

reviewText: The case is a little rubbery, but with the separate cut outs instead of one long cut out it feels like it will hold up better.

reviewText: Ever hear of a company called Tridea??? Well they have some very nice looking cases that are supposedly made from some high grade material but in reality are made from cardboard covered in faux italian leather. I own a few of Tridea wallet cases and they do not fair well over time (2 months). The faux leather begins to peel, color changes and the wallet/card slots are loosen to the point of not being able to hold cards firmly anymore.But wait this is supposed to be a review of CellTo so why am I talking about Tridea? Reason is because of the price. You may find Tridea cases priced from $20-$60+ while CellTo sales for $8 including shipping.  Also both cases do and advertise similar features.CellTo has what I think is same material used with  Tridea cases, looks appealing to the eye, and overall has a nice grip feel thanks to the ribbed design.There are two magnets, one in the front to cover the screen and one in the back so that the cover does not flap around when talking on the phone.The inside TPU bumper holder looks and fits very nicely. My samsung note 3 looks great in it and its very easy to remove if need to.The card slots need to stretch to break in so be a bit patient also maintain 1 or 2 card (preferably 1) so that bulging does not occur in the front. Try not to keep too many bills either because bulging will result.The magnets will interfere with the compass on your phone (its a magnet) but GPS works fine.Some people say that the S pen does not work where the magnets are located but it worked fine for meIts a pain to remove the S pen due to the deep groove but it just takes getting used to.The included screen protector actually surprised me and feels like a Spigen protector. It was slightly harder to install than Spigen but I got it to fit just right without bubbles.I modified my note 3 back plate with an Qi wireless charging receiver so that I may use my TLYT wireless charger and I was happy to learn that the phone charges with the case on.The case is not made of high quality and I do not expect it to last me too long (so far its doing great) but for the price you pay, it's hard to pass up. Oh and it does add a bit of thickness but all wallet cases do so just make sure this is the style case you want.If you want to see some pictures then please head over to xda forums and go to the follwoing thread:Samsung Galaxy Note 3 > Note 3 Accessories > What Cases are you waiting for?Page 12 post #112I would include a link but it is not allowed so I apologize for the hassle
summary: Great price and the phone looks great with the case

reviewText: Cons:- install could be smoother. I was unable to install this without several bubbles, despite a lot of patient re-pealing and squeegee-ing when I noticed them forming. That said, you really can't see the bubbles when the phone screen is lit, so not too big of a deal. It just looks a bit unprofessional when the phone is off...Pros:- cheap, and you get 3 (you'll have extras to practice with)- matte finish didn't appreciably degrade phone resolution (I've used other matte protectors and disliked their blurring effective on screen resolution)- durability seems good (it hasn't pealed anywhere after a few weeks of daily use)All in all, I'm happy given what I paid. Just know there are probably better (but more expensive) options out there.  If you're in the market for a decent matte finish protector and not too finicky about a few bubbles, though, I'd surely give this a try.  (And if you know a trick to applying this particular product without bubbles, do let me know!)
summary: Product is fine given its price, but I've seen better in general

reviewText: I have tried dozens of styluses (styli?) and the mesh tip is by far the best. So far it has held up to a lot of use and it writes smoothly. I have tried rubber tips and I find they drag which makes writing hard. They also eventually tear and then you need to buy a new pen. I also have tried the expensive ones with the plastic round tip thingy. The main issue with those is that they click when you touch the screen. You think it won't bother you, but it is really annoying. These are quiet and smooth. The construction on these is a little poor. Sometimes they get stuck in place and other times you find the mesh doesn't protrude far enough. You can yank and pull on them into the right place, but it does take a little fiddling.
summary: These are almost perfect, but still the best I have used

Pros:This set has better noise isolation than Jabra Sport. With several different ear gel sizes included, there should be one that fits your ears well enough. In a noisy environment, such as a gym, you won't have to blast up the volume as you would have to with the Sport. It won't shut out everything, but it's much better than the Jabra in this regard.Note, though, that the lowest volume when using it for phone calls with the iPhone 4 is still pretty loud. Not sure whose fault that is.Good sound across all ranges, with decent bass. Tried it with iPhone, iPad. Unfortunately with Garageband you can't do recording in real time, due to the Bluetooth lag, but playback is fine.Seems sufficiently workout-proof. The hydrophobic mesh seems to be holding out. We'll see ...Pairing is easy - it prompts for pairing each time it's powered on. Voice prompts for pairing, power on/off, etc.Mic for phone calls and voice control (if your phone has it); pretty good voice quality.Cons:The Power button is kind of a strange little nub. To press it, you'll have to get leverage against the other side of the battery thingy that goes behind your ear.The battery, etc. thingy that goes behind your ear is largish, and the connecting wire is kind of stiff and (when worn with eyeglasses, at least) seems to be a factor in making the earbuds less secure. I think it rubs on the neck or collar and slowly unseats the earbuds.The stem near where the eargels go into your ear are kind of big, so it's hard to get them into your ear further to block more sound.The case is a weird, flat thing with a strip of velcro in the middle, so it's kind of open on the sides.Misc:Battery life is 6 hours or more, depending on usage and volume.Uses multi-function button - one press for play/pause/answer call, two for next track, three for previous track, etc. Whether this is a pro or con depends on how much you want separate controls for these. Due to the size of these things, the multi-function button seems like a good tradeoff.UPDATE: After using these for a while, my chief complaint is the rather large earbuds, which cause my ear canal to ache after a bit. Another thing is the tendency of the cord to unseat the earbuds. I've changed the rating to 3 stars from 4.

After my wife got a shiny new car last year with Bluetooth, I found myself longing to ride in her car more and more often just so that I would have the convenience of hands free cell phone usage!  I had a Jabra JX10 Bluetooth earpiece from years back but found that it was not loud enough to compete with the enhanced exhaust and 13"-wide rear tires of my sports car.  Having been pleased with Jabra in the past, I naturally looked at their offerings first and decided upon the very reasonably priced SP200.The unit was as easy to pair with my phone (a Palm Pre) as any other Bluetooth headset and the volume is so loud that I can hear everyone just fine even if I'm roaring down the highway.  The noise canceling works so well that people often don't know I'm on Bluetooth and they never know that I'm in my loud sports car.  It's that good.A single charge lasts me several weeks (I don't talk that often while driving) and when it does get low, the handy LED reminder triggers me to drag it into my office with me and I simply attach it to the USB port on my computer (cable included) and let it charge for a couple of hours and I'm good to go again.Things I like about this headset:1) just tap the button and it wakes up from sleep mode and locks onto my phone2) have it paired with my wife's phone too (it can remember multiple phones)3) I don't have to turn it off- it magically goes to sleep after I've been away from the vehicle for awhile (15 minutes?)4) again, volume is ridiculously loud if you want it to be5) excellent clarity of my voice and their voice6) fairly stealthy up on the sunvisor- you forget it's there7) it's portable: sometimes I bring it in the house for conference calls8) crazy cheap for this level of qualityThings I don't like:1) I wish I didn't have to push anything to turn it on/wake it up.  Though I'm sure such a feature would be murderous on battery life.2) voice dial like my wife's car has would be awesome.  I think if I had a better phone, it could maybe use the phone's voice dial capability.  Sadly, I bought the godawful Palm Pre (never again).
It's dirty but nice

I need a portable charger for my Samsung Galaxy S3 and various Android tablets. Previously I have had good results with two other Poweradd products I purchased, so I decided to try thisPoweradd LE011 5200mAh Power Bank with LED Flashlight.There are many cheaply-built power bank units with poor output regulation and inflated battery capacity ratings. That's why I conducted a test to measure the true capacity of this Poweradd unit.First, I made sure that the internal battery pack was fully discharged and recharged for several cycles. Next, I connected a 5-ohm power resistor as load to the USB port, and measured its output voltage and current over time. Here is what I have observed:- For the first one hour, the unit generated a very well-regulated 5.02V at 0.96A, or 4.8W of output power- After 70 minutes, however, the output voltage (hence power) starts to drop linearly with time. It dropped from 5V down to 4.75V over the next 100 minutes- Right after 172 minutes, the power cut off completely.(see the chart I uploaded to 'Customer Image' section for details)Based on the above data, I can estimate the internal battery capacity through energy calculation:- Average output power = 4.7W- Runtime = 172 minutes- Total output energy = 4.7*172/60=13.47Wh- Assuming conversion efficiency of 80%, input energy required = 18.84Wh- At 3.7V, the internal battery's capacity = 18.84/3.7 = 4.55AhTherefore my measured battery capacity is 4550mAh, or 88% of the advertised capacity. To put this capacity number in perspective: it is enough to recharge the 2100mAh battery in my Samsung Galaxy S3 for 1.5 times (since part of the energy is lost during conversions). By the way, my other two Poweradd products also show slight discrepancy between their measured and rated capacities:- ThePoweradd 2600mAh Ultra Slim Power Bank with Mini USB flashlighthas a measured capacity of 2490mAh, or 96% of rated value.- ThePoweradd 5000mAh Dual-Port External Backup Battery Packhas a measured capacity of 4380mAh, or 88% of rated value.The battery status indicator is very good. It uses 4 LED 'dots' to give a fairly accurate indication on the remaining battery capacity. Based on my observation:- 4 dots = 77-100% (approximately)- 3 dots = 57-76%- 2 dots = 39-56%- 1 dot  = 21-38%- 1 blinking dot = below 20%The LED flashlight, on the other hand, is very disappointing. The light is so dim that it is weaker than any of my keychain LED flashlights. In fact, the blue status indicator from the other 5000mAh Poweradd unit is about equally bright.Overall, I consider this Poweradd unit a good value (4-star). I would give it a 5 if the LED flashlight were a little more powerful.[Update on Oct 28, 2013]I tested thePowerBot PB5600 5600mAh Power Bankwhich is currently available at the same price. The PowerBot unit offers 10% higher capacity and a more usefull LED flashlight. The Poweradd unit still has the advantage of being more compact.
summary: Adequate output regulation and battery capacity / Wimpy LED flashlight

reviewText: Update: Dec. 22, 2012Since I wrote this review, two (2) new stereo bluetooth headsets have hit the market: one by Jaybird ("Bluebuds X") and the Motorola ("S11 Flex HD").  An acquaintance bought the Bluebuds X, not wanting to wait for it to be sold on Amazon and was floored by the results.  I have the Motorola S11 and can tell you, it is better than these Jaybird Freedom Sprint.  TheMotorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Whitehas 5.5 hours of battery life, the comfort and the sound is impressive.  That's not to say that "Freedom Sprint" is not good, it is.  It's just that the battery life is VERY poor and the knobs are very small and delicate, but audio-wise, it's top-notch.I also need to mention that the Jabra Sport which I heralded for it's battery life is, most recently, not holding up a charge as it first did 18-months ago.  The ethical question I pose to myself with regard to the Jabra's is this:  Do I say that if you're considering buying the Jabra Sport that it only get about 3 hours before needing recharging (after having it 1.5 years) or do I leave the original comment that when new, the battery life is about 3.75 hours?So, concerning the Jabra's in regards to the newer models, if you buy them, the battery charge will decrease noticeably after about 1 year.Original review follows below:***  ***The Jaybird brand came highly recommended to me last year and after having them a few weeks, I know exactly why they're loved.  But, with a couple of minor and annoying issues, this is one terrific device.From a practical standpoint, there's really no good reason to keep spending money on inexpensive to moderately priced ($15- $65), wired headphones with the majority of bluetooth headsets approaching 4 hours of use time and the new Motorola ("S11 Flex HD") well over 5 hours.*** Design ***The Jaybird is a compact left and right headset with an enclosed microphone.On the right earpiece, you'll find the volume control/ track advance and mute button combo and on the opposite side is the micro usb to usb plug.  On top is a slightly raised and nearly invisible power button, which also serves to activate the Bluetooth pairing receiver.This is my greatest concern.Because it is compact and slimmer than the previous model, all of the functions are crammed into a smaller space.  After I had trouble connecting the device to my desktop, I called customer service in Salt Lake City for assistance.Having the power button only slight raised above the unit (not to mention, it takes holding down this button for 7 seconds before it's activated) means that this button will eventually - and long before its life expectancy--wear out.  If you need to pair a device, you're forced to turn off the device (another 7 seconds) then depress the same button again for 10 seconds: five gives you ten, the wear and tear of daily use will probably make you replace this, otherwise, stellar device within 1 year.Why not have separate and raised buttons placed on the left earpiece?  From an engineering standpoint, you can only reduce the size so much.*** Sound ***Fabulous.  Simply great.  Call reception was very good and that's considering that they were worn outside of a nippy and windy South Florida night, just days after Hurricane Sandy swept through.  And, the Jaybird's don't have a noise-cancelling mechanism built in.Streaming music from Amazon or iTunes or playing songs housed on my phone's SD card sounded crisp and full.  They were on par, sonically, with the garrulously-priced Sony ("XBA-BT75") and significantly better, in comfort, than theMotorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Blackand theJabra SPORT Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Black/Yellow.*** Comfort ***The Jaybird offers you two (2) different ways to attach the earphones.  One is the standard earhooks.  Earhooks are a hit or miss proposition.  On some brands you don't know they're on; on others, your ears are throbbing within minutes.With the Jaybirds, they hook on to my small ears very nicely and they're definitely not intrusive.The second option is the ear wedge.  A cute design that is popular with Bose products.  The issue with the wedges is that they don't fit everyone (even with a selection of S-M-L) equally well.  Jaybird found the sweetspot with their design.I could use either comfortably, but I like the safety of the earhooks.Compared to the Sony's--The Jaybird's are much softer and fit snugly.The Sony's designSony XBA-BT75 - Balanced Armature Bluetooth Headsetis horrendous to hold: they're hard and intrusive to the ear canal.Compared to the Motorola, the Jaybird is just as snug.  The Motorola hugs the entire ear and simultaneously blocks out a lot of extraneous noises.  I'd give the Motorola a slight edge in comfort and safety.The Jabra is the lightest to carry in the ear canal and they're also comfortable.  But, the Jabra's work their way out of the ear after about 30 minutes and you're constantly re-adjusting thereafter.  Advantage: Jaybird.*** Battery life ***Charging time for the Jaybirds are two hours long.  Two hours.  It was one hour and fifteen minutes to charge the headphones out of the package and two hours subsequently.The tech support from Jaybird offered this explanation:  The Jaybird headsets use a stronger battery which takes longer on average to charge but they also last about a year longer than those found in the headsets of their competitors.I asked if it were practical to expect a customer to wait for 75- 90 minutes until their headsets were re-charged after about 3 hours of actual audio use?So you're essentially giving up longer use time and a longer re-charge time than the Sony's, Motorola's and Jabra's.  So, of the four wireless Bluetooth sets, this is the order of best battery life: Jabra's, Motorola's, Sony and Jaybird.  Advantage: Jabra.*** Price ***The Jaybird's are a new model and the $125 is typically the high end of what you'd pay for a decent headset, wireless or otherwise.  They're worth having even at this retail price, but it becomes a Must-Buy during the holiday sale season.It offers the best of the other wireless, Bluetooth headsets and it is less than half of what Sony demands for their set and you have a much better sound than the Sony's and in terms of call quality, comfort they're equal to the Motorolo's and the Jabra's.  So, even though the Jaybird's are roughly the same price as Motorola and about $50 more than the Jabra's, in terms of overall quality, the Jaybird's can't be beat.Pro's+ Sound reproduction is excellent.+ Call reception, very good considering no noise-isolating feature+ Comfortable and you have a choice of two different holders.+ Price vs. Quality--Very good buy.Con's- Battery life and charge time is deficient when compared to the competition.- Power button and Bluetooth access is cumbersome and should be re-designed.Overall, this is a very good quality device that allows to listen to music, have conversations, watch a Bluetooth-enabled device like Netflix without the burdens of a chord.  But, the battery life and design makes it an annoying oversight.So, better than 4 stars but not quite 5.  Since, Amazon doesn't allow for half stars, I have to choose between 4 and 5--the issue of design (which I have no doubt will result in early replacements and the weak battery life can't be overlooked.4 stars.
summary: The Battle of the Big Dogs!  Jaybird vs. Sony, Motorola and Jabra!  A Critical Review.

reviewText: Bought for wife for her new phone. It charges the phone in car. It works and that's about it. It is what it is. LOL
I have had a few Iphone cases and this is my favorite.  Price is good and looks great on my on my phone  Mine has not yellowed like others have stated.

It came fast but when I opened it ( I had assumed it was made in USA since I went to their website) a surprize. Made in China OK, what isn't? The screen protector was not very good but overall pleased better than none... it fits well and lite. I don't know if it will stand the test of time, I admit I am picky there's always room for improvement.I had gone to Obliq's website and thought I saw an identical case.

reviewText: I recently acquired a couple of Nokia E63 phones and these are my observations so far:Pros* On Mac OS X transfers contacts and calendar through iSync using a plugin downloaded from Nokia* On Mac OS X transfers photos to iPhoto and music to iTunes through Nokia Multimedia Transfer downloaded from Nokia* On Mac OS X transfers both through bluetooth, and USB through USB-to-miniUSB cable using miniUSB-to-microUSB adapter OEM Motorola SKN6252* Uses microSDHC memory; tested using 8GB class 6* Includes FM radio, Internet streaming radio, and plays video and music (aac/mp3)Cons* Mac users, firmware updater only available for Windows* Built-in email program works only over packet radio (provider data plan)* E-mail over WiFi/LAN requires additional application download on the phone and an account with Nokia; setup WiFi access point on the phone first* Does not bundle data cableNote that if you are a techie the cons are minor.

This one is a real glass.when installed it is no different then already existing phones glass.This screen protector is very clear and hardly noticed. The screen is crystal clear and protected. The durability is unknown but any glass breaks if it is stressed out.The edges are very smooth and the size is perfect. Some can argue that size is 1 mm less at the surrounding. This is necessary to avoid hitting the surrounding border.The installation was very easy. I am able to install without dust in a steamed bathroom.The price is obviously best. I got it for under 10 and it cant be bet by spigen. Though the credit goes to Spigen any way for coming with there Glasst product in the market.I have only one complaint which may not be resolvbed. The screen with this glass or without is very slippery. This problem exist even if this glass is not installed. As previously i used to have plastic protector they used to provide enough friction for the screen.I hope i will get used to it.Highly recommended to save money for very similar product as Spigen Glasst.
Works well with iPhones but not for iPads, not enough juice to get iPads to charge....  I suggest something else to get the juice level to where you need it for iPad use.

Price is awesome, I needed this since my wife broke the micro USB charging port, and broke the regular rapid charger ( I know, how irresponsible! ). This works great, and she is no longer allowed to use the playbook, I use it as an alarm clock while on this stand.

Product worked great for the first couple months, since then the uplink audio on mine has deteriorated to the point that people cannot understand me very well, even in quiet environments.  My friend also purchased one and is saying his downlink audio will deteriorate while on a call as well as the uplink audio.  I believe the uplink audio issue is due to the noise canceling failing because people have a hard time hearing me while driving where they didn't previously.Even in the first few months when the product was at its best while in a quiet environment, I have to cup my hand to channel my voice to the microphone when giving information such as spelling my name or giving numbers for account numbers.  The audio doesn't seem to be very crisp.  Sometimes I just disconnect the bluetooth and use the handset to give these details to which I am told  "That sounds much better" which isn't what I want to hear after spending $70 on a BT headset.I wouldn't recommend this headset after several months of use as it appears the headset degrades in performance.  This isn't just my experience, my friend who bought one at the same time is experiencing the same issues.
summary: Quality deteriorates after only a few months

reviewText: I just got a smart phone, and ATT wanted 40 bucks for a case when I got the phone. I just couldn't afford the phone and the case, and theyonly had black. Well I found this really cool purple hard rubber case and I just love it. It was under 5 bucks and i got it within 3 days of placing the order. And it was everything they said it would be. I am very happy with e everything I have ever ordered.

Not giving a 5 yet because I need time a longer time to compare this to my stock battery.  So far, I have not had issues with either battery.  The charger is a little bit of a challenge, but I would rather have batteries stay in the charger tight instead of loose like my last battery charger (For Galaxy Note) which the slightest touch would cause battery to literally fall out.  I have read some reviews where folks say the charger is crap, I have had issues.  One potential issue I could see is that since it is hard to get the battery out, folks are "twisting" or "wrenching" battery out and causing dividers on battery terminal to break or the terminals on the charger to break. They charge in a reasonable time and they seem to last as long if not longer than stock battery, but again, I have to apply some real science to my determination before I say that they "definitely" last longer.
Got this one for my nephew and he loves it. a great case, holds the phone snug and tight. haven't heard any complaint from him since.
Much better quality than I expected for the price and a great alternative to spending an absurd amount on body glove or other overpriced cases.

Worked well, but on the 4th use of it I left it on the charger for 3 hours or so.  Came back to find the phone hot and unresponsive, I was unable to wake the device.  I let it cool off for 10 min or so then the phone was able to be powered on and work as normal.  But its too big of a risk to use the charger while unattended.  If I left it overnight, would the device ever work again?
It is perfect to use when mowing the lawn and working around the house to listen to my music without worrying about dropping it.
Charger works perfect with my iPhone. Good buy for the money. (Only suggestions is maybe they should be red so I would not lose the so easily!)

Seriously, for a rugged case this is nice because it doesn't add much thickness to the phone. I'm not so sure how much the removable plate on the back appeals to me because I like case all black, but the silver is pretty nice contrast. If anything, it helps differentiate your phone from others. What's cool about this case is that it wraps all around the phone and has a plastic screen protector on the front. All the edges are nicely beveled so you get the feeling that the case is machined instead of injected molded. I like this because I had an element case previously and nothing comes close to the CNC machined aluminum. But if I had to choose something close, it would be this case. Everything lines up perfectly and there is hardly anything bad to say about it. The volume buttons are not raised, so you do have to push a bit harder to get them to operate, but nothing that will give you carpal tunnel syndrome or anything. 5 stars. Easy purchase.

I love everything about this case EXCEPT that it doesn't fit perfectly. Which is a big deal! It is too loose and I'm afraid my phone will fall right out. It also doesn't completely cover the silver on the sides/front, which is pretty important.I don't know if this fit is common to all or if I just got a defective one. I really love the feel and the color and the glitter. The writing on the back is wiping off after only two days using it but that doesn't bother me. I just wish they could fix the way it fits so it covers the front a bit more, and is a bit more snug, and it would be perfect. As it is, I can't really trust it.
summary: Love the grip and look, but fit isn't perfect, doesn't protect enough

reviewText: I ordered this by mistake but turned out to be a perfect birthday present for my best girlfriend.  It all worked out!!
This fit well but quickly wore out. Stitching came loose and the inside cover constantly left my phone smudged. Cannot recommend.

This review is for the Galaxy S5 Shell Holster Combo case. I love this case. I had a similar one for my Galaxy S3, and as soon as I knew I was getting an S5, I ordered this case to make sure that I had it by the time I purchased the S5. The case is slim, allows access to all the phone's functions, and provides adequate protection.I love the kick-stand, as I primarily use it to improve my grip on the phone while holding it (I just slip a finger through the kick-stand opening to make the phone easier to hold). When used with the holster cover, this case provides great protection. However, if you do not use the holster part, the screen will be exposed, and you will need to be careful with the phone. This case will protect your phone from *some* drops, but not all. So if you are especially prone to dropping your phone on hard surfaces, you may want to consider a more heavy-duty case.I highly recommend this case, it is a great value and does not add much bulk to the phone.(A tip for removing the phone from the case: slip a credit card or other plastic card between the phone and the case at one of the corners, to gently pop the case off).
summary: Great Case for the Galaxy S5

reviewText: I had a purple cover for my iphone from another company and I wasn't satisfied with it so I ordered this one.  And I am most pleased with this one.  I got the one that is black around the sides, but clear in the front.  I like that with this one the buttons aren't stiff for the volume and turning the phone off and on.  And it is easy to put on because it has two pieces.  It doesn't involve a tight squeeze as with the other one I had.  And this one comes with a cleaning cloth for the screen and it comes with the protective screen cover as well.  So it is the whole package in one.  After trying another brand, I can say I prefer this product.
i got this to go on long trips with my wife. and we connect both phones and keep them fully charge at all times. i highly recommend this item.
I ordered the phone expecting it to be new. But after it got delivered, when I opened the box, it seemed used. The screen guard had lots of scratches as if it was taken out of the box many times.

My husband dropped his V3 razor while riding his motorcycle. This is the only type of phone he swears by because of its sleekness. So, I noticed it was on sale at Amazon and I jumped at the chance to buy this phone that he enjoys dearly and is easy for him to manage while riding his motorcycle.

I think like with a lot of items, personal preference comes into play. I like minimal cases, but not a fan of hard plastic. I had the iFrogz Luxe Original on a few of my iPhones and always liked them. My last one had a crack in the piece that holds the 2 parts on and it would slide off a lot. It was the first time I had an issue with any iFrogz, so I decided I would try for a little more protection and something new. I have an Incipio Feather on my iPad, so I figured I would try this one. It's a good case. I don't really care for the rubber under hard shell type, but once it's on, it's not so bad. It has a weird extra rubber lip that comes up just under the home button. Not really sure why that's there, but it took a little getting used to. I am not going to run out and replace it anytime soon. It offers good protection and isn't too big.

My item not only came 2 business days after I ordered? But it was absolutely perfect. The colors are even more beautiful in person than the pictures. It fit marvelously, my phone is protected... and I love that the Commuter cases are smaller than the Defender cases, with still basically the same amount of protection. The only downside about the Commuter, is that it doesn't come with an already installed screen protecter, but heck, as long as you have a quality single screen protecter you're good to go. When it comes to protecting your iPhone, it's Otter all the way. I would recommend this product and seller to ANYBODY.

This is perhaps the smallest charger I have seen to date.  It's about half the size of a cigarette pack and comes with a USB cord to charge from either your computer or an iPod plug-in converter.  It says it takes four hours plugged into the wall and eight hours plugged into the computer.  Perhaps this one had some charge because it only took about 4 hours to charge (light indicators) on the computer.It has 2200 mAh - which is about the strength of one rechargable AA battery.  This is a lithium power pack so it should recharge several times before it loses its life.Very simple to use, charge on computer or with cable; plug into iPod; automatically charges iPod; done!  Great device to bring on a trip where you know you're not going to have access to a power source.  Be sure you put this in a sealable plastic bag to keep it protected from moisture!
summary: Small compact Charger for you iPod, other devices

reviewText: This is awesome. All your bubbles get out, screen is protected and everything. Only thing you should note is when you have a tight fitting case...(like on my Lumia 1520 I have a JKase) you need to either be very careful not to pull of edges when putting case on (very hard) or get the CASE FRIENDLY version of this product.It is supposed to be a little bit thinner for tight fitting cases. Only downfall of the case friendly version and reason I am still getting thicker one is because I am an amazon prime member and this is not prime eligible.

reviewText: The Samsung Chargers works good and chargers the galaxy's phones perfectly. The charger is nice to have in your car the blue light stay on when the charger is indicating power charging.

Very SOLID phone case.  Hard core hiking/biking/rock climbing equipment.  Good for everyday use as well as "rough-n-tumble" with a mix of rubber and hard plastic hybrid case.  The only down side I have found to this case is the larger, rubber, protective corners drag in your blue jean and pants pocket....making it a bit difficult to pull out without a jerking motion; almost causing you to drop your phone.  So for all guys out there....be careful pulling this one out of your pocket.  If you have a purse, backpack, fanny pack *(or whatever) you put your phone in other than a pants pocket, then you should be fine.All in all, I would recommend this case simply for the protection factor alone.  The case just about has it all; is stylish, rugged and gives your phone a good/solid layout for texting and/or taking photos.  Just be cognizant of how you yield it out of the confines of your jeans, shorts or any firm fitting pocket that may cause drag.
Fits the phone perfectly. It's tight enough to protect it but not too tight to struggle too remove it from the phone. Definitely recommend.
This case is very sleek and keeps the flat look and feel of the phone, which I like.  It also has a very premium feel to it.  I would recommend it

You can use this product with all micro usb cellphones i tried fits blackberry.almost same charging time compare wall charger.blue light looks good but it lits all the time not only charging in progress.it would be better if it can be retracted thats why i gave 4 star.over all perfect charger,recommended.
This item took a while to get here, but that was to be expected, It is a very good case just wish it came with directions, still not sure if I put it together right, I still had pieces left.

Loved the looks of this case, bought it for the purpose of it being so slim and not adding bulk to my phone but still protect the back and sides from scratches and it served this purpose perfectly. My only complaint is that it is a little tricky to take this case off, I don't know how you would if you didn't have nails honestly. But I'm glad that it's so tight fitting because I feel like it prevents dirt from getting between the case and the phone and scratching the phone.
This case is very nice. Fits the phone great. Light weight and not bulky at all. You barely know its there. Will get another when this one wears out or something happens to it. Great case!!!

I really like this case. It offers good protection and looks really nice. My phone looks just like the day i bought it. I dropped the phone a few times and it is still without a dent, even though the case has a tendency to fall of the phone when it hits the ground. But the point is that the case still takes most of the damage.The part of the case that covers the front of the phone comes attached with a clip. I have not found a way to remove the darn clip without breaking it. I honestly hate strapping the clip to my belt and therefore have found myself only using the front cover only when i have the phone on my desk or when i leave it charging.As far as the stand in the back is concerned i have only used it a couple of times and i have to say it doesn't feel durable at all. If you want to purchased this case because of the stand i would not recommend it. It just feels cheap.Overall, when you take the price into consideration this case is a great value.
summary: I like this case a lot.

reviewText: Our son loves this case. Very sturdy and protective - much higher quality than we expected at this price point.
I had price the USB car chargers and was not willing to pay the prices I had seen, this was a great deal and works wonderfully.

I've long needed a better armband for my gym workouts and the Belkin Pro-Fit Armband for iPhone 5 is definitely better than what I had been using previously.I'm actually using it for an iPhone 4 and it fits (a bit snug at first), provided I first remove my phone from its protective case.  It might be different if I used it for jogging, but for my gym needs (cardio and weights) it does what it needs to do.  I don't have the biggest biceps in the world but I've had no problems with it slipping once the clasp closure was adjusted.  And yes, as some of the other reviews have noted, the nylon backing gets pretty sweaty but because the inside is rubber-coated, the phone itself remains dry.The protective plastic screen, on the other hand, makes using your phone's touchscreen admittedly tricky but not impossible--during my workouts I only really need to access it for the music apps.All in all, it's easy to see where there would be room for improvement in subsequent versions, but, for my needs, it's still a more comfortable fit than my old armband.
summary: Good for workouts, but there's room for improvement.

reviewText: I bought this as a case to use with the holster while on the job and while at the gym. I really wanted to like this case after seeing it, but it falls short of my expectations.The problem I have with the case is the part that wraps around the screen. It's flimsy, and it doesn't clip to the phone in enough spots to actually keep it from moving around, like on the sides of the screen. Due to the lack of a rigid design in the screen part, it results in it not staying secured, and it is constantly pulling up the ZAGG Shield I have on the phone, even when I'm careful with it. Since ZAGG doesn't make a case friendly version for the Droid 3, my only options are to either remove the shield, which I will not, or remove the case from the screen, which then causes issues when putting it into the holster, which I constantly use. All they had to do was go for a Case-Mate like solid design for the screen part that was 1mm wider on the sides and it would be perfect. Getting it in and out of the holster could be a bit easier too if they just made the base of the holster a little narrower so you could use two fingers to push the phone out of it easier, but at least I know the phone is secure in there.It's really a shame, because I love the rest of the case. It fits the body of the phone great, has well designed cut outs for all ports and buttons, and feels great. I wasn't crazy about the angled ridges design at first but I appreciate it now because it gives it some grip. The holster itself is nice too. The clip hinge is metal and plenty tight, and the plastic clip has a hook on the bottom that will easily secure it to a 1.5" belt and ensure that it stays put. It also swivels too if you're looking for that.I'm going to end up trying the Seidio SURFACE case too just to see how that compares, and if that fails, I'll just get the Case-Mate Barely There case and I'll just mix and match all three. Seidio holster, Qmadix main case, Barely There screen case; maybe that'll work.
summary: Bit of a let down - Not good with ZAGG Shield

reviewText: The unit is very solid and looks very nice. It is way better than those Chinese knock-offs and it even comes with a good warranty.

The case is well built and feels sturdy.  It has a strong magnetic flap that really locks the phone into place so that it won't fall out.  The clip on the back is well made.  Overall it is a solid case and worth the buy. Highly recommend.

If you need a USB outlet in your car but still needs to keep the 12V cigarette lighter adapter, this is one simple way to do it.Pros:- cover.  I have other adapters similar to this that doesn't have a cover for the cigarette lighter adapter.  The cover makes it safe that you don't accidentaly touch the inside with your fingers and also prevents the outlet from getting dirty.- aesthetically pleasingCons:- only one 1A USB outletA sample of this product was sent to me for review purposes.

reviewText: After getting tired of carrying multiple chargers for the family's multitude of smartphones, iPad and Android tablets and almost likely limited by the number of wall outlets in the hotel room, I decided it it time to act smart.  This 5 port changer is perfect for connecting up to 5 devices connected to ONE wall outlet.  I have many Anker single chargers and battery backups and they make quality products.  No regrets.
summary: Anker 5-port charger makes my life more logical and convenient.

reviewText: not real pleased with this item.. they get scratched easy, and the corners dont lay down very well.. for very long.

For those of you who got a 3G handed down, or practically free. Your battery drains quickly, I know. Now the battery life is tolerable thanks to this. All the tools you need. Replacing battery on iPhones is not easy, no matter which version. Glad they offer a replacement for cheap.

It almost feels wrong to put this bulky, clunky thing around your beautiful sleek new iphone. It pretty much eliminates the  high res screen, and the light feel of the phone. But it does protect it, and that's its purpose. So for that, I give it 3 stars.

reviewText: This is one of the clearest  headsets I have every owned.  It works great 40 feet away from the phone and it charges in about 15 mins.  Easy on and off by just flipping the mini boom mic.

This headset gives the best audio quality in both directions that I have found, and I have bought about 20 Bluetooth headsets over many years.But this one failed in three days. It would not turn on or take a charge, or do a manufacturers reset. I found that other people have had the same problem by searching the Internet.

The Seagle dual port charger is a good device. It offers a 1 A and a 2.1 A charging port for your hungrier devices such as iPad or Samsung tablet.Depending on your price range, I have seen chargers with a few more ports for only a few dollars more, so keep that in mind.That being said, the Seagle is very well built and easy to use. The only con I can find, other than "just" having 2 charge ports is that the flip out prongs for the wall can seem to sit a little too flush with the device when closed, making opening/closing the prongs to plug them in a little challenging.A nice addition is the ability to use this when traveling international. It is rated for 110W-240W input. You would need an adapter to change the prongs into the configuration of the country you are visiting, but voltage would be a complete non-issue.It is light weight, so traveling with it would be another non-issue.Recommended.I received a free sample for review purposes from the manufacturer.

For the price, this is fantastic!! As far as quality, its about as good as any other. This last purchase I ordered 2 sets of this product and one of the batteries was loose in the comparment, had to use a small folded up wedge to keep battery in place, but the battery workd so I guess it aint too bad.I gave this a 4 star cause at this price, the battery is a superb buy, worth every penny.
These stylus's are perfect, there really isn't much to say but that they work, they aren't to big and are the perfect size. They're perfect for my tablet. I would recommend this product.
With the replacement tips, this stylus should last me a long time. Comes with a puller also. Easy to replace the tips.

This headset are really good, the reception is amazing and the design light and flexible it is ideal for anykind of activity (from workout to walking). Too bad that I lose them. But I can say that compare to the other two brands that I could find for Wireless headsets this were superior in:VS Motorola S10-HD = Plantronics are more confortable, flexible and greater reception distance.VS Jabra = Seems that has better reception and greater reception distance.

I have mixed feelings about this Motola mount. The actual mount itself is great. It can be attached to either your windshield or dashboard (I choose the latter), it can be adjusted very easily, it is literally a snap to put in or remove the phone with the easy release button on top, it can be oriented horizontal or vertical for the phone, and the phone automatically enters car mode when it connects and exits car mode upon disconnecting. Again, the mount itself is great.However, I have two major problems with the product as a whole. After only a couple months I noticed that one day I was driving and the mount just fell forward onto my dashboard and off the bottom adhesive. I put it back up but this is still a frequent problem and I typically have to reach up and push the mount down onto the adhesive as I start to see it lifting up slightly. I assume this is a heat problem, as it doesn't seem to be an issue when it's cloudy or at night; just when it's sunny and hot. So that is one problem. The other is that it is just impractical in the first place to mount on the windshield or dash if you live somewhere with a sun that comes out and actually plan on using the phone for navigation or anything that requires the screen to be on. The Droid heats up fairly quickly when its screen is on and the CPU is actively working (such as for navigation). If it is a sunny day, all the plastic in the mount absorbs the heat and transfers it right into the phone, increasing the heat by a lot. I have a battery meter app, and I have literally seen my phone sit in excess of 130 degrees on my dashboard on a hot day while I'm driving. Not only is this excessive heat bad, but it makes it impractical to use for navigation for a long period because the phone will not charge at that temperature, *even when plugged in* (try it and see). It will discharge and your battery will drop fairly quickly, putting you at risk for having a dead phone if you're not keeping an eye on its battery meter.The bottom line is that the mount itself works great. I think it is perfect the way it is. However, I hesitate to recommend it if you live in a sunny area because mounting your phone in plain sun exposure will cause it to heat up very quickly and by default cause the battery to discharge whether plugged in or not. If you live somewhere where the sun is hidden more than out, then you're in luck...but in a sunny area you may think twice before getting this kind of mount. An A/C vent mount may be better for keeping the phone cool and working efficiently, if you can find a good one.
summary: Great mount, poor mounting material and impractical in the sun

reviewText: I usually like getting clear cases for my phones because I like seeing the white color of my phones. I am not a big fan of hard cases, so I was excited when I saw this TPU type case for my phone. I didn't even hesitate, I just ordered it. And it came exactly looking like it was described. Although clear tends to turn yellow-ish after a while, it's still going to be in good condition. Heck, I'll just order another one of the same if it gets too dirty. I like it.
The product is really cute, and yes I know it's cheap.. but it really does break after only a few weeks and I get horrible service with this case on my phone. I don't even think it's worth the 2$.

1 year review:Since this unit has elastic bands I knew it would be sturdy enough to be on the motorcycle. I ride year around, regardless of weather. Okay, maybe not snow/ice, but rain doesn't phase me a bit. I commute with my bike so I put on about 10,000 miles since I added this mount. The elastic still works great and I have had no worries about this product getting old and unsecure. I use it in landscape mode and the only time I ever had a problem was when I accidently yanked on my headphone cord...which pulled my phone out of the device at 70mph. Totally my own fault, and luckily the little 3.5mm connector holding the phone to my headphones was strong enough to not let my brand new phone fall to the ground. Anyways, if your looking for an alternative to the expensive RAM solutions, this is it. You could buy 20 of these things for the price of all the pieces you would need for a RAM mount.

The one that I got, at least, did not have enough power to charge my iPhone 5, which has the same charging requirements as the iPhone 4 and earlier. It took more than an hour to charge barely 2%. Not acceptable.
Need extra cords for my phone and for the car chargers inn the car whilr traveling. Very useful product when needed.

I really like theEasyAcc 25 Watts 5V / 5A 4-Port USB Wall Chargerfor several reasons.  If you're like me, you have multiple devices that you charge either daily or every other day.  Tablet, Phone, PDA, GPS, ect; it's just so hard to keep track of chargers, cables, and keep organized.  This charger changed that for me.One awesome feature of this charger is the four USB charging ports on the front.  The unit may seem like it will block outlets, however I find it to not be much of a problem in my home or while traveling.  This charger has two (2) 2A USB charging ports and two (2) 1A USB charging ports.  The 2A ports are great for tablets, and I have used it with my Nexus 7 with no problem.  The 1A ports are great for Smartphones or when you have more time to charge your tablet.  I generally charge my Smartphone with the 1A port and it charges really fast.In my case, this unit has now provided a central hub where I can keep all my devices together and charging at the same time.  There are no included cables with this unit, but you can use the USB charging cable that came with your tablet or smart phone with no problem.  I think this is a great product and it really provides a great charging solution for those who have too many gadgets to charge at the same time.  I have used all four ports on this charger at the same time and it worked beautifully.  I would thoroughly recommend this charger to the gadget obsessed.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: Too Many Devices, Not Enough Plugs?  Get This Charger And Never Worry Again...

reviewText: **Charger stopped working June 26th. That's less than 2 months after purchase. I tried different plugs and alternative devices to charge and it just didn't work. I would not recommend**I am very happy to have this charger, as mine went kaput. The pivoting plug is helpful since my outlet is in the center console. A complete charge of my phone takes the same amount of time as my USB/ AC Apple charger at home. I love that it is Apple certified.The cord is supposedly 5 ft long, but seems much less since it is a tight coil. I would have a tough time talking on the phone while charging, the cord would continuously be yanking back toward the outlet.However, it is good at its job.

I really put this thing through some abuse.  I have a T-Mobile Galaxy S2 (ancient by now) which is the equivalent to AT&T's Galaxy S2 Skyrocket.  This meant that it had a larger screen and it was kind of a pain looking for accessories.  I needed this armband for when I hit the gym.  Having the phone in my pocket with a long cord for my earphones resulted in a LOT of yanks.  My phone fit into the armband very well, and I had no issues adjusting the strap.  My only two cons for this are that the armband would sometimes get a little itchy on the inside of my arm, and after a good workout, the moisture from my sweat would get on the inside of the clear plastic cover and make it very hard to slip the phone out after I finished.

reviewText: Let me start off by saying that I'm a fan of the generic cheapy screen protectors because they are well, cheap and they protect your screen from most common scratches. Now, after using the 3M Natural View, I have to say that I still prefer the cheapies - but barely.For about 17 duckets, you get 1(one) 3M Natural View screen protector that, while it's one of those put on and "re-put on-able" deals, if you get just a speck of dust on it, it's very visible and you've just kinda blew your $17.Still, if you've found yourself to a factory that makes hard drives and are able to borrow one of their dust-free rooms for a spell, and are able to apply the screen protector on your phone without an air bubble, the 3M Natural View is faaaaaantastic!  The material is light and has some heft to it's thickness, don't worry about something puncturing the protector - you are good to go! The holes are cut accurately for the buttons and microphones (something the cheapies get wrong sometimes) and there are no distortions on the retina screen.Reccommended!

I purchased this Otterbox Defender for my iPhone 5 because I have one on my iPod Touch (1st edition) and on my iPad 1 and was thrilled with how well they protected my devices.  I have 2 young kids and am an avid camper so protecting my devices from sticky hands, dust and drops is more important than sleek looks.PROS-  The case offers good impact protection.-  The case seemed big at first but now seems normal after a week.-  Fits in the back pocket of my jeans - real jeans, not skinny ones.-  The case protrudes enough on front and back that it should protect your device if liquid were to be spilled around it.CONS- The screen protector kept sticking to the screen producing what others are calling a watermark effect.  It is horribly annoying.  I followed online suggestions to use Windex and newspaper to clean the phone and screen protector and it fixed the issue.  That said, the news paper/Windex did scratch-up the screen protector.  Lame.- I stuck the phone into the included belt clip and it started to tear the rubber casing on the phone.  Won't be using the clip anymore!- If you have really short finger nails than you may have trouble opening the flap to the phone silence button on the side. I have to use my keys.  The covers on the bottom are easier to flip open because of the speaker/mic holes.I think Otterbox could have done a better job on this case.  It's not bad if you absolutely need the protection but I recommend getting something else if you don't need your case to be bomb proof.I hope this review is useful to you.UPDATE 1/28/2013Otterbox is so nice to deal with.  They have sent me a new case and claim that they have resolved the "watermark issue" by applying a new material to their screen protector.  They also said that if you have an existing case to NOT use Windex or newspaper to get rid of the watermarking and to use baby powder instead.  They said to gently apply to screen of iPhone and to inside of screen protector - gently wipe away so you can't see anymore and then install the case. Also, the case really is very resistant to drops.UPDATE 1/31/2013Otterbox sent me a new case and the design has been slightly modified to prevent the water mark issue.  The good news is that there is no more water marks.  The bad news is that the built in screen protector no longer lays on the iPhone so there is a small air pocket between them.  It feels horrible.  Each time you press down on the screen you connect with the protector and then your finger must continue pushing down until it makes contact with the iPhone.  My wife said it "wasn't horrible" but i think it's pretty bad.  I have purchased a UAG case and plan on only using my Otterbox for camping trips.

Very Nice. I mean, common people. It's a SPARE battery just in case of emergency or you're too lazy to charge your phone and want a pre-charged ones ready to go when you wake up. Nothing beats the original of course, but this one does the trick of having extra power on your cellphone just in case your current battery dies out. I use my Galaxy S5 (rooted) really heavy such as playing 3D Games for 2 hours, Text message and calling the whole day and night, Netflix, lots of music listening, video calling, and also some tweaking and modding my phone. This battery does the job for the price. It is a nice spare for extra phone power, but don't confuse it as a complete replacement and ditching the OEM Samsung battery because generic ones won't last long. Nice to keep in your pocket or backpack fully charged without having to carry those pesky USB and power outlet. Also great for storing in your car  (just make sure it doesn't get too cold or hot where you live especially if your car is parked outside all the time).Overall, I recommend this product if you are looking for extra spare batteries, just make sure you also have the time to charge them.
summary: Great spare batteries for the price

Can't believe to see such a terrible product from Duracell!This charger is very very slow and unable to fully charge my iPhone 5S once.It charges at the rate of 1% per minute for about first 30 mins and then slows down even further. I have calibrated it several times by noting the battery %age and the time by keeping c charging log and this is SLOW.And then it can only charge my iPhone 5S only about 75%. So, if I started charging at 15%, this charger will exhaust somewhere around 85-90%, and that too without any intermittent usage, all apps closed, Bluetooth, wi-fi off, display off, etc type of power saving settings while charging.The ten dollar trickle charger which you get from Groupon Goods deal is way way faster than this.The wireless charging function is not really a much useful feature for an average consumer. You will still need a spot for the charging mat which need to be purchased separately.Overall, if you have to spend fifty bucks but one of those mega battery packs with USB ports which will provide power for more than one device.

I have a 2008 Honda Odyssey and I have been shopping around for options for Bluetooth phone upgrades now that it is illegal in my state to talk on the cell phone itself while driving.  Most of what I was looking at were full replacement radio systems which offered DVD player, Touchscreen, Navigation etc.  These were NOT cheap and I was getting frustrated.  I also didn't need all the features of a full replacement system.  I have a Samsung Galaxy S4 which offers Navigation and can stream Pandora.  Why would I want a DVD player in my car anyway?I stumbled across this option and snatched it up for less than $40!  I was able to install this in minutes (I even was able to make the cable to the unit almost invisible by running it along a seam in the dash).  Using my "Llama" app I set it so that when I plug it into my car the bluetooth turns on.  When the BTC450 pairs with the phone, Pandora automatically starts up.  Now when I start my car, plug in my phone and push one button, Pandora automatically comes out of the speakers.  Seamless and easy with the push of one button to pair the unit to my phone.Perfect for the job and nice looking too.  I feel like this unit saved me hundreds of dollars since I didn't end up with a replacement for my existing radio.I am not a technically gifted person and this was easy for me to install and use.  I recommend it!

I received a review sample of this speaker and was immediately struck by the aesthetics. It's relatively tiny, taking up the volume of a four inch cube, and has an attractive design that would be at home in an UFO.What sets this speaker apart from others on the market is the minimalist design. For one thing there are no volume controls - you do that from your phone or other device.The only real controls are the on/off button that will also put the device into pairing mode, and the call/answer button to answer calls on your phone. That feature requires that your phone be less than a foot from the speaker. That is why I mentioned that this is a personal speaker.Sound, in close proximity, is clear although a little light on bass. Still, it is rich sounding and not tinny like some tiny speakers I have tried. If you want something louder and richer sounding I suggest that you considerEasyAcc Bluetooth Speaker with Built-in microphone, which has a lot more volume (and controls for it), and a richer bass sound.Overall, this is perfect for me. I have it on my night stand to stream music from my Galaxy Note 3 to help me sleep. The interesting lighting arrangement on one side makes for a functional night night, and this would also work well in a kitchen, office or other work space in which you want to keep the music level down, as well as have a hand's free phone speaker.
summary: Small, clear and designed to be a personal speaker

The Verizon screen protector I had on my Galaxy Note II had a few hairline scratches, so I was in search for a replacement.  This product had pretty good reviews, so I decided to give it a shot.  It went on very well, with no bubbles.  I couldn't even tell I had a screen protector on visually. I did notice that the texture had somewhat of rubbery feel after installation.  My thumb didn't glide across the screen, and the the S-Pen wasn't as smooth as I'd like.  I thought about taking it off and purchase the Verizon screen protectors again.  I figured I'd break it in and see if it got any better.  The more I used it, the oil from my thumb got rid of the rubbery feel.  My thumb and the S-Pen began to glide across the screen.  Even after wiping it clean every now and then with a micro-fiber cloth, I no longer experience the rubbery feel.  I recommend this screen protector.

I never do this, but I almost bought this product based off of the amazing sounding fake reviews provided by the shills for PowerBear. If you look at all the positive reviews for this case, you will see that none of them are verified purchases and yet every negative review, other than this one of course, is a verified purchase. What that means is that everyone who has actually bought and used this product thinks that it is crap. Furthermore, many of the reviewers have posted twice on this product, once per color. Why Amazon allows this is beyond me, but that is not the point. Also, if you look at the profiles of the positive reviewers, you will see that they have posted multiple positive reviews for PowerBear products and many of the reviews are carbon copies of each other. Beware the paid shills!
summary: Almost every positive review posted for this product is fake

This very cute Otterbox is the middle man that really is perfect for my needs.I have an IPhone for my work which means it is in and out of pockets, my purse, and my hands all day long. Therefore the case had to be durable, attractive, easy to use, and not prevent typing or otherwise viewing/using the phone. I am very satisfied. If something happens I'll update this review but, so far, this is my favorite phone case in years!

Kimberly R. Norton's very helpful June 8, 2014 review is spot on. Like her I received mine as a review sample, and like her I am impressed. For once someone has come out with an organizer that takes into account that the world is full of electronic devices that need to be (1) properly stored, and (2) charged.This makes no attempt to provide the charging electronics - that is up to you. What it does is provide a clever way of organizing and routing cables to tablets and phones that you store with it. This is perfect for households what have two or more tablets and as many phones. In my household I am the exclusive user with a phone and tablet, so I use the other parts of the organizer for stationary and some documents.Aesthetically this looks just like an old fashioned desk accessory. It fits my personal decor, but I would have loved one in brown. As for it being leather I cannot say for sure. It does not have the chemical odor of faux leather, so I am inclined to believe that it is genuine,One use I have put the bottom compartment to is as a hiding place for valuables. Since I only have two charging cables snaked into it, there is ample space for a few twenties, a watch and some other valuables.If you want an old school organizer that will accommodate an array of charging cables in an organized manner, this is it. Like Henry ford said of the Model T: "You can have any color as long as it's black." That is a limitation that I can live with.

The only downside to this product is that you can't keep too much stuff in it at once or the magnet doesn't keep it closed. But this is a great thing for going out to bars if you don't want to bring an entire purse, or if you're just going to the store really quick. Definitely worth the money!

I owned the V300 and found it to be a bit quirky, strange things would happen when ever I charged it, when it was finished all the personal settings would revert back to factory standard. They seemed to have fixed that with this latest version of the phone. My understanding is that they have combined the features from both the v300 and the v 600 to make this phone. I've only had it for 1 week and so far so good I always enjoyed functions such as speaker phone, voice dialing and voice memos, now I get the blue tooth and a much better redesigned key pad along with video clip capabilities. All of this is good news! If I had to pick a down side I would have to say that I'm dissapointed that Motorola decided to make this phone look exactly like the v300. I like what the body of the phone feels like, but a change of color would be better, maybe silver.
summary: Nice, but could be a different color
