reviewText: WOW! OMG! LOL! What a beautiful little charger.  It is as sleek and shiny as it appears online, also I love the gray and black appeal it offers.  It is an original RIM product and will work well with my BB 9700 once it arrives I'm sure. The BB 9700 arrived yesterday (10.05.11), but I had to return it to AT&T because the box had been opened because the seal was broken.  I feared it had been either tampered with (something maybe switched out), a used product, or a refurbished phone etc... This charger even have some weight to it with a rubber bottom to keep it from sliding or damaging the surface it sits on.  This is a great buy and I strongly reccommend it to everyone who should need one.
Just took a trip this last weekend, had plugged two iPhone 5, an iPhone 4 and an iPad 2 - worked like a champ, and amazingly it does not warm up or heat up.
It's an ugly shade of blue and it's a very cheap quality.  It doesn't even work!  They are sending me a replacement so hopefully that one is actually functional.

The batteris are working fine and seem to last maybe an hour or two more than the OEM battery. I was hoping they would last longer, but they are certainly acceptible and a slight improvement over what I had. I would have given 5 stars but the charger is a little difficult to use. The pins should lock in place since it is very hard to get them in position and have they stay that way while you try to get the battery into the spring loaded charger. It would be much easier to work with  if the pins simply could lock in place. But for the price it is certainly acceptible. A big plus is you can use the charger for almost any battery and it has a usb port so for travelling it is all you need no matter how many different phones you have. I would certainly recommend this product.
summary: Batteries slightly better than OEM, charger ddifficult to use

reviewText: I was agonizing over a case to get my husband for his Christmas iPhone 4s.....Reading review after review after review....  I wanted something non-bulky so it would fit nicely in his pocket...I wanted the Apple logo to show through the back (what good is a cool phone if you can't show off its total coolness???)  PLUS I wanted it to have a small bit of a bumper to protect the front glass.  This one seemed to fit the bill, and I figured for this price he could just pitch it and get a new one if he did not like it.BUT on Christmas he put it on...it went on easily.  The bumper is a tad loose around the buttons but not much...and I think its good because other more snug cases have complaints that its almost impossible to put on or remove.  The grips on the side have a great feel, very comfortable to hold.  The back shows off the "Apple" and the "iPhone" logo perfectly.  It lines up great with all the buttons and plugs and the camera.My husband is not rough with his things so it has not been dropped yet...it seems like it would protect against minor bumps and drops but I would be afraid to drop it from a distance but hey, never know!  I will update if something bad ever happens to the phone through the case.I said he could buy a new case if he wanted, but he said he liked this one and preferred to just keep it.  It feels good in his hand, and does not detract from the iPhone itself at all.  Really good buy...you can't go wrong with this!

I play a lot of poker and, therefor, I am always carrying an iPod or my Android phone to listen to music. Before I got the New Trent iPulse I used to obsess over keeping my electric gadgets fully powered. You never know when a buddy is going to tip you off to a game and... Oh crap? Did I recharge my iPod last night?No worries now. With a 12,000mAh battery this thing is all I need to worry about charging now. Then again, with so much power packed into this thing I often don't charge it because it is still plenty charged from the last time I had used it!My first New Trent product was a replacement battery for my laptop. It cost about $28 and the laptop's manufacturer wanted $70 for their name brand battery. I was apprehensive, but ultimately I was impressed. It has performed beautifully. It was built with tight tolerances and was very well made.After I registering my battery I got onto the New Trent newsletter. They sent me a $20 coupon for my iPulse. It was a no-brainer for me to buy this thing. After my previous good experience with the laptop battery and the $20 off coupon I couldn't resist!We just got back from a weekend camping and fishing trip. I was able to provide Pandora music with my phone during the campfires all weekend long. One of the guys used my iPulse to power his iPad. Pretty much the entire group used it to recharge their phones and iPods all weekend long. This thing lasted all four days! I couldn't be more impressed and neither could the guy with the iPad. He used his iPad to buy one of these while we were out there camping!Unfortunately for my friend he couldn't use a coupon. But he told me the way this thing is built and as long as it lasts he'd gladly have paid twice the price. I noticed when I came to the product page to write my review they knocked another $30 off of the price. Normally I would say, "Awe shucks, I should have waited," but this thing made our camping weekend a rocking success!

reviewText: very good audio and noise cancellation.This is the smallest/cheapest (well, cost/quality ratio) that has has noise cancelation with two microphones.Only downside is that i use it for work meetings, where i have to press mute several times. And it only have two volume up/down buttons. you mute by pressing both at the same time, and then sound cuts the call to inform you about the mute state. and there is not way to check mute after a long time into the call other than talking or pressing the two buttons twice to hear the muted/unmuted sounds (and loosing important call information)if they had used the microphone boom switch to enable/disable mute, it would be much, much easier and you could check the state with a touch of the hand very easily as well. But instead, closing the mic boom turns the thing off.I'm not using the phone mute button. which completely undermines all the advantages of having a wireless headset. i could use the wired ones with the same comfort (not to mention not having to worry about batteries)
summary: perfect, if you Never use the Mute function.

I've been doing the Android thing for years now. Been through a few manufacturers in that time. And the Samsung Galaxy Note II is, by far, the best phone I've ever had the privilege of using.First and foremost, the size. It's hard to talk about the Note II without mentioning its size. Based on the reviews I read on the web, I expected this thing to be enormous. Turns out it's really not nearly that big. It's amazingly thin, and a very comfortable size for my hands. Mind you, I do have somewhat large and clumsy hands. For my purposes, this is the perfect size for a phone. If anything, the Otterbox Defender case I put it in is what makes this phone appear really large. Without the case, most people don't really have anything negative to say about its size. Since I always have large pockets on my person (cargo pants, cargo shorts, jackets with large breast pockets, etc), I have no trouble accommodating this device no matter where I go.One drawback to the size is how ridiculous it looks holding it up to your face when you use it as a phone, especially with the Otterbox Defender case. For this reason, I got a Bluetooth earpiece (Motorola Elite Sliver) which interfaces perfectly with the phone and allows me to make and receive calls without taking the phone out of my pocket. I can also interact with the phone in various other ways via voice commands.Of course, the Note II's size brings us right into... the beautiful screen! What a fantastic screen. Best I've ever seen on a phone or handheld device. It's large, clear and colorful. In fact, it was so vibrant that I changed the screen mode to "Natural" to help mute some of the colors a bit. As a photographer, I can really appreciate this screen for reviewing pictures and doing some quick edits. It's the best compromise between a normal phone and an unwieldy tablet. It's also fantastic as a driving tool. Navigation is a dream to use on the large screen, and I can fit a ton of huge shortcuts on one home screen to safely interact with the phone while driving without ever taking my eyes off the road. In many cases, it's possible to use the tablet version of apps on this device for better functionality. For example, I use the SwiftKey Tablet keyboard rather than the phone version. This gives me a huge split keyboard in landscape mode, with room for arrow keys and other neat features, thereby making two-handed thumb-typing a joy. (note: the tablet version of Photoshop Touch is not available for the Note II, Adobe specifically blocks it. Only the Phone edition is officially available, which is a shame)Can you say fast? This thing is blazing fast. I've got well over 100 apps installed, with at least 30 running in the background at all times. I've got 17 active widgets on 6 home screens, all of which update with online data on a regular basis. The interface never misses a beat, and everything runs smooth as silk. I've run some pretty demanding games (Real Racing 3, Modern Combat 4, etc), and none of them needed any special treatment to run properly.With all those apps and widgets, I was worried battery life would become unbearably short. But that's not the case at all! If I'm using the phone constantly (which I often am), I can get a solid 8 hours out of it. Mind you, this is with constant use of data, heavy graphics, etc, all without ever plugging it in. If I'm just using the phone occasionally for communication tasks and checking updates (like a sane person), then I'm good for about 2 days on a single charge. None of my other Android phones ever lasted much more than a single work day on a charge, so this is a vast improvement.Another very unique aspect of the Note II is the S Pen. Some might dismiss this as a gimmick (I did at first). But after learning to use it efficiently, I now see the S Pen as a revolutionary way to use a phone! Taking notes is quick and easy, regardless of my current task. Using the S Pen to interface with the screen helps prevent the accumulation of dirt and oil on the surface. And swiping on the keyboard is much more precise. I can type quickly and efficiently with the S Pen in a way I never could with my fingers. As proof, I'm writing this review on my Galaxy Note II right now!Some will complain about the Samsung TouchWiz layer on top of the stock Android interface, and I guess they have a right to do so. Samsung imposes some frustrating limitations upon users. For example, the included music player is the default music player, and there's no simple way to change that, even if you have another one installed. If you use the call button on a Bluetooth earpiece, S Voice gets triggered, and again there's no simple way to change that. Then there's all the bloatware that comes pre-installed from both Samsung AND AT&T;, and most of it is complete garbage. Media Hub and Music Hub are useless memory drains that can't be disabled, S Suggest and S Voice are inferior alternatives to what's available on the Google Play Store and can't be removed, and the TouchWiz launcher is sorely lacking many features that can make the Home screens so much more useful.But the beauty of Android is that it's endlessly customizable! There ARE alternatives for all of those crappy included apps. And while I state above that some things can't be disabled or removed, that's not exactly true. If you're willing to root your Galaxy Note II, then the sky's the limit for customization. Rooting this device is unbelievably easy and opens the door to making the device truly your own. I've rooted mine. I'm still running the stock Samsung version of Android on my Note II, but I've gotten rid of all the unwanted bloatware, and replaced the built-in "default" apps with my preferred versions from the Google Play Store. My own music player, my own voice command interface, my own launcher, my own lock screen, all without any interference from the Samsung bloatware. No more Media Hub and Music Hub auto-scanning my device and running in the background every time I turn on the phone. In addition, rooting the Note II has allowed me to better secure my phone (Avast! Mobile Security works better on a rooted device, full system backups are now possible, etc). The Note II is a fantastic device as it comes from the factory, but it really becomes the perfect device once it's rooted.The only version of the Note II available from AT&T; is the 16GB edition (in gray and white). I was initially disappointed that the 32GB edition wasn't available, but it turns out that 16GB is more than enough for all my needs. With a 64GB SDXC card installed, there's plenty of room for all 100+ apps that I use, AND all the data they generate. I still have 9GB available on the phone and 35GB on the SDXC card (with over 30GB of music on the SDXC card). I also keep full system backups handy at all times. Turns out the 16GB of onboard flash memory are more than sufficient, and I had nothing to worry about.Have I heaped enough praise on this yet? But wait, there's more! The current official Android version for the Galaxy Note II is 4.1.2, which is a very recent version, even if it's not quite the latest. But apparently the upcoming version of Android (version 5, Key Lime Pie) is scheduled as an update in the near future! This device is getting a lot of attention from Samsung, they're not going to abandon it anytime soon, and that's great news for someone who's looking for a phone that will remain relevant for a while.Yes, it's an expensive phone. And it's larger than most phones. But this device has almost completely replaced my desktop as a daily computing device. It's the best portable computing device I've ever used, and I plan to keep it for a long, long time. Worth every penny.

reviewText: I've had a lot of bluetooth headsets over the years and this one currently ranks as my all time favorite. It is not perfect but it does many things well.  A summary:Pros:-paired very easily-call quality coming in and going out is excellent and works well with voice dialing (and voice commands on my iPhone).- great for listening to podcasts just using the single headset (without extra earpiece) since they are already monaural.- good for listening to music with the second earpiece attached.-controls my phone and ipod functions very well. I can pause and resume what I was listening to on my  iphone anytime.cons:-Sometimes misses a second of music (doesn't happen with calls at all).- Stereo sound quality is good but not fantastic.  Since I listen mostly to podcasts and audiobooks, it doesn't make any difference and when I listen to music, it is good enough for me.- the connector for charging is micro usb.  My first 855 had a problem with the connector loosening so it would reliably charge. Plantronic promptly replaced it. I hope that was a fluke or they have improved that part of the build.Overall, really like this headset and its versatility.
it fits perfectly. i loved it so much when i had it for my htc one v that i got it again for my sgs2 phone for virgin mobile. i recommend it to the highest level. get it and work it.

I use it to connect my beats by dre tours to my bravia tv so I can play call of duty without waking up the neighbors. It works, its a 30 foot cable for a discounted price. Mine has worked perfectly for about two months now.

My previous wireless earbuds were the Jaybirds--and I thought those were relatively ok until they broke.  However, after using the Motorola S10-HD I realized these have a more stable connection than the Jaybirds.  They stay connected better, do not seem to require line of site to stay connected, and have decent battery life.  It does get a little uncomfortable after wearing for over an hour, as it pinches slightly at the ears, especially if you wear glasses.  However, at this price point, it is a very good deal.
summary: Good connection, but can be uncomfortable over time

reviewText: The battery lasts me about 8 hours with minimal usage, I was a bit surprised as I was expecting it would last about the same as the one that came with the phone.  Though it arrived in OEM packaging and looks genuine in all aspects, It does not match up to the one that came with the phone.  Even so, with two batteries and battery charger I am happy.  Thank you seller for I'd a paid a lot more for a lesser battery a few weeks back and doesn't last as long.  It is truly worth the price to get a charger, battery and wall outlet for less than $35 bucks!  It's been a few weeks since I wrote this I would like to add the charger works on and off every now and then.  I was very pleased in the beginning, but now I am apprehensive.  Are there better similar chargers out there? Did I get a lemon or was this just bad luck for me?  IF there are similar chargers of better quality I'd like to purchase one.  Having a spare charger is a heck of a lot better experience than just charging via phone.  All the same the battery works great now, I get more than 20 hours of use on my Samsung Galaxy Note II without having to turn off the WiFi, GPS and bluetooth.  Still worth the price.  Thank you.
summary: Works Great as A spare battery Charger

For the price this is the best headset I've owned. I did really like my last one, a Jawbone Icon, but that one was over twice the price of this Jabra, and broke into three pieces after I dropped it on a wood floor. So this Jabra is my replacement. After over a week of use I'm happy to have it. The pros outweigh the cons. My list of each is below, with only one real con from my perspective.Pros:1. Easy setup: My iPhone didn't even require the headset's passcode, it just connected automatically.2. Great Clarity: Jabra has always made good headsets and this is the clearest of the three or four Jabra devices I've owned.3. Battery: After a few uses battery life seems strong, I got a whole week of occasional use and standby time before I had to recharge it. Heavy use would probably require daily charging.4. Fit: The thin loop of wire that fits around the ear initially seemed far too loose, but it pivots in its fitting and therefore can be adjusted to fit snugly with a simple turn of the headset downward against your cheek. Additional rubber nubs for the inside of your ear and loops for the outside are included in the box (as is the charger, of course).Con:1. Voice Control (iPhone): Initially I was thrilled to notice that pressing the headset once activated my iPhone's Voice Control Feature. But then I realized that it almost never (only 1 out of 5 attempts) accurately recognized the actual voice command I was giving it. This was under reasonable usage conditions (driving at moderate speed, windows up, no music playing, etc.) This is unfortunate as I means I will still have to hold my iPhone directly up to my mouth to use the Voice Control feature.Overall this is a great bluetooth headset for the price.

GENTLY squeegy bubbles from the center out or you will leave permanent scars on the guard.  Which leads me to the real issue.  After a few weeks of use this guard starts showing its weakness to being poked, prodded and rubbed.  On installation this guard is crystal clear, better than similar products.  However, it's all to easy to leave scars across the surface that can't be removed.  Other brands I've used seem to magically heal themselves.  If this brand did the same I would rate it 5 stars and use nothing else.

reviewText: This little kit saved me $100, even with the expedited shipping!!  Love it.  It would be five stars if the included tools were just a tiny bit better, but if I could give 4.5 stars, I would be happy.  Couple of thoughts:- Make SURE to download or make your own sheet of paper with instructions on where everything should go.  There's no reason you should pay the $0.99 that a major repair company charges for this download, so use your powers of ingenuity and google "iPhone 4 screen repair guide sheet."- Use some little piece of tape to tape down every single one of those grain-of-sand-sized screws, and number them in steps (see my picture for a suggested method).  While not necessary, the combo of aScotch PopUp Tape Handband Dispenser, 0.75 x 2 Inches, 75 Strips per Pad, 1 Pad per Pack (Colors May Vary) (96-G)and aSharpie Permanent Marker, Fine Point, Black, Pack of 5made for easier re-assembly.- The included phillips head screwdriver was adequate, but didn't hold a magnetic "charge" and seemed to strip the screws.  So I ran to the store and got theGeneral Tools 6 Piece Precision Screwdriver Set(for a *lot* cheaper than this price on Amazon).  THAT was a good idea.  I ran it along a strong magnet 20 times in the same direction to "charge" it up a little more (don't worry about it by the phone parts - you remove the motherboard and anyway, it's not very strong of a magnet).- Search for youtube videos and make sure you find one you like before starting.- The screen WILL fit perfectly flush with the phone and the home button, but you'll need to clean it properly of any itsy bitsy pieces of dust or glass to make sure AND pull the screen connectors through properly.  You'll know you pulled them both through correctly if they are exactly the same length (I had to disassemble it again to figure this out).Anyway, start-to-finish took me 2.5 hours and while it was a bit infuriating at times, it wasn't really a big deal.  As others have said, if you have replaced/installed RAM or done other delicate computer work, you should be fine.  PLUS, you'll feel great when you've finished!
summary: Worked perfectly and was super cheap!

reviewText: One person said in a review "While this phone is thin, it is too bulky to handle, and seems flimsy."I could not disagree more. It feels extremly sturdy, and while it is not a tiny phone, it is very thin. It weighs more then you would expect, but I don't mind because it feels a bit more well made.I had an off version of the Motorola V557 that I have had for well over a year now. I got it free, so I gave it up to a friend who needed a phone badly. I am a cingular customer. I was wanting a new phone anyways and it worked out well.I got the Nokia 6102 about one or two weeks ago. I have to say while it is a good deal for the price I just didn't like it at all. So I returned it and got the razr. I spent a bit more on the razr, but it was reasonable. (...).The razor is simple phone, a good phone. It comes in a very pretty case that will make you happy each and every time you open it! It has a good quality camera (it's NOT a digital camera, its more like good quality web cam) and I find it very easy to read, and dial because everything is so clear and spaced out nicley.I got the black version, and I nick named it KIT after the night rider car, it reminds me of it. Yeah I am a dork!I had read some complaints that this phone didn't come with enough stuff, well at it's launch price point I would say yeah it was overpriced. Now it has come down and it is a good deal in my book.I am very pleased with it so far! Pleased enough to come write a review!I also love all the cool accessories you can get, including vynle(sp?) skins in any color you want.

The TopG 5.1 amp 3 USB port car charger is one of the highest quality and highest output car chargers on the market.Pros:-5.1 amps of output power (this means that when all the ports outputs combined they add up to a max output of 5.1 amps)-1 of the USB ports, labeled “2.1A”, has a max output of 2.1 amps which is great for charging tablets like an iPad Air (this port is designed for Apple devices like an iPad but will still work with other tablets and smartphones)-1 of USB ports, , labeled “2.0A”, has a max output of 2.0 amps which is great for charging tablets like a Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 (this port is designed for Android devices like Galaxy Tabs but will still work with iPads, smartphones and other tablets)-1 of the USB ports, labeled “1.0A”, has a max output of 1.0 amps which is great for charging smartphones like an iPhone 5/5s (this port is designed for all smartphones like an iPhone 5/5s or Galaxy S4)-Comes in 3 cooling looking color combos (I have it in red/black)-LED status lights indicates that the car charger’s USB ports are ready for use and it is not bright to light up the car (in other words, it will not distract the driver)-Tight fit in the cigarette lighter socket which means it will not slide out easily during use-Tested on a car ride and it worked great for charging an iPad Air, an iPhone 5 and a Galaxy S4-Small for its very high output of 5.1 amps-Protects against over-heating, over-charging, over-current and short circuits-Overall, this is a high quality car charger that has a very high output that works very well-Excellent price!No cons that I can find about this car charger.My wishes:-Add multiple LED’s so the USB ports are visible in the dark (LED do not light up the car, just the USB ports)-Make it have a 7.2 amp output, so 3 tablets, like 3 iPad’s, can charge all at once at full speedThis is an excellent car charger and it works great. I highly recommend this wall charger!Watch my video review.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, for free to keep, and I promised that my review is fair and honest.
summary: Cool looking, high quality car charger that is very affordable!

I switch phones frequently, usually trading with willing participants on Craigslist, so I am a stickler for keeping my phones nice, and holding on to everything that came with them. I just got a Verizon Galaxy Nexus from a private party (I traded my iPhone 4S) he clearly got the better part of the deal. I had the original box, all accessories and wrapped ear buds. He had only the original box and paperwork. He gave me an HTC charger, no phones, and a Motorola charging cable. Also, the phone was beat up from use, not being in a case and having no screen protector. OK, rant over. Now the review. Samsung doesn't supply a headset with every Android device they make, but they do with the Nexus S and Galaxy Nexus (I think Google makes them do that) and these are those phones. I find them quite serviceable. They are in ear with extra sizing gels for your comfort. They have a mic/pause/call end button on one cord so you can go hands free. The sound is good but not great, but better than Apple's and more comfy as they are IN not ON ear. They have the metal accents as well which makes them look good. Overall, if you need to replace your phones, for the price these can't be beat. If you need to, as I have, replace them so you have everything that comes with your phone, that works too.

The second port was under powered.  My Blackberry gave me a warning that I should use the charger that came with the device to charge more quickly.  I had to return the charger for a refund.  I liked the light, but it stayed on whenever the charger was plugged into a powered outlet.  It would have been better if it came on only when the charger was charging something.  The housing seemed well built.

The downside is that doesn't seem very protective. I am not sure if I dropped it if the case would be that much better than having the phone naked, so-to-speak.

What I'm really looking for is an intregrated system that will allow calls from both paired phones simultaneously.  I researched them extensively and none offer this feature.  I have to say the range is pretty good.  Its strange because I prefer to talk on a larger handset than my cell, but still keep it around for email and such so for me the investment was reasonable to give it a try.  Both myself and my wife have iphone 4's running iOS 4.21 with no problems so far.
Fit is great and the color combination is nice. The rubber back helps keep the phone from sliding off of hard surfaces. All of the buttons are still easy to use with it in place.

I looked at several wireless charging receivers on Amazon, read all the other reviews, researched etc before settling on this one.  I almost purchased one for twice the price.This receiver is perfect!  My biggest concern was being able to use it with a decent case, and I am happy to report that this works with my SGP Slim Armor case.  I really wasn't worried about NFC (while nifty, it doesn't really have a useful purpose for me), but I tested it anyway.  It NFC'ed to my Nexus 7 FHD without a hitch.Charging speed is slightly slower then USB, but it saves the hassle of finding (and keeping) a USB cable that fits well with the S4.  I did not notice any back bulge before putting my case on, but even if it did slightly, who really cares?  An expensive phone like the S4 should always be in a good, protective case.

This extra iPhone battery does give you an extra 50 to 80% spare capacity compared with an iPhone alone.  I like having a back-up when I travel to places where there is no electricity until I get back to my hotel which can be as ling as 18 hours.This battery has a capacity of 1,200 mAh (compared to the iPhone4 internal battery at 1,420mAh) meaning it will increase your battery life by ~85%, which matches my observation.The only small issue I have is the LED on the charging base isn't as informative as I feel it should be.  It lights up amber when charging the battery and green when fully charged.  The problem is it lights up green even when there is no battery!  And it's sometime hard to tell that your battery is making good contact with the connector on the charger so I've been fooled thinking it's fully charged when it's not even been charging at all.A better indicator would tell me (1) when it's connected to a USB power source but no battery is connected, (2) when it's charging (3) when it's fully charged.
summary: A good "safety net" for your iPhone

reviewText: I purchased a few of these for my smart phone family so they would quit arguing about whos was whos.. they work great!

As I mentioned in my review of the Miccus Bluebridge, I was heavily biased towards a transmitter that plugs in directly to my iPod with the use of a wire. Wires break. They are also awkward if you clipping your iPod on while you work out. But I had lots of problems with the Miccus freezing up and many times not pairing. So I did a ton more research and simply bit the bullet...getting the Jaybird based on the recurring reliability theme I saw across many reviews. I got it yesterday and so far, it's working on. The fact that it's tiny and light as feather (similar to the dimensions of the most recent iPod Nano), the tiny cable becomes less of a concern.Pairing was quick and easy. It pair several consecutive times with no hiccups, unlike the Miccus.Now--here's the real kicker that I'm really excited about. There is a hardly any delay and the sound quality is as crystal clear as when I plug in through the jack. In fact, bass, mid-ranage, and highs are all there with no distortion. In a way, I'm glad I got the Miccus because there was a huge delay between changing the volume on the scroll wheel and my Logitech Boombox. With the Jaybird the delay is far less noticeable.All in all, I'm joining the chorus of Jaybird fans out there. It's a solid purchase.

If you follow the instructions that come with the package, this product works the way it should. I charged it to 100% and this thing still has yet to run out. I have had it off the charger since like 9am. It is now 4am the next day and it still has barely reached 50%! And that's with everything in full power; data on, screen rotate, blue tooth, screen brightness, etc., I can't imagine how much further this battery would get with my usual moderate use throughout the day. I have been running everything on the phone at full power on purpose to try to make the battery drain faster so that I can keep cycling it and conditioning it, but it's nearly impossible to run it out fast. Just gotta let it run out. Follow the instructions though, they are there for a reason. Other than the very first time you use this battery, it should not be charged unless it's at 5% or less. Otherwise you risk depleting the lifetime span of the battery. That's common sense though; even with the stock battery. I only charge it when it's down to 3%-ish or less. The stock battery, btw has been a great battery for me. But I wanted a back-up in case I ever found myself in a position not to get to a charger for a couple days.As for the size and stuff, honestly, it's not as bad as I thought it'd be. It actually makes the phone feel better in your hand, and less like it's going to drop from your hand at any moment. I may want to get a phone cover for this, but that's about it.I love this product and it is already proving to be a great investment. If you are looking for an extended battery, and could care less about aesthetics, then this product would be great for you. Highly recommend.

so i'm here to review this product only. nothing else, obviously, but to start, i dont know what everyone else is talking about. it doesnt take 3 minutes to disconnect and reconnect your iphone 5. i was working with it tonight, and i was able to pull the iPhone out while holding the base dock onto the table (obviously you need to do this no matter what) and it came out fine, the lightning cable did not get dislodged or pull out with it. i also placed the iphone onto the dock easily. the major advantage to this dock is that you can put the iPhone either facing front OR facing back as long as the audio port plug is down and not up. this makes it really simple if your just climbing into bed and you dont realize the orientation of your phone if its facing forward or not.the one negative i can think of, which is why i gave it 4 stars instead of five, is that it only accepts the apple licensed lightning cable. i bought griffin tech iphone 5 lightning cable which comes in black, and i thought it would be great for this dock, but its too thick, so it won't fit in the dock unfortunately. but thats fine. other than that, it does as advertised and i dont see any REAL reason other customers are being so lazy and hateful to this product. its the only iphone 5 dock out there at the moment and its a great choice!Belkin Charge and Sync Dock with Audio Port for iPhone 5

reviewText: This case is the bomb-diggity!It is very easy to put on, stays on the iPhone very well, and does not add excessive weight. It does add some but it's really not taht noticable. I use my iphone for pretty much everything - it is my work phone, my web pretty much anytime I'm outside the house, I use apps to run on it, and just generally get my money's worth.This is a superb battery case - looks classy and feels awesome on. It does show some fingerprints (even though it is matte) but who the heck cares? Not me.I am training for a marathon/half marathon and so I need a case that helps me use several apps at once because I keep track of my runs on the phone via GPS. That usually means I have to chose one app because with running for hours the battery died too quickly previously. Now I can run and run and run without any battery issue at all.The charging pad works perfectly. Just pop your phone on and it charges it and the battery pack. This thing really is revolutionary - and it is so easy to use and deal with. I have never had such a great case. I think it's totally worth the money. I can contrast this with the LifeProof case (yuck!) and my Otterbox Commuter. While the Commuter may have provided more protection (though I'm not sure of that) you cannot beat having double the battery available and the charging pad.Disclosure: I received this case in exchange for my review. However I review tons of products and I review them honestly regardless of how I get them.
summary: Utterly in love with this case - this truly makes the Iphone a jack of all trades!

This Amazon Basics silicone case is remarkable similar, with notable exceptions, to one thePremium Soft Silicone Gel Skin, one of the first inexpensive iPhone 4 cases on the market.  The Amazon Basics case adds a tiny cleaning cloth, one screen protector (forget the plural in the product name), and a squeegee for application of the protector.PLEASE NOTE:  Amazon has combined product reviews for different Amazon Basics cases, some with screen protectors and some without. Also, different colors share the same reviews.  Customers should check the descriptions to see which version they are ordering.The Case: Four StarsFirst, the pros:  it has textured bars on the side for firm gripping; the case slips on easily; the cut-out for the rear camera is two-tiered, which protects the lens without casting a shadow over it; the silicone minimizes the possibility of the phone slipping out of your hand; controls are easy to reach; it's inexpensive and unobtrusive.The cons:  the case doesn't fit tightly; as I pull it out of my handbag pocket, the sides can get caught and can open up, thus becoming a lint catcher; the circular cut out in the back to display the Apple logo is unnecessary and perhaps will catch its share of dirt.The Screen Protector: Three StarsI've never used a screen protector for either one of my iPhones, but I figured that, since one came with the case, I'd give it a try.  Now I'm not so sure.  Make sure you use the squeegee (a small plastic tab) to apply.Pros:  it adds a protective layer over the "gorilla glass"; it does not impede the touch operation of the phone.Cons: you have to get the plastic lined up perfectly the first time; no matter how careful I was, I couldn't avoid two small areas with bubbles that I still can't get out; the iPhone glass is easier to get clean than the plastic protector surface; the sharp lines around the phone openings look and feel, well, less elegant than the original.If you really want a screen protector, then I'm sure this is as good as any other, but I have never had a problem with scratching either my 3G or my iPhone.Recommendation:  I would get this for the case and not the screen protector, unless you're going to buy a protector anyway.  This inexpensive option to protecting your phone works well enough for a reasonable price, although I find theReveal Etch, which has a hard back that supports the sides enough to improve the fit, a better option.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Floppy silicone case, with one screen protector (3+ stars)

reviewText: I have only had one on my phone so far because I also have the mirror one so I really use that one.  However, they still do what they need to do.

I've only had this unit for about 24 hours, but I really like it.  These are my initial impressions, and I compare this to the Motorola H680 as overall about equal, very similar to the findings by a major consumer-oriented organization as to these two Bluetooths.I gave my used H680 away to a friend of mine because she was driving me crazy always speaking to me over her speaker phone while driving.  She used the speaker phone out of necessity because in California you can not put the phone to your ear while driving, and her bluetooth's battery had died.  My friend is not mechanically adept and I would've kept the H680 otherwise.  It is smaller and more convenient to use than this Plantronics, but I feel the sound quality with this unit is better.  This unit takes some adjustment so I hope the following comments will be of benefit to those of you who purchase this unit:1.  Thoroughly read the instruction booklet.2.  Thoroughly read the instruction booklet.3.  Once you have thoroughly read the instruction booklet (it's not lengthy) and you get past setting it for your left ear (if that is your desire), the only major thing to do is to determine which of the three eartips is best for you.  This is important for comfort and I suggest that you start with the smallest tip and work your way up.  I am using the smallest tip-it works best for me.Though the unit appears to be somewhat awkward looking, it really is not uncomfortable on the ear if you accustom yourself to placing the eartip comfortably in your ear first (contrary to the booklet and as if the unit did not contain the curved attachment)-the rest will follow.Sound is crisper than with the H680, and appears louder.You can't go wrong with either, but I think I like this one more.Update:  1/7/10  Sound is definitely better with this unit, and it appears to hold charge longer than H680.  Voyager is definitely larger than H680.  When you get past that, and realize the benefits of sound quality and longer use on a charge, you might favor, as I do, the Voyager 510.  It's quite enjoyable not to have to repeat myself when transmitting - no one on receiving end has complained about poor sound quality!

I've just had to replace the Plantronics 510 Voyager that I've had for over 2 years because I twisted it incorrectly when trying to adapt it for use on my right ear instead of my left and that errant twist apparently broke a wire inside renedering it useless. This was my error and not an indication of the quality of the headset.I am replacing it with the exact same thing as this is the best headset I've had the experience of using. I've had several over the years...jabra, another plantronics. The 510 Voyager has the best audio clarity of them all and people tell me my voice sounds clear and strong. Some people can't believe I'm using my cell-pone.The only thing I don't like about this headset is the on-off button can be difficult to press. It's just a bad design of that particular feature but all things considered, I think this headset is an outstanding bargain considering it's performance.UPDATE: March 4, 2009: Unfortunately I've had to return the "Recertified" Voyager 510 because the battery life was not per specifications or what I was accustomed to with my previous 510. The battery did not hold a charge for very long thus the talk time and standby time was diminished. I've returned the unit and have reordered the "normal" 510 for $10 more.
summary: Excellent sound quality. Decent battery life. A bit clunky

reviewText: These cables are great for stuffing into a bag, or using at home or in the car. reviewText: I bought this one instead of the Motorola (twice the cost and history of problems with the back breaking).  I could not be more happier.  The headphones look very nice, came with one long and one short charging cable and seemed to be very well put together.  They are advertised as sweat resistant as well so I am using them during biking with no problems.  The sound clarity is very good and I was amazed that the sound has as much bass when listening to music as it did.  The headphones paired right up with my HTC One and the volume control on the headphones work well as does the multi function button for switching tracks, answering phone etc.  The ear inserts also worked well and are a nice fit.  I have an average sized head and the headphones fit nice and snug.  I researched a lot before buying these and there is nothing in this price range to compare with this quality.

This pouch is very nice. I got it to use with my Droid X in a protective case. Unfortunately it barely fits the Droid X without the case. It does fot my Droid Incredible in a protective case. It is very dressy looking and has a good clip

My cat has a bad habit of chewing my cords so I really needed a back-up. I purchased this for my Note 3.The product shipped quickly but I was a little concerned that it came from someone instead of the company that is listed here. It definitely was a residential address which included an apartment number. That for me was the first alarm.This charger is not the same charger that accompanied my Note 3. The original cord is much longer as compared to this one. The original port is mainly in English. This port has some English but it is mainly Chinese. Second Alarm.The lettering on the original port is slimmer and much more defined. The lettering on this one slightly thicker and is faded sort of like when you rip a sticker off a surface. Last alarm.As for the performance, it does pretty well for my Note 3. I like this as a back-up charger but I am not happy that I thought I paid for an authentic Samsung charger and received something else.Recommended as a back-up. Keep in mind, this is not the original cord that comes with the Note 3.
summary: Not the Original Charger for Note 3

It keeps falling off.  I do on occasion remove back cover to reset a frozen phone or to replace the battery with a fresh one after extended use.  I replaced the blue back cover with the white one but it cracked when I dropped the phone. It still fits but not flush.  My main complaint with the back covers is that they are slippery.  When combined with my butter fingers the result is many dropped phones.  At least the GS3 is one tough phone.I would  buy another back cover but I cannot find them sold separately.  I just found this battery and cover set at another site for $10 less.  So now I guess I'll have to go that route just to get the extra covers.

reviewText: I love this Bluetooth- I have never had a issue with his pairing with my Samsung Galaxy S and the sound quality is the best I have had for a Bluetooth- I never get that annoying " am I on speaker or on Bluetooth" that I get on other Bluetooth units- The battery lasts a long time also! reviewText: just spent a extra 2 dollars and get a better case than this. it looks nice but it only lasted 2 weeks or so before it started falling apart.

It's very nice to have a car charger and a house charger. I use it everyday. As for the car charger it's nice to have so if I need to charge my phone it's as simple as that and I don't have to fiddle with out car conveter.

For the price it's a great android phone. But it slows down when too many apps are using it. And it only allows a small number of apps to be moved to the sd card. That leaves little space on the phone. As a starter phone, it's a good value

BlueAnt Ribbon Bluetooth streamer is a neat little device that I have found pretty handy so far! The BlueAnt Ribbon has paired perfectly with any of the devices I have used. My iPhone has been hassle free in syncing up. Very straight forward in terms of bluetooth pairing and those who have used bluetooth pairing capabilities in the past will get it right away. It's as simple as holding down the Play button for around 10 seconds until a traditional blue light blinks and gives you the go-ahead to turn on the device you want to pair with. That's pretty much it! I haven't had any sort of issues getting this paired or synced up.It's nice to have such a light-weight device that still allows you full control over switching up tracks and having the ability to adjust the volume with easy to manipulate corresponding plus and minus symbols. The device hooks easily onto your collar and this gives you perfect access to use the built-in microphone for hands-free calling...which I LOVE! This is such a great feature and the call quality is up to par with more expensive devices by Jabra, Plantronics, Motorola or Sony that I own. Voices come in crisp and clear and I haven't had any problems on that end.The ability to hook this up to my car is actually my favorite feature. I have yet to upgrade my only recently paid off Explorer and don't have any sort of fancy-schmancy touch-screen console to play music with and I have been making mix cd's for about 10 years now which has been annoying and cumbersome. I hate having to shuffle through discs! This makes it SO simple! I simply connect with my Auxiliary port and can play whatever playlists I want from my iphone through this device! I love this feature so much!The ear-buds that come with this are comfy and fit snug for me. I like that though. They aren't too wobbly or too tight. They are pretty much spot on for my normally picky ears. I usually loath earbuds and prefer wrap around headsets but these are decent. I am not planning on taking this set on jogs or anything like I will with my other headset devices so I am not going to worry too much about the buds falling out during rough activities.Overall, I really like this set. My only complaint would be the packaging. I received this and could actually feel the componants at the bottom section of the box just clanging around together. They weren't really secured in. That was a little odd but it's a minor complaint. It has nothing to do with the actual device quality and how this works. Love this!! Well done BlueAnt!
summary: BlueAnt delivers with this quality Bluetooth setup...

reviewText: I purchased two of these at a great price of $9.99 each from Amazon for my Droid X2. I really don't use the one I bought for my bed stand as the dimmed setting for the station is too bright for me.As I stated in the title I like the station but I could love it if there were some small changes.One would be the dimmed setting. The other would be that you could fit the phone into it with out removing its case.Fortunately, I purchased the Qmadix Flex Gel Cover for Motorola Droid X and Droid X2 which is easily removed and installed.I do like the way that the station is heavy and holds the Droid well. It feels of good quality and fits good in my hand so I can make quick texts while it is in the station. I am glad to have one at my desk as it is functional and looks good also.I am happy with this purchase.
I love this otterbox. It is our schools colors so I can show my school pride and support in more ways then just clothing. This box is very secure and fits my phone like a glove.
Alright quality for the price. Works just fine. Only problem is the silver part broke off within a few days.Overall for the price you can't beat it.

The myCharge Freedom 2000 is a very handy device for those of us who, sometimes, forget to charge our phone. This doesn't stay plugged into your phone but can be easily plugged into the iPhone 5 and kept in your pocket while charging. The charge was fairly quick, and it's easy to do. The case itself adds a fair amount of heft and size to the phone; for me, this is not a big issue, but I could see it being an issue for some. The case has a brushed metal look, which I like. It's easy enough to pop the iPhone in and out of this case. The charging unit uses the more standard micro-USB charger, so you can charge the case by plugging it into your computer, or a wall charger. The unit seems to charge quickly, and it in turn charges the iPhone quickly.Overall, this is a pretty handy device to have around if you're worried about battery life. It looks good on the iPhone, but does add a bit of heft. It's very simple to use.
I absolutely love this case! it showed up on time and keeps my phone safe from the little ones!I like the hard plastic faceplate! No scratches on my phone!

Bought this for my new AT&T; Galaxy SII, the case arrived super fast, its fits the phone perfectly and snug. I have no issues with any buttons, and the rubber is in a smooth, sort of laminated finish. It does not stick to your pockets. Overall, I am extremely happy with the purchase, especially for so cheap.And just FYI: This is for the AT&T; (i777), or International (i9100) Galaxy SII.This WILL NOT FIT Sprint, T-Mobile or the AT&T; Galaxy SII Skyrocket phones. You've been warned.

when I bought this item , I was looking for the golden color, so this item were the only one exactly the same as the iphone 5s gold.first of all I found it difficult to install the case ,the case has tow pieces(white rubber & plastic golden frame) you have to install the white rubber first then you put the frame above.  Actually it looks very niceit also includes a screen protector for both sides,I recommend it .

Great price for this. I just used the back and sides from IQ Shield, and a separate glass screen protector for the front. The sides started to peel at first, but I emailed the company, and they quickly sent me a new set.Installation was very easy after following the directions. At home I didn't have any soap that wasn't moisturizing or anti-bacterial, but I work in a retail store, so I used some of the cheap soap from our dispenser, and it worked great! No bubbles or specks underneath. I do wish, though, that the edges were protected a bit more, but I realize that would be very hard to produce and to apply.

reviewText: This case was so hard to remove from the phone, I returned it.  If you have to struggle that much, you risk dropping or flexing the phone.  It was horrible.  I liked the look, and it was sleek, and seemed to be carefully designed.  I'd say it offered moderate protection, maybe.  If you put a case on the phone and don't take it off, you might be okay, but I change cases all the time for different looks, and change batteries sometimes too.  Way too much trouble for me.

reviewText: I gave this to my dad, who is constantly on the phone when he's driving. It makes me crazy, and I feel better knowing he's using this instead of putting one hand on the wheel and the other hand to his ear. He says that the sound quality is good -- not great -- and he doesn't experience any drop offs, and it was simple enough for my dad to pair with his phone without assistance so it can't be that hard to do! He does complain of it not being loud enough when he's in crowded places, but it's not much of a problem since he really just uses it in the car during his commute.The design is pretty sleek and attractive, and though my dad has never really liked using Bluetooth headsets he has become accustomed to using this quite frequently in the past five months that he has had it.

I was very excited about the product, when I received it. It all was going very well, the car charger worked well. The packaging was very neat and all. As I started to use the wall charger I then noticed my phone showed it was charging, but it really wasn't. The adapter was loose and it wouldn't stay in place on the wall. Make some minor adjustments and I'm sure the whole purchase would have been Great!

This works for what I bought it for (iPod Classic). The only criticism I have is that it fits loose enough (very slightly) that I think over time it may scratch the surface. It should do the job, however.

This case is great.  It has a silicone liner and a solid plastic case outside of that.  It all fits as if it had been original equipment that came with the phone.  Very snug. The phone buttons are now activated by pushing the appropriate (marked) place on the silicone, and all work well.You need to protect an expensive phone like this, which is why I originally bought just a silicone cover for it.  However, this made it very difficult to slip in and out of my pocket.  With this new cover, the phone is both protected and there is no pocket problem.My only annoyance, and the reason I did not give this 5 stars, is ironically due to the snug fit which I praised above.  This phone is a battery hog, and when I need to replace the battery with one that is fully charged, the case is somewhat challenging to get on and off.All said, I would buy it again.
Great for travel and home. It charges 1 tablet along with 3 other devices. Well built and nice smooth design.

I bought a Kindle Fire HD (My 2nd Fire). It only came with the USB charging cable. Since I watch a lot of movies on my Fire the battery was draining fast. I hated to have to charge it overnight after each use. So I bought this high speed charger. Using the top USB slot it charges my Kindle Fire in around 3 hours. I use the bottom slot to charge my LG Optimus Elite smartphone. Takes about two hours.  Using the Battery HD app that is free on Amazon I was able to determine the rate of charging, the amps being given at any given time, etc. In short, this charger works.
summary: Charges my Kindle Fire HD faster

reviewText: I ordered this case for my new iPhone 5c.  The case shipped quickly and the seller was top notch.  There apparently was a manufacturing issue with the case where there was too much material left on the TPU rim by the power button causing the case to continually attempt to power down the phone.  I was notified in advance of the issues and was given options either return or have replacement.  Other than the flaw of the power / volume button moldings the case itself was not bad.  The skin covered the edge of the front face to prevent scratches and there were openings obviously for the camera, switches and ports.  I have OCD about my phone cases and the thing I noticed most briefly was that the edge of the face along the front next to the volume controls did not cling to the side as much as the rest of the edge and can is always slightly bowed out and is easy to move.  I cannot say how protective this case would be for drops or action, but for most general use it would be probably fine.  If they correct the manufacturing defect give it a try.  Not the case for me, but hey, it is just my option.
summary: Case was not formed correctly for iPhone 5C

reviewText: This case snaps on easily and fits perfectly. I was looking for the slimmest case possible for a Nexus 4 and this fits the bill.  It is not TPU material but rather some rigid plastic that nonetheless provides better grip than the Nexus 4 glass body.  Of course, I don't expect it to provide the protection of an OtterBox, but it will prevent scratching of the cell phone back and may provide some bump protection.

reviewText: Finally a USB charger that will charge all my toys.... at once. Benn using it for over a week and everything charges fast. Love it.

What more can I say? I've owned the Samsung Galaxy line since the original Galaxy and have a lot of experience with numerous cases out there. My favorites used to be TPU cases as I loved how they hugged the phone well and most importantly protected it from face drops by having a lip that curves over the front of the phone. You know...around the edges...the rim. That's ideally my main concert with cases if they provide that rim that will elevate the front of the phone just enough off the ground in case it does a face plant. (Assuming it's on a smooth surface.) Anyway, this Spigen case is the Mercedes of the auto World. Just pure elegance. Strong and durable. It's the luxury of all cases. The best way I can describe it is this: It gives you all the protection of those stupid bulky armor military cases that make your phone look like brick (so annoying), while being as thin as possible to achieve a slim profile. All the cut outs are perfect. Also if you notice from the picture, there are rubber areas where it needs it..ie..the top, bottom and around the front of the phone on the "rim." -- Look no further.
summary: This is by far the BEST phone case I've ever owned. Perfect fit, thin, light and durable.

This Qi wireless charger is a great way to charge you phone minus the cord.I do not know about you, but I hate searching for a cord to charge my phone. Having this wireless charger, makes charging much easier. This charging method will take more time than a standard wall charger. Most people charge their phones at night time, so this is not a deal breaker.First, you have to make sure your phone is Qi-Compliant (wireless charging capable). There are there options to choose from: your phone comes with wireless installed; you change your back cover to a wireless cover; or get a wireless patch that goes between the back cover and battery. Once you have chosen you wireless charging method, plug up the wireless charger and let the magic happen.Once you phone is placed on the charging pad, try to keep it centered with the white ring to ensure the best charge. There is a status LED that will show the charge state, blue for standby and a blinking red for charging.This device looks great on an office desk or nightstand.CONTENTS:iClever Qi Wireless Charging PadUSB Wall AdapterMicro USB CordUser GuideFEATURES:Input: 5V/2ATransmission Distance: 0.19-0.31in (5-8mm)Size: 6.2 x 3.5 x 0.39in (157.5 x 88.9 x 0.99mm)Weight: 4.23oz (120g)Charging Efficiency: 72%Warranty: 1 YearI was supplied a sample for the purpose of review.
summary: Charge You Phone Without The Cord

UPDATE:  I traded this for a Nexus 5, but I still loved this phone like no other Android since... Original review below.----------I'm a regular iPhone user, but I always own the latest greatest vanilla Android so I can keep my knowledge fair and equal. I've owned every Google vanilla phone since Google started with the Nexus One. This hardware with the latest OS is the first time I've felt really comfortable and ready to switch. The apps I use are also finally usable enough and in the right place that I could do it with little heartburn.Because this phone and the previous phone, Galaxy Nexus both support the latest edition of Android OS, my main objective is to tell you what I like about this phone better. It's simple-- the edge of the phone has a really nice bevel to grip it. The Galaxy Nexus has a pretty smooth edge which requires you to "cup it" in your hand and sometimes use two hands is easiest. This phone has a nice bevel to keep it gripped in the hand so there is no issue holding it.From a performance perspective I should notice a marked increase from the Galaxy Nexus but I'll be honest-- this is not something I noticed. It may be that I simply didn't use in extreme ways to prove this difference.That all being said, in my opinion this is superior hardware experience to the Galaxy Nexus, but I wouldn't hesitate to go with the Galaxy Nexus if cost is an issue/focus.

This is an interesting take on a pretty conventional product: a powerbank for phone/device recharging. It includes a USB cable that wraps around the device to eliminate the need for carrying a cable to connect the powerbank to the device you want to charge. I've seen that feature on a couple of other powerbanks, but PBS does it very well - the wrap-around design for the cable keeps in handy and also adds some visual interest to the powerbank.The wrap-around cable has a rubbery covering that appears very sturdy and able to withstand quite a bit of use. It snaps securely into a groove in the powerbank so it does not unfold when you don't want it to unfold. It can also be removed should you want to use your own cable.Additionally, the powerbank has an Apple-to-USB adapter that fits into a slot in the device and is held in place by the wrap-around cable. A great feature if you want to charge an Apple device - the adapter is there when you need it, and stows neatly when it's not being used.On the downside, it only has one USB output, and the size is a bit larger than other 5000mAh powerbanks. It measures about 2.25 side and 5 inches tall, which is notably larger than other powerbanks in it's power range. But, for me, the size is livable given the convenience of not having to remember to bring a cable.The case is white and glossy, and does show some fingerprints. The wrap-around cable is a nice shade of blue. While it's hard to call a powerbank "attractive," this does look pretty nice.It also includes a decent cloth pouch with a drawstring, and comes very attractively packaged in a box with a foam insert.The 5000mAh rating means this is fine for phone or other small device charging. It's not the best choice for tablet recharging - you'd want to step up to at least a powerbank with an 8000+mAh rating for that.Well worth considering if you value convenience in a powerbank, and are willing to deal with a somewhat larger device to get that.[Sample provided for review]

I am a runner, gym patron, and longtime Plantronics bluetooth customer: I've had several 903+'s and a Go 2.  The Go 2 doesn't stay in my ears and is on the large side for exercising, but it seemed like the best thing available last year.The Fit is disappointing in three ways: 1)  It's not loud enough, 2) the ear pieces hurt my ears due to their hardness, and 3) the phone functionality is the worst of the Plantronics I've had, and the call quality isn't very good with the other Plantronics headphones I mentioned above.1) Not loud enough -- The is a big problem.  I like to download movies to my Note 3 and watch them in the gym as I work out.  These movies typically play more quietly than other videos.  The Go 2 plays the movies just loud enough for me to hear and enjoy them in my noisy gym.  The Fit plays the very same movies just quietly enough that I can't hear them in the gym.  Music and other videos that play louder sound excellent.I have a speakerboost application that doesn't seem to make any difference to the Fit volume, but they have a feature that Plantronics should use.  Namely, they only boost to 60% unless you go into settings and allow them to boost more, which requires acknowledging that you are making this change.  If Plantronics is so worried about lawsuits if they make the headphones loud enough to hear in noisy places, they should use this feature to allow people to choose a higher volume.2)  The Fit doesn't fit --  The Fit earphones do stay in place no matter what I do.  I think it may also be possible to find positions for each ear that don't hurt, but so far, I have either failed to achieve that or I may have succeeded once.  They take me a lot of fiddling with them to try to find a position that won't hurt.Why it would have been so hard to make the earpieces softer is anyone's guess.3)  Call quality is bad -- I've made five calls with the Fit.  Three were so bad on both ends, it was almost pointless.  Two were good on both ends.  The three that were bad were with the same person, someone with whom I had spoken on the Go 2 as well.  On the Go 2, the other party sounded fine but complained about background noise.  With the Fit, both sides break up terribly and the person on other side hated the noise far worse than with the Go 2.It's nice to have earphones that stay in place--I bought a pair of wired earphones 7 years ago for under $5.00 that had an over-the-ear component that kept them in place, but they weren't waterproof.  It's nice that in 2014 Plantronics had the breakthrough of waterproof earphones that stay in place.  Now if I could only hear them without ear pain and make calls, they'd be perfect.  Perhaps Plantronics will resolve one of these issues next year and soak me for another $150, then resolve another one in the following year for, say, $180, and maybe they can do the last one in three years for, say, $210.UPDATE:  I exchanged my pair in hopes that my complaints were particular to the unit I received.  The connecting chord in back on the new one is slightly longer, within a margin of manufacturing error.  With the new one, I can get a more or less comfortable fit.  Unfortunately, the volume level and call quality are precisely the same.

Shure's QuietSpot headset is the best headset on the market, period. The only problem with it is Shure's coyness about how it works and why microphone placement is *absolutely crucial* when using it. Once you understand that, you understand everything you need to in order to want it more than you want anyone else's.The "problem" with the QuietSpot--mentioned by other reviewers here--is not a failure of engineering or quality control, but one of emphasis in their documentation. Barring an actual defective unit (which will usually not work at all) there is nothing wrong with the QuietSpot that proper adjustment doesn't totally eliminate. I believe that Shure doesn't tell you this for fear of alienating technically unsophisticated customers. Since I have nothing to sell you, I am blissfully unconcerned with boring you and can write something useful. Please note that I write this on the basis of a close examination of a working QuietSpot and an educated layman's knowledge.Observation tells me that, Shure's QuietSpot headset uses active noise cancellation and it is the only cellular headset on the market that does.  This means that the mouthpiece of the headset uses two microphones: one takes in the sound from the world around you while the second takes in the sound from your mouth.Using  a trick of wiring, this dual-microphone arrangement uses the sound from the outside world and uses it to weaken the sound from the microphone closer to our mouth. Since both microphones take in surrounding sound, the strongest sound that *isn't* cancelled out is your voice.For this to work, the microphones need very good alignment with your mouth. The  QuietSpot demands that you have the 'mouth-side' microphone pointed directly at your mouth, and the 'world side' microphone pointed directly outwards without mis-alignments like having the microphone-housing too far below or two far above the side of your mouth, or having the microphone housing turned on its side.The tough part about this is that the boom that holds the microphone can twist and bend while the QuietSpot is in your pocket or case, turning the microphone head around onto its side. If the microphone-head is turned on it's side, or set too far above or below your mouth, then both microphones pick up your voice with equal intensity and the arrangement does exactly as it's supposed to: It treats *your voice* like background-noise and sends everything you say off into oblivion.The solution is easy and useful: you have to learn to put the QuietSpot's microphone in the right place every time you put it on. Once you learn to do this with the windscreen on, you have what is close to the perfect headset. I have used the QuietSpot, standing in bars in New York City with the jukebox blasting and not had to raise my voice very far above an ordinary conversational volume and with the QuietSpot's noise-blocking earpiece, I could hear my listener perfectly. The two-way noise elimination of a well-adjusted QuietSpot is amazing, providing a sense of intimacy and privacy in conversations that no other headset ever gave me including one or two that cost more.The only other thing you need to know about the QuietSpot is that it is particularly sensitive to wind=noise and unless you intent to never use it outside, it is best to keep the windscreen permanently attached to the unit. You can do this with a needle and thread through the foam, or with a thin-strand of wire. Once you've done this, you'll have to learn to make the important adjustment by touch but even then, it's still easy.Now that you know all this, give the QuietSpot a try. You won't be disappointed.

The color screen is small but good-quality.  The only thing I don't like is Tracfone's 60-day refill polic: you must refill every 60 days to keep your account active; otherwise you forfeit your number and balance.  Other prepaid providers like Speak Out Wireless (from 7-Eleven) give you one full year of usage.

I received this as a review unit from RAVPower Genesis Reviewer Program. The package comes with the following: the 10400 mAh battery pack, two microUSB coiled cables, one battery pouch, and finally one multilingual user manual.The battery pack itself is self-explanatory. It has a battery status bar on the front with a button that once pushed, can indicate the level of battery charge. On its side, it has three USB ports. From left to right, you have (Out) 2A regular USB port, (In) microUSB port (for its charging purpose), and finally (Out) 1A regular USB port.The battery out of box, has over 75% of battery charged, so it is ready to use right away. However, in my case, I chose to charge the battery pack to full prior to first use, simply because that's how I use all my electronic devices for the very first time. To charge the battery pack, you can use your iPhone wall charger, connect both to the microUSB cable that comes with the battery pack.The first time charge can take quite a few hours for the battery to finish charging. Once charged, all four indicators will stop flashing and will all light up in blue colors.To charge up your device, you simply use the USB cables that come with your device. It works with lightning cable that comes with Apple iPhone 5, as well as the microUSB cable that comes with Google/LG Nexus 5. The two microUSB cables that come with the battery pack also work with Nexus 5 as expected.This is a great product when you are on the go, especially if you are not anywhere near a power outlet. Besides charging my phone devices, I also use it to charge up my FreedomPop 4G hotspot. So far the battery pack works as advertised, and I have yet to find any issues with it. It simply works! Highly recommended!Here are some additional information that may interest you. If you charge the battery pack, and at the same time want to charge your mobile device, it does seem to work with iPhone 5. It means that while you are charging the battery pack, your iPhone is also getting charged, regardless of which USB port it connects to (works for both 1A and 2A port). However, the same scenario does not work for a Nexus 5 phone. It means that while you are charging the battery pack, the pack in turn does not charge Nexus 5 at the same time. A little weird, but this information may interest some of you anyway.
summary: Great portable battery pack and works as advertised!

Battery was down to 80-something percent...in fifteen minutes. So either I screwed up, got bad batteries, or...?(4) Battery was dead in 2 hours. Dead. Got home in afternoon, put original battery back...NOTHING. Phone would not boot (Samsung Note 3). After half-hour trying to facilitate a reboot, I panicked not having my phone and data. Finally called Verizon w/o mention of ZeroLemomn. Got with level 2 Tech and went over seemingly every possible fix/reset. NOTHING. He offered me a NEW PHONE, which I accepted, and sent out next day SATURDAY...so I have new phone.(5) You already know it's big so no point mentioning this issue. I'm a gadget&toy; guy and truly struggled with case, but perhaps, maybe, just me. Given the mathematical odds between the 5 star reviews, and lesser comments, I have no idea what went wrong to be fair & honest.Going to try 6400-mAh Hyperion battery, and will report back. Thanks.Ron.

And the QR code for being able to retrieve it if it's lost like others have said is a novel idea but it really relies on an honest person on the end of that transaction. I'm hoping the next iteration will allow this case to be found more directly by you. As in a case that even if somebody steals your phone and disables or wipes the phone as long as the case is attached you can still located to me that would be the ideal case for today's world. And I know a case like that would cost more money but I think it be worth it. But when I saw this case that's kind of what I thought.Now I did not use the QR code to share my personal information it seems like it would work pretty straightforwardly but she is not something I really need to use. Plus nowadays it's pretty easy to say follow me on twitter or Facebook.But I think for $15 if you want an extra layer of security it might be worth it but then again if you have an honest person who find your phone as long as it's not locked there be able to get your personal information and get back to you.Thanks for reading hopefully you never lose your phone because that would suck.

There are a lot of external batteries out there. OXA has a whole line of them and I've evaluated some others (as in the other cases, I received a sample for review). All of them are quite good if you understand how you're going to want to use them.Let's start with the basics. Input: 7800mAh, allowing for about 80% efficiency, should charge up in just under 10 hours. I found this unit charges in about 9 hours, a little better than expected and quite reasonable. Output: 7800mAh will give a typical tablet one full charge and a typical smartphone about 3 full charges. My results are in accord with this estimate. I was able to charge my phone about 2.5 times as well as charge an external speaker twice. This is about right. There are two USB output ports, one at 2A and the other at 1A. These are suitable for use in parallel and will charge your devices in a reasonable timeframe. (I don't believe in fast charging unless absolutely necessary; the heat generated can be damaging to both the device and the battery pack.)The unit is small, relatively light, and quite portable. It goes readily in a large pocket or easily in a briefcase, purse, or backpack. It is supplied with a cable and four adapters making it usable with just about any mainstream device. There is also a nice velvety carrying case. The unit has a small "flashlight" that doesn't put out much light but might help in a pinch.The 7800mAh rating places this unit between the larger (heavier, bulkier) 10000mAh and up battery packs, and the smaller (lighter, pocket/keychain size) chargers in the 2600mAh class. What unit you choose depends on your intended use. Do you want something small that will just "top up" your phone once or twice during a working day? Or do you want something that will provide a week of emergency power?This 7800mAh unit will provide emergency power for a phone for 4 to 5 days, from my testing. This makes it very good for camping trips and the like, and also useful at home during a power outage, even a somewhat extended one. If you're concerned only about home use and only an emergency power source, you might opt for a larger unit. But if you want something that will combine home and away use, including long-weekend recreational trips, this one is an excellent choice.I have no trouble giving the battery pack a five star rating. It works exactly as it should and it's very portable and convenient for a variety of uses.
summary: Very convenient for a variety of uses

reviewText: I knew it would be a bit of an uphill battle to install this home button in my iPhone 4.  I got the home button, clearly from China, in a crappy destroyed looking plastic bag.  It works, but its a pretty flimsy junky spare part.One point on installation.  Of course you have to unscrew and take apart your phone.  I actually kind of enjoy doing that, but there is one step that I absolutely do not enjoy...heating the glue under the screen and peeling the screen off of the frame.  Its doable, but it sucks to do.  You will literally have to take your entire phone apart to install this button and no tools are provided with this particular button.  My advice would be if you don't have tools to take apart an iPhone, then buy a button that comes with tools and have your blow drier handy when you begin the installation.  Can't imagine how hard home button replacement is going to be on the iPhone 5s.

For example, when you want to increase or decrease the volume, you have to push pretty hard on the rubber piece covering them in order for the volume to respond. The main issue is that the thickness of the case and the size of the cutoff for accessing the switch that silences the iphone are completely inadequate. Unless you have long thin nails there is no way you can switch the iphone to silence without taking it off the case, which is not how this should work. Therefore, if you use this function I guarantee you will be extremely annoyed.
summary: Protects your phone, but limits functionality
